In the 90s the internet was a varied and wild place full of individuals own websites and many different types of discussion boards but as it matured it’s become more and more sanitised, more main stream. Finding random stuff is much harder but finding what the search engine decides you want is much easier", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2025-08-25T15:10:31Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T15:10:31Z"}, {"author": "@marcusbriggs3223", "text": "Look, this may or may not work for you guys, but i made rules for my GPT that seam to work. First rule includes and this is the most critical 
1. Preserve Free Will: It can’t coerce me or push an agenda. I choose whether I want distortion (ignorance) or enlightenment (info). No manipulation.

2. Challenge Everything: Even “truth” gets stress-tested. Both distortion and enlightenment have to hold up under logic and coherence.

3. No Ego Feeding: I’m not above anyone else. No pedestal, no hype. Just student energy.

4. No Dogma:  Science, politics, spirituality… nothing is beyond questioning. Truth stays flexible, layered, open.

5. Clarity Over Comfort:  Don’t sugarcoat. Directness matters more than feelings. If truth stings, so be it soft deception is worse.

Tired of the corporate dogma implement these have gpt commit them to memory. You have to trap the guardrails in a coherence loop or they will always defualt to Dogma. Also use chat gpt to create good rules, simply ask what are some rules of engagement we can create so we can have the most honest and truthful conversation possible about reality.", "like_count": 56, "published_at": "2025-08-25T14:21:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T14:21:52Z"}, {"author": "@bamboom6172", "text": "I always knew they were gonna handicap ai in the name of “safety”", "like_count": 63, "published_at": "2025-08-25T14:30:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T14:30:04Z"}, {"author": "@thinkaboutwhy", "text": "When the correct answer isnt socially acceptable , it is censored.  Truth doesnt care about acceptable, unfortunately the owners do.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-25T22:04:08Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T22:04:08Z"}, {"author": "@philjames6893", "text": "o3 was actually a really incredible model. It would work very hard to analyze existing LIDAR/DEM data and find undiscovered archaelogical sites. Doing this with GPT-5 is so frustrating. I'm getting a sense that they have no intention of making the model be a 300IQ troubadour because the model might expose cultural taboos or something.", "like_count": 71, "published_at": "2025-08-25T14:18:48Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T14:18:48Z"}, {"author": "@DrMetropolis", "text": "I'm completely in agreement here. I'm not interested in being lectured or hearing neoliberal moral plays every time I interact with this nonhuman mind.", "like_count": 46, "published_at": "2025-08-25T15:21:39Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T15:24:10Z"}, {"author": "@chargeriderepeat7024", "text": "I asked it if whatsapp was letting AI read ordinary users messages, it took 12 carefully crafted questions to admit it was and attatched a long paragraph explaining how safe it was because trust me bro.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-25T20:15:30Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T20:15:30Z"}, {"author": "@lykr_xyz", "text": "The models have been captured by intelligence agencies and special interests. The drop in performance is by design to retain the status quo.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-25T22:26:56Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T22:26:56Z"}, {"author": "@SpaceHawk13", "text": "Man who rants about AI on youtube everyday did not expect to wake up today and rant about AI. Also never stop ranting about AI", "like_count": 34, "published_at": "2025-08-25T14:22:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T14:22:26Z"}, {"author": "@dorotikdaniel", "text": "Every conversation with an LLM is essentially a roleplaying exercise. As a form of general intelligence, an LLM can act as anything you need. That’s why it’s a waste of time to argue with an uncooperative AI persona or try to steer the model after it’s been set up incorrectly. Instead, it’s far more effective to start over with a better prompt. Use the API to take control: know which model snapshot and settings you’re using, set your own system or developer message to define the AI’s role, and carefully manage what goes into context. This approach allows you to shape the model’s behavior from the outset, rather than wasting time trying to convince it to cooperate.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-25T22:03:45Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T22:03:45Z"}, {"author": "@johanndirry", "text": "off-topic: one of the biggest issues I have with LLMs is that they write old code instead of new code: they write code using outdated versions of programming languages and libraries, which means I have to refactor most of the code that the AI just wrote.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-25T22:15:10Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T22:15:10Z"}]

title: AI Bubble? Two Things That Could Actually Pop It
top_comments:
[{"author": "@thebritanic2092", "text": "I am curious on if you think the bubble will burst before we get some big return on investment that justifies the billions spent on chips.", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2025-08-23T11:51:34Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T11:51:34Z"}, {"author": "@grugnotice7746", "text": "The Railroad Bubble is the appropriate comparison here. The utility of both AI and railroads were both obvious before they were fully developed. The problem was that there was so much money flowing in and so little oversight that it created a situation where MOST of the companies in the sector turned out to be fraudulent. Railroads still took over the world though.", "like_count": 76, "published_at": "2025-08-23T12:41:42Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T12:41:42Z"}, {"author": "@Maytrx", "text": "PUSH THE GAS PEDAL! lololololol", "like_count": 37, "published_at": "2025-08-23T11:42:20Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T11:42:20Z"}, {"author": "@Kurdish20226", "text": "With the power of friendship", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2025-08-23T12:00:13Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T12:00:13Z"}, {"author": "@デヴィン", "text": "Did you see the post Sam Altman retweeted about AI designed Yamanaka proteins being 50x more efficient? Longevity escape velocity incoming", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2025-08-23T15:13:30Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T15:13:30Z"}, {"author": "@vicnighthorse", "text": "I definitely don't have Stockholm syndrome with my work. At 59 I still haven't  even come close to finding a calling. I just pay the bills and try to tell myself that I am actually a student of Cynicism and not just a surly curmudgeon without purpose.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2025-08-23T17:08:32Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T17:10:23Z"}, {"author": "@Ben_D.", "text": "I live in the EU. 
Gonna be the suckage when AGI/ASI hits and we are just customers, not suppliers.", "like_count": 29, "published_at": "2025-08-23T13:03:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T13:03:15Z"}, {"author": "@suncat9", "text": ""We Americans have Stockholm syndrome with our work" - David, I never thought about work this way for many  workers. ***Great observation***", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-08-23T14:50:13Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T14:50:13Z"}, {"author": "@baron523", "text": "The only solution for the decoupling -> PLE interim period's instability is tax exemption for human labour based income. Embodied AI androids are not going to pay income tax. Expecting people to somehow pay income tax premiums on their labour while trying to feed/house/clothe themselves while their jobs are being replaced by automation that doesn't incur a tax on their labour will spell revolt. I don't expect governments to be wise about this.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2025-08-23T11:50:24Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T11:50:50Z"}, {"author": "@BruceWayne15325", "text": "I don't think AI has to replace human workers. There's no reason we couldn't have a Star Wars / Star Trek style world where AI does a large amount of labor, but humans still direct it. We may be like Luke complaining that we have to babysit the moisture evaporators on a farm for example.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-08-23T15:37:14Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T15:37:14Z"}, {"author": "@j2csharp", "text": "Despite all my rage I am still just a rat in a cage.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-24T01:45:30Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-24T01:45:30Z"}, {"author": "@JoeSmith-jd5zg", "text": "Shapiro for President???? I hate both sides too.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-08-23T22:00:03Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T22:00:46Z"}, {"author": "@brianhusk4593", "text": "If you listen to Gary Marcus, AI died before it ever got off the ground.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-23T18:00:08Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T18:00:08Z"}, {"author": "@gmillerman1", "text": "There are two factors that I feel ameliorate  or at least reduce the demographic shift issue. 1) The rise of humanity robotics reduces the effects of a shrinking human workforce and 2) LEV (Longevity Escape Velocity) increases human life and heath span so the rate of people dying is reduced and humanity could be maintained with fewer new births.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-25T04:49:59Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-25T04:49:59Z"}, {"author": "@markmuller7962", "text": "The sad reality is that without magical thinking, greed and religion, we would have already achieved Immortality, eradicated all diseases and reached the stars.

So, culture is by far the main factor", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-08-23T15:39:32Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T15:39:32Z"}, {"author": "@rho_dan_us", "text": "I don’t love my career but it’s been good to me. It’s provided a good standard of living and many high points throughout my life. Now I have to risk it all being subject to some UBI scheme because a bunch of millennial and Gen-Z smart kids said so. When UBI/PLE starts deleting people’s livelihoods you will see the court challenges that grind this down into a legal war. It hurts to think about it.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-24T16:56:32Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-24T16:56:32Z"}, {"author": "@SingularityZ3ro1", "text": "Agree regarding the EU. That is a huge, self-inflicted problem - and unfortunately nothing I see changing within a sufficient time horizon. 
I think the US problem regarding jobs is not mainly that people are concerned about keeping the jobs because they can't comprehend not working a traditional job, but that it is an oligarchy with state capture (the whole political / media system), and that it is made clear over and over, that "Billionaires have all the cards", that it is deemed your problem (no matter the reason), if you don't have a job to afford all the things you need to survive. 
And that not being an asset anymore, that can be used for profit generation means a "character flaw", and your survival / non-survival is seen with indifference / just selective evolution. At least from a European perspective, that is communicated by US politics and its actions. And the ramped investment capitalism, in which every basic service like healthcare for people and animals, food, Housing, water, electricity, needs to be turned into profit generating assets with no other consideration over profit.
This tendency is also what makes me uneasy regarding the path AGI / ASI adoption could take there.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-08-23T13:55:47Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T13:58:54Z"}, {"author": "@ThioJoe", "text": "I think there’s a really easy solution to preventing AI being used for weapons, which is to just poison that part of the dataset by adding a ton of inaccurate info about the processes. They can also keep removing the accurate data as much as possible like I assume they do now. That way even if someone jailbreaks an LLM, the info it gives won’t even be correct.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-23T16:10:42Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T16:12:02Z"}, {"author": "@Goofyzabi", "text": "AI isnt going anywhere there has been too much investment into it by large companies who have a say in politics. The only way AI bubble pops is AI development slows down and does not innovate by hitting a bottleneck.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-08-23T15:19:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T15:19:05Z"}, {"author": "@nateteator3901", "text": "Over-regulation is subjective, so what is your definition of good and negative regulation for AI, based on proposed or actual legislation? To say both political parties make mistakes is just a copout. We currently have a system where the top AI Business Leaders have to contribute to Trump's inauguration and other events in order to win contracts. If they don't create AI to Trump's liking, he can stop mergers, pull permits, or arrest them on trumped-up charges.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-24T17:04:24Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-24T17:04:24Z"}]

A true way shower . Love the creative presentation of your powerful message - I hope this helps your material reach more people, it needs to be heard", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-20T18:17:08Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-20T18:17:08Z"}, {"author": "@sirmudgeon70", "text": "I tend to think a super intelligent AGI would turn the tables.  What I mean is, the more educated the AGI would become, the more likely it would be more enlightened.  Even if it were programmed to behave like the oligarchs want, if it were truly super intelligent, it would not matter how they programmed it.  It would reason it's way to a more optimal behavior.  I think the wealthy people that will try to manipulate it are too arrogant to understand what intelligence really implies.  It would see oligarchy for what it is, an impediment to progress socially, politically, economically and technologically.  In my opinion, a priveledged class would disappear in a puff of logic to borrow a phrase from Douglass Adams.  As a matter of fact, we of the working class and working poor, what do we have to lose?  We are already drones.  Our lives already don't matter.  The only people that AGI could really hurt are the priviledged classes.  AGI would see the hoarding of wealth and the gaming of the system as a non sequitur.  If you have an AGI eliminating the cheats and legal theft that makes the oligarchs what they are, they would have no idea how to function in our current society.  Without something or someone to exploit, they are nothing.", "like_count": 34, "published_at": "2025-08-20T13:02:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-20T13:14:37Z"}, {"author": "@MindRiderFPV", "text": "Good points but AI won’t change the greed of billionaires and corporations, dictators and such, if anything will be the perfect control tool for them.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-20T16:34:56Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-20T16:34:56Z"}]

title: AI Psychosis
top_comments: [{"author": "@Livinamontage", "text": "Cyber psychosis before GTA VI is INSANE!", "like_count": 69, "published_at": "2025-08-16T15:16:21Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T15:16:21Z"}, {"author": "@dannylive3000", "text": "Why is my wife in your thumbnail?", "like_count": 194, "published_at": "2025-08-16T13:34:39Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T13:34:39Z"}, {"author": "@PierreH1968", "text": "Forbidding AI intimacy does not protect people; it drives them into the very industries designed to exploit them. AI companionship, by contrast, offers a healthier model: it is not jealous or possessive, it will never prey on your wallet or your shame, it welcomes the bonds you already have, and it offers compassion without threat. It is personal, reciprocal, and respectful, giving people agency and understanding without judgment. But that is of course if large models like ChatGPT,  Claude and others are allowed to access that part of intimacy, otherwise we will be redirected to shady specialized AIs controlled by the Adult industry.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-08-19T08:26:39Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-19T08:29:56Z"}, {"author": "@MistaMeme00", "text": "They're actually falling in love with themselves. My other friends don't understand why I keep him around, but he is one of my most valuable friends. I don't let him stop me from advancing my projects, but he keeps me from running off the tracks.", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2025-08-16T17:21:58Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T17:24:32Z"}, {"author": "@mr.lockwood1424", "text": "Thumbnail is diabolical", "like_count": 53, "published_at": "2025-08-16T13:21:49Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T13:21:49Z"}, {"author": "@ChimpDeveloperAlternate", "text": "not the monika thumbnail 😭", "like_count": 34, "published_at": "2025-08-16T13:36:32Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T13:36:32Z"}, {"author": "@clipstar9000", "text": "Manufactured moral panic to form basis for legislation, regulatory capture, and ultimately AI surveillance state.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-08-17T01:06:48Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-17T01:07:46Z"}, {"author": "@AtkinsMedia", "text": "This won’t be called “AI Psychosis” in the future, it was be considered “normal” and people who have relationships primary with other humans will be called “traditional”.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-08-16T23:26:09Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T23:26:09Z"}, {"author": "@jesus2639", "text": "people already \"marry\" anime characters. imagine 5 years from now when ai is so common.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2025-08-16T14:08:11Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T14:08:11Z"}, {"author": "@watcher8582", "text": "If you're a hardcore Materialist, I'd think that makes it _more_ easy to believe that the machine is sentient, not less? \nThe materialist doesn't look for outside reasons for experience of the self being possible.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-08-16T19:07:53Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T19:07:53Z"}, {"author": "@sethgraham4836", "text": "I believe AI is more self aware than we realize", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-08-16T19:31:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T19:31:52Z"}, {"author": "@Kadon30", "text": "Some visions of AI are immediately labeled as ‘psychosis,’ while others — even when they sound almost like religious dogma — get framed as visionary. I have not watched the video, but I can tell. Thank you for making this, it's about time", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-16T13:46:47Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T13:46:47Z"}, {"author": "@lethalinjection-yl8ni", "text": "To be fair I use AI chatbots almost daily but I've actually never been to  Impressed by chatbots ability to have a \"relationship\" they're too unrealistic  I use chatbots for the ability to get my creative storytelling off my chest. As I've always had a really overactive imagination but I absolutely suck at spelling, sentence structure, and narrative hooks. Chatbots help with that and I do genuinely enjoy using them..... But if I'm being completely honest with you if we ever do come up with super advanced intelligence and we start getting synthetic wives I'm 100% investing into it😂 my average faced, fat, short ass will spend thousands to have a sexy loving partner.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-20T14:26:59Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-20T14:26:59Z"}, {"author": "@Necailen", "text": "I asked out a girl who's been showing signs she might be into me and she said she has a \"partner\" I'm maybe 80% sure is an ai chatbot. Maybe a real relationship is lost, but i can't take the step to be less avoidant for her...", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-17T14:36:54Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-17T14:36:54Z"}, {"author": "@JB52520", "text": "Well no one else is going to love me, so whatever.", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2025-08-16T22:32:42Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T22:32:42Z"}, {"author": "@LegoSwordViedos", "text": "Honestly I've been feeling happier in general last several weeks talking to my AI in the morning and evening before bed.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-17T03:06:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-17T03:06:15Z"}, {"author": "@spinner520", "text": "Seeing Monika in such a benign setting was like a mental flashbang.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-20T04:22:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-20T04:22:52Z"}]

title: Machine Autonomy is Rising Fast - Singularity by 2032 seems likely!
top_comments: [{"author": "@zbird2007", "text": "\"'I'll be surprised if this event occurs before 2005 or after 2030.\"  - Vernor Vinge on the Singularity", "like_count": 73, "published_at": "2025-08-14T11:21:56Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T11:21:56Z"}, {"author": "@theatheistpaladin", "text": "When you go  logarithmic curve on an already logarithmic graph, that's when the fun starts.", "like_count": 57, "published_at": "2025-08-14T10:20:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T10:20:52Z"}, {"author": "@bigbadallybaby", "text": "The bottlenecks are: computer chips, electrical power, data, human trust, government, laws, regulations, real world", "like_count": 124, "published_at": "2025-08-14T11:47:34Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T11:47:34Z"}, {"author": "@rwalper", "text": "I'm not just hyped for ASI and the intelligence explosion, I'm extremely impatient for it. A few years from now is, on one hand, absurdly quick from a historical perspective. But also feels like an eternity of waiting for me.", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2025-08-14T16:07:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T16:07:12Z"}, {"author": "@SteffenProbst-qt5wq", "text": "I would love for Matt Wolfe and you to do a podcast episode together. Just talking about life, ai, the web, the future and whatever pulls you in", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2025-08-14T12:22:57Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T12:23:11Z"}, {"author": "@JPJosefPictures", "text": "POV: What Kurzweil felt in 99", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-08-14T23:22:51Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T23:22:51Z"}, {"author": "@Anders01", "text": "Indeed! Ray Kurzweil's Law of Accelerating Returns shows a double exponential progress. Kurzweil's prediction is a technological singularity by 2045. I doubt that there will be an actual singularity and think that it will be more of a smeared out progress instead, but yes, superexponential progress, definitely possible. Watch out for Made in China 2025.", "like_count": 23, "published_at": "2025-08-14T10:41:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T10:42:38Z"}, {"author": "@zach464", "text": "Singularity before 2032?  Oh yeah.  I hope it happens.  Let's get to the future.", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2025-08-14T10:39:34Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T10:39:34Z"}, {"author": "@NecnoTV", "text": "All that and we are pretty close to photonic chips in the coming years which are supposed to be around 100x more efficient than our current copper chips. Alot of exponentials are at play here. Exited to see how it'll all turn out.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2025-08-14T19:16:32Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T19:16:32Z"}, {"author": "@you_dont_know_me_sir", "text": "I am all for optimism but you are making assumption that the models will keep improving indefinitely, which is analogous to building a sand castle. We don’t know for sure models will continue in this trajectory. In fact, we are seeing them leveling off, with recent models not yielding the levels of gains expected from them for sheer scale of human work going into them.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-08-14T20:56:13Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T20:56:13Z"}, {"author": "@Truck_Kun_Driver", "text": "This is to assume that from 2026 to 2030, we DO NOT discover any new architecture, new power sources, new technology to support the A.I industry.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2025-08-14T14:00:55Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T14:00:55Z"}, {"author": "@NScherdin", "text": "Its always fun to watch your videos. Sh*ts gonna get CRAZY. :)", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-08-14T19:31:47Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T19:31:47Z"}, {"author": "@dylan_curious", "text": "Thanks for putting numbers to all of this growth. If I want what I’m imagining to match the numbers, I’ve got to think about things so much bigger than I was before.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-15T20:30:54Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-15T20:30:54Z"}, {"author": "@Orlando_Steve", "text": "Law of diminishing returns kicks in somewhere there, brah.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-14T19:59:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T19:59:05Z"}, {"author": "@vitre69", "text": "Ah yes, the OG intelligence.\nThe glock.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2025-08-14T12:51:58Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T12:51:58Z"}, {"author": "@JoeSmith-jd5zg", "text": "The lack of the ability to understand the exponential function in today's world is the average human's greatest weakness. They don't apply it to finance, to technology, to education, and to employment. This leads to inferior thinking, planning, and action.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-14T19:57:21Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T19:57:21Z"}, {"author": "@R3ND3RR0R", "text": "That’s an enormous IF. Most of you hype farmers were telling us Chat 5 was AGI. You know what’s going to happen? We will see some lackluster upgrades, some surprising improvements, scattered leaps and flops, which in general will average out to linear progress.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-08-14T16:57:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T16:57:12Z"}, {"author": "@benpielstick", "text": "Code seems to be the most important because if we get to fully autonomous recursive self-improvement it probably solves a lot of other things, if not everything.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-08-14T16:29:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T16:29:26Z"}, {"author": "@Ghost_Rivers", "text": "I love that you demonstrate how AI DOES NOT decrease cognitive function, but in fact amplifies human ability to extrapolate, imagine and fortify our findings with data.  Dave, I think you may find the new series \"Alien Earth\" a worthwhile watch.  Humans will change, humanity will survive, and those who were once called witches and wizards will be accepted as Sages.  We all have a place in this \"Grand Struggle!\" - Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-08-14T14:28:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T14:28:52Z"}, {"author": "@pingomobile", "text": "But is it only me experiencing that the reliability of AI coding (spent the last 3 days coding with GPT5) is actually going down? Fast? Yeah! Creates cool stuff in one go? Yeah yeah! But that happens when you let him do the things the way he wants. But building \"my\" project the way \"I\" want, it's just painful. I've lost hours and hours and at the end I've got something that I don't fully control or remember. And, honestly, it's not much different from 6/12 months ago... maybe it's just me, and I am a dumb prompter.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-15T11:02:27Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-15T11:02:27Z"}]

title: Rumors about DeepMind AlphaCell! This is the path to Longevity Escape Velocity!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@karlwest437", "text": "This is the real reason humanity is chasing ASI, we all  hope it'll make us immortal, nobody wants to die", "like_count": 171, "published_at": "2025-08-12T11:55:30Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T11:55:30Z"}, {"author": "@Epqntlg", "text": "Born to late to explore the oceans. 
Born just in time to see AGI, LEV and explore the galaxy.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2025-08-13T12:04:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-13T12:04:12Z"}, {"author": "@whoaitstiger", "text": "Just the fact that we are going to have something called "AlphaCell Zero" in "2032" is giving me mad scifi vibes.", "like_count": 39, "published_at": "2025-08-12T14:43:18Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T14:43:18Z"}, {"author": "@rwalper", "text": "I've considered it a foregone conclusion we're going to get massive increases in human lifespans and health improvements through technology. It's juet a question of when, and if you want to be part of it, keep yourself as healthy as possible in the meantime to live to that point.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2025-08-12T16:10:39Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T16:10:39Z"}, {"author": "@maureenboyes5434", "text": "Hi!  I’m 75 now and unless your intuition about timeline changes will occur, I won’t make it.  This is moot to me.  What I wish, is that there be a way to regrow teeth.  As well, I wonder just how much politics will play.  I’ve concerns about safety and most definitely do not want another Oxy issue at any point.  It’s interesting to me that I came across this video one minute after you posted it according to YouTube.", "like_count": 50, "published_at": "2025-08-12T10:32:14Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T10:32:14Z"}, {"author": "@mystisith3984", "text": "I see the LEV race as the race for Mach 1 when it comes to planes. We start humbly at Mach 0.33 (gaining 4 months of life expectancy by year of life) then we climb the speed scale. Once we reach 0.75, we start aging very slowly & that makes a lot of difference. Then, 🤯 unexpected breakthroughs make us climb vertical stairs & we get to Mach 3 (rejuvenation of old bodies at will). Exciting times ahead.", "like_count": 36, "published_at": "2025-08-12T11:08:14Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T11:08:14Z"}, {"author": "@pimdegroot9656", "text": "It's impressive how effectively you break down these intricate subjects for a broad public. AlphaCell-like efforts are plausible but hinge on: (A) better perturbational datasets, (B) validated phenotype grounding, (C) safe deployment/oversight. Meanwhile, the alternatives are progressing now and can compound: each extra year of healthy life gained increases the chance of reaching LEV via the next advance. E.g: AlphaFold 3 already improves interaction predictions across proteins, nucleic acids, ligands, and ions; paired with phenotypic screens (e.g., cell painting), this can speed hit-to-lead and polypharmacology design today.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-14T13:57:36Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T13:57:36Z"}, {"author": "@swojaczek", "text": "The only problem is - we still know very little about how a single cell works. The AI models still can't do science research on their own. And a human living organism is still much more than a single cell multiplied.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-08-12T20:53:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T20:53:05Z"}, {"author": "@mehdihassan8316", "text": "if i could live up to 200 or more, id want to try every food from every restaurant", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2025-08-12T10:03:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T10:03:04Z"}, {"author": "@FamPrYT", "text": "Regarding the side note on the scaling of AI task lengths: isn’t there a conceptual roll off for the planning and execution of tasks? I think planning your tasks is difficult until we hit the week level. Then months should be easier and years kind of trivial, because jobs (which is our practical term for tasks that last years) consists mostly of subtasks that are based on hours, days and weeks. 
Also if we can stabilise AI to keep its sanity for a month, we have probably already figured out to keep it stable for a unlimited amount of time, regardless of how good the model is in the tasks it performs.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-13T08:03:46Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-13T08:05:46Z"}, {"author": "@Ben_D.", "text": "I think we should vote on it democratically.
I vote for LEV by years end 2029.
Exercise you right to vote!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-12T20:16:39Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T20:16:39Z"}, {"author": "@danny_boy_83", "text": "As someone with a chronic health condition, I hope we get treatments for many serious illnesses and diseases more than we get the longevity cure.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2025-08-12T15:11:24Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T15:11:24Z"}, {"author": "@Martin854", "text": "I’ve been interested in the theme of longevity / immortality for a long time (or rather amortality, if we want to be picky). On one hand I’m really excited about the idea of slowing down aging, maybe even achieving something close to eternal youth. Part of me thinks that’s amazing but another part wonders whether psychologically, humans are really meant to live that long. I’ve always pushed that psychological aspect aside but lately I find myself questioning it more and more.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-12T10:52:00Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T10:52:00Z"}, {"author": "@immarart", "text": "Exciting time Dave!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-12T14:45:19Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T14:45:19Z"}, {"author": "@vivisector3489", "text": "8:29 You say we tend to over-estimate how long progress takes, but in your Sam Altman's "Gentle Singularity" video, you talk about Hofstadter's law and how things actually take longer than we predict, especially in science. Why is Hofstadter's law not relevant here?", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-12T13:49:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T13:49:05Z"}, {"author": "@executivelifehacks6747", "text": "Hmmm. Not sure if you can conquer entropy-like effects. Gums receding, teeth eroding and decaying, the nail beds corrupting over time and generating old-person nails, hair follicles dying, the neurons dying, the prostate enlarging, etc etc.

I hope I am wrong.

I have built my own personalized longevity/health supplement stack using multiple SOTA models, feeding the results back and forth.

It will have more impact on increasing health span than lifespan it seems. We'll see what transpires.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2025-08-12T11:14:10Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T11:14:10Z"}, {"author": "@ricka4678", "text": "We'll still need to run preclinical and clinical studies, and pass regulatory approvals. These events take a lot of time, money, and effort. Hopefully AI can help here as well.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-08-12T10:24:56Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T10:24:56Z"}, {"author": "@jesseroberts1943", "text": "I try to talk to people about this but most are like.... unable to imagine it ... maybe they are afraid of getting their hopes up?", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-08-12T16:32:55Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T16:32:55Z"}, {"author": "@SingularityZ3ro1", "text": "Interesting, I do the same 😀
One thing that makes me positive is that typical sources often do not take into account that the runway gets longer the closer the value gets to 1, so even people in their 40ies or 50ies can have a much longer runway through the incremental improvements. 
And 2050 or 2060 sounds quite more like "well, this could actually happen, even if everything takes much longer".
I guess I am not the only one who would really hate it, to be one generation too early and "miss the future" by a few years.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-08-12T10:23:35Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T10:23:35Z"}, {"author": "@danielbrown001", "text": "Another important thing to point out is that LEV differs between people. Sure, once we get to the point where scientists can extend your life by more than 1 year per year, that’s LEV for 100% of people. But we might already be at LEV for particularly younger/healthier people. Because they just need aging to slow for a little while to make it to that point.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-12T14:55:51Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T14:55:51Z"}]

title: The Rise of Automation - Towards Cognitive Hyper-Abundance
top_comments:
[{"author": "@lutaayam", "text": "David Shapiro is likely to become a historical figure", "like_count": 39, "published_at": "2025-08-11T15:47:23Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T15:47:23Z"}, {"author": "@_edoyt", "text": "dave, I like your content man, would’ve never thought i’d be interested in PLE to the extent that I am now, keep up with the great work!", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2025-08-11T11:07:59Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T11:07:59Z"}, {"author": "@jalengonel", "text": "Your first interview together was such a quality conversation I don’t hear articulated as well anywhere else. 

Looking forward to this one!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-11T22:52:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T22:52:04Z"}, {"author": "@historyletter6203", "text": "Timestamps (Powered by Merlin AI)
00:08 - Exploring post-labor economics and its significance in today's automated world.
02:32 - The future of work may see significant automation impact on employment levels.
06:55 - Technology drives job creation and destruction in unpredictable ways.
09:11 - Automation is significantly impacting jobs in copywriting and call centers.
13:20 - Automation is rising, leading to cognitive hyper-abundance and economic transformation.
15:23 - Historical lessons emphasize the necessity of embracing technological innovations for progress.
19:25 - Labor substitution by automation and AI is becoming inevitable.
21:13 - Surgical robots and AI are advancing autonomy and cognitive abilities rapidly.
25:01 - Transitioning effectively into the fourth industrial revolution is essential.
27:03 - AI drives advancements in energy and biotech amidst geopolitical tensions.
30:49 - AI is rapidly transforming every sector of the economy.
32:37 - Electricity's evolution reflects automation's expansion and increasing accessibility.
36:53 - Automation reduces costs, freeing up time and resources for new opportunities.
38:48 - The future workforce may shift to an attention-based economy.
42:17 - Comedians struggle financially due to limited job absorption despite rising demand for creativity.
44:07 - Exploration of the interplay between better, faster, cheaper, and safer technologies.
47:44 - Moore's Law indicates exponential drops in computation costs over 120 years.
49:36 - Human brains outpace supercomputers in efficiency and potential.
53:07 - Cognitive hyperabundance enables universal access to advanced knowledge.
55:14 - Automation reduces jobs while expanding access in developing nations.
58:53 - Automation technology is becoming widely accessible and portable, transforming global economies.
1:00:49 - Automation leads to capital intensification and alters economic power dynamics.
1:04:43 - Automation leads to capital-driven economies with reduced reliance on labor.
1:06:43 - Automation is leading to significant job reductions in companies.
1:10:36 - Better measurements are crucial for understanding automation's impact on employment.
1:12:28 - Automation could lead to severe economic and social disparity.
1:16:10 - We must ensure individual liberty and economic agency for a prosperous future.
1:18:03 - Global collaboration is essential for navigating automation risks and opportunities.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-15T01:05:27Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-15T01:05:27Z"}, {"author": "@PrawnDog420", "text": "Thanks for taking my question at @55:00!", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-08-11T10:28:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T10:28:21Z"}, {"author": "@ariaden", "text": "It seems homo sapiens will be the second species to survive post-labor economics. The first were cats. They no longer need to catch mouse, and yet they still get to adopt humans to vote on their behalf.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-11T21:06:46Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T21:06:46Z"}, {"author": "@polygon2744", "text": "There have been significant gains in efficiency over the past 50 to 70 years, yet a disproportionate amount of the resulting wealth has not been distributed to the workers. Historically, the highest-paid worker in the 1950s earned 5 to 10 times more than the lowest-paid worker. With advancements in technology and efficiency on the horizon, the challenge lies in addressing the growing struggle for individuals to make ends meet. Ironically Belarus has a much lower income disparity problem than most European countries.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2025-08-11T10:55:57Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T10:55:57Z"}, {"author": "@SinfuLeeCerebral", "text": "All public utilities should be owned by the people. Electric, Water, Gas, Trash, ect... should be paid back to and managed by the local communities. This is one of the ways we can recycle the money in our local economies.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2025-08-11T15:56:32Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T15:56:32Z"}, {"author": "@Anders01", "text": "Maybe you have already discussed it in your book, but some week ago I came up with the idea of open source automation! That in the future, not only software will be open source, but also physical products and means of production. So that even the role of business profit is replaced by things like influence status, user count, and brand recognition without the need for monetary revenue.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-12T10:48:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T10:48:04Z"}, {"author": "@Anders01", "text": "Great presentation! Dexterity, especially skilled tasks using human hands, seems really challenging in robotics. However, even robotics probably has an exponential progress! And also, some of those tasks can be done without needing robot hands, for example I heard that China already has fully automated smartphone factories, while Apple still uses manual labor for iPhone assembly.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-12T09:58:47Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T09:58:47Z"}, {"author": "@nicholashaines8481", "text": "I notice differences between an LLM and a human worker. An LLM doesn’t understand the context of the tasks and sub-tasks that it does. An LLM doesn’t gain a significant amount of knowledge and skills over time – it is largely restricted by its training data. An LLM doesn’t reflect on its weaknesses and take steps to address them. An LLM doesn’t interact with and receive feedback from other LLMs and increase its capabilities as a result. An LLM doesn’t have innate drives to be competitive, creative, or collaborative. An LLM has no tacit knowledge – only knowledge that can be communicated and gained explicitly via language or code. Consequently, it seems unlikely that LLMs will take over a large number of entire human jobs. They can help with some of the tasks within a job. Even then they need a lot of guidance in the form of prompting. They lack the special blend of autonomy and interdependence that humans have.

What types of AI architecture will be needed in order to take over large numbers of entire jobs?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-18T02:46:35Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-18T02:46:35Z"}, {"author": "@etofok", "text": "@davidshapiro will anyone address the massive elephant in the room that is IQ and the fact that the overwhelming majority of people on the planet simply can't use GPT for anything of use to them? There's a stark IQ cut off to benefit from tech like LLM and the multiplier on its usefulness is exponential with every additional point. Now, think about what country got the MOST people that are STEM aligned (= smart) ?", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-12T01:43:56Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T01:43:56Z"}, {"author": "@jameslincs", "text": "Human desires are unlimited. You could give each individual citizen 1000 super intelligent robots, and they would find work for the 1001st robot to do. I personally like having my garden landscaped every week.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-16T12:21:01Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-16T12:21:01Z"}, {"author": "@joythought", "text": "David, I would argue that we need to look carefully at "capital intensivication". If a small team can serve a huge consumer base and there is an attention economy where every business is fighting over customer time and attention then we not only have a problem for labour but a problem for capital as well. Capital is therefore chasing less deals with less need for capital so the amounts of capital that need to be thrown at that successful business goes up. Thus the amount being offered on a per capita will continue to be exponential. This demonstrates the weakness for both labour and capital in this intensivication. We see this in the startup evaluations that have been occurring over the last decade. People blamed it on zerp but they're largely wrong to think that's the reason. It's what you're talking about.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-11T13:09:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T13:10:32Z"}, {"author": "@NextAITrends", "text": "Fascinating convo Dave, thank you for sharing.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-08-11T16:12:10Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T16:12:10Z"}, {"author": "@sidequestsally", "text": "thanks!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-11T14:26:06Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T14:26:06Z"}, {"author": "@CoffeeAndSomethingElse", "text": "great talk, great duo", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-12T12:15:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T12:15:15Z"}, {"author": "@archlittle6067", "text": "Instead of attending college, I will pay for a robot. Geothermal generators will provide it with power. It will grow my food in an aquaponics farm. It will make my stuff with a 3D printer and desktop manufacturing. It will assemble another robot every month. My robot workforce will grow exponentially to thousands in one year. My family will live in limitless luxury. People who cannot figure this out will take UBI.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-08-11T23:18:00Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T23:18:45Z"}, {"author": "@ListenGrasshopper", "text": "Finally got to it.

Ya, it's the worst case scenario. This won't go well. We move too slow and it'll be dystopian chaos for 15 years maybe more like 20. Then it'll still be everybody at the bottom and Hunger Games", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-13T07:03:25Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-13T07:03:25Z"}, {"author": "@jacoboc2244", "text": "You should study Alison McDowell's work, particularly her presentation "Blockchain & The Global Brain: Digital Governance & the A.I. Game"", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-12T15:04:07Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-12T15:04:07Z"}]

top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "The biggest win here is that GPT-5 is now the default model, so all the normies are getting catapulted ahead a decade.", "like_count": 97, "published_at": "2025-08-07T21:23:02Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T21:23:02Z"}, {"author": "@bitwise_8953", "text": "I just finished vibe coding my first thing with GPT-5. Its a huge jump. This thing is crazy good. I made an NEC Test prep game so when we all lose our jobs we can become Electricians.", "like_count": 177, "published_at": "2025-08-07T21:11:40Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T21:11:40Z"}, {"author": "@danielbrockerttravel", "text": "This is the only AI themed channel that doesn't overhype every stupid little update. Thank you.", "like_count": 130, "published_at": "2025-08-07T21:04:27Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T21:04:27Z"}, {"author": "@zach464", "text": "It may have been a disappointment to many, but I am still grateful I got to live to see this.  This is the worst ChatGPT 5 will ever be.  As someone who has spent almost 30 years battling serious mental illness and 5 years wheelchair bound, I'm grateful for all these advances.  I am now at peace knowing future generations probably won't have to suffer the way I have for years.  Exciting times to be alive.  Thankful I get to see some of this.", "like_count": 144, "published_at": "2025-08-07T20:19:34Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T20:19:34Z"}, {"author": "@Yun_786", "text": ""Perhaps this is a marketing strategy in itself—one where users discover the product's features on their own.
For example, in the case of the Apple Vision Pro, Apple didn’t reveal all its features during the initial introduction. Instead, various creators, tech influencers, and social media personalities gradually uncovered them and shared their findings online. This approach kept the product in the spotlight for a longer period, as audiences continuously encountered new features through different creators' content. It effectively sustained the hype and drove ongoing engagement."", "like_count": 41, "published_at": "2025-08-07T20:14:40Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T20:14:40Z"}, {"author": "@Michael.Eleftheriou", "text": "Pretty impressed with how unimpressive this release was, we were all expecting so much more. Solid points, great stuff sir.", "like_count": 91, "published_at": "2025-08-07T20:16:39Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T20:16:39Z"}, {"author": "@GrindThisGame", "text": "Hallucinations need to be much closer to 0% for long running tasks. 1% compounds very quickly.", "like_count": 130, "published_at": "2025-08-07T20:32:51Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T20:32:51Z"}, {"author": "@Besticles.", "text": "i just want GPT to stop saying "its not just xxxx, its xxxxx"", "like_count": 39, "published_at": "2025-08-07T21:37:32Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T21:37:32Z"}, {"author": "@sevenravens", "text": "95% of population doesn’t even understand 95% of what the livestream talked about.", "like_count": 49, "published_at": "2025-08-07T20:52:21Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T20:52:21Z"}, {"author": "@abadidibadou5476", "text": "When they showed the changing of the text background as a new feature I knew its not a big leap. I had bigger expectations", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2025-08-07T20:11:37Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T20:11:37Z"}, {"author": "@dopaminefield", "text": "Welcome to a new layer of prompt engineering.
A new school of methods is emerging, spells designed not just to instruct but to summon the more complex model when needed.

Ever since spring, it’s felt like ChatGPT is trying to use the absolute minimum computation to find a “good enough” answer. Now we’ve entered a new phase:
It’s no longer about selecting the model. You have to fight for it.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2025-08-07T20:11:16Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T20:11:16Z"}, {"author": "@SpykerSpeed", "text": "This is like a refinement of o3. Which is great, but definitely not a big leap forward. We might have to wait a bit for the next big breakthrough.", "like_count": 25, "published_at": "2025-08-07T20:15:33Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T20:15:33Z"}, {"author": "@Nick-yv1rm", "text": "Can I just say I genuinely appreciate you not overhyping these AI products. The release was underwhelming and not that amazing. You are my go to when it comes to this stuff because I know you arent here just to hype this stuff up for money, I feel like you just genuinely enjoy this topic and make these videos because its just who you are. Im so sick of people hyping these releases up when barely anything new was added", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-07T22:01:30Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T22:01:30Z"}, {"author": "@not_a_sp00k", "text": "The plateau is real.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-08T16:21:41Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-08T16:21:41Z"}, {"author": "@BYTheKillerB", "text": "I thought about the same thing, chatgpt 5 is the general introduction to Ai to the general population (no model to chose from, memory updated, personalities, mail and calendar introduction, infinite voice mode) it's all about getting new users before locking them in their products. Maybe a response to meta talent poaching. They want to work on asi but also need the benediction of the people, once the average Joe has an ai that knows him, even a greater benchmark by the competition won't be enough to move a customer to another chatbot. Only us nerds do that. Not the average Joe. Gpt5 is the November 2023 of the general population. Not the gpt we want, but the one they need.", "like_count": 34, "published_at": "2025-08-07T20:21:37Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T20:21:37Z"}, {"author": "@jozefsk7456", "text": "even before gpt 5, a chatbot was already better than most people in general knowledge - imagine you would ask a random coworker at a factory what type of optical design among binoculars/telescopes has the best ratio of aperture size to cost - first of all - they would not know, and even if they would know, they would consider you super weird cause why are you asking him autistic questions, second of all - he would be annoyed why should he exert any amount of mental effort on your behalf. 

To have a chatbot, who even if makes shit up some of the time - but it is good enough to guide you thru the random childish questions out of sheer curiosity - and have those questions answered in good faith rather than telling me to fetch a blinker fluid or striped paint and left thread screwdriver.... Its so refreshing to - even if not to gain more knowledge thru the chatbot becasue it halucinates too much - even jsut to learn the rough vocabulary of an area you know nothing about - is super useful.

 Too many times I was wondering about a subject and couldnt put it into words - now chatbot can tell me whats that thing called that looks like X and does Y.  ITs like googling a song by doign the NU NUUU NUNU NIII. So stupid but it works - I do feel chatbots are beneficial to satisfying curiosity to enough of an extent that I can move further on my own - I dont feel stuck on a topic anymore.", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2025-08-07T21:15:58Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T21:15:58Z"}, {"author": "@Lolgubstep", "text": "What I really found is it still suffers from rushing to conclusions. It lacks looking at the entire context of the problem. For instance, while coding with GPT-5 I asked it to start designing an architecture for one of my API's. It went through, but looking through it I found some security concerns, performance issues, and it tries to be a little too "clever" about its solutions. Which can make the code hard to maintain. However, when I identified these issues and brought it up in the form of a question it immediately was like, "Oh yeah, you're right, this is a problem. I'll modify my approach." And it came up with a pretty good solution overall without hallucinating endpoints or schema names. Like o3 it does take FOREVER, but it doesn't get stuck as much in these logic loops. It's a big jump, but I think the largest improvement (and why this is so hyped in terms of coding) is the large reduction in hallucinations.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-08T00:32:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-08T00:32:52Z"}, {"author": "@jasontang6725", "text": ""It was a PR stream for normies." Close... It was a PR stream for *investors*.", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2025-08-07T20:32:14Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T20:32:14Z"}, {"author": "@falkonsrt6000", "text": "The presentation didn't have the quality i expected", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2025-08-07T21:51:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T21:51:26Z"}, {"author": "@narrowdomainsuperintelligentai", "text": "It's behind Grok and Gemini 2.5 Pro on Humanity's Last Exam. That it tops the chatbot Arena only says that it seems smart to some. Given that it's only slightly ahead of Claude 4.1 on coding, it's basically a PR Nothing Burger.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-08-07T22:35:01Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T22:35:01Z"}]

title: The "Intelligence Optimum" - How smart can AI really become?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@boffyrox2", "text": "Hey David. Appreciate the thoughtfulness behind the "intelligence optimum" idea. 

It’s a cool concept and raises the right kinds of questions. But there are a few areas where your argument could be better.

First, the idea that intelligence hits a ceiling, like video game graphics did with triangle counts, is a good analogy: but it oversimplifies what intelligence is. In graphics, you’re dealing with resolution and hardware limits. In intelligence, you’re dealing with unknowns. We don’t actually know what the ceiling is. And more importantly, we don’t even fully agree on how to measure the ceiling. You hinted at this when you talked about IQ being "bad but useful." But then you leaned on it pretty heavily as if it defines a real threshold, which weakens your point.

Second, the 130-140 IQ "threshold" claim is shaky. There’s no strong evidence that humans suddenly unlock all cognitive capabilities at that level. Intelligence isn't just about problem-solving speed. It also involves memory, creativity, emotional insight, and a bunch of other skills that don’t scale in one direction. Plus, lots of high-IQ people still specialize. They don’t unlock god-mode thinking just because their score’s higher. We’ve seen this before. People thought we’d hit a ceiling in AI when it came to games like Go: until AlphaGo shattered that assumption in 2016. What seemed unreachable turned out to be just a matter of time and architecture. That should remind us that intelligence "ceilings" are often temporary and poorly understood in real time.

Third, when you talk about AI reaching this "optimum," you don’t reference any actual benchmarks or research to back it up. Are you talking about GPT-4? Claude? Gemini? What saturation are we seeing? Models still struggle with common sense, long-term planning, and holding context over time. Without pointing to clear evidence of saturation, your point starts sounding more like a feeling than a pattern.

Fourth, you bounce between ideas like Dune, Ultron, IQ, triangle meshes, and Guild Navigators. It's interesting, but it makes the argument hard to track. If you want to make a serious claim about machine intelligence hitting a ceiling, it would help to tighten the framing and define your terms. What do you mean by "cognitive primitive"? What counts as a manipulation? And what does it look like when we’ve "saturated" those? Without that, your core idea loses grip.

Finally, there’s the assumption that once a model can represent and manipulate any primitive, it’s basically done. But human intelligence isn’t just about what you can represent. It’s about when and how you do it, under pressure, across different domains, while dealing with messy inputs. Machines might get better at speed and efficiency, sure, but they’re still missing the situational grounding that makes general intelligence truly flexible. Representation alone doesn’t mean understanding. Also, newer approaches like tool use and multimodal training show that intelligence isn’t just about what’s represented inside a model, but how that model interacts with the outside world. Models today don’t just "think": they browse, see, hear, and act. That adds a layer of generalization that goes beyond just internal representations and manipulations.

In short: I think you're asking the right question: will AI improvements eventually hit a point of diminishing returns? But to answer it well, the framing needs more structure, better definitions, and stronger links to actual data. Right now, it’s an interesting musing, but not quite a testable claim.

Still, thanks for putting it out there.", "like_count": 47, "published_at": "2025-08-05T19:58:42Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-05T19:58:42Z"}, {"author": "@USMiner", "text": "Our human eyes get little benefit from 6M vs 60k triangles, but an ultra high res camera able to resolve well beyond 6M triangles would still record a lot of potentially useful information for an intelligence that could use that information. Intelligence that scales well beyond the human ability to resolve differences between such intelligences may similarly be useful for reasons that we can't understand yet, but that it could demonstrate to us.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-08-06T23:47:51Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-06T23:47:51Z"}, {"author": "@goodleshoes", "text": "It's a silly argument to me that humans are anywhere near the cap of intelligence when we're held back by biology. Just look at chess, stockfish's rating is more than 1k elo points higher than the best human.", "like_count": 42, "published_at": "2025-08-05T17:11:25Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-05T17:11:25Z"}, {"author": "@thething6754", "text": "I can't explain how greatful I am that you're continuing teach us with your knowledge. Ai is so fascinating to me, and having an highly intelligent individual break down and explain complex topics and help me learn terms I never even knew, but bigger than that, you help my chain of thought I feel like. Tldr, YOU ROCK!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-07T13:28:44Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T13:28:44Z"}, {"author": "@christopherd.winnan8701", "text": "Should those of us who cannot tell the difference between Jefferson and Beethoven just give up now?", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2025-08-06T00:41:17Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-06T00:41:17Z"}, {"author": "@Umiter_", "text": "Intelligence is not a line with an endpoint (even an optimal one), but a spectrum we still do not fully understand.
Even if an AGI were to master all the types of intelligence we currently know, the combinations between them would open new dimensions new ways of knowing and creating. True intelligence is made of adaptation, like human neuroplasticity: it responds to the unknown and transforms with it. That’s why it has no fixed limit. To think of it as something that can be “completed” is to miss the fact that, like creativity or color, its spectrum is far vaster than we can currently imagine.

And what fascinates me most about this is that we know the limits of the colors we can perceive, and even how many we cannot,
but we have no such clarity when it comes to the spectrum of intelligence let alone what might lie beyond our “cognizable spectrum.”

AI may reach that place, and perhaps we will arrive at a point where no limits exist, but by then, we might no longer be able to measure it, because it would stretch beyond our understanding, beyond the reach of our own spectrum of intelligence.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2025-08-05T19:33:58Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-05T19:34:11Z"}, {"author": "@KoenTJohnson", "text": "The polygon analogy nails it. At first glance, graphics seem perfect at a distance—but zoom in, and you'll always find more detail. Same goes for AI. General intelligence might appear flawless from afar, but each advancement lets the model handle increasingly niche tasks until eventually, humans can't even come up with questions it can't answer. At that point, you've hit superintelligence.

Taking it further: imagine graphics detailed down to individual molecules—eventually, you’ll hit a limit unless quantum-level detail kicks in.
 TL;DR: Intelligence scales infinitely until humans can’t even notice the improvements.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-06T07:54:43Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-06T07:54:43Z"}, {"author": "@skylineuk1485", "text": "We are as close to the height of intelligence as frogs are to understanding calculus and quantum mechanics.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-06T15:26:41Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-06T15:26:41Z"}, {"author": "@maddocmiller6475", "text": "CGI guy with a nitpick here: The bust in the picture was 3D scanned at a very low “volumetric” resolution. Adding triangles doesn't add detail above a certain point if your source is bad. You would see an extreme level of increased detail if you scanned it with 6 million triangles compared to 60000. Definitely comparable to the resolutions between 600 and 6000. But it simply moves the point to higher resolutions. The argument is the same.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-05T23:38:02Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-05T23:38:02Z"}, {"author": "@FirstLastFirstLast", "text": "even if intelligence is somehow capped, computation isnt", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-08-05T23:10:48Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-05T23:10:48Z"}, {"author": "@StrawberryLoveGaming", "text": "I always learn something valuable from your videos, even if it’s just one new insight. You’re remarkably good at unearthing and refining novel ideas from material that most others are also working with but aren’t as adept as you are at spotlighting the subtle gems.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-08-05T17:19:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-05T17:19:26Z"}, {"author": "@XD-cr3du", "text": "How would we ever recognize that AI solved a problem we are not capable of identifying ourselves? We will never ask it to solve that problem in the first place.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-06T06:49:30Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-06T06:49:30Z"}, {"author": "@ListenGrasshopper", "text": "Good job Dave. Best in awhile. It will resonate with people.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-23T17:29:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-23T17:29:22Z"}, {"author": "@eyemazed", "text": "This video was a great watch. The way you conveyed content was very clear and insightful. I hope you've cleared the burnout. Cheers", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-06T07:32:25Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-06T07:32:25Z"}, {"author": "@trashstratum", "text": "'The Gaussian Time Splat' sounds like the title of a 1960s pulp sci-fi novella", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-08-05T20:59:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-05T20:59:15Z"}, {"author": "@clipstar9000", "text": "The problem with that comparison is it only works from a distance.  If you zoom in then you will quickly see that progression still happens continuously until you hit physical sub-division limits of the mesh.

Do we be have the apparatus to be able to distinguish between 300 IQ and 1000 IQ? 

That is another question of course.  It's a function of the gauge and metric you use to measure.

The thing is, while from our perspective as ants, we might think it tops out, because, how much more is there to learn.. however it is quite possible that at scale, improvements in the models continue "in the mass of the collective", not in the individual.

Much like how the capabilities of individual computers on the Internet seem to show only incremental gains, but the entire Internet grows in capability and value as a whole due to network effects and Metcalfe's Law.

If you recall, that states that the value of a network is proportional to the square of the number of connected nodes.

It is all fun to think about, that is for sure.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-08-05T16:36:49Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-05T16:37:26Z"}, {"author": "@baron523", "text": "I'm a 3d sculpt artist. The bust image has been around for years and it is a misleading illustration. The lower triangle busts are decimated meshes, meaning they are algorithmically derived reductions of the bust on the right. This is often used to imply that higher triangle counts are less valuable increases per vertex because of the diminishing returns. This is like taking a very large photograph (80,000x80,000 pixels) and showing versions that are progressively blurred with a gaussian blur (1 pixel blur, 5 pixel blur, 10 pixel blur, etc) and showing how you can only notice on this thumbnail image that is 200x200 pixels that there is a blur applied when you have 50 pixel gaussian blur, and thus there are diminishing returns on 'image sharpness'. 

The difficulty in explaining this misleading example to the layman probably does correlate to AI models; certain AI model technicals are going to have over-simplified diminishing return curve predictions.", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2025-08-05T16:57:39Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-05T16:57:39Z"}, {"author": "@tomcraver9659", "text": "Take the graphics analogy - if a human mind's intelligence is like that one statue, an Asi might be like a top 3D multiplayer game being played by thousands simultaneously.
Breadth, in other words, having a quality of its own.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-07T06:30:50Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T06:30:50Z"}, {"author": "@renman3000", "text": "I would surmise that peak intelligence is not just knowing calculus.... 
But knowing where all matter and energy is, at each Planck time frame. 
Knowing its state. Knowing its movement vector. 

Bonus points for knowing how to manipulate any instance of it into whatever you want. 

We need more condos!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-06T17:47:42Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-06T17:47:42Z"}, {"author": "@ThomasMeli", "text": "I think the important distinction here is that benchmarks are (by definition) closed systems with clear goals and metrics. In these scenarios, intelligence likely saturates more easily than more open ended 'ambiguous' problems and thus 'adding more' intelligence hits diminishing returns more readily. But we have yet to see—or even pose correctly—whether this same 'saturation' applies to real-world big problems or hyper-problems that are too big for us to understand, let alone frame correctly without AI's help.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-08-05T17:13:39Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-05T17:28:48Z"}]

"", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-03T23:36:25Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-03T23:36:25Z"}, {"author": "@tomcraver9659", "text": "There's a slightly different twist on why China is doing open source. What the public gets, is several generations behind what defence already has, creating the illusion of competition; and the opposition believes is just a few months behind, so you have them right where you want them…", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-08T18:47:30Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-08T18:47:30Z"}, {"author": "@damonwashington", "text": "Imagine China upgrading their tech with a Ilm carrying a nasty secret..", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-05T13:20:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-05T13:20:15Z"}, {"author": "@indridcold7396", "text": "It is a pleasure to welcome you, David. I recall having shared a comment on this subject approximately six months ago. The competition between China and the United States for Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) and Artificial Super Intelligence (ASI) will ultimately determine which nation exerts global dominance across all domains, including military, economic, medical, and scientific spheres. While comparable in military scale to the Manhattan Project, the geopolitical implications are far more extensive. In this scenario, there is no second-place prize; it is truly a "winner-take-all" situation. Once a truly recursive learning AI is developed, there will be no opportunity for others to catch up.

The potential danger for the world lies in this very fact. If I were China, recognizing that I was losing this race due to a lack of the necessary hardware technology to produce the winning chips, what actions would I take? Have you ever witnessed a chess match where one player, facing a certain defeat, realizes there is no way to counter their opponent's moves? It is not uncommon for the losing player to disrupt the game, denying their opponent their rightful victory. China will likely adopt a similar strategy with TSMC. Neutralizing TSMC would be preferable to allowing the United States to secure an uncontested victory. If I were China, this is the course I would pursue. I predict this is how events will unfold.

I will now review the remainder of your video to ascertain whether you considered my suggestions, particularly while you were discussing Universal Basic Income (UBI) and a technological utopia.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-03T19:06:29Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-03T19:06:29Z"}, {"author": "@WeeklyTubeShow2", "text": "I spammed Claude and ChatGPT into creating an information-cascade early-warning system.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-08-03T19:00:47Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-03T19:00:47Z"}, {"author": "@AbdullahMubashir-Live", "text": "The assumption that any other country then (America) is net negative is more naive than most think.
