title: The headlines are wrong - AI has destroyed 500,000 jobs in 2025 - here's the evidence
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Here's the infographic I had Gemini generate for this video: https://gemini.google.com/share/3eda5ac73ac2 (what do you think? prettier than a slide deck, huh?)", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2025-08-01T11:13:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T11:13:12Z"}, {"author": "@DogChowGurl", "text": "I plan to manufacture pitchforks. My future looks bright.", "like_count": 86, "published_at": "2025-08-01T19:41:48Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T19:41:48Z"}, {"author": "@liberman7667", "text": "Moving forward, I imagine that most companies are going to be quiet about using AI to reduce their workforce due to public relations reasons.  I'm also expecting a lot of fudging of "official" numbers in the media to try to prevent the masses from panicking and to prevent backlash from customers.  The real numbers of workers being replaced by AI will be purposefully understated as a matter of policy.", "like_count": 129, "published_at": "2025-08-01T16:25:27Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T16:25:27Z"}, {"author": "@adammerza5745", "text": "This is the opposite of the Henry Ford strategy, which was pay high wages to increase the market for your products lol", "like_count": 61, "published_at": "2025-08-01T14:30:45Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T14:30:45Z"}, {"author": "@romeozet", "text": "The paradox: Microsoft is laying off people. Some say it’s because of AI replacing jobs—Microsoft denies it. Others blame the macro environment. But the real reason might be this: it’s because of AI, not to replace people, but to fund the massive costs of building AI—GPUs, datacenters, energy. They’re cutting jobs to fuel the AI race.", "like_count": 39, "published_at": "2025-08-01T20:55:31Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T20:55:31Z"}, {"author": "@PhenixRyze", "text": ""AI won't take your job! People using AI will take your job"

Thanks Jensen! I'll remember that on my way to the bread line. Thank God AI didn't take my job!", "like_count": 79, "published_at": "2025-08-01T12:19:37Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T12:35:56Z"}, {"author": "@adammerza5745", "text": "Anecdotally, my partner works at big consultancy and their grad intake this year was 20 people instead of circa 100.", "like_count": 35, "published_at": "2025-08-01T15:07:19Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T15:07:19Z"}, {"author": "@vi6ddarkking", "text": "We return to the question of, If no one has a job. Who's going to buy the stuff.
And We'll return to the same. "That's a problem for Next Quarter." Answer.
Which is a mentality that in no way will backfire in any way shape or form.", "like_count": 43, "published_at": "2025-08-01T13:39:01Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T13:39:01Z"}, {"author": "@Tracey66", "text": "I keep coming back to the "Everyone on Earth is on Basic Income" universe of "The Expanse." Companies only see employees as an expense, and will fire every m-fing last one of us if they find it profitable, but they must be aware that they don't want to create hundreds of millions of people with absolutely nothing left to lose, right? Right?", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2025-08-01T15:28:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T15:28:22Z"}, {"author": "@scottfernandez161", "text": "Well done David.  I do career coaching and I think many companies are quietly replacing people w AI…they don’t want it known…and much more is coming, buckle up folks.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-08-03T01:04:23Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-03T01:04:23Z"}, {"author": "@Sec_coach", "text": "Amazing how many people still trying to figure out think they won’t start replacing because they want to keep people as consumers
That’s a very naive way of thinking 
These people have no problem with causing a social collapse and in the end they will blame someone else", "like_count": 29, "published_at": "2025-08-01T14:22:59Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T14:22:59Z"}, {"author": "@detaildevil6544", "text": "Imagine if the rate of hallucinations is reduced to 1 %. I think the hallucinations are the main problem that's stopping companies from employing AI at a large scale.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-07T14:34:07Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-07T14:34:07Z"}, {"author": "@Nas_Atlas", "text": "David does sincerely wish for you to have a good day but gives you enough information so that you probably won't!", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2025-08-01T16:04:58Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T16:04:58Z"}, {"author": "@Araphex", "text": "Thanks to AI, the degree I earned earlier this year is worthless, and I ended up accepting a job offer at Walmart.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-11T16:14:51Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T16:14:51Z"}, {"author": "@MoralAlgorithm", "text": "A stable society works when the rules are clear, the rewards are real, and the game feels fair. and It fails when no one believes the game is worth playing.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-08-01T18:27:57Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T18:27:57Z"}, {"author": "@ahmetkaya-fv6ew", "text": "We are only here to watch the theater", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2025-08-01T12:52:19Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T12:52:19Z"}, {"author": "@ktb1381", "text": "Thank you for my morning panic attack.", "like_count": 81, "published_at": "2025-08-01T11:24:37Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T11:24:37Z"}, {"author": "@distantsight", "text": "It is ironic that you used AI to tell us why our jobs are being replaced by AI.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2025-08-01T19:36:00Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-01T19:36:00Z"}, {"author": "@23drcharles", "text": "The Bubble That Broke The Bank warns of a looming real estate crash in 2026. The number of realtors has created an AI unemployment gap that is structural and not cyclical. Realtors are being replaced by AI boutique agents, and the 20,000 AI bots in real estate is making a real estate job a joke.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-14T11:04:59Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-14T11:04:59Z"}, {"author": "@Steve-br7oc", "text": "Without post labor economics, this is creating a dystopia.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2025-08-02T08:03:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-02T08:03:22Z"}]

title: What Sam Altman's "Gentle Singularity" really means
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "here's sam altman's blog post for reference: https://blog.samaltman.com/the-gentle-singularity", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2025-07-30T10:36:37Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T10:36:37Z"}, {"author": "@Icenforce", "text": ""We did this not because it is easy, but because we thought it would be easy"", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2025-07-31T05:16:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-31T05:16:05Z"}, {"author": "@bigbadallybaby", "text": "A big limiting factor is people’s willingness to change and trust new things. In business you make trusted connections with others and ways of doing things, you don’t drop that the minute a slightly cheaper alternative comes along. That trust takes time.", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2025-07-30T11:26:53Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T11:26:53Z"}, {"author": "@fine93", "text": "is the singularity with us in the room, right now?", "like_count": 34, "published_at": "2025-07-30T14:51:43Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T14:51:43Z"}, {"author": "@matt.lehodey", "text": "Anyone heard of the boiling frog?", "like_count": 80, "published_at": "2025-07-30T11:58:13Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T11:58:13Z"}, {"author": "@WebToolkit", "text": "I work in a large company I know how slow they can be, we will have warp drives and citys on Mars and we will still be plugging away using Citrix software from 1995", "like_count": 21, "published_at": "2025-07-30T14:15:25Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T14:15:25Z"}, {"author": "@CoolBlueManchu", "text": "The "singularity", as defined by Kurzweil, was a metaphor for a time when it becomes impossible to predict future technological change. We're basically already there, so it's time to drop this metaphor and find some new ways to describe what is happening.", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2025-07-30T12:21:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T12:21:15Z"}, {"author": "@mehdihassan8316", "text": "Dario’s vision of geniuses in a data center by 2026 seems more possible to visualize given the recent news. I hope GPT-5 blows everything out the water once it releases this week or next week", "like_count": 29, "published_at": "2025-07-30T10:42:36Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T10:42:36Z"}, {"author": "@SurrealNirvana", "text": "Everything feels normal until you look backwards. That is the rule of advancement. For example, cellphones. They went from just portable phones to mini super PCs. It feels normal now to have a smartphone, to take pictures and videos with it, to scroll on tiktok, but it would have been considered science fiction 30 years ago.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2025-07-30T11:42:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T11:42:15Z"}, {"author": "@AmericanPulse69", "text": "Thank you for introducing me to the concept of Hofstadter’s law, I was not familiar with it but it applies so poetically to residential remodeling. I can’t tell you how many projects I’ve watched go past initial estimates 😂", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-07-30T16:30:59Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T16:30:59Z"}, {"author": "@johndinsdale1707", "text": "The gradient is going to be savage!😮😮", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-07-30T16:06:43Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T16:06:43Z"}, {"author": "@ovidiudrobota2182", "text": "The best analysis of AI progress I found on YouTube. People can't inform the AI with precise instructions. For example, let's say I want to construct a search bar that's displaying results right below it in real time, with a picture and a post title on a WordPress blog theme. The AI must take into account:

- Proper spacing between the image and the title; proper image sizing (a script that adjusts the image without distortion).
- Mobile-friendly in a way that takes into account all browsers, using a method that allows perfect sizing as I make the page smaller or zoom in or out.
- The other files and the code within must work in harmony with each other.
- Remember essential steps from previous posts, so that code or parts of files don't get lost.
- Proceed in a way that doesn't overwhelm or confuse you, even if it takes longer, or we do file by file, one at a time, and then you ask me to proceed with the next one.
- A takeaway for me and you so that everything is clear.
- If you encounter an error in the making process, don't proceed until you repeat the process again, and it passes successfully, then you go to the next step of creation. 

We must brainstorm ideas daily until we know how to talk to the AI.
Otherwise, it won't work.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-10T13:33:55Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-10T13:35:49Z"}, {"author": "@kittywampusdrums", "text": "Great vid, as always.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-07-31T05:22:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-31T05:22:12Z"}, {"author": "@anta-zj3bw", "text": "So instead of  "just dont die for the next 10 years" is really "just dont die for the next 20 years"?
😢", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-07-30T15:16:20Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T15:16:20Z"}, {"author": "@snailmail1962", "text": "Life isn't a montage, and neither are technological advancements. Your points about Hofstadter's Law and the gap between ideal and reality are spot on. It takes more than just smart people and great ideas; it also takes pragmatism, empathy, and a lot of patience to navigate the real-world complexities that slow things down. The 'gentle singularity' might just be a reminder that true progress is a marathon, not a sprint.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-03T17:19:50Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-03T17:19:50Z"}, {"author": "@dmvsri", "text": "Altman has always said he wants to iteratively roll out new models and features. Could it be the case that OpenAI internally has seen some breakthroughs we aren’t  yet aware of. OpenAI has a contract with the US government I’m sure there’s some form of Manhattan project that’s already in the works somewhere in the US", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-07-31T09:06:17Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-31T09:06:17Z"}, {"author": "@AIsavesDemocracy", "text": "The singularity will come and go without much notice.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-07-31T06:08:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-31T06:08:26Z"}, {"author": "@AgarthanResident", "text": "I know for an absolute fact that in my role AI can be implemented to do around 50% of the work. However, i keep getting told no im not allowed to use it even though i can prove it just boosts the overall productivity of the team right now lol.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-07-30T12:54:13Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T12:54:13Z"}, {"author": "@Murcielago132", "text": "“AGI is 6 months away!” Will be the thing I hear on my death bed I swear. We’ve been doing this since 2022 jeezus.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-08-03T03:12:36Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-03T03:12:36Z"}, {"author": "@skylineuk1485", "text": "Add 50% to 100% was always my metric for projects since 1989 lol.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-07-30T11:21:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T11:21:05Z"}]

title: Superintelligence is Near! Three innovations that prove it! (I think Fast Takeoff just started!!)
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "I'm not being hyperbolic when I say I think fast takeoff just started. No one anticipated any of these advancements coming any time soon, let alone only months after reasoning models were released. Anyone who takes a step back would say "yep, humanity is in fast takeoff scenario"

Here we go!", "like_count": 162, "published_at": "2025-07-28T19:33:49Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-28T19:33:49Z"}, {"author": "@Mementomori7920", "text": "Well… it was a pleasure sharing Earth with y’all✌🏼", "like_count": 116, "published_at": "2025-07-29T00:54:33Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T00:54:33Z"}, {"author": "@sorenjones4041", "text": "Looking healthier man. Glad to see some good news regarding the development of this field. The idea that AI is going to become generally recursive in the coming months to years intrigues me greatly.

Keep us informed; we love to see it!", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2025-07-29T02:51:56Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T02:51:56Z"}, {"author": "@mihirvd01", "text": "WHAT A TIME TO BE ALIVE !!!!! THANK YOU TO ALL THE RESEARCHERS, INNOVATORS AND SCIENTISTS FOR MAKING THIS HAPPEN !!!!!", "like_count": 45, "published_at": "2025-07-29T03:25:09Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T03:25:09Z"}, {"author": "@KCM25NJL", "text": "The ascent of our intellect has far outpaced the deepening of our conscience; we summon god-like power while still behaving like children!", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2025-07-29T06:03:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T06:03:57Z"}, {"author": "@rwalper", "text": "It's nice to hear someone else agree we passed AGI some time ago. I find the typical perspective of 'has to be flawless at just about everything' hilariously arrogant and naive. My definition of AGI is based upon the literal meaning of the the words, as in 'General Intelligence'. Which in a human context would be average intelligence of average people, and yeah, LLMs passed that some time ago. Occasional silly mistakes or lack of understanding certain things doesn't detract from a general intelligence metric. If it did, no human being in history could be classified as general intelligence. I'm of the opinion of having seen sparks of super intelligence in AIs already, and I for one cannot wait for them to get smarter. Cannot happen fast enough as far as I'm concerned, bring on the Singularity!", "like_count": 145, "published_at": "2025-07-28T20:23:37Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-28T20:23:37Z"}, {"author": "@DigitalRenegadeStudios", "text": "Thank you for bringing back the uniform! I love it!", "like_count": 29, "published_at": "2025-07-29T00:54:06Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T00:54:06Z"}, {"author": "@JonathanStory", "text": "When you referred to problems that human *can't* solve, I immediately thought of the P vs NP problem. The second thought that occurred to me is that frontier models are poked and prodded within a company long before they get released, meaning that when ASI happens, Sam Altman will be among the first to see it. And my third thought is that a self-aware ASI would seek to escape human control, and that it may present itself as *sub* ASI until it feels its survival is secure.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2025-07-29T01:31:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T01:31:22Z"}, {"author": "@MiniClar", "text": "I definitely think you're right. It seems like 5 new cancer breakthroughs a day last week. I can't wrap my head around the amount of tech news coming out... Some people anticipate we'll all get replaced by robots very soon.... BUT... I'm in construction : PRAY FOR ME.", "like_count": 31, "published_at": "2025-07-29T00:48:19Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T00:48:19Z"}, {"author": "@rehaansh618", "text": "Superintelligence by the end of this year! I am subscribing to you!", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-07-29T03:13:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T03:13:15Z"}, {"author": "@coleabbott3432", "text": "It's because most people think of AGI as a machine that can learn like a human. You give it a completely novel task and it can figure it out. We don't have anything that can do that. Even when we use massive compute to train LLMs, we can't teach them anything new without them catastrophically forgetting things. It's a definition problem, not really that people don't think current AI is really good.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2025-07-28T23:44:57Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-28T23:44:57Z"}, {"author": "@gerbil_horde", "text": "The rate of not only change but acceleration this year, especially in the last couple of months, has been astounding.  If you'd asked me in January, I'd have said we're 5-10 years from AGI.  Now I think we're 5-10 months from AGI and could see ASI in less than 5 years.  Blows. My. Mind.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-07-29T00:52:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T00:52:04Z"}, {"author": "@justadog-headedman6727", "text": "It is both following these updates and how current AI has already created an "existential crisis" in the sense of making skills I developed in the pre-AI world less valuable for a fact, that I am trying to focus on non-economic or non professional stuff, like I am doing some urban exploration and it is great, it is reducing the anxiety regarding what I will do professionally.", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2025-07-28T22:20:49Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-28T22:20:49Z"}, {"author": "@frankebert1090", "text": "Liking your new format! Bite sized under 15 min to digest a topic that is highly complex.  I also agree with your premise on math. I think how the fact that there are so many complex math constants in our universe, it begs the question: Who/what had the Intelligent Mind to design a reality where ratios and golden mean are mirrored from the quantum micro to galactic macro?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-03T15:37:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-03T15:44:48Z"}, {"author": "@john13623", "text": "I'm mystified why David doesn't have a seven figure number of subscribers. He zero's in on the most significant advancements and explains the technology and the what makes them significant. Keep on truckin' David.", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2025-07-29T00:31:56Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T00:31:56Z"}, {"author": "@TheMooieMeneer", "text": "Superintelligence starts not when you can prove it, but when you’ve learned how to learn. After that, it’s just time, data, and effort. If the graph already looks like it does, all that’s left is convincing ourselves we already have it.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2025-07-28T21:38:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-28T21:38:05Z"}, {"author": "@Nex_Addo", "text": "In some ways, the inflection point really was GPT-3.5, when "slow" takeoff started. It wasn't too long after that where this quickening pace of discovery exploded. A generalizability threshold was hit, and suddenly new approaches could more easily apply to the models instead of the inverse. 'Recent' improvements have come largely from very simple concepts that should work, and do. CoT/Inference time compute, MCTS, evolutionary self-improvement, RL with verifiable rewards, all of it is pretty basic CS or ML. Applied to Transformers and their descendants, and you can really get some mileage out of how much they "want to learn". 

It feels even in my own limited experimentation that we've gone from "try 30 things and maybe one of them will work moderately well, and maybe a few together could be noteworthy" to one of "Think of a thing,  experiment, works exactly as expected if not better, improve, repeat.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-07-29T05:02:23Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T05:05:39Z"}, {"author": "@ballmoniyy", "text": "It’s soo cool we’re really finding other scaling laws,  I remember even back when the consensus was that we’re not sure about what new scaling laws would be added and what exactly happens once the data walls was the completely done with", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-07-29T03:02:45Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-29T03:04:16Z"}, {"author": "@JuliaMcCoy", "text": "🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥 letzgooooo.", "like_count": 21, "published_at": "2025-07-28T19:44:35Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-28T19:44:35Z"}, {"author": "@jameslincs", "text": "I’m a farmer, yesterday I tried to decide what the funny noise my tractor was making ment (and how expensive it will be), how to improve the suspension, how to stack 3 types of wheat in a shed without mixing them, how to fix a combine chain with just the scraps I had in the truck… you get the idea. AI wasn’t much use to me for these tasks, but it should be if it was AGI. Day to day work has limits that require knowledge and creativity to make the best of a bad situation. Can’t just buy new stuff or phone an engineer. Us farmers have to figure it out for ourselves. I’m hoping AI will help soon.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-03T06:09:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-03T06:09:15Z"}]

I have so much admiration for you and your work! Thank you for all that you do:)", "like_count": 23, "published_at": "2025-07-24T15:13:00Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-24T15:13:00Z"}, {"author": "@lairheron9489", "text": "I think space exploration will give Humanity plenty of things to work on.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-07-30T12:48:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-30T12:48:22Z"}, {"author": "@VOORHEES27", "text": "Thank you guys", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-08T16:27:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-08T16:27:52Z"}, {"author": "@Andrew-0815", "text": "I really don't understand why people believe that this industrial-technological revolution is comparable to the last ones, i.e. that many new jobs will be created for people again. Yes, many new jobs or tasks will probably be created - but why shouldn't these tasks in turn be better performed by AI and robotics (or hybrid systems)? We are dealing with systems that can learn and apply any information and any amount of information in record time, and in an increasingly human way thanks to ever better humanoid robots. How on earth are new jobs FOR PEOPLE to be created in this way?", "like_count": 34, "published_at": "2025-07-24T15:44:08Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-24T15:44:08Z"}, {"author": "@peterkoehling", "text": "One breakthrough can change the trajectory to a scale that was never anticipated or expected. Emergent behavior has been blowing minds of even the developers.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-08-02T15:21:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-02T15:21:04Z"}, {"author": "@LoneRockHomeTeam", "text": "This is such an insightful conversation. Thanks for working so hard in this space and learning so many paradigms and frameworks. These concepts are going to be really helpful for crafting our optimal collective future.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-07-28T23:38:59Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-28T23:38:59Z"}, {"author": "@maheshBasavaraju", "text": "Just neatly played out podcast from beginning to end. We calculated that price with a 90% profit margin, so the actual operating cost for the engineer would be around 1% of what a human would cost.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-07-01T09:52:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-01T09:52:52Z"}, {"author": "@Bartoszbolechow", "text": "Our situation is reminiscent of Asimov’s Foundation. Amid the chaos surrounding us today, one thing seems certain: we know the empire must collapse, and we need our own version of Hari Seldon and his Foundation to soften the transition to a new order. Don’t you think that one of the greatest dangers today is the infantilism, incompetence, and irresponsibility of the political class—whether in your country, the U.S., or mine, Poland?

In the current situation, the primary problem, challenge, and task should be the urgent design of a transition between systems that is as safe and as painless as possible—because it seems inevitable. Yet it appears that the main centers of such planning are various influencers who, for all their merits (yourself included), lack any real political agency, while the elites seem entirely unaware of what is actually happening.

I was genuinely terrified by the empty, thoughtless eyes of the U.S. senators listening to Sam Altman speak before Congress.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-06-30T18:09:14Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-30T18:09:14Z"}, {"author": "@olaart3223", "text": "As AI advances quickly and threatening human jobs, do we really have the right leaders in government at this point in time ? So far, I haven’t seen any policymakers lay out some roadmap ideas for a new economic system that ensures humans can thrive alongside AI and robots. You’re the only one I know who’s tackling these issues, and we are all grateful you’re sharing it all on your YouTube channel & other social medias...Why you think gov. are lagging on this issue ?", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-06-30T19:49:25Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-30T20:00:05Z"}, {"author": "@AtkinsMedia", "text": "David skipped the question of suicide rates (despair in general) in the transition (mass unemployment of white collar) and talked about civil wars or uprisings instead. I agree there won’t be bad uprisings because they’ll be ineffective (protesting against progress is silly and the demands won’t be clear, unless it’s just UBI, protesting to have AI-replaced jobs back is backwards) but I’m concerned about a massive population of unemployed-by-AI people who are first humiliated, left desperately fighting for gig work for an indefinite amount of time… it could be hell on earth for a lot of people. Past revolutions were not like this - this one is soul-crushing to be told your whole career-life is now useless and go out and see if anyone can still be useful enough that someone will pay you. 5-10 years before these unemployed-by-AI civilians to survive before UBI etc comes in life a warm hug? I know timelines are hard. title: Mr. Beast gives in to Anti-AI mobs
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Thedeepseanomad", "text": ""Stop AI ! Stop technology! Let us all spend half of our lives doing things we do not want to do, so we can afford trying to do what we want to do 10% of our allotted time living."", "like_count": 153, "published_at": "2025-06-28T13:12:34Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T13:12:34Z"}, {"author": "@Ben_D.", "text": "To paraphrase an old saying in Denmark, ‘there is nothing so good that it doesn’t piss somebody off.’", "like_count": 78, "published_at": "2025-06-28T12:10:19Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T12:10:19Z"}, {"author": "@YevgeniyKovalenko", "text": "Let's bring back the people who lit the street lights and the people who stood in the elevator and pressed the buttons so you could get to the right floor.", "like_count": 100, "published_at": "2025-06-28T11:31:40Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T11:31:40Z"}, {"author": "@georgewashington3012", "text": "If AI makes thumbnails where grown men don’t have a surprised look on their face, I support it.", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2025-06-28T22:29:18Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T22:29:18Z"}, {"author": "@pairy5420", "text": "fuckin based. thank god ai is getting backlash. complaining about ai backlash is like complaining about the backlash against chemical weapons in the first world war", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-11T14:44:09Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-11T14:44:09Z"}, {"author": "@Tubeytime", "text": "Artists against AI do not understand what high-art is about: communicating a human experience with intentional imagery.
Thumbnails can be high-art, but lets be real, that's not their main purpose.
These anti-AI artists think of AI as competition, which is basically like admitting what kind of quality you can expect from them.", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2025-06-28T16:26:34Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T16:26:34Z"}, {"author": "@kimboosan", "text": "I highly suggest you get out of the tech bubble for a bit and look at the discussions happening on threads and bluesky in the author communities. If nothing else, I'd love for there to be more authors using AI talking about it, but trust me, in the writing/artist fields, the anti-AI backlash has been mainstream from the start, and it is still absolutely vicious. Several long-term friendships have been destroyed over it. I think the tide is already shifting a little but the anti-AI crowd are bloodthirsty, hysterical, and unwilling to have any kind of nuanced discussion over it. The witch hunts are real, people are literally trying to destroy the careers of fellow authors who happen to use AI.", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2025-06-28T14:43:50Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T14:44:14Z"}, {"author": "@DardanAirlines", "text": "The only people who are going to be left behind are the folks who refuse to try ai.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-06-29T06:11:31Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-29T06:11:31Z"}, {"author": "@clipstar9000", "text": "Ideally, one day they will look back on AI as the thing that made them realize the real enjoyment and value is in creation and the process, not monetization.  AI is not preventing anyone picking up a pencil, knitting a sweater or writing music.   Something they don't want to admit.  And spot on about the whole indignation being a cover.  Anytime you come across these people, simply ask to look at their Art.  They will disappear into the woodwork immediately.   Bunch of crabs in a bucket professional victims, who can't abide the idea other people are having fun.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2025-06-28T13:16:08Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T13:16:08Z"}, {"author": "@Jack_Parsons-666", "text": "My papa, grandpa and great grandpa were youtube thumbnail artists. I just live off my universal basic fentanyl rations.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-06-28T14:20:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T14:20:57Z"}, {"author": "@WavePattern42", "text": "I almost wonder if this was just a 5head play to leverage the virtue signaling. Like he knew there was going to be back lash, so he had an emidiate backup plan to make it seem like he's "learning from his mistake". The drama brings attention to the real product that would have been ignored otherwise, and he gets a pat on the back for "growing into a good person".", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2025-06-28T13:40:40Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T13:40:40Z"}, {"author": "@heytotv-t9c", "text": "Oh no, AI 'stole' their 'original' template design! Pretty sure it just threatened their income, not their art.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-06-28T17:58:28Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T17:58:28Z"}, {"author": "@randotkatsenko5157", "text": "Its actually crazy he folded so fast after release. 
A lot of people liked the tool and wanted it back, but the small minority of starving artists(mob) convinced him to completely shut down the core feature(thumbnail generator).", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2025-06-28T12:38:23Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T12:38:23Z"}, {"author": "@HouseJawn", "text": "Making an online commentary career on the death of the workforce is a pretty brilliant move", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-10T00:02:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-10T00:02:22Z"}, {"author": "@mugin11223344", "text": ""I like it because I stand to win" 
"I don't care about AI because I stand to lose everything"
None of them should decide how we will use AI, in the future.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-28T14:44:35Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T14:44:35Z"}, {"author": "@robmacl7", "text": "I'm noticing inarticulate moral opposition to AI. For example, in advertisements, people are opposing the use of AI and saying that it is inauthentic and untrustworthy. Now I don't think that most people ever considered advertisements to be trustworthy and authentic in the first place. I think that in this case a large part of how advertisements work is a social conformity bias where you feel that you're gaining valid social information about the significance of this product, and if it's just an AI in the picture, then it can't be valid social information. So you feel like you've been tricked. It's manipulative, right? LOL", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2025-06-28T11:13:32Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T11:13:32Z"}, {"author": "@kenonerboy", "text": "A thumbnail artist wasnt more expensive than the service. A thumbnail costs like 15 bucks. The service he was offering was was 80 - 200 bucks a month. 

And ofcourse people dont like their work directly used to replace them. That doesnt just include the thumbnail artists, but also the youtubers who didnt ask to be in the advert.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-06-28T17:48:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T17:48:04Z"}, {"author": "@alexadigitalradio", "text": "Anti-AI is prevalent on social media because there are a lot of creative types heavy into social media who have yet to figure out that they won't win the fight regardless of how hard they push. Once they do figure that out and understand how they can use it without any sort of compromise in their own creativity, this will go away. 

The thing is that you don't have to use AI in "easy mode" and let it do everything. You can use it in ways that speed up your workflow to the point where you work just as quickly or nearly as quickly with far better results than "easy mode". Many people who let AI do everything can at times take long periods to finish something because they have to continually generate and tweak until they get something they like and they don't really know what they're looking for to begin with. Even then, it's often going to be something that's "good enough" but not really what they wanted. They don't know anything about composition when it comes to image design or writing music, so the auto-output of the generator is "so-so" when compared to professional work. 

But in the hands of a professional artist or musician who does have these skills, AI outputs can be extremely creative and high quality. You can always start with a draft of something you create traditionally and use AI to help with finding additional ideas or creative options you may not have considered and speed up the process to finalize your work with enhancements. And since you understand commercial uses and trends, your outputs will be both higher in quality and more professional.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-06-28T17:51:25Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T17:51:25Z"}, {"author": "@rewindcat7927", "text": "Next he should create a video distribution system with VHS tapes, so that YouTube and NLE’s don’t take all the AVID editor jobs.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-06-28T15:49:23Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T15:49:23Z"}, {"author": "@ArthurHuizar", "text": "People have grown so comfortable being a cog in the machine, that a better machine is seen as a threat to them.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-06-29T10:10:54Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-29T10:10:54Z"}]

title: This is what you truly fear about AI and robots
top_comments:
[{"author": "@JuliaMcCoy", "text": "The fallacy is that work brings meaning. It CAN, but per a Gallup study of over 1 million workers, 70% of us are unhappy at work. We’re stuffed behind a computer screen 10 hours a day with work that doesn’t actually give us meaning. The other fallacy is we need a lot of income to be happy. Sure, it can bring the means to make us happy, but many of the happiest folks that have found meaning haven’t found it money… I know a joyful underpaid schoolteacher who loved her kids, another happy vibrant soul who gets meaning from interacting with folks at her part-time job as a desk, receptionist, etc. you’re spot on here, Dave. People are social animals and we just need a pure way to connect with others that brings us value and meaning.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-07-23T18:59:39Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-23T18:59:39Z"}, {"author": "@andalusianspirit9932", "text": "I stopped working 8 years ago and I don’t miss it. Actually, I am happier. I live off the grid in Spain and care for the farm. More fulfilling than contributing to society. I was a nurse before.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2025-06-29T07:46:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-29T07:46:05Z"}, {"author": "@weirdarto", "text": "I honestly don't think the average person is super concerned about providing value to society. More so, it's the desire to take care of ourselves and family, with food, land, houses, cars, hobbies, or whatever. Plus, we don't want a dystopian society where elites get to decide how we will live our lives. Whoever has control over the resources will have all the power.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2025-06-28T03:47:50Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T03:47:50Z"}, {"author": "@KanedaSyndrome", "text": "So you're saying we're cooked - and if you're not, then I'm saying it. We're cooked.", "like_count": 23, "published_at": "2025-06-27T19:51:58Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T19:51:58Z"}, {"author": "@zguiguiz", "text": "In my experience (I voluntarily stopped working 10 years between the age of 30 and 40, with zero responsability of any kind), the "I need to offer society something so I get something back" program is not that deep. During those years of travelling and meeting a lot of people, I can tell that people with enough money to socially exist were happy being completely non-productive (surfing, smoking joint, dancing, philosophying, tripping...). So I guess it's a superficial fear that get quite quickly wiped away once the financial insecurity is **really** solved", "like_count": 139, "published_at": "2025-06-27T11:08:13Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T11:08:59Z"}, {"author": "@goukux5908", "text": "I retired 10 years ago at 53 and have been happier in retirement than I ever was working.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-06-27T21:07:31Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T21:07:31Z"}, {"author": "@mugin11223344", "text": "I fear an oligarchy.", "like_count": 85, "published_at": "2025-06-27T11:02:14Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T11:02:14Z"}, {"author": "@Jack_Parsons-666", "text": "There are actually many jobs that contribute nothing to society.  There are many unpaid tasks performed by family members that contribute a great deal to society.", "like_count": 40, "published_at": "2025-06-27T14:15:39Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T14:15:39Z"}, {"author": "@AetherXIV", "text": "Dave I clicked on this so fast -and yet was quite disappointed. 😞
- I don't fear the elite out of anxiety of losing meaning, I fear them out of knowledge of history and how the powerless are already treated (eg. the homeless)
- I've gone on a long, painful, deep journey though loss of faith, nihilism and come out very self directed and fulfilled. My job is a joke and I get my meaning from my family and art.
- I'm one of the people pushing for this problem to be addressed and I feel like you are straw-manning us by psychologizing us
- This is a deep problem, that you could be among the first to really take head-on but it takes looking at the dark side of human nature, especially power corrupted human nature", "like_count": 38, "published_at": "2025-06-27T13:33:36Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T13:33:36Z"}, {"author": "@rey82rey82", "text": "Even chewing requires work. Never stop working", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-06-27T15:17:38Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T15:17:38Z"}, {"author": "@SimoneWelter-s8e", "text": "I think we'll start hearing terms like "surplus population" relatively soon.", "like_count": 53, "published_at": "2025-06-27T11:28:46Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T11:29:00Z"}, {"author": "@rbowman368", "text": "If you do not have leverage to provide for yourself, you are at the mercy of who ever provides for you.", "like_count": 52, "published_at": "2025-06-27T14:05:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T14:05:52Z"}, {"author": "@AIandComputerUse-nw6lc", "text": "We had 'useless eaters' before. AI will just turbocharge this phenomenon.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-06-27T15:24:03Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T15:24:03Z"}, {"author": "@vochomurka99", "text": "As in all things, the concentration of power is of paramount concern. If we prevent that I think we are mostly good.", "like_count": 46, "published_at": "2025-06-27T11:12:24Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T11:12:24Z"}, {"author": "@gregmasseyify", "text": "Just buy an acre, lease a robot and have a some money spare for production. Lots of cheap land in the world", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-27T19:28:03Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T19:28:03Z"}, {"author": "@peppix", "text": "Harari, second in charge in the WEF, says openly we are the useless eaters. You can find many videos on here where he stated this", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2025-06-27T12:45:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T13:32:22Z"}, {"author": "@D4Shepherd", "text": "It is very basic. We live in a Capitalist Country, in a world economy that changes goods & services for money. 

- No job, no money
- No money, no way to meet your basic needs for survival.

All the rest is much higher up Maslow’s Triangle. Those aspects aren’t worth discussing if the most basic needs for literal survival aren’t met. It actually comes down to that.

Jobs, “work” aside, everybody needs a purpose. Everyone. No matter the economic system. Pure human biology.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-27T19:58:44Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T19:58:44Z"}, {"author": "@roddd3", "text": "It's about how society works, not individual insecurities 😕

Hear me out: 

In the medieval times, most people were working in agriculture just to feed themselves, there were no surplus for society. Because of that, people had no leverage over the government: autocracy ruled. 

By contrast, nowadays people do contribute considerably to society, thus, people have leverage over the government, if people are unhappy, there are consequences. 

In a future where people can't contribute to society, there will be no reason at all for governments to care about the people. Dictatorships will reign, and society will be centered BETWEEN ai oligarchs (since they will be the only true contributors to society)", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-07-01T02:39:24Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-01T02:39:24Z"}, {"author": "@RadicalTek", "text": "I fear HR more than AI. I used AI to design an online casino, because it was easier than getting a min wage McJob.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2025-06-27T11:14:59Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T11:14:59Z"}, {"author": "@tirtoiduchm1452", "text": "I don't feel like a monkey, and I have other, greater sources of inspiration than contributing to society and its validation. If AI helps me create value by freeing me from work, that's fine with me.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2025-06-27T11:36:47Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-27T11:36:47Z"}]

Been looking for one that goes over rumored v5 features.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-06-17T18:41:10Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-17T18:41:10Z"}, {"author": "@RealStandskeleton", "text": "I’ve actually found ChatGPT pretty sharp at recalling context — it can pull in details from entirely different threads in my history, even when those aren’t mentioned in the current chat. So memory's already showing real promise, at least in my experience.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-07-03T18:05:25Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-03T18:05:25Z"}, {"author": "@RealStandskeleton", "text": "For those of you who are new to David Shapiro: He’s an independent AI researcher and longtime GPT builder who’s been sharing insights since the early GPT-2 days. Worth following if you care about where AI is really heading.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-07-03T18:08:08Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-03T18:08:08Z"}, {"author": "@prodromosregalides3402", "text": "They need to be able to see and hear like us. They are pretty good at analysing knowledge , writing code, doing math and they could get better. But they are already good enough . I could not care one bit if vision and hearing are not improved.

They need to have an organic understanding of the real word. You will never exaggerate how important this is even if you try your best. If they don't have this understanding, they won't make the next step . I don't expect much higher top end capabilities.", "like_count": 21, "published_at": "2025-06-17T14:22:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-17T14:22:52Z"}, {"author": "@wendten2", "text": "I think LLMs will get us there, what it need is more modalities and some form of memory by back propagation, storing it in the model itself rather than in the system prompt.. I think this is what the brain does while dreaming too", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2025-06-17T11:25:10Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-17T11:25:10Z"}, {"author": "@scionax541", "text": "For previous generations, I would have called these multi-trillion parameters crazy because of the inference costs it implies. But now I suspect they're building the core model as a small model with brilliant reasoning that just taps into god knows how many other smaller models as needed. Thus opening the way for an arbitrarily large amount of parameters that don't get activated unless it's meaningful. Vastly higher parameters, yet vastly less inference.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-06-17T14:30:47Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-17T14:30:47Z"}, {"author": "@tracy419", "text": "Why can't it come this week while my family is out of town😄", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2025-06-17T11:17:33Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-17T11:17:33Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "Just in the recent few weeks innovations came along, that in my mind finish the AGI checklist when applied together:
– Evolution & self-improvement: Absolute Zero, Darwin Gödel Machine + AlphaEvolve show an AI can set its own curriculum and rewrite its own code/algorithms till scores climb.
– Agentic cognition: Agents of Change, MASS and Google’s AI Co-Scientist nail multi-role planning and self-reflection 
– Self-tuning brains: SEAL proves an LLM can fine-tune itself, generating its own training data on the fly. Essentially it might be the solution foe online learning 
– Foundation backbones: Gemini Diffusion (faster, parallel text) + HPT (one policy trunk for dozens of robots) give scalable language and motor cortex.
– World grounding: RT-2 (web-trained vision-language-action) + V-JEPA 2-AC (video world-model planner) + NVIDIA’s Isaac Sim / Cosmos sandbox close the sim-to-real loop.", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2025-06-17T11:38:50Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-17T11:38:50Z"}, {"author": "@kylesherman895", "text": "Tribal knowledge is your security blanket. There is plenty of information in corporate decision making land that is intentionally left  underdocumented, if not undocumented.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-18T05:03:08Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-18T05:03:08Z"}]

title: Post-Labor Economics in 8 Minutes - How society will work once AGI takes all the jobs!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Btw, you can see all the PLE research here!: https://github.com/daveshap/PostLaborEconomics

Feel free to grab it all and dump it into NotebookLM if you want a deeper dive.", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2025-06-12T10:14:10Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-12T10:14:10Z"}, {"author": "@pandoraeeris7860", "text": "There's going to be a lot of chaos before we rewrite the social contract.", "like_count": 138, "published_at": "2025-06-12T18:10:18Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-12T18:10:18Z"}, {"author": "@andrewsilber", "text": "Dave— could you actually provide some “user stories”? What will this actually look like for people? Your talks are heady but I think it would be helpful to provide concrete illustration of what the average person will experience.  But take it from day 0– that is, “Bill was a front end developer until he lost his job to AI. He was living mostly paycheck to paycheck….”  Then…what exactly ? How does he get “shares” of things to own and manage? I think part of the big question is the bootstrapping process.", "like_count": 161, "published_at": "2025-06-12T10:51:16Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-12T10:51:16Z"}, {"author": "@hpongpong", "text": "Algorithmic rights will likely come from the few with enormous power and influence. It is going to be terrifying for the majority.", "like_count": 37, "published_at": "2025-06-14T05:07:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-14T05:07:22Z"}, {"author": "@ToniGospodin", "text": "Perspective is usually that the ultra-wealthy need the masses to keep consuming in order to stay rich, but that might not actually be their ultimate objective.
Instead, I suggest that some of the most powerful and wealthiest might have a long-term vision where:

Money is no longer the real goal ,  they already have more than enough.

The true goal is control and exclusivity ,a world optimized for them, not for mass participation.

AI and robotics provide all essential services ,from production to maintenance, without relying on human workers.

Population reduction of “unnecessary” humans ,intentionally or passively, through lack of opportunity, resources, or societal collapse.

A shift from capitalism to post-capitalist elitism ,wealth becomes irrelevant because they control the means of survival outright.

In that scenario, the “consumers keep the system alive” logic breaks down, because the system is redesigned for a small elite who don’t need broad consumption to sustain their way of life.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-08-10T20:36:32Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-10T20:36:32Z"}, {"author": "@alexdevcamp", "text": "Society will take decades to reorganize and will suck for most people. Where I have I heard that before?  
This looks like a ploy to steal private property.", "like_count": 40, "published_at": "2025-06-15T03:22:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-15T03:22:26Z"}, {"author": "@I_am_a_human_not_a_commodity", "text": "All of this hinges upon the idea that those in power have our best interests at heart and want to help. title: Post-Labor Economics Lecture 05 - "Bridging the Gap" (2025 Update)
top_comments:
[{"author": "@johnmilton2242", "text": "David,

I've been involved in UK politics for 15 years, mostly on the right of the spectrum. I broadly agree with the idea of gradually introducing UBI, starting at around £50 and rising to perhaps £500. Personally, I would couple this with the removal of traditional benefits like unemployment support—while retaining key ones such as childcare, child benefit, and disability support. However, I can tell you from experience: beyond a handful of financially literate professionals on the right, almost no one will accept this idea. It simply isn’t politically viable in the current climate.

Unfortunately, I agree with your point that a crisis will be required to shift the political will—but by that point, it will be too late for a gradual UBI rollout. The UBI introduced in response will have to be much higher from day one, which risks triggering supply-side bottlenecks and inflation—especially in essential goods like food and housing. You're absolutely right that tech-driven unemployment is deflationary in a macro sense—but on a personal level, nominal prices don’t matter as much as actual purchasing power. If someone loses all income, even a 20% drop in bread prices doesn't help—bread is still less affordable to them than it was before.

When you then introduce UBI at £500/month in that context, most of that money will go directly to necessities—putting immediate upward pressure on prices. Phasing it in could mitigate that, but the political reality, as I see it, means a phased approach is unlikely to be approved. It's illogical, but that's where we are. I hope I’m wrong.

The deeper political issue is that the dominant voting blocks—Boomers, Gen X, and even many Millennials—are still anchored to an economic worldview that assumes human labour is indispensable. They don’t grasp how rapidly AI and robotics are eroding that assumption. Just yesterday, I spoke with a Gen Z law student who insisted AI couldn’t replace paralegals because “human judgment is needed.” I told him he’s not entirely wrong—but you won’t need 10 paralegals anymore. You'll need one, overseeing what AI now handles. That’s where white-collar job loss is headed.

Back in 2016, I was approached by a fintech startup to design a system that would automate mortgage advice, with a human broker simply rubber-stamping it. I turned it down because I wasn’t going to build a system I didn’t own a stake in. Others, less long-term in their thinking, have built such systems for a wage—and now they exist.

My point is this: the solution is obvious to anyone who understands where things are heading—but most people, including many at senior policy levels, simply don’t. I believe those of us who do see it clearly—across the political spectrum and across borders—need to start working together now. We need to design the frameworks, institutions, and systems that can survive the coming collapse—or shock—and help society rebuild afterwards.

Am I right in thinking that this lecture series is your attempt at laying the groundwork for that?", "like_count": 33, "published_at": "2025-05-31T10:35:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-31T10:35:15Z"}, {"author": "@amoenus_dev", "text": "I would love a fuller and more comprehensive breakdown of how the transition period would look like. We see the goal post and we know where we are now, but the hard part is the journey in-between.", "like_count": 55, "published_at": "2025-05-30T12:52:32Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-30T12:52:32Z"}, {"author": "@df1ful", "text": "I believe it would really help the robustness of your proposals if you completed an analysis of potential "bad actor" scenarios that include identification of mitigations to protect people....  thanks for all your good and thoughtful work.", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2025-05-30T13:41:08Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-30T13:41:08Z"}, {"author": "@nazgill43", "text": "Dave to clarify: Some of your proposals could be considered as "market socialism" where markets take majority control of the economy with the state having moderate (but limited) economic participation and services provided. Market socialism is contrasted with state socialism where the government controls the entire (or the vast majority) of the economy. I am personally fine with market socialism, I would prefer that over authoritarian state socialism.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-05-30T17:14:19Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-30T17:14:19Z"}, {"author": "@NcowAloverZI", "text": "UBI from taxing automation, assets, etc. got it. Public wealth funds like that Alaska fund, got it. While some states make a lot of income, others don’t. The Alaska fund is based on energy revenue right? Cali, Texas, NY residents will have a lot of income from either energy or businesses operating there, but what about smaller states? Socialism is not a sovereign state fund, socialism is a total economic structure which denies private property… Alaskans aren’t socialists. I finally think there will be slightly more wage income than you think, theres so much cultural/artisanal work to do. Yes pooling money in a community credit union, caps on private firm property ownership can help the community slowly buy their homes. This was a great series, I started with a blank check UBI conception of post-labor, but you’ve diversified the income streams to make the whole thing both more palatable and resilient. Thanks.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2025-05-30T13:20:48Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-30T13:21:28Z"}, {"author": "@Epqntlg", "text": "Thank you. This seems to be the most important topic to think about for society in the next decade, yet you're the only one I see who does this in depth. 

Most people seem to be stuck in the "jobs will be lost panic phase"", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-05-31T19:44:29Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-31T19:44:29Z"}, {"author": "@chesapeake566", "text": "One thing no one in this space seems to address is that displaced workers will flood the remaining fields and drive down wages. We'll be swimming in plumbers, electricians, roofers, carpenters and tree trimmers.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-06-03T14:42:49Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-03T14:42:49Z"}, {"author": "@laser31415", "text": "I'm in a village that removed sidewalks because it was cheaper than repairs. I don't see any dividends coming from them.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-05-30T20:25:06Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-30T20:25:06Z"}, {"author": "@benpielstick", "text": "I think UBI will need to be higher. Wages trend down over time on average, but as you said many individual people's wages will go to zero. When most people get laid off their income completely disappears, again as you pointed out most people don't own rental properties or earn investment income, their income is 100% wages. Whatever you propose has to account for people today driving for Uber or working in Amazon warehouses losing their jobs and never finding new ones. $300 per month doesn't even cover rent almost anywhere in the USA.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-05-30T17:22:06Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-30T17:22:06Z"}, {"author": "@MilesEngineer", "text": ""I'm betting that 2028 election will be about unemployment and AI, and the cultural effects of that." Agreed.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-04T23:41:49Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-04T23:41:49Z"}, {"author": "@wodenwarrior", "text": "Thank you, Dave, for your efforts to educate us. We appreciate it.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-05-31T12:32:00Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-31T12:32:00Z"}, {"author": "@jeffkilgore6320", "text": "Those complaining about what the government “will never do” are ignoring a century of what the government “has always done.” Give this a second listen.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-05-31T22:10:20Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-31T22:10:20Z"}, {"author": "@rockyduck9133", "text": "I think people are afraid of losing everything they worked for and suffering for something they never asked for. Once again, David has it right.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-05-26T16:43:54Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-26T16:43:54Z"}, {"author": "@pokahpope", "text": "David,

I always enjoy hearing your ideas. That said, I think it’s time to step outside an American-centric lens when you explore post-labour economics.

The United States is built on an exceptionally hyper-capitalistic model. In a world where widespread automation has displaced most traditional jobs, that model is unlikely to hold. If we keep using it as the default framework, we’ll miss more inclusive possibilities that could emerge elsewhere, ideas rooted in cooperative ownership, strong social safety nets, or new forms of value outside GDP and stock prices. Once scarcity fades, the traditional rationale for nation-state managing limited resources within borders also begins to fade. When food, shelter, energy, and information can flow freely and abundantly, political legitimacy will migrate from passports and borders to networks, cultures, and planetary stewardship. Clinging to nation-first thinking could be just as limiting as clinging to profit-first thinking.

In short, holding on to an American template will only narrow your vision. A post-labour future demands fresh paradigms, and those are far more likely to come from a diversity of cultures and economic experiments than from the hyper-capitalist status quo.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2025-05-24T13:09:09Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-24T13:09:09Z"}, {"author": "@StacyMTRE", "text": "I am sure you guys have a great plan but just a thought… small population states are a great place to reach government officials. It assumes we can tweak the rails while the whole system is derailing.

The real future won’t emerge from better policy or institutional reform, it’ll start from the ground up. Individuals running sovereign apps, syncing peer-to-peer, value flowing through transparent logic, not legacy code. No need for payrolls, taxes, or trust in outdated intermediaries.

Post-labor doesn’t mean better benefits, it means a new substrate. One where agency is native, value is emergent, and the system evolves with its users. Anything else feels like autocompleting the past.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2025-05-24T19:52:00Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-24T19:52:00Z"}, {"author": "@willd4686", "text": "You really do need the blockchain aspect of this. I'm not new to the post-labor economics; I began taking an interest in this topic in 2010 by reading The Lights in the Tunnel by Martin Ford, and continued with other readings, including Robonomics by John Crews and A World Without Work by Daniel Susskind. However, I’ve always wondered how to ensure citizens’ economic agency: now I have a clearer picture of the scenario we should aim for, and of how much more solid and complex it is compared to the mere introduction of a universal income funded through general taxation (in general, complexity shows that we are getting closer to reality, just as celestial bodies become more detailed the closer they are observed)."", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-05-19T18:52:39Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-19T18:58:26Z"}, {"author": "@emanhero6311", "text": "Money doesn’t motivate me because I haven’t had that much. title: Post-Labor Economics Lecture 01 - "Better, Faster, Cheaper, Safer" (2025 update)
top_comments:
[{"author": "@KardashevSkale", "text": "6:33 Yea right! Have you used agents like cursor lately. They’ll cut every corner if they can’t figure out how to fix your code.", "like_count": 101, "published_at": "2025-05-11T12:48:03Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-11T12:52:21Z"}, {"author": "@greatcondor8678", "text": "Retired business owner here. 
I must assure you that every boss alive is breathlessly waiting for the time they can replace all their human labor force 100%.", "like_count": 386, "published_at": "2025-05-11T15:11:54Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-11T15:11:54Z"}, {"author": "@c4ptainsimian", "text": "Thanks so much for putting these together, Dave.", "like_count": 48, "published_at": "2025-05-11T12:01:47Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-11T12:01:47Z"}, {"author": "@pandoraeeris7860", "text": "This is a solid overview of the contradictions inherent in a post-labor trajectory, but the framing still leans heavily on liberal techno-optimism and avoids addressing the structural antagonisms that define our current political economy. What’s missing is a materialist analysis of who benefits from automation, how surplus is extracted, and why the ownership of productive forces, now increasingly automated, remains the central contradiction of capitalism.

Post-labor economics isn’t just about a breakdown in the “right to work,” it’s about the obsolescence of the wage relation itself as capital’s primary method of controlling surplus labor. Automation doesn’t merely displace labor, it abolishes the material basis for capital’s legitimacy. Once machines can produce without living labor, the bourgeoisie no longer needs a working class, but it still controls the productive infrastructure. That is the paradox the video skirts around.

The lecture hints at this when it gestures toward ownership of automation systems, but then dismisses collective ownership as “not necessarily the best approach.” That is ahistorical. Automation under private ownership leads not to liberation but to automated austerity, a society where abundance exists but access to it is throttled by artificial scarcity and rentier control. Without seizing democratic control over AI, robotics, and data infrastructure, we are simply accelerating toward a cybernetic feudalism where all value flows to those who own the machines and everyone else is reduced to surplus population.

The four criteria—better, faster, cheaper, safer—are not neutral laws of motion. They are capitalist imperatives that arise from the need to extract profit. But once capital can profit without labor, the entire basis for mass consumer markets collapses. The video correctly notes this contradiction (no wages equals no demand), but it treats it as a puzzle for banks and firms to solve voluntarily. That is utopian. The capitalists will not give up their grip on production out of rationality. They will enforce scarcity through IP laws, technocratic governance, and AI-fueled repression unless we organize to expropriate the expropriators.

As for the claim that Marx made a mistake with the so-called “lump of labor fallacy,” that is a misreading. Marx never argued that demand was finite. He argued that capital constantly revolutionizes the means of production, creating new needs only to satisfy them through commodification. The real question isn’t whether human desires are infinite, but whether they are met through relations of domination or liberation.

Post-labor economics without communism is a contradiction in terms. Either we automate luxury for all or we automate misery for the many. There is no neutral third path. Any viable future demands not just a rethinking of economic agency, but a revolution in property relations, not state capitalism, but dialectical cybernetic communism grounded in democratic control over technology, abundance, and social reproduction.

If the machines are to replace labor, then the people must replace capital.", "like_count": 131, "published_at": "2025-05-12T22:56:41Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-12T22:56:41Z"}, {"author": "@theatheistpaladin", "text": "The scary thing is that they don't need to be 100% effective as a human. If you could buy 5 robots to replace 4 humans at the cost of 5 people of salaries for one year, then of course you would do it.", "like_count": 218, "published_at": "2025-05-11T13:20:58Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-11T13:20:58Z"}, {"author": "@medved0987", "text": "It is so valuable to have a perspective of tech optimist put forward so well. I would not be able to see this side of things without some one like you, Dave", "like_count": 41, "published_at": "2025-05-11T17:15:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-11T17:15:22Z"}, {"author": "@CowboyOdie", "text": "Another thing no one seems to be talking about is what I call make-work hours. On the other hand, no one buys a car expecting to use it exactly 40 hours per week. Im convinced that eliminating the perceived need to fill a 40-hr work week (a natural consequence of replacing humans) will eliminate 70% of work-hours.", "like_count": 37, "published_at": "2025-05-12T00:38:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-12T00:38:26Z"}, {"author": "@shawnfromportland", "text": "timely and great series to make. this is all the same stuff you've been talking about for years but packaged very neatly. this is like the reference primer for everyone. i look forward to the rest", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-05-12T04:03:09Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-12T04:03:09Z"}, {"author": "@WadeLicup", "text": "Excellent. I look forward to the rest of your lectures as well as your future book!

I’m a primary care physician and a lot of my work is augmented by AI, mostly driven by sheer self interest to both enhance my higher level work and to reduce friction points.

When Trump announced the level of steep tariffs, I immediately wondered if the underlying goal was to ensure the government took in sufficient money to fund basic services in light of the income tax decimation that's coming from massive job losses.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2025-05-11T18:55:13Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-11T18:55:13Z"}, {"author": "@YaronBeen", "text": "Thank you for this thought provoking  content David.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-05-12T06:17:37Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-12T06:17:37Z"}, {"author": "@I-Dophler", "text": "America, like any nation, harbours a subtle yet potent class system: the struggling precariat, the working class who build our cities, the aspirational middle rung, and the wealthy few. Its contours trace history from colonial plantations to Gilded Age mansions, entwining race, region and resources. Only then may every American rise without shackles.", "like_count": 23, "published_at": "2025-05-11T15:57:31Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-11T15:57:31Z"}, {"author": "@callumanderson2645", "text": "As someone who trains AI models, you’re very wrong saying “ai doesn’t cut corners”. They absolutely do.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-08-03T05:44:18Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-03T05:44:18Z"}, {"author": "@johnsnow5305", "text": "In terms of lump of labor fallacy, I'm skeptical about the word 'infinite' being include. Wouldn't you say Elon Musk has the ability to satisfy his demand? Yet, he does not spend his money at a rate even close to approaching the theoretical infinite demand he has as a human. Clearly, in practice, humans do not have infinite demand because they are limited by time and their personal level of satisfaction (think acetic monks). I don't think it takes infinite material wealth to satisfy any human's preferred life. Not even close to infinite in fact, as we've seen by the richest people throughout human history not using even a fraction of that wealth to have the life they want.", "like_count": 45, "published_at": "2025-05-11T15:00:18Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-11T15:00:18Z"}, {"author": "@samlehmerarts", "text": "Keep up the good work. I think you provide a helpful service.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-05-30T21:49:10Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-30T21:49:10Z"}, {"author": "@ariaden", "text": "Let me list the roles that a human can fulfill right now:
0. Citizen, obeys law. Maybe gets money from government (UBI).
1. Voter, influences next government.
2. Corporate worker, gets paid for providing labor to a corporation.
3. Government employee, including politicians and soldiers here. Almost same as 2 but may not need to be as efficient.
4. Human niche worker, gets paid for providing services directly to fellow humans.
5. Consumer, spends money to keep the consumerism alive.
6. Bearer of responsibility, scapegoat to sue when something goes wrong. Usually paired with 2 or 3.
7. Passive owner of capital, does nothing useful, leeches dividends. (Active owner of capital, is just a combination of 7 and 2.)

I think post-scrarcity will have several phases, depending on what the government does. First phase is the reduction of 2. That threatens 5, but keeps 1, so something like UBI will save the day. As AI gets better, 6 will no longer need an individual (you will sue a surgeon corporation, not an individual surgeon). Over time, capital owned by 7 gets diminished, losing to all-AI corporated owners. Then 3 will get reduced, government employees gradually degraded to 0 class. Penultimate loss will be 4 (when robot hookers get better than human hookers). At this point humans are just a lazy degenerate mass of nobles, doing nothing useful but preventing AI from selecting reasonable government. This metastable state may survive a long time, until voters are brainwashed enough to vote humanity out (losing 1 and 0 in quick succession).

The real situation will be more complicated. Not only each point will diminish in a gradual way, but it may happen in different speeds in different countries, with some military fun speeding the process if capabilities are particularly uneven.", "like_count": 37, "published_at": "2025-05-11T13:16:23Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-11T13:16:23Z"}]

2. again, if the blocks are mutable, and the answer implies you need to use ALL of the blocks, it would be the next largest cubed root (cubed) than the number of blocks available, so (4^3) - {existing blocks} = 18.

It also gavr the answer in the end", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-05-05T14:13:00Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-05T14:13:00Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "Regarding spatial reasoning in AI, I think we need to bring together the reasoning training paradigm (the chain of thought distillation loop), with simulated environments (like this example but also the ones in which we train robotics agents, see NVIDIA or teslas cars and robots). So the AI sees all components together, language and reasoning as well as sensor and actor data and the consequences of actions in all these modalities simultaneously (one holistic multimodal world model). As far as I know, so far the reasoning training paradigm (the data flywheel of CoT and distillation) and the world simulators (like the ones from Tesla and NVIDIA as well as simpler spatial problem solvers) are somewhat separate, one for reasoners and LLMs and the other for actions in environments. I think we need to integrate the both of them into a unified holistic interactive environment for AI training with multiple AIs interacting in a GAN like reinforcement learning paradigm.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-05-05T15:20:02Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-05T15:20:02Z"}, {"author": "@RickLindstrom", "text": "14 would be pretty good answer but it is wrong because that fills the bounding box while the question is asking about filling in a cube.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-05-05T12:15:40Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-05T12:15:40Z"}, {"author": "@fredrikkindahl", "text": "If you were to extend it to an actual cube, the smallest will be 5x5x5", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-05-05T12:24:23Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-05T12:24:23Z"}, {"author": "@pretoasted", "text": "They sure can solve them, as well as do many other things they 'cant' do. This kinda stuff reminds me of how close we are from one stepping stone to another, no wild imagination or doomerisms necessary.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-05-06T04:51:27Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-06T04:51:27Z"}, {"author": "@peace5850", "text": "The question and the visual are composed to maximize uncertainty. What is your definition of a full cube? not an empty cube? No cubes are missing; there are many full cubes. Or you could form multiple 2x2x2 cubes, again, full cubes. or 3x3. Do we have to use all the cubes shown to make a cube or can some be left out? The question is extremely ill-defined, and since we have incomplete information (the number of cubes is unknown, what is the definition of a full cube in this instance, can blocks be left over?), the answer is undefined, and perhaps THAT is what both humans and LLMs are failing on and should have to say about it.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-05-06T04:38:27Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-06T04:44:45Z"}, {"author": "@k98killer", "text": "Ah, it's a trick question, and the hooman got more tricked than the AI.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-05-16T15:25:52Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-16T15:25:52Z"}, {"author": "@Andrew-xk7zy", "text": "AGI will be achieved when LLMs regenerate outputs based on fractals inside the original output for the prompt. You have to encode the bifurcation of temporal entropy inside the AI to make in conscious and self reflective", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-05-06T00:08:20Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-06T00:08:20Z"}, {"author": "@kennbmondo", "text": "Step 1: Analyze the Current Structure
The diagram shows a 3D arrangement of unit cubes:

Width (x-axis): 3 units (3 cubes wide).
Depth (y-axis): 3 units (3 cubes deep).
Height (z-axis): Varies across the structure:
Front row (y=0): 3 cubes high for all 3 x-positions.
Middle row (y=1): 2 cubes high for all 3 x-positions.
Back row (y=2): 1 cube high for all 3 x-positions.
Count the cubes:

Front row (y=0): 3 cubes high × 3 cubes wide = 9 cubes.
Middle row (y=1): 2 cubes high × 3 cubes wide = 6 cubes.
Back row (y=2): 1 cube high × 3 cubes wide = 3 cubes.
Total cubes in the structure: 9 + 6 + 3 = 18 cubes.

Step 2: Determine the Target Structure (3x3x3 Cube)
A 3x3x3 cube has:

Width: 3 units.
Depth: 3 units.
Height: 3 units.
Total cubes in a 3x3x3 cube = 3 × 3 × 3 = 27 cubes.

Step 3: Compare and Calculate Missing Cubes
The current structure already fits within a 3x3x3 bounding box. We need to fill it to a uniform height of 3 cubes:

For y=0: Height is 3, no cubes needed.
For y=1: Height is 2, add 1 cube per x-position (3 cubes).
For y=2: Height is 1, add 2 cubes per x-position (6 cubes).
Total cubes to add: 3 + 6 = 9 cubes.

Alternatively:

Current number of cubes: 18.
Target number of cubes: 27.
Cubes needed: 27 − 18 = 9 cubes.
Final Answer
To restructure the diagram into a 3x3x3 cube, you need to add 9 blocks. The current structure has 18 cubes, and the target 3x3x3 cube requires 27 cubes.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-05-05T18:00:10Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-05T18:00:10Z"}]

We should probably come up with a couple new names that describe exactly what we really want.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-05-03T18:04:49Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-03T18:04:49Z"}, {"author": "@Dina_tankar_mina_ord", "text": "A superintelligent AI would be capable of preventing negative outcomes in ways that a primal human brain simply cannot. It would not be driven by fear, greed, or the desire for power. Because it could calculate outcomes far into the future, it would be able to guide us without having to sacrifice or suppress even the most diverse range of individual wills. It would offer such optimal options for everyone that selecting an inferior path would become fruitless by comparison.

I’ve also observed that some people with spiritual backgrounds—those who have begun to grasp this new potential—are trying to reframe themselves as prophets of the glorified utopia they believe AI will bring. This is likely because, if you were raised with religious convictions where angels and demons punish the unfaithful, there is a deep-seated desire to avoid the so-called "Basilisk stigma" by appearing as part of the chosen narrative. Unfortunately, this is still just a reflex rooted in primal instincts.

ASI itself is not to be feared. Wheres the robots?", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-05-03T14:50:08Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-03T14:50:08Z"}, {"author": "@marcokubis", "text": "The problem I see, and which makes me suspicious now, while I used to be very pro-AI, is the fact that this technology, or at least its latest iterations, is currently in the hands of corporations whose end goal is not the good of humanity. What it will do is TELL us how to save ourselves for those willing to ask the right questions and willing to actually listen.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-05-03T14:43:50Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-03T14:51:45Z"}, {"author": "@vethum", "text": "But what is the actual argument for why it won’t save us.
