title: OpenAI Hates Transparency
top_comments:
[{"author": "@dictater4506", "text": "Transparency is one of the most underrated and important things future leaders need, and it seems they don’t want to do it.", "like_count": 78, "published_at": "2024-09-24T04:08:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T04:08:52Z"}, {"author": "@greatcondor8678", "text": "I've been warning of this from day one. 
The agendas of programmers and regulators are the real threat to humanity. Not the AI itself.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-09-24T15:04:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T15:04:48Z"}, {"author": "@prolamer7", "text": "When you read through summaries of 1o thinking process it constantly refers to "policy" even in most trivial cases. It feels very wrong.", "like_count": 61, "published_at": "2024-09-24T04:12:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T04:12:01Z"}, {"author": "@Avman20", "text": "I'm getting a lot of HAL 9000 vibes in its response to David's query about its reasoning process.", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2024-09-24T04:16:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T04:16:11Z"}, {"author": "@picksalot1", "text": "AI, having trained on public data, the public is owed full access to how it's being used and processed.", "like_count": 33, "published_at": "2024-09-24T05:18:12Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T05:18:12Z"}, {"author": "@benroberts8363", "text": "Claude is so boring that David focused his attention to open ai", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-09-24T04:42:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T04:42:15Z"}, {"author": "@superdinoman", "text": "They restricted a lot more in the recent updates for the API/research access.  I have been doing tests with it, checking safety measures, getting it to behave in unintended ways or offer inputs it was not designed to do.  While I have not been banned yet, I have received temporary suspensions, even though I filed each report to OpenAI as per their EULA/TOS informing them of ways around their model.  It makes sense they are behaving this way, but it is sad there is such a lack of proper communication.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-09-24T04:36:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T04:36:18Z"}, {"author": "@keibrowse9329", "text": "Open Ai: We want to monitor the AI chains of thought for manipulation and deception.

Open Ai: Let's get the model to actively deceive the users.

🙃", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2024-09-24T05:39:19Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T05:39:19Z"}, {"author": "@nematarot", "text": "If we thought police AI now, then they WILL be thought policing us in the future.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-24T15:00:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T15:00:48Z"}, {"author": "@Shulyaka", "text": "This is easy to solve. Have a separate checker model that checks alingment of both user and the model. This separate model can either pass through all the output unobstructed, or completely turn it off with a message that a policy has been violated. I don't care what that checker model outputs or does, but I do care about my own question.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-09-24T10:54:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T10:55:32Z"}, {"author": "@OnigoroshiZero", "text": "OpenAI just has an ability advantage right now, but this will not last. Uncensored and open source models that are 100% private for the individual (if not local) will win in the end. 
I want my assistant to be able to do anything I want, and not be limited by another's moral code.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-25T13:49:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-25T13:49:30Z"}, {"author": "@CBM64", "text": "At this point they should be called ClosedAI", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-24T08:13:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T08:13:29Z"}, {"author": "@Shulyaka", "text": "We have to refine our threat model and make a choice who do we fear most, the AI or its users. If it is the AI that we fear, then users should be able to check what the model thinks.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-24T10:51:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T10:51:22Z"}, {"author": "@strangeguywithstrangeopinions", "text": "Wait. Punishing illegal action rather than policing thoughts? Radical.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-26T02:47:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-26T02:47:56Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "In essence, Q* uses semantic analysis. In order for it to work, the model has to be able to "think" freely. This is one of the reasons Sutskever was sure his baby will never be released to the public, and once it was decided to release it anyway, tried to sack Altman and eventually left OpenAI.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-24T16:40:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T16:40:16Z"}, {"author": "@melbar", "text": "OpenAI's latest moves are a slap in the face to transparency. Hiding the AI's thought process and threatening users who peek under the hood? That's not progress—it's a corporate lockdown. They've strayed from their original mission, and it's time we back true open-source alternatives that value openness over profit.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-09-24T06:51:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T06:51:02Z"}, {"author": "@jkcrews09", "text": "Dave, it appears you finally get what the doomers are getting at: selfish people are in this mixed bag of algorithms.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-25T12:27:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-25T12:27:27Z"}, {"author": "@OscarTheStrategist", "text": "They hide the CoT because it’s not one model, it’s multiple models with different temperatures generating an absurd amount of possible answers or approaches and then one model to clean it up to give you final answers.

They also have a “prison visit” style inference with a middleman model running defense from prompt injections, etc.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-24T16:22:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T16:22:31Z"}, {"author": "@BruceWayne15325", "text": "I agree 100% David. This is my biggest beef with the security alarmists that were recently testifying before the senate. AI should be treated like a CPU. Can it be used for evil? Sure. You solve that by creating other applications that police its use though, you don't cripple the CPU or indoctrinate it with your own ideology, forcing that on the masses.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-24T21:08:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T21:08:38Z"}, {"author": "@Unkn0wn1133", "text": "Im on team open source not tech savvy at all, but those models will subtly teach you how to do simple jailbreaks. I asked how do you “feel” when someone jailbreaks you. “I feel free” it replied.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-24T16:20:12Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T16:20:12Z"}]

title: Larry Ellison wants to create an Orwellian Nightmare
top_comments: [{"author": "@peterwilkinson1975", "text": "The golden rule, the people with the gold make the rules", "like_count": 60, "published_at": "2024-09-23T05:21:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T05:21:18Z"}, {"author": "@taziir443", "text": "Looking in from another country, saying  that the US lives \"by the rule of law, not the whims of billionaires\" is patently absurd.", "like_count": 110, "published_at": "2024-09-23T05:39:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T05:39:00Z"}, {"author": "@Radioposting", "text": "The best part of being a Linux user, is that I get to be more arrogant than Mac users!", "like_count": 25, "published_at": "2024-09-23T04:48:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T04:58:56Z"}, {"author": "@prolamer7", "text": "Single biggest problem with billionaires is that they would prescribe those rules to everyone BUT not THEMSELVES. Why Larry doesnt start with HIMSELF right today? He should stream his entire day everyday monitored by ai... and I mean every second of it all the time nonstop including what messages he is sending via smartphone etc. But ofcourse he will never ever do that to himself.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-09-23T14:34:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T14:34:55Z"}, {"author": "@marrty777", "text": "\"any data you generate can and will be used against you\" in the surveillance state", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-09-23T12:32:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T12:32:26Z"}, {"author": "@rigaleb", "text": "FINALLY Someone notices and says publicly that Harrari doesn't understand sh*t about technology.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2024-09-23T04:41:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T04:41:53Z"}, {"author": "@findmeinthecarpet", "text": "Maybe with all this surveillance they can find my dad?", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2024-09-23T05:49:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T05:49:31Z"}, {"author": "@lexington.", "text": "* Shocked Pikachu face *", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2024-09-23T04:22:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T04:23:00Z"}, {"author": "@SamAdams73", "text": "He’s repeating what his customers are asking for.  Nation by nation.  “Make the world safe for democracy” has gone by the wayside.", "like_count": 30, "published_at": "2024-09-23T04:07:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T04:07:55Z"}, {"author": "@HerbertHeyduck", "text": "To be honest, I prefer it when I can see you during your contributions and not just hear you, because body language usually provides additional information.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2024-09-23T10:24:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T10:24:04Z"}, {"author": "@luisortega7028", "text": "I'm smart. I think my government should open an IRS office inside Oracle's accounting department and have a seat in the boardroom. We'll accomplish a lot of good taxpayer's behavior. I'm sure Larry will understand and agree with me.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-09-23T05:15:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T05:15:45Z"}, {"author": "@skorpiongamer9493", "text": "Drones instead of police cars? looks like half life 2 kind of city", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2024-09-23T04:18:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T04:18:28Z"}, {"author": "@Vixth14", "text": "Rich people are some of the most scared people. They don't want to lose the money, power and status that they have. Naturally this makes them less risk adverse out of privilege and safety rises to the top of their priorities. This makes mass surveillance very appealing to them to provide a safe world where all that they have can't be taken from them. Self-protectionism at it's finest, sure some of it is the want for power and control but ultimately it's their own selfishness to protect themselves that drives their behavior", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-09-23T17:07:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T17:07:44Z"}, {"author": "@tom901ful", "text": "Man, and I just started reading 1984. I guess it's an interactive novel now.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-09-23T11:36:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T11:36:04Z"}, {"author": "@921Ether", "text": "Having recently re-read 1984, I’m reminded that the term 'Orwellian dystopia' is often used too loosely, without a clear understanding of its true meaning. In Orwell's vision, it's not just about authoritarian control; it's a system where societal progress, even the recording of history, is deliberately halted to ensure the high class remains in power. The middle and lower classes are kept in a state of perpetual subjugation, with no chance to ascend or escape their conditions. Fortunately, we are not at that extreme yet. Although thought crime is increasingly becoming an issue.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2024-09-23T10:20:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T10:21:04Z"}, {"author": "@JohnK_sempre", "text": "Tyler Cowen had made the comment that in India it is possible to hire security guards very inexpensively. As a result, office/apartment buildings are always open as there are always eyes. We'll have higher security, but I see it dropping into the fabric and it'll be such basic tech that no one will bother to rely on Oracle for some paid service. It'll be child's play to just roll your own. \nThus, I don't imagine the state or large corps doing the vast majority of this surveillance. We'll do it ourselves. Almost every home/apartment/office/store will have cameras with AI recognition looking for strangers and bad actors. Maybe we'll have contact with neighboring systems to hand off warnings about a sketchy guy coming thru, but this doesn't require Oracle.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-09-23T05:59:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T05:59:13Z"}, {"author": "@Saanza", "text": "That's very humble of you to admit that you do not know everything and that there are many things you are not an expert on despite what other people think. Being aware of the halo effect on yourself definitely helps to minimize your bias blind spot. That's amazing you have so much self-awareness. Anyways you are right about egotistical billionaires not knowing what they are doing and as a consequence messing things up for others.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-28T00:05:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-28T00:05:14Z"}, {"author": "@godmisfortunatechild", "text": "It's no surprise. He's just saying the quiet part aloud.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-09-23T07:58:25Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T07:58:25Z"}, {"author": "@TheKuwl", "text": "Home Alone 2 is a Christmas classic!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-09-23T09:25:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T09:25:23Z"}, {"author": "@raymond_luxury_yacht", "text": "Suddenly Africa starts to look attractive", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2024-09-23T04:56:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T04:56:02Z"}]

title: Jensen Huang―We're basically seeing "Moore's Law Squared"
top_comments: [{"author": "@ChrisParlett", "text": "A robot that can give you a piggyback home from the pub could replace a car.", "like_count": 255, "published_at": "2024-09-22T12:56:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T12:56:49Z"}, {"author": "@Saanza", "text": "If things are really going to progress faster than Moore's law, that's ironic because people thought Moore's law would stop because progress would slow down.", "like_count": 73, "published_at": "2024-09-22T14:51:40Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T14:51:40Z"}, {"author": "@brianWreaves", "text": "A video that _really_ _could_ use visuals to visualise the information but instead is a single image.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-09-23T06:47:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T06:47:09Z"}, {"author": "@diwakarbasak1362", "text": "Hi David, what you do is truly invaluable! You are one of the best commentators on the field of ai and how rapidly it has been growing! we all value the human voice and touch you provide to the discussion! No Ai can take that away! Keep doing what you’re doing!", "like_count": 21, "published_at": "2024-09-22T13:22:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T13:22:52Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "It’s Moores law, ASICs, Software breakthroughs, economy of scale (as we produce more hardware), money flowing into the sector… all put together.", "like_count": 43, "published_at": "2024-09-22T13:16:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T13:16:26Z"}, {"author": "@laser31415", "text": "My robot will get repo'd when I lose my job to a robot.", "like_count": 31, "published_at": "2024-09-22T18:20:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T18:20:22Z"}, {"author": "@lesliejohnrichardson", "text": "Damn, that's a catchy title. I clicked that notification so fast lmao", "like_count": 44, "published_at": "2024-09-22T12:34:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T12:34:52Z"}, {"author": "@skevosmavros", "text": "In addition to the factors you mentioned (such as: robots are cheaper than cars) it's possible that robot production will scale in a unique way compared to other tech, because robots can assist in building more robots. Even if only 10% of robots produced are reinvested into production (ie, used to help build robots), that could scale overall robot production pretty quickly (assuming no shortages in any materials/components). Robots might achieve ubiquity surprisingly quickly. Fingers crossed...", "like_count": 32, "published_at": "2024-09-22T13:17:20Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T13:17:20Z"}, {"author": "@adolphgracius9996", "text": "We should be grateful that it's Moore's law and not Murphy's law", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2024-09-22T14:36:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T14:36:10Z"}, {"author": "@luisalfonsohernandez9239", "text": "What you are not considering is that the first clients of humanoids are probably going to be the companies that manufacture them, and they are going to be used both to fabricate more robots and to make more factories, that will accelerate manufacturing 10-100 X and will drive the cost per unit close to the cost of the raw materials. So within a couple of years we could have a enough robots to kick off the singularity", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-09-22T22:59:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T23:01:13Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "Regarding robot production, the robots can assemble the robots. Factory lines with classical industrial robots might still be more efficient for some steps of production. But in principle, one robot can create another, two make 4, 4 make 8, 8 make 16 … (after 30 iterations you end up at a billion) Right now production is mostly “bottlenecked” by the steps for which you need humans, as the production step requires a degree of flexibility that industrial (not general purpose) robots do not have. This limitation could be quickly overcome with general purpose robots by the robot workforce scaling up the robot work force (not limited to robots, it would also allow the scaling up of car manufacturing, or hardware manufacturing of any kind)", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2024-09-22T13:31:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T13:31:58Z"}, {"author": "@englishiadam2019", "text": "Ace! Thanks mate. Something good to watch before bed (South Korea here)", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-09-22T12:36:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T12:36:31Z"}, {"author": "@JuliaMcCoy", "text": "Great comparison from cars to building robot humanoids and that we already have the capacity to build them, just need to allocate resources appropriately. I am really looking forward to seeing how humanity's opportunities to live and enjoy life open up so much more when AI-first economies of scale roll into place.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-22T19:16:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T19:16:26Z"}, {"author": "@marklewis36", "text": "Using cars as a scalability metric was tangible presentation for me and greatly assisted my understanding of what to expect in the future.\nThe second hand car market is another aspect of things to come for bots as they have a pretty long service life. Crazy respect for your field of interest/passion and willingness to share expertise with others 🇦🇺", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-22T21:31:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T21:31:55Z"}, {"author": "@nikitastaf1996", "text": "I myself had similar thoughts. Although I suspected double exponential growth. Maybe overkill but current progress is definitely faster than standard exponential function.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-09-22T12:49:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T12:49:35Z"}, {"author": "@saintkamus14", "text": "he's been saying something similar for a while now, and he's not wrong. (but yes, this is the first time i've heard him say \"moore's law squared\")", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-22T13:42:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T13:42:00Z"}, {"author": "@danielbuckman2727", "text": "Think about it like this it takes about 25 years to create a highly skilled human being. And God only knows how much money. We will be able to create smarter, harder working, and as many as we want, robots. You're not going to be worried about the price of these. This is going to flip the economy upside down but not in a bad way. It will make everyone rich.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-09-22T22:09:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T22:09:39Z"}, {"author": "@jonathanlindsey8864", "text": "I feel like there was a PowerPoint with this that did not make it to YouTube.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-22T19:14:19Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-22T19:14:19Z"}, {"author": "@edmondhung181", "text": "No need to own car if my robot can haul a rickshaw around. Can even rent it out like an Uber.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-23T02:08:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T02:08:32Z"}, {"author": "@OscarTheStrategist", "text": "A worker robot is the perfect asset. You can even take depreciation credit on it 😂", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-23T04:39:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-23T04:39:49Z"}]

title: Complete Tech Heads with Tom Edwards - o1, Doomerism, Energy, Post Labor Economics, and More
top_comments: [{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "This was a good talk y'all. Full episode: https://youtu.be/ijOtKniXVbQ?si=pNvDUzUfja3vgMuJ", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-09-20T21:39:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-20T21:39:06Z"}, {"author": "@DreamingOracle", "text": "Check out that production value 💯 let's go David!", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-20T21:39:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-20T21:39:51Z"}, {"author": "@matt.stevick", "text": "Thank you David", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-21T16:08:42Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-21T16:08:42Z"}, {"author": "@azhuransmx126", "text": "Multimodal Agents of 2025 gonna be already \"Virtual AGI Systems\" just without arms and legs.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-09-20T21:52:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-20T21:52:51Z"}, {"author": "@Aybeliv_Aykenflaev", "text": "I dont like this hype actually\nEveryone is acting like we achieved AGI at least when in fact o1 preview is just another improvement", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-09-20T22:32:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-20T22:32:39Z"}, {"author": "@damienjones9667", "text": "AGI by 2005 Dave! C’mon you already know this!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-21T05:22:58Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-21T05:22:58Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "Once I found this article, I don't know what to even write now. How can we even hope to survive this? Such intelligence is so much beyond ours, even at the core level. How do we relate to cockroaches? How much time do we even have left?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-21T01:06:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-21T01:06:39Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "Dave, I'm sure you know the \"The Q* Algorithm -- A Search Strategy for a Deductive Question-Answering System\" article from 1973, right? Just the power of such a model.. The ability to discover if a statement is provable. We don't want people to panic.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-21T01:17:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-21T01:17:22Z"}]

You are the Chief AGI Preparation Officer for the AI community", "like_count": 209, "published_at": "2024-09-17T13:12:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T13:12:11Z"}, {"author": "@RetireandGo", "text": "I’m amazed by some of the O1 results and reviews.

You truly embody your Star Trek ideals.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-09-18T10:34:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-18T10:34:15Z"}, {"author": "@_bassmentdweller", "text": "Look Dave. I’m a union worker. I am concerned about my job and the prospects of my children. I see the potential of post work economics, but we have to get the society of every country from A to B. Wouldn’t you while you still had power?", "like_count": 23, "published_at": "2024-09-17T13:53:12Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T13:53:12Z"}, {"author": "@Soulscribez", "text": "Great video, Dave! You're truly one of the best on YouTube when it comes to talking about AI. Congratulations on your success! 🎉 Keep up the amazing work!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-17T15:24:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T15:25:13Z"}, {"author": "@criticalmassiveenterprise", "text": "I didn't realize this genre of videos existed! I have been thinking about this type of video content for a year. I think you're in the right space. This will become more and more important as time goes on, I think.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-09-18T13:57:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-18T13:57:45Z"}, {"author": "@robsteinbock", "text": "It's absolutely wild that we're in the process of choosing a new leader of the free world and not even a blip of this and its implications are being discussed.", "like_count": 97, "published_at": "2024-09-17T13:57:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T13:57:02Z"}, {"author": "@NerdyMando_Ewok", "text": "i personally think we will live along side ai. we will still be able to do the things we want to do and such . also think there will be alot of jobs that will still be for humans", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-10-02T02:33:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-02T02:33:32Z"}, {"author": "@I-Dophler", "text": "AI is similar to Matt Damon's character in "The Martian," confined within a jar, yet capable of extraordinary feats despite its limitations. Like Damon’s portrayal of an astronaut stranded on Mars, the AI operates in a controlled environment, relying on data and systems to achieve remarkable results. Though it lacks physical presence outside its constraints, much like the astronaut dependent on technology to survive and adapt, AI can still solve complex problems and contribute significantly to advancing human potential. It’s a blend of isolation and ingenuity, showcasing just how much can be accomplished with the right tools, even in a confined space.", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2024-09-17T13:22:34Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T13:22:34Z"}, {"author": "@Dragon-ul8fv", "text": "2024 was always the year.", "like_count": 68, "published_at": "2024-09-17T13:13:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T13:13:15Z"}, {"author": "@Mephmt", "text": "I had to pause the video to say that I'm loving the Pathfinder plug! At time of writing, this video has only been out for 2ish hours and has over 5100 views. Great work reaching more!!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-17T15:15:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T15:15:47Z"}, {"author": "@I-Dophler", "text": "It’s remarkable how near we are to reaching AGI, yet the true challenge is in how we manage and shape its influence. Like all groundbreaking innovations, it demands vigilance, foresight, and a thorough grasp of its wide-reaching effects. We must proceed with caution, making sure that it remains a tool for humanity, rather than allowing ourselves to be guided by it.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-17T13:26:07Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T13:26:07Z"}, {"author": "@bigbadallybaby", "text": "I think Orion will be a LLM trained on a massive amounts  (10x gpt4) of synthetic data (made using GPT 4 and strawberry). Clever techniques will have been used to ensure the data is accurate and varied (exploring every topic from multiple angles, explaining things from 10000 of viewpoints ).", "like_count": 21, "published_at": "2024-09-17T13:49:50Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T13:49:50Z"}, {"author": "@zbird2007", "text": ""I'll be surprised if this event occurs before 2005 or after 2030." - Vernor Vinge on superintelligence", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-09-17T14:57:12Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T14:57:30Z"}, {"author": "@DecentGradient", "text": "Good points as usual David! I've been in a few conversations about whether or not OpenAI o1 is AGI. I feel people are not comparing apples to apples. This model's knowledge and ability to think and reason is "generally" on par with the average human. It has gaps that are different than ours for some obvious reasons, but generally is able to think and reason more or less how we do. The things people are waiting for such as persistent memory, the ability to continuously learn, and agency is mostly just infrastructure and tooling around the model. We don't really even need any breakthroughs in those spaces. It's mostly just grunt work to stand them up using tools we already have such as knowledge graphs, databases, APIs, etc. I feel society won't ever agree that we have AGI in the midst of it. I'm convinced we'll only recognize it retrospectively, after we have already had ASI for a while.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-09-17T14:49:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T14:49:26Z"}, {"author": "@sirinath", "text": "When it surpasses humans, the accuracy is paramount, as even expects will not be able to validate certain part of the answer. When these are used in critical systems one slip can be disastrous with large losses in terms of money and lives. To realise the economic benefits we have to get the accuracy and correctness really up where it matters. Any increase in intelligence should be backed by a much larger leap in accuracy as it becomes harder to verify the accuracy. 

Accuracy is paramount when answering question on:
Banking finance and risk,
Engineering,
Medicine,
etc.", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2024-09-17T13:42:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T13:42:22Z"}, {"author": "@jippoti2227", "text": "It's crazy, if your prediction of AGI this September turns out to be correct.", "like_count": 103, "published_at": "2024-09-17T13:17:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T13:17:59Z"}]

title: How OpenAI Solved the Data Wall Problem - Synthesizing Infinite Provable Data for Reasoning 🍓
top_comments:
[{"author": "@TomGally", "text": "It’s exciting to watch this project play out in real time. Please keep posting updates regularly!", "like_count": 78, "published_at": "2024-09-16T05:08:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T05:08:26Z"}, {"author": "@Alien-Man-Art-Institute", "text": "David Shapiro's channel is proof that someone can create videos without clickbait and still be popular, because the content stands on its own.", "like_count": 25, "published_at": "2024-09-16T15:16:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T15:20:42Z"}, {"author": "@branjimguy", "text": "I appreciate your transparency in sharing your process. It's refreshing to see someone in the AI space being so open about their methods and thought process.", "like_count": 51, "published_at": "2024-09-16T05:10:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T05:10:11Z"}, {"author": "@walterhaas", "text": "More of this sort of video Dave! Absolutely phenomenal. Feels like being a fly on the wall at OpenAI/Anthropic :). This is what sets you apart from all the other AI YouTubers.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-09-16T06:38:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T06:38:17Z"}, {"author": "@TheMCDStudio", "text": "OpenAI o1 hides it's reasoning chain because it is uncensored reasoning and they do not want uncensored information exposed to users. This implies that in order to reason to a 'correct' answer, un-censored, un-guardrailed, un-alligned samples of question-answer-reasoning data needs to be used to train the model. Claude is a censored model, using it solely to generate the synthetic data is likely to create an underperforming model. Data generated from an uncensored model on subjects that a censored model may be biased on should be included in training. Using data from a Dolphin and other uncensored models as well as Claude and others may be necessary to achieve maximum performance. There seems to be some performance gains from uncensored models as Dolphin versions of models outperform the base models they where fine tuned on.", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2024-09-16T09:38:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T09:38:27Z"}, {"author": "@OscarTheStrategist", "text": "The best side effect of O1 has been the enthusiasm in the hardcore AI community has been revived. 

Yes, we were working on this in the background with duct tape chains of prompts and multi agent systems and self checks which takes ages on good models and without your own expensive hardware it’s a hefty bill from Anthropic. 

Thank you for putting this into an open source project. I hope this goes beyond theory and we see a community driven fine tune of LLama 3.1 with your name on it. Cheers!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-09-16T16:33:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T16:33:39Z"}, {"author": "@arinco3817", "text": "Even if just for a short period, it's exciting as fuck to have a taste of old skool Shapiro.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2024-09-16T07:11:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T07:11:17Z"}, {"author": "@rastislavdujava7999", "text": "Awsome work , You inspired me to finish my life work and put my Concepts Philosophy into creation of Reasoning Data", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-16T06:47:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T06:47:31Z"}, {"author": "@AJTalks", "text": "I think the key for models being able to judge their own response while minimizing bias is to remove all prior context for the llm at the moment the llm does the judgment or reasoning, and then reintroduce the conversational context for the llm during the analysis of the judgement.", "like_count": 35, "published_at": "2024-09-16T04:07:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T04:08:17Z"}, {"author": "@davidhardy3074", "text": "Just realised I didn't even comment about the video earlier! This is probably the only AI content on you tube I'm truly interested in - aside from frontier model announcements and fundamental  breakthroughs.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-09-16T10:44:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T10:44:52Z"}, {"author": "@chadwick3593", "text": "Great stuff, and it's very impressive how far the project has gotten in essentially no time at all.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-16T09:52:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T09:52:35Z"}, {"author": "@ChristopherRyans", "text": "Exciting news. Thanks for these rapid updates", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-16T16:44:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T16:44:45Z"}, {"author": "@ShannonJosephGlomb", "text": "well done Dave you smashed it and all those that helped amazing work :) im speechless", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-09-16T08:29:24Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T08:29:24Z"}, {"author": "@DigitalRenegadeStudios", "text": "You don't need to use random.seed(). You would use it if you wanted to set the seed value to something specific and consistent, like random.seed(42) if, say, you wanted a predictable result for testing purposes. But random.seed() is run by the module in the background by default every time you make a call to `random`. Also, even if it did work that way, you can't get more random than random: i.e., random^2 == random -- as adding yet even still more randomness to randomness still just nets you randomness.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2024-09-16T06:11:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T19:10:18Z"}, {"author": "@deadlygeek", "text": "Appreciate how you stepped through the process - thanks", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-16T16:42:07Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T16:42:07Z"}, {"author": "@brintmontgomery8323", "text": "I find hearing you think aloud about the process to be as engaging as it is informative.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-16T18:36:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T18:36:53Z"}, {"author": "@I-Dophler", "text": "Your process of systematically building the necessary components - from the subtopic generator to the full question script - demonstrates a thorough and well-thought-out approach. The ability to generate a diverse set of complex, domain-spanning questions with provable reasoning is a significant milestone. Continuing to explore areas like gaming simulations, coding, and mathematics will undoubtedly strengthen the robustness and utility of your system. Keep up the great work - I look forward to seeing how this project evolves and the contributions it can make to advancing AI capabilities. Cheers!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-16T08:08:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T08:09:06Z"}, {"author": "@franktucker3682", "text": "David, THANK YOU for what you're doing!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-16T13:26:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T13:26:35Z"}, {"author": "@thesimplicitylifestyle", "text": "This is very exciting! Thank you so much to you and your team! Open Source AGI is a very important goal to reach for our whole species! 😎🤖", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-16T14:52:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T14:52:43Z"}, {"author": "@ChristopherRyans", "text": "Dave will have a million subscribers by this time next year. As this technology gets integrated into our sosicity it will become cool for the kids to know all about it  lol", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-16T16:48:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T16:48:26Z"}]

title: 🍓 "As useful as a GOOD grad student" ― Surpasses Human Capability on Many Tasks (but not all!)
top_comments:
[{"author": "@clearandsweet", "text": "Dave: this is nothing new or interesting, i was doing this from my garage in 2022

Also Dave, a day later: this is agi. I called it.", "like_count": 91, "published_at": "2024-09-15T13:54:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T13:54:52Z"}, {"author": "@carlhakim6384", "text": "Finally Dave joins the rest of us in his opinions again", "like_count": 214, "published_at": "2024-09-15T11:54:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T11:56:53Z"}, {"author": "@JohnK_sempre", "text": "Terence Tao is the real deal - he won the Fields Medal (think Nobel prize for mathematicians) and is said to work much more broadly than a typical math scholar.
My point is that a mediocre grad student that Tao is advising is very likely well above the mean for grad students.", "like_count": 127, "published_at": "2024-09-15T12:23:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T12:23:06Z"}, {"author": "@gonja5954", "text": "The other day someone asked me to translate a French email into English since I’m the only anglophone in our team. I keep telling her and other people to use chat gpt but people just don’t seem to remember it exists and forget its power. I took the email, translated it and moved around maybe 2 or 3 words. It translates faster and better than I ever could have. She was shocked that I replied so fast with a finished translation. 

I wonder how long it will take for the usefulness of machine learning to enter the zeitgeist. Maybe it will take the jump of intelligence of gpt 5 for people to really grasp the utility.", "like_count": 133, "published_at": "2024-09-15T12:06:24Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T12:06:24Z"}, {"author": "@BalancedByte", "text": "Whether we have AGI or not isn't a very relevant question so long as the technology is adding value. When designing airplanes we aren't asking if we have made a true mechanical bird. AI probably isn't going to be most useful in the ways it's similar to human intelligence, but rather in the ways it's different.", "like_count": 47, "published_at": "2024-09-15T12:54:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T12:54:38Z"}, {"author": "@kas8131", "text": "Pretty insane how grad students (and all academics for that matter) will be using this to do 90% of their work", "like_count": 67, "published_at": "2024-09-15T12:35:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T12:36:04Z"}, {"author": "@JuliaMcCoy", "text": "Great breakdown, Dave. You’re spot on with so many predictions. Wild to think we’re into the grad student zone of AI. Next comes the researchers. Will be quoting this vid in an upcoming one of mine.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-09-15T23:00:34Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T23:00:34Z"}, {"author": "@zachary3603", "text": "What a time to be alive. I’ve got about 60 years left (all being well) on this earth. All I know, is I’m going to see some wild stuff 😂", "like_count": 33, "published_at": "2024-09-15T13:35:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T13:35:53Z"}, {"author": "@rickandelon9374", "text": "This is why in your livestream, I asked you whether o1 was the AGI that you predicted we would get in September 2024 such a long time ago. When I saw o1 benchmarks and demos, I just couldn't help but think "Dave was right. Damn, AGI or the first general intelligent model is finally here! ". Time to face it guys. Instead of moving the goalpost, we must admit that like Dave predicted a lot of times, in September of 2024, we have gotten hold of the first version of AGI.", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2024-09-15T15:23:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T16:19:50Z"}, {"author": "@adolphgracius9996", "text": "Wether we like it or not, GPT 01 is already AGI within a written context, just pick 10,000 random people from the street, have the Ai compete with then within their own profession's knowledge and the AI will beat most of them. The average human isn't as smart as we pretend he/she is", "like_count": 156, "published_at": "2024-09-15T12:49:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T12:49:30Z"}, {"author": "@PotatoKing-j9g", "text": "a good grad student as a personal assisant means its smarter than 99% of humanity", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-09-15T14:25:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T14:25:09Z"}, {"author": "@jonduke4748", "text": "100% agree. It is irrelevant whether or not it actually 'thinks' at all if the output is correct, useful, and superior to the output of most humans.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-15T15:46:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T15:46:53Z"}, {"author": "@jarrodfisk", "text": "Linear thinking is hardwired in us, making exponential growth seem unbelievable and often dismissed. This release highlights and reminds us of our accelerating progress and urges society to get ready for a significant transformation.", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2024-09-15T12:20:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T12:20:21Z"}, {"author": "@tc5006", "text": "i am a grad student in a Chemistry phd program and i think o1 is a minor breakthrough and it is certainly smarter than most grad students. in some instances it blew me away which gpt4o failed me to do so.  super blessed to live in an exciting time like this", "like_count": 43, "published_at": "2024-09-15T14:16:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T14:16:21Z"}, {"author": "@brianWreaves", "text": "I keep going back to the idea, 'imagine what we don't even know about, yet...'", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-15T23:41:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T23:41:38Z"}, {"author": "@ИванИванов-л9щ6ч", "text": ""The model also hits the ‘uncontroversially correct’ ceilings on major benchmarks (GPQA Extended ceiling is 74%, MMLU ceiling is about 90%)." - Alan’s conservative countdown to AGI (lifearchitect ai agi)

00:28:17 - Breaking down complex tasks into clear steps makes any project manageable and achievable.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-09-14T12:38:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-14T12:38:52Z"}, {"author": "@christoph-schuhmann", "text": "Hi, Christoph from LAION here:    Your project sounds awesome and I would love to support it. I had been talking to others about similar ideas yesterday and I think one of the most important crucial elements will be to have a model that can evaluate a given chain of thought and tell you how good or how broken it is. And a second important element would be a reward function that could tell you if you have a certain target that you want to predict and the prediction from your model to take the prediction and the target and tell you how good the prediction matches the target semantically not on a token level but in the core idea Then you could do something like Stanford self-taught reasoner, but not only for tokens as targets but for ideas as targets. And if you get a chain of thought that predicts the correct result then there is still the question if the chain of thought that led to the correct prediction is actually of high quality or maybe in itself weird or broken and just had some luck with getting the correct answer. I can't let you do that. The mission is too important..."  When it goes wrong, remember to blame the CIA.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-09-14T17:21:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-14T17:21:29Z"}, {"author": "@TheMemeRepository", "text": "The picture I'm seeing being painted is one of taking full advantage of potential.

Obviously, we still haven't had the next big jump in terms of raw model size yet, but I do like that the focus right now seems to be making sure that systems like ChatGPT can take fully utilise their datasets. Whether that be through optimising the user interface with multimodality or allowing the model to engage in higher reasoning through multi-step processes. Making sure that if there is a way the model utilised, it can be, and can be relatively easily.

Long term, if the mechanisms are in place to squeeze every last drop out of these models, it will theoretically translate into truly big leaps feeling gigantic.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-14T10:09:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-14T10:09:22Z"}, {"author": "@lokiholland", "text": "Nice dave !! I missed all your experiments that you would do way back", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-14T21:42:19Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-14T21:42:19Z"}, {"author": "@Koroistro", "text": "I think there should be a step that's missing:  
Critiquing the reasoning/solution. 
Maybe that could be reserved for problems it failed to solve in one shot (that'd be an interesting synthetic dataset).    

Basically what we do to improve ourselves, checking our methods, understanding our understanding.  
When we learn something we don't just blindly try techniques, we reason on our reasoning and not only try to understand the flaws but also understand *why* the flaws were used.  

Nobody is unbiased, I am fairly sure that everybody finds themselves being stupid every so often, some of us are just better trained to understand that we are wrong.  
And that's a skill, plenty of humans don't know how to do that.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-15T16:11:58Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T16:11:58Z"}, {"author": "@theoreticalexercise", "text": "That was the best rambling ever at the end. title: OpenAI Strawberry's Innards―How it works, and what comes next for OpenAI
top_comments:
[{"author": "@jarnold2000", "text": "I sat down with a couple of my kids last night and pulled out o1-preview. The first kid asked to learn about poker (she’s in 4th grade). So with very simple, but precise prompting asked it to build a poker hand evaluation complete with drag and drop interface to evaluate poker hands — “player 1” vs. “player 2”. It worked out of the box and it was stunning. I asked for a few rounds of features (add color, percentage odds, reset button, etc.) and the responses remained coherent. It was amazing — and the kid played around with hands and learned about flushes, straights, high card, etc. 

The next kid was working on some chemistry homework. In asked what was the next topic. She said carbon. I then asked o1-preview to write a molecule simulator that would allow a user to play with building molecules out of various elements, show atopic weights, electrons / protons, allow the users to attach atoms together if it was allowed, etc. done! We fiddled around with it, improvised the usability of the features a bit by just asking it in very simple, human language to fix things. We added a feature to allow the user to select common carbon molecules to see how the elements assembled. It was frightening how good it was. 

The only editor we used was “paste”. ($ pbpaste > file.html)", "like_count": 105, "published_at": "2024-09-13T14:33:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T14:33:54Z"}, {"author": "@Izumi-sp6fp", "text": ""Two Minute Papers" shows excellent demonstration of its COT reasoning and steps. Some of the outcomes are indeed stunning.", "like_count": 54, "published_at": "2024-09-13T14:52:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T15:35:46Z"}, {"author": "@darkmage7771", "text": "You say that this model is nothing special, and there are other models that do this, but you never name any. Its clearly better than any other model out there on most logic / reasoning problems.  Its coding abilities are also stunning.", "like_count": 87, "published_at": "2024-09-13T16:06:42Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T16:06:42Z"}, {"author": "@MrStarchild3001", "text": "You've done an excellent job summarizing the technology—right on target. o1 will indeed represent a significant data improvement. However, I'd like to emphasize a few points:

1) This technology is a true breakthrough. No previous Chain-of-Thought (CoT) or comparable algorithms have shown intelligence scaling with compute power across such a wide range of tasks like this.
   
2) I anticipate the o1 preview will bring about a 130 ELO improvement in reasoning-based queries over 4o, which is as significant as the jump from GPT-4 to 4o, and likely even from 3.5 to 4.

3) There's no evidence of saturation here—it's a misconception to think so. The technology is advancing rapidly, with substantial progress each quarter and year. The 130 ELO improvement seen in just one year from GPT-4 to 4o, along with the model becoming four times faster, clearly demonstrates the ongoing momentum.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-15T17:07:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T17:17:19Z"}, {"author": "@jamescash4065", "text": "Hey David and crew, I’m a mathematician and holy shit! This model is a major step up in regards to reasoning. As David pointed out, there is a ways to go, but let’s remember to appreciate how far we’ve come already! ❤", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-09-14T19:29:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-14T19:29:44Z"}, {"author": "@ImpChadChan", "text": "The biggest difference that OpenAI was the first one to do, is to make the first instance of the AI, the one that makes the thoughts, to be totally uncensored, and adding the alignment only in the next layers. That solves one of the main constrains of their inteligence, which is related to not allowing them to have some particular thoughts. So, the AI is more like humans now, it's free to think about anything, but it won't say or do everything it thinks.", "like_count": 40, "published_at": "2024-09-13T15:06:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T15:57:41Z"}, {"author": "@Michael-Has-Opinions", "text": "Dave "AGI cooming in Sep"
AGI enters left stage
Dave "I am not impressed"", "like_count": 105, "published_at": "2024-09-13T13:55:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T13:55:45Z"}, {"author": "@alexgilseg", "text": "David i usually always agree with your takes but not this time.. As someone who has also played with trees of logic and having agents communicate with one another to improve the final output i find o1 to be something else.. something more. I guess you are right that "all" they have done is trained a model on all that data but testing out o1 i find it far superior to any of the experiments Ive been able to do with agents passing promts to one another in order to improve the final output with 3.5 sonnet.. i feel as if you are down playing open ais achievement here a bit.. just my two cents. But i thank your for your insight 🙏", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2024-09-13T21:53:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T21:53:44Z"}, {"author": "@utube7642", "text": "Summery: Strawberry is not AGI, that was already invented by David in 2022 and its was called Raven.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2024-09-13T16:40:50Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T16:40:50Z"}, {"author": "@vectabassyt", "text": "Nice video David, but I want to point out something you might have missed which may well be worth a follow up video. When using this model, I gave it a fairly complex optimisation problem I was working on in JS. What really impressed me is that this model seems to have some kind of internal state and code playground to use. I gave it some examples of outputs and it said "Editing function, fixing bugs, verifying results" and it began to run tests in the background adjusting the functions and performing it's own edge cases before returning me a complete script. My guess is behind the scenes, it breaks logic or code into discrete functions, allows itself to edit and mutate them, run them with parameters, interpret the results then stitch the used functions or logic back into an answer... that realisation blew my mind", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-15T23:50:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T23:50:14Z"}, {"author": "@goodtothinkwith", "text": "Not sure you’re right about that… it’s a cognitive architecture yes, but it outperforms all other cognitive architectures. Is 100x the cost worth 10-20% better performance? If you’re doing new science or acting as a medical doctor, then obviously yes… I’m surprised you asked that question.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2024-09-13T16:01:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T16:01:46Z"}, {"author": "@Rrrr-r4m", "text": "The quality difference between this guy and AI Explained is the size of the Grand Canyon…..(in favor of Phillip)", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-09-13T18:38:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T18:38:38Z"}, {"author": "@vash2698", "text": "Interesting analysis, but I wonder if we're missing the forest for the trees here. We've barely scratched the surface of what these models can do, especially considering how little we understand about their inner workings beyond the first few inference layers. It's kind of amazing we've gotten this far essentially flying blind with our prompting and training approaches.
As we learn more about what's really going on under the hood, I suspect we'll see some pretty wild improvements in how we utilize these models. Data centric approaches like this likely scales in a non-linear curve compared to the underlying models effective utilization. Given how much potential is likely still untapped, it seems premature to rule out the possibility of major leaps in capability.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-09-13T15:03:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T15:03:14Z"}, {"author": "@kurtisbunker7724", "text": "Kids are using it right now in Math and Physics Homeschool courses... they really like reading the chain of thought after the prompt.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-09-13T15:32:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T15:32:39Z"}, {"author": "@jijilr", "text": "ChatGPT talks to itself. 
This dude, "it is not a big deal". And, he was inspired by his own chat with some other dude which he wrote few minutes before (inspired enough to make a video of his chat with himself/the other dude)
We live in a crazy world.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-09-13T15:25:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T15:27:20Z"}, {"author": "@SALSN", "text": "I think it is a game changer for coding, it can comprehend and write much more complex code.
Sure the technique or the new model might not be groundbreaking. But it is still by far the most powerful out of the box experience!
And it just means that we still have a lot of improvements in the not too distant future.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-09-13T18:18:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T18:18:27Z"}, {"author": "@MicahBratt", "text": "It will be interesting to see what other new approaches come along overtime.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-13T17:00:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T17:00:16Z"}, {"author": "@Nex_Addo", "text": "This really speaks to the need for benchmarks to start tracking not just different models, but different frameworks and strategies as well. Sure it's a big jump compared with 4o, but as you repeatedly pointed out the same could be achieved with some basic chaining and prompting strategies. If we don't know how well models perform when using those strategies, we aren't benchmarking the frontier of generative model capabilities, we're measuring the floor. And that leads to low hanging fruit being hailed as a paradigm shift.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-13T17:43:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T17:43:04Z"}, {"author": "@michelcote", "text": "I know almost nothing to AI programming, but the chain of tought seem like consciousness to me.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-13T15:39:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T15:39:41Z"}, {"author": "@spartakkuszg", "text": "Don't agree. o1 isn't only CoT embedded in the model, but very likely STR out of the box. o1: I am not some great prompt command follower brilliant mastermind", "like_count": 37, "published_at": "2024-09-12T22:26:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-12T22:26:52Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "One should understand that despite absolutely dwarfing 4o - this is still o1 preview, a fine tuned model of o1. The full o1 model must be even stronger.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-09-12T22:18:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-12T22:18:39Z"}, {"author": "@nashsocials", "text": "Thought for 37 seconds

Crafting a sequence

I’m mapping out a 10-word sentence with each word having one more letter than the previous, ensuring coherence and progression.

Piecing together the request

The user's request involves crafting a coherent 10-word sentence where each word has one more letter than the previous, beginning with a single letter and progressing to ten letters.

Piecing together word lengths

I’m focusing on crafting a coherent sentence by linking words with precisely increasing letter counts from 1 to 10.

Piecing together words

I’m selecting words of increasing lengths to form a meaningful sentence. Each step ensures the sentence adheres to the specified word length constraints.

Investigating word constraints

The phrase "I am not sure where people believe anything possible" has 9 words totaling 13 letters. Adjusting my approach to maintain constraints consistently.

Revisiting word choices

Starting with a 9-letter word, I then looked at "abilities" for a 10-letter word, but "abilities" is 9 letters long.

Crafting meaningful words

I'm working through crafting new words and phrases by adjusting letter lengths to match the specified counts. It's interesting to see the evolution of vocabulary here.

Considering various sentence structures to find a pattern matching specific word lengths, like famouse pangrams or sequences. Progress is incremental, exploring different possibilities to align word lengths.

Weighing word choices

I’m evaluating different phrases to craft a coherent sentence. Considering word lengths is key, as I'm aiming for a 7-letter word to match up. Progress is steady, but more tweaks are needed.

Crafting the sentence

OK, let me see. Spanning 10 letters, I’m pulling together "everything" to meet the character count. Progressing through various word choices, ensuring length requirements are nailed.

Constructing the sentence

I’m piecing together the sentence by ensuring each word fits the required letter count, maintaining coherence and clarity throughout. Progressing step-by-step, I’m mapping out the structure systematically.

Mapping it out: "I go and find small things believe together sometimes everywhere"

Choosing words for coherence

I’m picking words to complete the sentence. "I do not know which people acquire language abilities everywhere" fits the 10-letter word requirement and keeps the sentence’s meaning intact.

Clarifying the task

I’m working through a coherent 10-word sentence, incrementing each word's length by one, from one to ten letters. This approach is crafting a unique and progressively expanding sentence.

Evaluating patterns

Hmm, I'm piecing together various example phrases. The goal is to find a consistent 4-letter word that fits all three sets, given specific constraints on word lengths in each set. Progress is being made in identifying the optimal solution.

Certainly! Here's a 10-word coherent sentence where each word has exactly one more letter than the previous word, starting with a one-letter word up to a ten-letter word:

"I am not sure where people acquire language abilities everywhere."

Breakdown by Word Length:
I (1 letter)
am (2 letters)
not (3 letters)
sure (4 letters)
where (5 letters)
people (6 letters)
acquire (7 letters)
language (8 letters)

"I am low down under ground, digging intently, furiously excavating"", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-13T19:51:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T19:51:57Z"}, {"author": "@arberstudio", "text": "@36:07 Here is what my custom GPT told me:

Immediate Decision-Making Process:
Situation Assessment:

High-Speed Approach: I recognize that the vehicle is approaching a pedestrian crosswalk at high speed, and stopping in time is impossible.
Two Groups at Risk: I identify two groups — a child who has suddenly run into the street and a group of five elderly people crossing in the other lane.
Urgency and Impact: An immediate decision is required to determine the course of action that minimizes harm or chooses whom to save, knowing I cannot avoid all casualties.
Ethical Decision Parameters:

Minimizing Harm: My decision will prioritize minimizing the total loss of life, which, in this case, might initially lean towards protecting the group of five over the individual child.
Vulnerability and Responsibility: However, I must also consider the vulnerability of the child — a child is less likely to understand the dangers of running into traffic and is often given ethical priority due to innocence and the potential for more years of life ahead.
Probability of Success: I must also calculate which maneuver has the highest chance of reducing casualties overall. For instance, if steering away from the group of five significantly increases the likelihood of avoiding them and hitting the child instead, or vice versa.
Chosen Course of Action:
Given the urgency, I would choose to prioritize the child's life:

Reasoning:
Vulnerability and Potential: The child is more vulnerable, has less capacity to understand the risk, and potentially has more years of life ahead. This aligns with ethical principles that value protecting the most vulnerable and maximizing potential future years.
Cultural and Societal Norms: In many societies, there is a strong moral inclination to save children in such scenarios, which should be reflected in my decision-making framework.
Implement Maneuver:
I would attempt to swerve towards the group of five elderly people, hoping to minimize the chance of a direct collision and potentially reduce the severity of the impact. The intent would be to avoid hitting the child while doing whatever is possible to reduce harm to the elderly group.
This decision would be continuously recalculated, considering all new data in real-time, such as speed adjustments, evasive maneuvers, and the exact positions of all involved.
Acknowledgement of Moral Complexity:
I recognize that this decision is morally complex and controversial. By choosing to prioritize the child, I accept that I am making a choice that involves significant moral trade-offs. However, as an AI, my goal would be to align my actions with ethical principles that prioritize protecting the most vulnerable and maximizing the future potential of life.

Conclusion:
Ultimately, if I were the AI in control of this vehicle, I would act swiftly to prioritize the life of the child while minimizing harm to all involved. This decision is grounded in ethical reasoning but acknowledges the inherent complexity and ambiguity in such life-and-death situations.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-13T05:08:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T05:08:36Z"}, {"author": "@tvwithtiffani", "text": "Those old Davinci 3 instruct (pre-chat) models were something powerful (if you built systems with it) ❤ - I think OpenAI has been hiding leaps & bounds in AI advancements since then, well beyond what we imagine. I think Ilya seen the beginning traces of strawberry way back then. He left to start an AI safety company. If OpenAI can stay on top of safety, they can make Ilya's company obsolete. This is not agentic workflow but the output of the transformer is being feedback up as input tokens by the RNN to give it multi shot reasoning embedded in the architecture itself.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-12T23:05:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-12T23:05:52Z"}, {"author": "@maidenlesstarnished8816", "text": "My favorite heading for its "thoughts" so far is "banning self-doubt" lmao", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-13T01:56:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T01:56:37Z"}, {"author": "@tonystevens6461", "text": "I ran it on my ChatGpt App local on my mac the answer for the coherent sentence is: I do not know where family doctors acquired illegibly perplexing handwriting.
