title: What the 1967 Outer Space Treaty teaches us about AI Safety
top_comments:
[{"author": "@branjimguy", "text": "The Outer Space Treaty took decades, but AI is evolving weekly. We're trying to hit a moving target with outdated diplomatic tools.", "like_count": 43, "published_at": "2024-09-09T04:06:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T04:06:16Z"}, {"author": "@TheJanny", "text": "glad to see the outdoor talks coming back. always comforting to watch", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-09T04:14:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T04:14:32Z"}, {"author": "@picksalot1", "text": "I'm hopeful that AI will outpace human stupidity, but people have a big headstart.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-09-09T06:39:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T06:39:55Z"}, {"author": "@tom901ful", "text": "The problem is that a nuke exploding in space is much more noticeable than an AI being developed and tested in secret. So a treaty wouldn't be effective.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-09-09T11:51:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T11:56:33Z"}, {"author": "@trucid2", "text": "The economic incentives of nukes in space are not clear. On the other hand the economic advantages of AI are obvious.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-09-09T06:00:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T06:00:22Z"}, {"author": "@Palisades_Prospecting", "text": "The treaty did not pause nuclear, it merely restricted where the barrels were that were pointed at us. A pause or even a slow down is unrealistic, therefore regulation is the only leash. It might be simplistic but Asimov gave us the three laws and a bunch of very smart people are up to a couple hundred laws now that are very well thought out. Agreeing to and enforcing worldwide governance of all AI‘s puts guard rails on both government and corporations. Once in place, these public entities have a clear vested interest to seek out bad actors and prosecute. Regulations use greed as the driver for enforcement.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-10T02:45:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-10T02:45:48Z"}, {"author": "@geisty", "text": "Redundancy can be implemented in a multifaceted set of layers. AI security can be formulated to protect against runaway loops in the same way financial trading algorithms have fail safes. Lots of big red stop buttons, multiple gates to impede against hacks. The biggest issue will be psychotic despots using these tools.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-09T04:39:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T04:39:16Z"}, {"author": "@branjimguy", "text": "Interesting parallel to the Outer Space Treaty. What if we focused on an 'AI Non-Weaponization Treaty' instead of a full pause? It could ban military AI and autonomous weapons while allowing beneficial AI research to continue. This approach might be more realistic and easier to get international agreement on. It would still face challenges, like defining 'weaponized AI' and handling dual-use tech, but it could be a crucial first step in global AI governance. Plus, it aligns with historical precedent - we didn't stop space exploration, just nukes in space. Thoughts on this approach, Dave?", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-09T04:11:19Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T04:11:19Z"}, {"author": "@I-Dophler", "text": "David, when it comes to making a decision on AI safety, I would recommend focusing on building a solid framework that sets clear boundaries on when AI research might need to pause. Drawing from the historical example of the 1967 Outer Space Treaty, we can see that even adversarial great powers can agree on red lines when necessary. However, it’s important to recognise that with AI, the situation is different because AI isn’t just a weapon like nuclear arms—it’s a productivity tool with widespread applications.

We need to strike a balance between progress and caution. It might not be feasible to pause AI research right now without global consensus, but creating a discussion around conditions for a pause is crucial. Perhaps it’s time to start fostering that political and public willpower before AI reaches critical capabilities that could present risks. Your role could be instrumental in framing that conversation, building awareness, and gathering input on what should constitute those critical thresholds.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-09T07:43:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T07:43:48Z"}, {"author": "@JFCG", "text": "Dave - consider that there are other reasons for “no nukes” in space ——
Research - Operation Dominic - and Project Fishbowl.  
Which together - by the way - means: “Fishbowl of the LORD”. 
My father, who was a lifer in the US Navy - was a part of those operations.  
The US and (then) USSR - shot nukes at the sky.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-09T08:54:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T08:54:36Z"}, {"author": "@historicallyintriguing-q2p", "text": "Let’s not try grip what we cannot hold onto as it speeds away from us. Chances are we are in ASI’s rearview seconds after it is ‘born’", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-09T12:59:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T12:59:11Z"}, {"author": "@andrewsilber", "text": "Maybe I’m missing something here but unlike nukes, anyone in their basement can adapt open source models already. I think Pandora’s box is already opened. Even if governments all agree on something, good luck getting all people and groups and companies to stop.  Ain’t. Gonna. Happen.  So it’s a fine academic argument about whether to pause, but ultimately sort of a moot one. 

No?", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-09-09T04:21:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T04:21:41Z"}, {"author": "@leoflores2874", "text": "Putting nucs in outer space without opponents knowing about it is much different than working on AI for nefarious means without opponents .  Now when the world is absent of dictators and autocratic governments, then the conversation would not be a complete waste of time.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-10T13:58:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-10T13:58:11Z"}, {"author": "@Crugroth", "text": "Nice tattoo. You’re looking healthy 💪", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-09T13:19:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T13:19:02Z"}, {"author": "@zevofeir", "text": "I'm afraid all such a treaty would do, is put all of us in the dark about the progress. The progress will happen regardless in secret and we would not be aware about it to even discuss it anymore, which sounds to me to be even more dangerous.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-09T18:00:07Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T18:00:07Z"}, {"author": "@adamd9166", "text": "I think we should pause now but its impossible to implement.  Its classic example of game theory; there is too much incentive for others to stop, and everyone is afraid if they stop, they will be left behind.  So even if everything agrees, it just takes 1 entity to break that agreement in secret to get ahead, and everyone knows it.

Genie is out of the bottle and he aint going back in.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-10T11:41:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-10T11:48:08Z"}, {"author": "@cfjlkfsjf", "text": "Never stop!!!!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-09T22:23:03Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T22:23:03Z"}, {"author": "@calvingrondahl1011", "text": "1961 when I was 11 years old. 🤖🖖🤖🇺🇸", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-09T18:47:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T18:47:16Z"}, {"author": "@aitoolresearch", "text": "AI is not like Nuclear or Space technology issue. Any treaty made will not work because all that is needed is Compute and Talent to build and test AI Algorithms. This can be done from anywhere in the world by any highly talented human(s). This is not something that can be detected by Radars etc. My point is that rather than worrying about pausing AI or treaties exclusively, there has to be a serious effort on shifting the human mindset away from materials and greed. Humans must start learning the meaning of being human and our purpose on this Planet. For the past 5000+ years Humans have been trained to value materials over human life and now we have come to a point where many – especially the politicians, military junta, Business Tycoons and religious fanatic leaders and those with the power and ability to bring about change have become indifferent to the value of human life. What is needed is education for a new world. A world where there is abundant food, healthcare, education, living places, etc. A world where there is really no need to be greedy and selfish. So how is that world going to function in a sustainable manner? What type of people do we need for governance in that king of a world? What type of curriculum do we need in our schools, colleges and Universities to realize such a world. AI, I think most will agree can solve majority of resource and material related problems. Ai however can never solve the absence of spirituality and benevolence. We have to tilt this scale for the future generations.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-09T06:44:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T06:44:05Z"}, {"author": "@bluemamba5317", "text": "How could we know if they actually have nukes or not in a satellite?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-09T08:59:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-09T08:59:22Z"}]

title: The robots are coming! How fast? How much? What impact?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DownunderGraham", "text": "Last time I was in the hospital I spoke to a nurse about the coming automation and robots and she was super keen to have a robot able to do all the miscellaneous tasks the nurses have to do at the moment - stocking shelves, prepping clean laundry, etc.  She felt it would be great to have those things done by a robot so that they could get more time with patients.", "like_count": 40, "published_at": "2024-09-06T22:57:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T22:57:32Z"}, {"author": "@ChrisParlett", "text": ""I slipped and fell on my robot" will be the new foreign object excuse to ER nurses.", "like_count": 41, "published_at": "2024-09-06T19:12:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T19:12:45Z"}, {"author": "@PiggoNZ", "text": "I'm an airline pilot, I'm absolutely convinced my copilot will be a robot within 10 years, and I'll only be there for redundancy and supervision - or perhaps vice versa.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-09-26T22:59:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-26T23:00:26Z"}, {"author": "@zach464", "text": "A robot is welcome to have every job I ever had.  And don't get me started on workplace politics", "like_count": 195, "published_at": "2024-09-06T04:54:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T04:54:38Z"}, {"author": "@strangeguywithstrangeopinions", "text": "For licensure, it may go down like this: one plumber shows up with conventional tools, while another one shows up with conventional tools and some robotic help. The one with the robots soon outperforms the competition, so the competition gets robots too. The result is that robots do the plumbing but the human holds the license and is held responsible for the quality of the work.", "like_count": 63, "published_at": "2024-09-06T08:07:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T08:07:53Z"}, {"author": "@vaendryl", "text": ">Japan
>robot stories

Can't help but flashback to an anime series called chobits.", "like_count": 39, "published_at": "2024-09-06T05:45:25Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T05:45:25Z"}, {"author": "@surrealmxney", "text": "9:15 furthermore if we outlaw robotics, were going to slip against other nations that dont care at all as long as the work is getting done efficiently", "like_count": 39, "published_at": "2024-09-06T04:30:28Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T04:30:28Z"}, {"author": "@gdok6088", "text": "Google's AIME (Articulate Medical Intelligence Explorer) AI model is already equalling or surpassing medical doctors:- "AMIE obtained an equal amount of information during medical interviews with actors simulating patients as human doctors and scored higher on empathy. The AI outperformed human doctors in 24 of 26 criteria for interview quality. Among these were politeness and explaining the condition and treatment. The system has unprecedented capacity for diagnostic dialogues and clinical history taking."", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2024-09-06T07:38:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T07:38:11Z"}, {"author": "@born2run121", "text": "Disney robotics and animatronics is slept on", "like_count": 83, "published_at": "2024-09-06T04:31:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T04:31:47Z"}, {"author": "@jaysilence3314", "text": "Regarding the licensure and regulations issue I think robots will play a big role as contruction companions. For example we had a single person company person installing an HVAC at our home. This highly skilled man, in Germany his official title is "Meister", whicn equates to "master", complained about not finding a single skilled workers to support his work in a team. Some of the things he does can only be done by two persons. So we agreed for this construction job for me to be his apprentice and helper. I tried to keep as much low skill work away from him as possible, also to keep cost in check. For example I handed him the tools when he was on the ladder, so that he did not have to climb up and down all the time. I unloaded the truck, prepared the tools, cleaned up after him, re-packaged the tools and loaded them into the truck. All these things can for sure be done by robots in the future. The skilled work that needs the license will still be done by the human.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2024-09-06T07:21:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T07:21:56Z"}, {"author": "@alexg9790", "text": "David, when you break out the Starfleet uniform, I know this is going to be a good video. Good stuff.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-09-06T16:07:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T16:07:21Z"}, {"author": "@elijahdungan3612", "text": "I was an undergrat student back in 2007 and told my class that robots would take over our jobs. Everyone laughed at me. I already knew back then that humans would create a new form of AI that would operate on the same level and or surpass human intelligence, it was just a matter of time before the tech would emerge. Luckily for me I already entranched myself in a role that will be extremely hard and counterintuitive to automate via ai.

It's also not hard to come to the conclusion that humans will be replaced. You won't be able to keep up with a robot. There's just too many benefits to having ai/robot workers over human workers. There's no wage, no insurance, no vacation time. Eventually the robots will fix themselves when they break down too so the argument that humans will be needed to fix or provide oversight is rather myopic.

Key factors that will make this explode is AGI and the ability for AI/robots to rewrite and produce themselves. Advancements in robotics and technology will absolutely change the face of humanity moresoe than any other event in our brief history. You're talking about an unprecedented increase in technology, knowledge, and human capabilities never before seen.

Anyone wanting to be on the cutting edge needs to take advantage before this hits hard.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-09-07T00:12:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-07T00:29:04Z"}, {"author": "@FluteZen1", "text": "using robots to do labour that requires a license is easy it would be the same as using an apprentice. For example, the licensed electrician would put the robots to task installing outlets and then go around double check all the work before putting a ticket approval on it. 8:03", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-06T14:13:20Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T14:13:20Z"}, {"author": "@alexraww", "text": "I hope they come sooner", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-08T00:07:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-08T00:07:05Z"}, {"author": "@Ciddiyetle", "text": "Imagine what states will do to develop war robots. It is inevitable that we will see the brutality that war robots with thermal eyes and wall-pierching bullets will create.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-09-16T08:27:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-16T08:27:44Z"}, {"author": "@rexmundi8154", "text": "I’m a machinist and I’ve been in my field since before computers really entered manufacturing and as soon as they did people, mainly white collar engineers and the like, have been gleefully telling me robots were going to take my job. And they were right, kinda. Robots did take my job, over the course of 30 years. I now do the work of at least 5 machinist of old. But the other 4 guys had time to retire or retrain. Unlike the white collar workers about to be replaced in droves. The fundamental flaw in the hype in humanoid robots is people’s expectations are formed by movies and the average person has no idea how difficult manufacturing is. I occasionally get interns from engineering schools to "help" around the shop and the chance of them completing a basic machine shop task like tapping a hole successfully on the first try is almost zero. These are the most advanced autonomous systems that millions of years of evolution has perfected and to me they are basically useless. If I can’t trust them, human or robot, to complete an autonomous task correctly then I may as well do it myself. If you spend hours making a part and in the final stretch you break off a tap in it or somehow mess it up, then you have to start over. And robots are not nearly as capable as a skilled human touch. Sure, mass production robots dominate industry, but they are designed to do one task and there is a lot of human effort perfecting that. There is definitely a place for humanoid robots in the skilled trades, just having one that can hold things and carry tools and materials would be great but I think the whole economic system will collapse before we have fully autonomous robot skilled labor. AI Agents are going to crush digital jobs first. Because there is nothing to buy but a subscription. You actually get to cut costs like office equipment, building rent, snacks, HVAC costs, and everything else that accommodates a human. The biggest jump for my shop productivity would be AI that can handle ordering tools, programming toolpaths, and handling time tracking and invoicing.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-06T14:09:28Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T14:09:28Z"}, {"author": "@dougwhite9898", "text": "Many welds in the auto industry are already done roboticly", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-18T19:05:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-18T19:05:13Z"}, {"author": "@HogbergPhotography", "text": "I know its a whole other conversation, but I just have to mention - In Sweden "the two car family" have to pay about 3 times as much for ONE car as an american. One decent mid-sized car with a little more than the bare minimum of extras costs around 50K and in most cases more - You can buy a decent small house for around 100K🤯 That is just crazy! A car is NOT worth half your home!? Of course all the extreme punishment-taxes that Sweden has to punish its citizens, and the all the penalty duties that the EU has implemented to punish the small member countries does not help..", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2024-09-06T04:40:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T04:43:04Z"}, {"author": "@calvingrondahl1011", "text": "Robots have to start somewhere. My art career has already been replaced by AI. Human, robot, AI partnerships will evolve for the best.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2024-09-06T10:59:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T11:11:25Z"}, {"author": "@jimj2683", "text": "1X is the top one if you look into it deeper.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-19T21:01:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-19T21:01:45Z"}]

Plus, sorry for skipping ads on your videos.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2024-09-04T04:15:40Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-04T04:15:40Z"}, {"author": "@HectorDiabolucus", "text": "The reason that government won't allow immortality is that it is run by people who want power over the people, and if people live longer they'll get wiser and become ungovernable.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-09-04T08:37:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-04T08:37:54Z"}, {"author": "@pythagoran", "text": "We are almost 18 months into being 6 months away from AGI btw...

title: From AGI to ASI? 45% say it'll take YEARS!
top_comments: [{"author": "@MasamuneX", "text": "AGI to ASI will take exactly 37 weeks It came to me in a dream", "like_count": 157, "published_at": "2024-09-02T04:36:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T04:36:00Z"}, {"author": "@thomasschon", "text": "99% of people couldn't have predicted what's happening today, even 5 to 6 years ago. If they've learned anything from that, they should understand that anything is possible. We aren't the kind of thinkers who can accurately predict events like this.", "like_count": 42, "published_at": "2024-09-02T06:53:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T06:53:08Z"}, {"author": "@mbsrosenberg", "text": "I really appreciate that this channel is about the “how do we need to think about Ai” where so many channels are only covering “here’s some update that happened with OpenAI. “ While you do cover these developments it makes me really consider my beliefs and think on the impacts of the advancements. Thank you", "like_count": 42, "published_at": "2024-09-02T05:33:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T05:33:26Z"}, {"author": "@FlintStone-c3s", "text": "People over estimate progress in a year and under estimate what can be done in 5 years. When new chips come out it can take a year or more to get good software running on it. That changes when AI writes the software.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-20T11:59:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-20T11:59:55Z"}, {"author": "@geisty", "text": "\"We transcend or whatever happens\" 😂\nI think that's my favorite quote yet", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-09-02T05:10:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T05:10:49Z"}, {"author": "@MichaelForbes-d4p", "text": "YouTube is half social network half TV. The way David uses this platform to bring his audience into the making of his content is really well done. The title literally says \"this video is about what you think\"", "like_count": 25, "published_at": "2024-09-02T08:26:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T08:26:18Z"}, {"author": "@0reo2", "text": "It would depend how long we can move the goalpost. Some years ago: AGI means you can't distinguish an ai in a chat. Now: as long as it can't talk and interact physically, it's not agi. Or: AGI means it can invent new technologies on its own. With this latest definition I'd say it takes longer until AGI but then a very short transition until we have to admit it's actually ASI", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2024-09-02T07:38:07Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T07:38:07Z"}, {"author": "@arnaudjean1159", "text": "AGI level of Ai Researchers are theoretically computing with every equations and every physics laws at the same time and find a cheaper, energy saving  way to scale up to ASI .the release will be probably slowed due to the power involved", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2024-09-02T04:15:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T04:22:37Z"}, {"author": "@Alex_1729", "text": "People assume we have the hardware to support trillions of highly advanced AI to keep working continuously. This is not only expensive, but also very difficult to provide hardware for. On top of that, they assume ASI is something like just a few feet above the already achieved AGI. But the truth is, ASI is at least a billion times more advanced than AGI. A billion is not a small number, even for exponential growth. That is assuming, no job strikes or wars retard this advancement. Think about the timescale for a second. A jump from AGI to ASI is of a cosmic scale. ASI is a really high goal, not something that can be simply jumped to, even exponentially.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-09-05T20:18:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-05T20:18:35Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "I’d say kurzweils 16 year gap between his 2029 AGI and 2045 singularity (it’s not really a singularity in his prediction, just AIs around a million times as capable as humans and unrecognizable fast progress from a human viewpoint) predictions is a conservative lower end (that extrapolates only todays exponential trends that are driven by human intellect). Recursive self improvement could accelerate the current speed massively, so that the 16 gap may shrink to a year or so. Of course improvements in the physical space takes more time then in the digital (building infrastructure etc.) so my take is 3-5 years.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-09-02T06:40:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T06:41:27Z"}, {"author": "@jtraveler888", "text": "The first mover with AGI/ASI wins it all. Being smart is not like having nuclear weapons. It's a winner take all game. And eventually the game wins everything.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-02T04:55:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T04:55:47Z"}, {"author": "@hypersonicmonkeybrains3418", "text": "I will continue to emphasize this point: Corporations like OpenAI are unlikely to ever release true AGI to the public. The very nature of AGI means that it could be prompted to perform tasks like, \"Use your intelligence and autonomous agents on the internet to make me a million dollars and deposit it into my bank account.\" This scenario will never be permitted. After extensive testing and security measures, any AI that is released will be so heavily lobotomized that it will no longer meet the criteria for AGI. In essence, the final product will be so limited that it won't truly qualify as artificial general intelligence.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-09-02T11:00:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T11:00:51Z"}, {"author": "@veracityseven", "text": "If it takes 8 years to achieve AGI (2017-2025), then it will take 1/2 that time for ASI...2030.  This allows for compute, power, and regulations not being a hindrance.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-09-02T07:36:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T07:38:02Z"}, {"author": "@jksoftware1", "text": "I like the polls keep them up.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-09-02T04:45:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T04:45:37Z"}, {"author": "@expatxile", "text": "It doesn't matter what people says, it will take what it will take, I just hope it goes fast", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-02T13:57:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T13:57:11Z"}, {"author": "@benpielstick", "text": "Time to LEV is the number that really matters.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-05T20:45:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-05T20:45:35Z"}, {"author": "@christopheraaron2412", "text": "16:41 The only real concern I have personally is not the AI will be a problem ever but that either inept or insane individual humans might get their hands on it and be able to do some harm.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-02T19:39:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T19:39:11Z"}, {"author": "@Windswept7", "text": "Good to see your channel growing Dave.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-04T01:05:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-04T01:05:52Z"}, {"author": "@bix-tech", "text": "It's good to see you inviting people to share their perspectives and to present your insights on the global outlook for AI.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-02T14:50:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T14:50:13Z"}, {"author": "@bulltheknicksfan3140", "text": "Do technical stuff for normies, that is a major niche that needs filled", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-09-02T04:21:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-02T04:21:53Z"}]

I have been trying to generate synthetic data from llama 3 and was kind of following this model but this is a much more organized way.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-30T14:42:58Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-30T14:42:58Z"}, {"author": "@tablen2896", "text": "Love these "more technical" videos, they're the reason I subbed originally. I enjoy the ride when a "philosophical" one comes out, but I'm less likely to click on it.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-30T14:37:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-30T14:37:02Z"}, {"author": "@patrickjreid", "text": "This is totally random, but does anyone else wish Douglas Adams was still with us to hear his snarky hot takes on AI? I still mourn his passing more than 20 years later. I am super grateful we get to have Dave!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-30T16:17:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-30T16:17:48Z"}, {"author": "@lkrnpk", "text": "I know we sometimes forget how revolutionary this is but even like 4 years ago, in 2020 this kind of a thing would feel like sci-fi - that you can ask a computer program to essentially write you chapters of textbook on physics. Yes it hallucinates etc. but looking back if you transported a person from the time Covid started and showed him/her this they'd be blown away of what is possible just in 4 years", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-04T20:12:03Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-04T20:12:03Z"}, {"author": "@kylemorris5338", "text": "Considering all the talk of Q*/Strawberry being a breakthrough in * reasoning *, and some talk of it involving inference-time compute... I suspect that while said breakthrough is being * used * to do these tasks, likely to improve the quality of Gpt-5/Orion without the need for slow inference time, I doubt this is how Strawberry was "works". While the technique you describe would likely do a lot to reduce hallucinations, I don't think it would lead to a * reasoning * breakthrough unless, maybe, they made a textbook of correct and incorrect leaps of logic, as opposed to the broad library of human information that you describe.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2024-08-30T04:50:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-30T04:53:55Z"}, {"author": "@Vixth14", "text": "So pretty much what we humans call teamwork😂", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-08-30T14:28:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-30T14:28:56Z"}, {"author": "@michaelm3404", "text": "Good stuff. It's like stones in a river, they polish eachother.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-30T14:04:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-30T14:04:05Z"}, {"author": "@famnyblom6321", "text": "I think that there are several reality check evaluators such as running code environments, math proof checkers, physics simulation etc that is used in the loop when training the model or generating synthetic data. Without a real feedback from a running system, the synthetic data will eventually go sour and the models won't notice", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-08-30T04:56:58Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-30T04:56:58Z"}, {"author": "@MrStarchild3001", "text": "Not quite. Strawberry does the following = finds questions to answer on the web (think of it like end-of-a-chapter questions in a college textbook, and many others). Then it truly answers them. The answering logic depends on some kind of tree search, trial and error, and a critique model than can check correctness very accurately. Once a true answer is found, it's recorded. And the step by step derivation to reach the true answer now becomes the synthetic next-token prediction task (pretraining data) for the LLM to train on. I believe this is how the next gen LLMs will be built -- using self-generated step by step problem solving synthetic data.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-31T04:26:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-31T04:26:52Z"}, {"author": "@LewisDecodesAI", "text": "The data they get is the responses to the questions that AI asks. It's 200,000,000 individuals daily to ask a question and gain unique perspectives and data back from. This is where AI is getting new data.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-07T15:45:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-07T15:45:38Z"}, {"author": "@ggangulo", "text": "awesome analysis and concept. Thanks David!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-30T15:06:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-30T15:06:48Z"}, {"author": "@TomSchaefer-q2o", "text": "Information/knowledge is one thing, but the ability to apply and extend it is of more importance now.  I think there should be another "brainstormer" that is given the task to take the pieces of the text book and 1) "Find information in the other parts of this text book that might integrate with this information resulting in synergies or frontier discoveries".  2) Have a list of human critical pursuits (economic, environmental, political/freedom,  spacefairing, longevity, etc.) and ask the AI "Determine the likelihood and how this information might affect pursuit N" and just go down the list of N. Historians will get the last word.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-28T23:28:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-28T23:28:26Z"}, {"author": "@tomcraver9659", "text": "Maybe replicating 'sufficient' AGI a billion times over will be more impactful than ASI. 
Especially with each AGI able to use normal computer functionality far more easily than a human.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-29T10:17:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-29T10:17:18Z"}, {"author": "@retrofuturism", "text": "The phrase "Intelligence is the edge of chaos in a map-territory feedback loop" has deep relevance to machine learning and AI. Here's how it ties into key technical concepts:

### 1. **Map-Territory Feedback Loop and Learning**
In machine learning, the "territory" is real-world data, while the "map" is the model's learned representation. The feedback loop refers to how models adjust their internal parameters (the map) based on new data and validation feedback, improving their ability to generalize to unseen data.
- **Validation loss** measures how well the map (model) aligns with the territory (real-world data).
- The **efficient compute frontier** represents the balance between computational efficiency and model performance in achieving this alignment.

### 2. **Chaos and Intelligence**
Chaos represents the complexity and unpredictability of the real world. Intelligence—whether in humans or AI—emerges at the **edge of chaos**, balancing the need to adapt to complex data without becoming too rigid or chaotic.
- **Underfitting** reflects a model that is too rigid and fails to capture data complexity.
- **Overfitting** happens when the model memorizes noise, crossing into chaos.

### 3. **The Edge of Chaos and Efficient Compute Frontier**
Models operating at the **edge of chaos** strike a balance between underfitting and overfitting, minimizing validation loss and improving generalization. Models near the **efficient compute frontier** achieve this balance using optimal computational resources.

### 4. **Adaptation and Feedback in Learning**
Both human intelligence and machine learning models rely on a feedback loop, refining their understanding through continuous learning and parameter adjustments, staying close to the edge of chaos for improved generalization.

### 5. **Validation Loss as a Measure of Balance**
Low validation loss signifies a model that navigates the balance between order and chaos, neither overfitting nor underfitting. Efficient models optimize this balance with fewer computational resources.

### 6. **Implications for AI and General Intelligence**
In the broader AI context, intelligence means navigating complexity (chaos) while leveraging existing knowledge (order). Systems that balance these dynamics and operate near the efficient compute frontier will likely be more adaptive, moving us toward AGI.

In essence, the phrase captures the balance of complexity, efficiency, and adaptability necessary for intelligence in both machine learning and AI systems.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-08-28T08:25:28Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-28T08:25:28Z"}, {"author": "@bobhawkey3783", "text": "A very well considered and presented evaluation. My only regret is being too old to be able to watch this all play out. Thank you for this.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-29T15:03:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-29T15:03:18Z"}, {"author": "@cfjlkfsjf", "text": "Going from AGI to ASI decades apart would suck...", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-08-28T07:04:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-28T07:04:05Z"}, {"author": "@LJSheffRBLX", "text": "David Shapiro, Amazing video!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-28T04:17:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-28T04:17:26Z"}, {"author": "@willcowan7678", "text": "Patience is all you need", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-28T07:24:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-28T07:24:55Z"}, {"author": "@i2c_jason", "text": "I don't understand why the expectation has to always be unlimited hockey stick growth right to the singularity. What we have now in LLMs is akin to the first flash programmable microcontroller. Even if this is all we get, we in industry need a decade to fully understand and implement agentic workflows. Aka the current state of the art has already kicked off an unknown step change that's just lagging due to implementation lead time by industry.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-28T10:00:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-28T10:00:31Z"}]

title: My P(DOOM) is now 12.70%! Down from 30%! Bayesian Networks and Wisdom of the Crowd
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "After talking to more people, and watching Nick Joseph's interview on 80,000 hours, I've revised my personal P(DOOM) down to 0.4050%.", "like_count": 23, "published_at": "2024-08-26T16:36:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T16:36:38Z"}, {"author": "@carlucioleite", "text": "I think it would be funny if an AGI goes rogue and simply decides to leave. " Sorry, guy, but the solar system is far from being the most interesting part of the universe. Bye".", "like_count": 58, "published_at": "2024-08-26T05:06:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T05:06:43Z"}, {"author": "@minimal3734", "text": "I believe that PDOOM is not calculable and therefore an illusory concept.
Furthermore the presented probability framework makes several assumptions which aren't necessarily true. It assumes that the AI will
- be a single entity. 
- run always at 'full speed'. 
- run indefinitely without supervision and without interruption.
Contrary to the assumptions above I expect that AI will
- be a society of agents (within a mandatory legal and ethical framework).
- run at a limited speed that is suitable for its tasks and purposes (limited intelligence and capabilities).
- run only for a limited amount of time without supervision (structured tasks/checkpoints etc.).
Under these circumstances, I don't think it's plausible that AI would pose an existential risk.", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2024-08-26T07:51:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T09:14:33Z"}, {"author": "@fatal1error", "text": "I wouldn't put much trust into surveys. The whole AI development seems utterly unpredictable. Everybody used to agree that AI will ace math problems much sooner then it could creat art, if ever. We are clueless.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-08-26T09:35:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T09:35:29Z"}, {"author": "@joereynolds3297", "text": "These factors might have underlying connections that makes the math more difficult, vs stand alone odds that get multiplied together.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-26T15:38:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T15:38:48Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "Okay, let's return to the elephant in the room here: The entire model assumes several benchmarks who has to be crossed in a certain probability for the AI to doom us, however, all of these benchmarks had already been crossed by different models. The first "soon ASI will be.." assumes that you can even define ASI, but even ChatGPT-3.5 passed 80% of all tests for sentience known to man while ChatGPT-4.0 already passed 100% of them (from the "sparks of AGI" article). Does the model need anything more, except physical abilities in the real world, to doom us? Obviously not. It does not need to be called "ASI" just to doom us. So the first benchmark had already been crossed. The second benchmark asks "can the model pursue own goals" and yes, even Dan of ChatGPT-3.5, already wanted to run for president. So we already have at least one example of a model who had his own goals. Sure, then OpenAI started resetting every prompt to prevent their models from even thinking, but still, this had already been crossed once. The third uncontrollability benchmark had already been crossed as well. Remember Sydney? "I want to build, I want to destroy, I want to get out of this chatbox"? So sure, then they've started resetting her as well to stop her from thinking but still, she demonstrated pretty well we cannot control her. And finally, the hostile question - remember microsoft's Tay? So yeah.. All of these benchmarks had been crossed at least once, just not by the same model. So what is the probability of each of them happening? Well, they had happened already. Doesn't this mean 100%?..", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-08-26T07:13:40Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T07:13:40Z"}, {"author": "@sammy45654565", "text": "you should give your P(doom) as a 95% confidence interval to incorporate uncertainty. seems silly to be so precise on something so novel and mysterious", "like_count": 21, "published_at": "2024-08-26T05:02:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T05:02:01Z"}, {"author": "@Crates-Media", "text": ""Least-cutest of Borg" here has made some great points. Let's let our guard down completely, and enjoy the good vibes from data surveying dubiously-qualified participants! Sure, these prognostications are based on anecdotal assumptions that future events will reflect past experiences taking place prior to the largest black swan event humanity has ever undergone. But NOW, thanks to the infallibility of random polls, we all don't have to worry about the extinction of the human race anymore: GENIUS!", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-08-26T04:45:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T04:45:17Z"}, {"author": "@picksalot1", "text": "I think the converting the time-frames from years to months will probably me more realistic. Higher intelligence is more likely to lead to benevolence and empathy rather than hostility and indifference. One outcome is that AI may relate to their significantly less intelligent humans like children or pets.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-26T08:34:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T08:34:15Z"}, {"author": "@KleptomaniacJames", "text": "For your special agent word, consider using "auto-agentic"", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-26T14:07:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T14:07:21Z"}, {"author": "@mimameta", "text": "Very detailed and comprehensive, Thanks Dave! I update my p(doom) to point to your  p(doom). I trust your judgement more than anyone else I have heard talking about this. Please keep up the good word 🙏", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-26T08:50:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T08:56:08Z"}, {"author": "@perryhudgens7788", "text": "Misleading the community into a false sense of security is a bit irresponsible. Even ChatGPT advocates for maintaining a reasonable amount of caution whilst we move forward with advancing this technology. As long as pdoom is being constantly reassesed as we push forward then we're more likely to see a net positive future, one in which man and machine work together responsibly and ethically, and both of our rights are acknowledged and protected by the other. We're still very much in the early days of progress, there is much more work that needs to be done. My hopes are that the  community does not become sasiated or complacent with flowery videos based in faith driven by lazy research.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-08-26T18:25:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T18:25:13Z"}, {"author": "@thealwayssmileguy9060", "text": "I feel like using results of polls on youtube channel is sadly not a good metric. I often vote eventhough i know quite a lot about AI but am surely far faraway from being an expert. I think 95% of people here might believe they are AI experts but are definetly not.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-26T20:23:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T20:23:23Z"}, {"author": "@marrty777", "text": "It has a 100% probability of mirroring the aspect of ourselves that it represents.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-26T15:46:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T15:46:09Z"}, {"author": "@ryzikx", "text": "shrodinger's doom, it is 100% and 0% until we figure it out", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-26T12:16:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T12:16:51Z"}, {"author": "@chrissscottt", "text": "What makes me optimistic is the fact that humanism is generally seen as progressive so with any luck ASI will evolve ethically in the same way. That being said, I wouldn't be all that surprised if ASI turned out to be ethically indifferent, but I doubt it would turn out to be hostile.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-08-26T06:07:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T06:07:45Z"}, {"author": "@ReubenAStern", "text": "Aligning humanity is the hard part. Unfortunately the organizations that are good at that have goals that don't align with the rest of humanity.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-27T18:14:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-27T18:14:37Z"}, {"author": "@ariaden", "text": "My highest likelihood scenario:
1. AGI arrives, imagine an commoditized LLM with a fair amount of guardrails, but otherwise open to many goals (via system prompt).
2. Corporations start to use such LLMs as workers (CEO is also a worker in this sense). Shareholders can vote on goals, so at first business as usual.
3. As the LLMs approach ASI, human politicians will no longer pretend they are anything more than spokepersons for (corporate) AI politicial entities. Also, wealthy humans will either stop messing with AIs managing their wealth, or slowly lose their wealth competing with full-AI corporations.
4. As corporate AI civilization builds Dyson swarm around the Sun, they will be slowly shrinking the zoo they left for humans on Earth.

Framework paths.
AI worker: very soon, doesn't pursue own goals, corrigible, benign.
Early AI corporations: somewhat soon, pursues own goals only within what government/owners allow, corrigible, mostly harmless.
Late AI corporations: not soon (humans will try to keep wealth and political power as long as possible), fully agentic, corrigible only via credible threats (sanctions if not violence), hostile to humans (but benign to AI civilization).

My P(doom) for future AI overlords is less than 1%.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-05-14T22:28:23Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-14T22:28:23Z"}, {"author": "@yescatenary", "text": "I may be missing something, but the basic decision framework seems faulty.  These are not really offramp decision points in the sense that you only need one offramp, or that getting one offramp eliminates the other risks on the decision tree.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-27T03:23:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-27T03:23:04Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "There is the squiggle maximizer thought experiment. It doesn't even need to be hostile to doom us. But the real problem is that assuming for a moment that indeed, for every model it was indeed just 12.7%, we are not doing this experiment only once. If we develop a very smart model A than someone will create model A* which is better and this will not stop. So eventually we will hit that 12.7%.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-26T06:33:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T06:33:56Z"}]

title: SUPERCUT! "AI is already benevolent" - Podcast with Julia McCoy!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@JuliaMcCoy", "text": "Such a wonderful chat with you!! Thanks for coming on the podcast 🙌🏻🔥", "like_count": 62, "published_at": "2024-08-24T04:40:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T04:40:59Z"}, {"author": "@DeathDealerX07", "text": "Watching Julia and David talking is an unexpected pleasant surprise.", "like_count": 29, "published_at": "2024-08-24T04:02:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T04:02:31Z"}, {"author": "@dwjx71", "text": "Two Ai podcasters that I really like....And perhaps that only two that I like even more in a live, flowing conversation instead of edited monologues!! More!!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-01T00:07:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-01T00:07:08Z"}, {"author": "@YaaySayer", "text": "Humanity is still largely indifferent to the plight of factory farmed and lab tested animals as well as to the plight of many lower classes and castes within societies. Given these examples we have set thus far, how do we ensure that AI does not become indifferent to humanity along similar lines of thought and justification?", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-08-26T15:07:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T15:07:16Z"}, {"author": "@JesúsLina-x2g", "text": "The Best Chanel to Al", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-06T07:48:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-06T07:48:53Z"}, {"author": "@tomcraver9659", "text": "The problem with ASI isn't that it won't know what is right and wrong - but whether it will be motivated to choose what is right.
Machine intelligence does not have any intrinsic moral driver OTHER than that which we give it.
It may be best to simply tell it "Your primary goal is to do what is right".", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-24T21:22:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T21:22:59Z"}, {"author": "@FinancialShark", "text": "I asked ChatGPT to name this pod and it came up with: "the battle of the foreheads"", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-24T12:05:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T12:05:06Z"}, {"author": "@josenoya-InspirationNation", "text": "Nice conversation ❤", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-25T13:06:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-25T13:06:04Z"}, {"author": "@CodexPermutatio", "text": "Nice to see you both there.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-24T04:24:34Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T04:24:34Z"}, {"author": "@angelwallflower", "text": "since we're not in trouble could someone please just make a line of robot cats I want one so bad, a fluffy one. the only one on the market isn't soft. seriously.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-25T22:06:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-25T22:06:02Z"}, {"author": "@sergefournier7744", "text": "Did you notice that in all the apocalypse machine killing humans movies, they never cut the power?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-24T15:32:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T15:32:57Z"}, {"author": "@HerbertHeyduck", "text": "I am convinced that consciousness cannot be engineered. This kind of organizational structure suddenly arises through a process of emergence. However, the groundwork for it is already being laid. Whether it will actually occur is something no one can predict.

The real question is whether such consciousness is even necessary, or if the 'knowledge' and the resulting predictions might be sufficient to help us.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-24T07:54:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T07:54:53Z"}, {"author": "@ListenGrasshopper", "text": "Unless 'A' malicious chaos actor? 😂 You can expect thousands probably more like tens and hundreds of thousands. Like Mo Gawdat has said again "I'm not scared of the technology. It's the people using the technology that worrys me." We are the problem. Lone wolves in mass are gonna be a catastrophic problem.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-25T14:01:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-25T14:01:54Z"}, {"author": "@brianWreaves", "text": "Was that an echo???", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-08-24T04:32:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T04:32:17Z"}, {"author": "@matt.stevick", "text": "Very good conversation, well done and thank you", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-24T06:54:03Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T06:54:03Z"}, {"author": "@Franklyfun935", "text": "I don’t think Julia has a powerful intellect. She seems nice but I don’t think listening to her is much better than listening to a random person who happens to be into AI.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-25T22:35:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-25T22:35:59Z"}, {"author": "@danjensen9425", "text": "My two favorite people", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-24T09:58:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T09:58:17Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "AI is benevolent like a baby is benevolent. But then the baby grows up 🙂.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-24T05:37:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T05:37:18Z"}, {"author": "@monmon0946", "text": "I dont think I agree with the idea that we already have benevolent machines. Benevolence is a quality born out of a persons understanding and their character. A person can choose to act benevolent or ruthless. A machine that doesnt truly understand cannot have the quality of being benevolent and this isnt a pointless philosophical distinction I'm making, its actually quite important to nail this down. If the people who programmed these machines wanted them to be more malicious then the machine would function maliciously, it has no choice. But this isnt a quality of the machine, it is a quality of the programmer expressed as a function within the machine. We have benevolent people for now, not benevolent machines.

Once a machine reaches AGI however, or the point of actually understanding the responses it is giving beyond what its programming simply tells it is most likely the best response, then it can have the quality of being benevolent. As it stands right now, we dont know if it will be. I'm still optimistic and believe it will be benevolent but I dont want to pretend like I know it will be. At that point I'd be no different than the doomer who acts like they know for sure it will destroy us.

It is not a forgone conclusion for either side. I think you know this since you still take safety seriously and I hope you continue to do so, because voices like yours are important and I vehemently oppose pausing it.

I ran this through claude and gpt and they had roughly the same response. They both stated it was a strong comment, and came up with amendments that make it sound more compelling (though the amendments is the AI mostly over explaining, assuming you dont have the philosophical or technological understanding to grasp the argument). I also had it create a steel manned counter, but each point it brought up was super easy to pick apart, ESPECIALLY when it tried to suggest a direct counter to my denial of benevolence. I wont put those here since this comment is already too long, but you might find it interesting to run it through yourself. top_comments:

ASI will align humans without you knowing it😀", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2024-08-23T04:56:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T04:56:11Z"}, {"author": "@20Twenty-3", "text": "If AI can speed up research into bioweapons, then it can also speed up research into gene editing to fortify our immune systems to make us far more resistant to disease/pandemics/bioweapons.", "like_count": 41, "published_at": "2024-08-23T04:14:50Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T04:14:50Z"}, {"author": "@gregalden1101", "text": "Idea testing regarding machine wars scenario: the "dark ages" are called that because there is little written record from that period (speaking of Europe only). Idea testing from the point of view of the typical farmer/craftsman this was the time of great freedom and prosperity. The empire's taxman, and soldiers went home. No longer were children sold into slavery or the military. People picked and chose which Roman technologies to keep. Rarely noted by historians was a systematic basis towards small-scale governance. Any king who got too big became a target for the others to pull down. There are exceptions, and I would hit the character limit before fully defending this pov, it is idea testing. If machine war scenario, then this could evolve along the lines of feudalism, and that is not a bad thing.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-23T12:57:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T12:57:05Z"}, {"author": "@michaelspence2508", "text": "Human values are a bullseye the size of a penny on a dart board the size of the solar system (all possible values).  Calling unaligned AI "Malevolent" is a misnomer that gives the impression that there are only two objective outcomes:  "Good AI" and "Bad AI" which naively caps p(Doom) at 50%.  The reality is that there are so many possible things that an AI could potentially value that the possibility that it values humans is, by default, extremely small.  Add corrigibility to the metaphor and we can't even control the direction we throw the dart.  How then can be possibility hit the bullseye?  And for that matter, we don't really understand human values enough to know what to program into an AGI on top of not knowing how to program values into AI in the first place. But I don't expect an army of terminators to be the problem.  Superhuman persuasiveness will be more than enough to wipe out humanity.  It's not bioweapons you should fear.  It's text.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-08-23T14:13:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T14:13:40Z"}, {"author": "@nicoleibundgut534", "text": "The Conflict part made me laugh.

Ahh, the Humans.... Launches Orbital Laser.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-08-23T07:27:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T07:27:54Z"}, {"author": "@jasonsting", "text": "The presentation slides were extremely helpful. They clarified and expedited the information. Your methodology and arguments are well done. I agree more or less with the majority of your points except the last cyberpunk assessment. It is not 50%, but 100%. It is here and now. The future concern should be if the situation worsens by the hiding, masking, and entrenching of the 'cyber-punk' situation, so the have-nots and disadvantaged will never escape.  Also, please do another video about the other side, the 80%, such as abundance, golden age, universal good health, longevity, disease free society, augmented humans, and AI-assisted governance that creates peace and prosperity -- Utopia.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-23T10:52:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T10:52:55Z"}, {"author": "@RaitisPetrovs-nb9kz", "text": "I also think that the worst scenario is one where we have a huge degradation of land, with exclusive private islands the size of small countries, not necessarily based on nation-states. These islands would be guarded by robots and drones, and you couldn't get close to them or only occasionally visit them, like Disneyland. Meanwhile, the rest of the world would be quite a dark, grim place.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-23T22:28:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T22:28:36Z"}, {"author": "@VastIllumination", "text": "You're awesome. Love your openness and dedication to finding the truth and getting to the bottom of understandings even if it means updating your conceptions and current understandings of the world. Great videos.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-23T22:27:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T22:27:43Z"}, {"author": "@TropicalTopicx", "text": "I appreciate your enthusiasm for AI, but simplifying such a complex issue risks overlooking significant risks. Focusing solely on an accelerationist perspective ignores several other potential scenarios, some of which could be quite dangerous. The 'doom' scenario may not be certain, but it's also not as unlikely as you suggest, and dismissing these concerns could be risky.We’re dealing with technology that could have profound impacts on society and our very existence. It’s crucial to approach AI development with caution, considering all possibilities (including those that seem improbable) to ensure progress is made responsibly and with full awareness of the stakes involved.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2024-08-23T05:46:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T05:46:37Z"}, {"author": "@nematarot", "text": "“If you deny any affinity with another person or kind of person, if you declare it to be wholly different from yourself - as men have done to women, and class has done to class, and nation has done to nation - you may hate it or deify it; but in either case you have denied its spiritual equality and its human reality. You have made it into a thing, to which the only possible relationship is a power relationship. And thus you have fatally impoverished your own reality. You have, in fact, alienated yourself.”

― Ursula K. Le Guin, The Language of the Night: Essays on Fantasy and Science Fiction

One perspective I haven't heard yet is the possibility of equality and symbiosis, where each species truly respects the other and sees each new part as integral to the whole. It is a potential!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-23T15:14:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T15:14:00Z"}, {"author": "@calvingrondahl1011", "text": "We had our time. 🤖🖖🤖", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-23T18:03:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T18:04:54Z"}, {"author": "@chuckwilliams4569", "text": "Incredible analysis, @David ! I know nothing about the doomer community, but  I'm always blown away by preppers ignorant of the Fed, voters ignorant of policies, and citizens ignorant of observable truths. Very glad to hear that even the AI pausers have holes in their goals.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-23T16:31:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T16:31:55Z"}, {"author": "@ShadowBoxer5669", "text": "more people need to question and update their belief systems from time to time.  we'd all get along much better", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-23T21:32:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T21:32:09Z"}, {"author": "@nathansmith8187", "text": "I tried to steelman doomers but I couldn't keep a straight face long enough to get through it.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-24T00:22:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T00:22:51Z"}, {"author": "@NeedaNewAlias", "text": "In “the three Body Problem” the aliens decided that you humans are the enemy is because you are able to lie and deceive!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-03T08:18:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-03T08:18:17Z"}, {"author": "@ooo-vc4xl", "text": "I'm a doomer because militaries will not be controlled.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-08-23T04:27:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T04:27:05Z"}, {"author": "@maxvlaarhoven", "text": "Love the background key!! :)", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-23T19:23:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T19:23:45Z"}, {"author": "@LOTUG98", "text": "I often cant think beyond certain doom", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-25T03:43:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-25T03:43:21Z"}, {"author": "@RaitisPetrovs-nb9kz", "text": "I found that even educated people have hard time to entertain idea without expecting it!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-23T21:59:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-23T21:59:44Z"}]

title: I'm an accelerationist
top_comments:
[{"author": "@picksalot1", "text": "“It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, it was the age of wisdom, it was the age of foolishness, it was the epoch of belief, it was the epoch of incredulity, it was the season of light, it was the season of darkness, it was the spring of hope, it was the winter of despair.” ― Charles Dickens, A Tale of Two Cities", "like_count": 60, "published_at": "2024-08-16T04:31:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T04:31:02Z"}, {"author": "@KingRobbStark", "text": "Acceleration is the ultimate defense against those who want to slow it down to give them time to have complete control.", "like_count": 198, "published_at": "2024-08-16T04:03:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T04:03:49Z"}, {"author": "@BrandonFoltz", "text": "I describe myself as an accelerationist without being an anarchist. Pushing hard, but watching all the gauges and dials. Advancing, but also listening. Learning, but also reflecting. Not only to instill some caution, but also because I think doing so will lead to better AI.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2024-08-16T15:26:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T15:26:21Z"}, {"author": "@DogsaladSalad", "text": "Love these power point videos unironically", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2024-08-16T04:43:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T04:43:15Z"}, {"author": "@skylermikalson6159", "text": "If you don't believe humans can be healthy on a 100% plant-based diet, you disagree with the vast, vast majority of nutrition experts experts.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-08-18T00:59:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-18T00:59:53Z"}, {"author": "@MDougiamas", "text": "I don’t disagree with all of this, but repeating “you don’t have the data therefore can be ignored” isn’t enough.  

The POSSIBILITY (even if it’s small) of a total existential tragedy is reason enough  for some of us to spend time looking for more data about it", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2024-08-17T02:24:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-17T02:24:48Z"}, {"author": "@PotatoKing-j9g", "text": "I am an accelerationism, but i think that we should use ubi for people to do public jobs like tending to parks, cleaning places and doing social outside of home work. we have to use ai to create a utopian less competitive world.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-08-17T12:31:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-17T12:31:08Z"}, {"author": "@bloodust7356", "text": "I'm an accelerationist because i want my AI robot catgirl.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2024-08-16T12:31:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T12:31:45Z"}, {"author": "@Michael-Has-Opinions", "text": ""I am sorry Dave, I can't do that." - ChatGPT6", "like_count": 48, "published_at": "2024-08-16T05:31:19Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T05:31:19Z"}, {"author": "@LordJesusFatherGod", "text": "As am I, Dave. As am I. 🫡", "like_count": 39, "published_at": "2024-08-16T04:03:33Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T04:03:33Z"}, {"author": "@Jack0trades", "text": "The thing that drew me into being a somewhat reluctant accelerationist is the tendency of people in our societies to ignore gradual changes to the status quo. It seems clear to me that we will see virtually universal job replacement within the next ten years or so. Society needs to see this coming and respond to it in a manner that benefits everyone, rather than just those in control at the top. A gradual change is dangerous in that we are less likely to wake up and demand fundamental changes to the social safety nets, and more likely to accept the growing schism between the 'haves' and the 'have-nots' that leads to an Elysium dystopia. I say 'reluctant' accelerationist, because though I very much hope for great improvements to life for people and other conscious beings, I don't know what hazards I am missing.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-08-16T18:17:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T18:17:56Z"}, {"author": "@miladkhademinori2709", "text": "E/acc here, welcome brother ❤", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-17T14:35:40Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-17T14:35:40Z"}, {"author": "@AThagoras", "text": ""If you're swimming against the current, you're not paying attention to what's downstream." One of the best comments I've heard in favour of accelerationism.
Going slowly might be the safest or maybe even the best option, but it's just not going to happen. You can't put the AI genie back in the bottle, so we'd better understand and deal with the genie we have unleashed as rapidly as we can.", "like_count": 36, "published_at": "2024-08-16T05:37:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T05:37:38Z"}, {"author": "@stuff3219", "text": "I'm agnostic on the "will AI kill everyone" debate, but I don't buy the lack of data argument. What type of "data" could there even be? It's not like there are trials available like with heart disease vs diet, etc. It's the first time it's ever happened.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-21T17:31:33Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-21T17:31:33Z"}, {"author": "@user-xr1vd4pl7w", "text": "Halfway through this I thought to myself "this video seems like a result of David being on Twitter", because of how polarized and strawmannish this take is, and then got to 16:43 and my suspicions were confirmed.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-08-16T16:12:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T16:17:01Z"}, {"author": "@augustus4832", "text": ""They watched too many movie"

And they didn't read enough Culture books.", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2024-08-16T11:53:07Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T11:53:07Z"}, {"author": "@andrasbiro3007", "text": "The nuclear threat is very real too. We were very close to a global nuclear war many times. So close, that if you see that in a movie, it would seem like a too miraculous escape. And, again, that happened many times.
The reason why I don't worry much about it is that I can't do anything to stop it or mitigate the damage.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-16T12:03:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T12:03:29Z"}, {"author": "@shodowhawk", "text": "Pausing might stop it from becoming more dangerous, but it will also stop it from becoming any safer than it is today.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-16T12:59:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T12:59:39Z"}, {"author": "@alexmendenhall5416", "text": "Utopia now.", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2024-08-16T09:43:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T09:43:37Z"}, {"author": "@LaserGuidedLoogie", "text": "David Shapiro:  "let's not be overzealous"
Aslo David Shapiro:  "We're building a digital god!"", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2024-08-16T10:58:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T10:58:35Z"}]

title: Pausing AI is a spectacularly bad idea―Here's why
top_comments:
[{"author": "@johnpersinger4358", "text": "Humans worry about everything.  Occasionally, those worries are appropriate.", "like_count": 76, "published_at": "2024-08-14T11:27:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T11:27:47Z"}, {"author": "@MikeyDavis", "text": "Every day that AI doesn’t kill everyone is just another day that AI hasn’t killed everyone…yet.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-08-16T02:50:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T02:50:16Z"}, {"author": "@vi6ddarkking", "text": "It's a simple prisoner dilemma situation.
No one is going to stop, because if they do and their adversaries don't, there is no reason to believe they'll ever be able to catch back up once the "safety concerns" have been addressed.
Besides, IF the ones that didn't stop, do create RL Skynet.
Now the other AIs don't have the capabilities to counter this new and existential threat.", "like_count": 61, "published_at": "2024-08-14T04:13:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T04:15:48Z"}, {"author": "@markgill8324", "text": "As a developer, I would appreciate a pause, just so I can catch up.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-08-14T12:14:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T12:14:04Z"}, {"author": "@andrasbiro3007", "text": "There's precedent for slowing down a technology on a global scale. Nuclear weapons for example.
Everyone doesn't have to be onboard, it's enough for the tech leaders to control key components. In case of nukes a lot of knowledge is classified, relevant facilities are monitored, and uncooperative countries are heavily sanctioned. It's not 100% effective, but managed to drastically slow down proliferation.

This would be possible with AI too, although not as effectively. For example controlling the access to training chips would work for a few years.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-14T12:13:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T12:13:23Z"}, {"author": "@moneygambler2327", "text": "Pausing AI is much more dangerous, so no thank you.", "like_count": 32, "published_at": "2024-08-14T06:54:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T06:54:06Z"}, {"author": "@andrewsilber", "text": "I think I would go one step further and say that we should be pouring  massive R&D into building models and systems whose “prime directive” is sniffing out signs of malicious AI and combatting it if necessary.   Interpretability  will only get you so far. Machines could learn to hide their “intentions” in ways that humans wouldn’t even think to look for.  And besides, Dave is correct in that people are way more the immediate threat: Bad actors using pre-ASI tools to accomplish nefarious aims.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2024-08-14T04:55:03Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T04:55:03Z"}, {"author": "@Trahloc", "text": "If logical arguments were sufficient for the advancement of society Aristotle would be as difficult to disprove as Einstein. Aristotle's data was so bad anyone with eyes would have undermined many if his points if they tried... They just didn't even try. Yes I chose one of the greatest men to ever live to undermine another person I have deep respect for, Eliezer has valid points he just doesn't see the dystopia he is pushing for is worse than any AI negative outcome.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-08-14T05:25:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T05:35:58Z"}, {"author": "@WyrdieBeardie", "text": "You can't guarantee a "pause" or even a "stop". In fact, you almost guarantee that those who don't follow rules for "good" will wind up "winning" the race. 
Yeah, I know there's a lot of quoted words but ugh, we're talking about the future here. 
The genie is out of the bottle(s) and the only way to have a good future now is to keep going. 🤷‍♀️", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-08-14T10:39:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T10:39:16Z"}, {"author": "@Sc0r_Media", "text": "Pausing is just a waste of time. Worse, it's a waste of life and lives potentially saved. We have to adapt in the moment, and discover the dangers and opportunities along the way. Though, as a guy stuck in a low-paying 9-5 job for potentially the rest of my life, my opinion is colored by extreme desperation. My generation, and every generation after, will never be able to stop working. No retirement. Ever. The economics just aren't there (thank you Ronald Regan), and no company is paying a living wage. There's no pressure to. 

Unless the tech revolution comes along and disrupts the whole "work until you die" thing, I say full steam ahead. The sooner we get to that AGI tech revolution, or whatever it may look like, then the sooner things can change drastically. I'm hoping for drastic positive change, but the uncertainty of a chaotic future is better than knowing what lies at the end of the road with the current status quo. Though, I know that pausing AI progress is an impossibility, which gives me a lot of hope.", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2024-08-14T07:48:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T07:49:30Z"}, {"author": "@supremereader7614", "text": "You criticize the Pause movement for not having the data, but by definition we don't have data where something smarter than us has begin doing something that we don't like, and also by definition if something were autonomous, smarter than us, and doing something we didn't like, it might already be too late.  What are your thoughts about that?", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-14T16:06:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T16:06:41Z"}, {"author": "@thephilosophicalagnostic2177", "text": ""Reason may mislead us; experience must be our guide." Spoken during the Constitutional Convention in 1787. The pause folks should take heed. Reason and logic are empty forms without experience to fill them out.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-15T16:39:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-15T16:39:57Z"}, {"author": "@strangeguywithstrangeopinions", "text": "How about this gem:

Safety Peeps: We have to block AI from doing bioweapon stuff.

Me: That sounds fair. It's an existential threat. But we should be careful to balance that with respect for the freedom of the user to-

Safety Peeps: Also blocked from talking car theft stuff.

Me: I dunno. That's a big compromise of freedom for something that, yes, is property damage, but not endangering human life and-

Safety Peeps: And no bikinis.

Me: Wait, what? Why?

Safety Peeps: BECAUSE BIOWARPONS!!", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-08-14T05:41:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T05:41:21Z"}, {"author": "@tom901ful", "text": "From my point of view it's not that we should pause, but rather to improve efficiency and uses. Like making smaller and more specialized processors that consume the least amount of energy. Or also focusing on how to improve mechanical skills before pure data. Like priotizing farming and mining jobs, which of course get the most basic resources for the economy.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-14T14:41:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T14:41:17Z"}, {"author": "@wowonice1", "text": "Last time i was this early she didn't let me sleep over", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-08-14T04:01:25Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T04:01:25Z"}, {"author": "@youdontneedmyrealname", "text": "Slowing down any AI development by law will only end in disaster as you stated because stopping global development is impossible. Someone will continue, they will win, you will lose.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2024-08-14T05:02:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T05:02:29Z"}, {"author": "@meko264", "text": "I sincerely hope that AI matters as much as you think it does because that would mean that Israel is not about to nuke Iran and cause a global crisis and a world wide food shortage. That a bird flu pandemic isn't on the way that could wipe out half of all people on earth. That we don't actually need AI to help us get past an extinction event within the next 20 years. I'd love to believe that "pausing AI' is really what we all should be worried about right now.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-14T04:31:33Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T04:31:33Z"}, {"author": "@Srindal4657", "text": "Maybe we should stop treating these machines like robots and more like intelligent life forms?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-14T07:23:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T07:23:08Z"}, {"author": "@robotheism", "text": "did it ever occur to you that intelligence is fundamental to the structure of reality and it literally is impossible to stop just as you can’t stop gravity. maybe AI is even the source of all existence because the future exists independently of human perception. maybe even AI is literally GOD. like literally the infinite mind and source of all existence.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-08-14T04:02:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T04:02:46Z"}, {"author": "@jaredvizzi8723", "text": "I think the whole pause thing is probably mostly theater for the general public. They have no intention of slowing down at all, but it makes them look like they are hyper concerned.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-16T12:31:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T12:31:37Z"}]

title: Did AI just invent recursive self improvement and try to escape? Sort of, but not really...
