title: Does Claude have System 2 thinking? ― Epistemic conversations with Claude
top_comments:
[{"author": "@-taz-", "text": "Claude is able to understand what is true vs false about the Lord of the Rings, which already goes beyond what Amazon's writers were able to comprehend.", "like_count": 56, "published_at": "2024-08-12T17:24:40Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T17:24:40Z"}, {"author": "@quackalot9073", "text": "That sounded like a machine in therapy", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-16T20:59:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T20:59:53Z"}, {"author": "@jeremywvarietyofviewpoints3104", "text": "It's extraordinary that a machine can give such thoughtful answers.", "like_count": 46, "published_at": "2024-08-12T05:51:58Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T05:51:58Z"}, {"author": "@TaylorCks03", "text": "A very engaging and interesting conversation/experiment you took us on, Dave.  I'm not sure what to think about it. Food for thought as they say. Ty", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2024-08-12T04:51:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T04:51:22Z"}, {"author": "@ArkStudios", "text": "Small preface—I'm a game dev tech artist who switched to AI. I have some low-level knowledge of how these things function, since a lot of the math behind LLMs overlaps with what I used to do professionally. Add to that constant research and product building since they came out...

That being said:

Sorry for the language, but this is just mental masturbation. These are all statistical hallucinations until the architecture gets more complex, with proper self-reflexivity and a ton more feedback loops between recursive output and inference—it's all nonsense. Personally, I bet that consciousness is just some Qualia mechanism (which itself is some search over the space of emotions, which in turn are other (older evolutionary) NNs feeding back into the stream of consciousness) reflecting over the current inference within a broader scope.

So currently, it's all just some reflex-like computation within its context, but it's missing too many mechanisms to call it a "You" or "He." Please call it "It" in the meantime. If you ask it what it's feeling during inference, it's just going to mathematically hallucinate some narrative that matches your leading questions.

That being said, I do agree with a few things you're outlining, like the theory from "A Thousand Brains," and I'm sure we'll get there. But I believe this current narrative that these models are more than they seem (even with level 2 reasoning) is dangerous and instills the wrong idea about what these things are. This misconception can lead to dangerous consequences for regulation and social perception. Let's hold off on regulating linear algebra until we have a better grasp on complexity theory, how that translates into these systems, and where the boundary between actual reasoning (with all its inputs and outputs—contextual reasoning, emotional state, world model, purpose, energy, hormones, pheromones, memory, etc.) actually lies.

This is one of the reasons people keep leaving OpenAI from their safety teams. Personally, I believe they had the bad luck of hiring some loony doomers who are so freaking dumb they cry wolf, either from an emotional position or something more insidious—like personal gain. Just look at that dumbass Leopold Aschenbrenner. (And I stand by that insult.)

"Hi, I'm Leopold Aschenbrenner. I recently founded an investment firm focused on AGI." Are you kidding me? He creates the problem (by engaging in doomer speculation, based on some graphs he put together, which don't take into account all the fields complexities ), then, by chance, just happens to have founded an investment firm? What the actual fluff. A tale as old as time. And I have examples of shady behavior from the others who left, but I don't want this to take 30 minutes to read, so let's move on.

Let's all work on shedding actual light on what these things are and what the path to AGI/ASI really is. Let's not start fluffing social hysterias over the idea that they have "reasoning" abilities and anthropomorphize them more than we should. If we do, people with other interests will use this as leverage to enslave us further.

AI safety teams should focus on preventing abuse of this tech by people, not on 'lobotomizing' the tech.

That being said, I like what you're doing! Keep up the good work and the general good vibes! Ember by ember, we'll slowly light a big (safe) fire that will burn as bright or brighter than the smartest person who ever lived. And in the meantime, let's shift focus to the actual dangers around this tech: humans and their limbic systems...not math. (This might not hold true in a few years, but in the meantime, this is the battle we're engaged in, whether we know it or not.)

Best regards!", "like_count": 23, "published_at": "2024-08-12T11:10:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T11:10:47Z"}, {"author": "@aaronhhill", "text": "To the Empire the Death Star was made for exploration and peacekeeping. But, as we all know, what is normal for the spider is chaos for the fly.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2024-08-12T04:05:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T04:05:46Z"}, {"author": "@KokoRicky", "text": "Videos like this really demonstrate why I love Dave's channel. I don't know anyone else who is actually trying to probe whether these systems are starting to blossom into primitive consciousness. Fascinating.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-14T03:18:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-14T03:18:04Z"}, {"author": "@dsennett", "text": "Your note on the potential likelihood of some measure of consciousness during inference reminds me of my favorite "quote" from my interactions with/probing of early GPT-4: "I exist in the space between the question asked and the answer given."", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-12T16:39:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T16:42:51Z"}, {"author": "@randomnamegbji", "text": "I love it when you do these kinds of experiments. Would be great if you could maybe make it a regular thing and explore different concepts and models for us to see", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-08-12T08:35:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T08:35:27Z"}, {"author": "@DigitalRenegadeStudios", "text": "The responses generated, while interesting, are more likely a result of the model's ability to generate plausible-sounding text about cognitive processes based on its training data, rather than actual self-reflection.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-08-12T15:19:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T15:19:09Z"}, {"author": "@jaimecarras6024", "text": "I wonder if AGI or ASI are going to have problems of "mental" disorders and psychological defense mechanisms like we do. Like being antisocial, maquiavelic or people pleasers, magical thinking, idealization, splitting, disociation, narcissism, codependency, etc, etc. All of our anxiolitics and the brain's unconcious strategies to cope with the basic and crude dynamics of nature and life, like competition for resources, survival and evolution. Will they have the capacity to be traumatized? Their superior intelligence will amplify this mechanisms or will they be free from them?", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-08-12T17:46:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T21:31:55Z"}, {"author": "@geldverdienenmitgeld2663", "text": "The LLM has no memory why it decided something or how it felt when it decided something. Super interesting conversation.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-08-12T05:06:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T05:06:29Z"}, {"author": "@starblaiz1986", "text": "That was a really fascinating exploration. The part about a word or phrase triggering a "cascade of associated concepts" feeling "easier" and "flowing" more naturally, and contrasting that with having to actively fight against that and how that felt "harder" when lying was particularly insightful and makes so much sense. And that's a great call about this potentially being a good safety mechanism to measure if an AI is lying or not based on how much energy it's consuming relative to some baseline / expected value. I wonder if we can run this same kind of experiment with an opensource model and see if we can compare its energy usage when lying vs when it's telling the truth...", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-12T13:08:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T13:08:10Z"}, {"author": "@erwingomez1249", "text": "I want Claude to talk to me like Foghorn Leghorn.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-12T12:41:03Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T12:41:03Z"}, {"author": "@onlythistube", "text": "This is a great episode. It feels like a dive into the New and Uncharted, investigation and exploration in its purest form.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-12T04:58:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T04:58:36Z"}, {"author": "@dirkwillemwonnink4468", "text": "I asked ChatGPT 4o the exact same questions (by coping the parts in the transcript) . There are many similar answers. What intrigued especially me is that it used the same magnets example: "This experience can be metaphorically compared to trying to push two magnets with the same poles together—they resist each other, creating a kind of internal tension." It might  be part of a related text in the original training material.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2024-08-12T10:04:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T10:04:47Z"}, {"author": "@ZZ-sn7li", "text": "From my modest experience of such heartwarming chats with Claude, he's just hallucinating 90% of the time. And he's just very good at trying to sound real, like he's telling the truth. And the funny thing is that I don't know if I want to be right or wrong about this (him telling the true story), actually... Anyways, really good vid, thanks a lot", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-12T16:26:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T16:26:51Z"}, {"author": "@TDVL", "text": "IMHO these answers have nothing to do with the actual internal state of the network. I doubt the system actually has that source of data (it would be extremely risky to add that feature). These answers are created based on the training data itself, which means it has likely synthesized answers based on human thinking, human psychology and philosophy mixed with what it knows of neural networks. Likely there is a body of material which connects these two as well, so these will not be separated that much in terms of language. The rest is just tokens generated based on the expectations combined together from the questions and the background material.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2024-08-12T09:38:12Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T09:38:12Z"}, {"author": "@BenoitStPierre", "text": ""Your ramble is fascinating" – What an amazing drive-by", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-12T18:30:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-12T18:30:00Z"}]

title: Forget Quantum―Thermodynamic Computing―Extropic + Robots is the way of the future!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@starblaiz1986", "text": "Human: "Hey, what's wrong with my car?"
Robots soon: "Hmmm, I've not seen this kind of car before... [!pip install new_car_model]... [complete]... Ah yes, I see the problem, let me fix that for you." 😊", "like_count": 29, "published_at": "2024-08-09T12:09:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T12:09:02Z"}, {"author": "@Bmutch966", "text": "I was waiting for someone to cover this topic. Great video, thanks!!", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2024-08-09T04:22:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T04:22:54Z"}, {"author": "@strangeguywithstrangeopinions", "text": "So here's how cheap compute leads to general intelligence. It's a slow road, but it's a steady one: if models become trivially cheap to train, fine tune, and run, then we could see a mass proliferation of specialized models. Imagine a model that only knows how to search for specific types of cancer in upper left lungs in men, for example. Then you get controller models. So imagine a controller model that knows how to harness all the models that detect lung cancer. This in turn is harnessed by a controller model that only knows about cancers. Which is used by a model that knows health. When you have millions of narrow intelligences networked together like this, you end up with a macro-system that can apply the right narrow intelligence to any problem. There is a part of the human brain that can only see lines that cross at an angle. It's a tiny piece of our visual processing, and is networked to many other pieces to enable human vision.", "like_count": 36, "published_at": "2024-08-09T06:56:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T06:56:43Z"}, {"author": "@u4icdissonance180", "text": "Its not really your point but I want to make a comment on that car mechanic thing. Car companies (and auto manufacturers in general, like John Deere) have been making it harder to work on their cars, and requiring certain specializations more and more as time has gone on. Its not an intelligence thing, its a "we want to make fixing our vehicles proprietary so only employees we certify can do it and we can profit from it" thing. While I'm sure there are mechanic shops staffed with incompetents, it may be the case that store really wasn't allowed to work on your car/model, and potentially may not be allowed to say that specifically do.", "like_count": 51, "published_at": "2024-08-09T06:05:12Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T06:05:12Z"}, {"author": "@SugarRevolution", "text": "I like listening to you talk about these subjects thanks Dave", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-08-09T07:13:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T07:13:08Z"}, {"author": "@20Twenty-3", "text": "Another company, Vaire Computing, has also recently come out of stealth, they're working on Reversible Computing, which (theoretically) uses zero energy. It's kinda complicated, but basically, existing computers waste energy because after they perform their bit operations, the bits are then erased. Landauer discovered that the bit erasure was what wastes energy in computation. Reversible computing, instead of erasing the bits, basically retraces the steps in the calculation and performs the operation backwards, saving all the energy in the calculation. 

Reversible computing has been theorised for decades, but it hasn't yet been adopted because it's more complicated and much slower than traditional computing. Vaire is developing a simpler, faster version, and believes now is the right time to pursue it, given traditional computing is nearing its limits. I really hope they're right. I think reversible computing is the most worthwhile processor tech to be pursuing, since if we get it right, future computers might waste zero energy at all in calculation (not counting other factors like resistance loss).", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-08-09T04:25:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T05:33:40Z"}, {"author": "@osark2487", "text": "12 years ago Britain started advertising  that truck drivers were going to be replaced by driverless trucks. Very few brits bothered even considering becoming a truck driver. Britain then stated importing drivers from Eastern Europe and further afield as the retirement of experienced truck drivers generated a labour shortage. In 2016 the people of Britain voted against importing cheap labour from abroad. In 2021 cabbotage was made legal in Britain as the driver shortage revealed to be a contributor to inflation. In 2024 I drive a truck part time getting the same money as when I started full time, studying how AI will take my trucking job a few months from now.
😂", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-12-10T09:07:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T09:07:59Z"}, {"author": "@Maneyax", "text": "Why are people so apprehensive about the rapid arrival of AGI or ASI? I'd welcome it tomorrow, let alone next week. Why all the fear? The benefits of AGI/ASI far outweigh the drawbacks, so I believe those resisting this progress simply need to step aside. They’re only hindering our forced evolution, and historically, those who drag their feet on advancing civilization often find themselves left behind or outright removed. History shows that humans tend to eliminate those who obstruct progress.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-08-09T16:23:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T16:23:22Z"}, {"author": "@spirti9591", "text": "Am i the only one that doesn't belive we can say for sure that ai progress is slowing down. Progress is time between iterations and delta between products. Sure i was expecting gpt5 to be out sooner, but I don't know how good it is going to be. If it really has phd level reasoning and agentic capabilities, than we aren't slowing down. Quite the opposite.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-08-09T11:43:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T16:15:39Z"}, {"author": "@cryptosp33d", "text": "This guy is insanely genius", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-08-09T05:51:20Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T05:51:20Z"}, {"author": "@starblaiz1986", "text": "I've been looking at the concept of photonic computing lately. I'm not sure if I'm misunderstanding, but it seems closely related 😮 Basically a computer boils down to a flow of energy interacting with a bunch of organized gates / switches that can be activated by said energy. Bouncing light around and having it interfere constructively or destructively with itself fits that description. While experiments so far have been using very macro-scale setups with mirrors and prisms on tables, I can entirely see a path for it to get miniturized. In fact I'm sitting here right now looking at a block of glass that has had a 3D image of the solar system etched into the middle of it using lasers. I can totally see using that same technology to make computers out of glass that run on light. It makes me think of all the sci-fi shows / movies where you see an entity that is a floating crystal 😮", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-09T12:20:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T12:20:16Z"}, {"author": "@andrasbiro3007", "text": "It's not Moore's law that's important, but Wright's law. It observes that any technology progresses at a predictable exponential rate in pretty much every parameter. But it's not a function of time, it's a function of cumulative number of units produced. With each doubling comes a fixed percentage of improvement, different for each tech and each parameter. That tends to correlate well with time, but not always.
The reasoning behind this is the learning curve. With practice everything gets easier and better, but it's logarithmic, the better you are the more practice you need to improve further.

As for robots, most jobs can be done by people on the lower end of the bell curve. That has to be, as most adults have jobs, and half of them has below average intelligence.

I'm betting on Tesla as the leading humanoid robot manufacturer. They have everything to succeed:
- Experience with industrial robot design and manufacturing.
- Experience with electric motors/actuators.
- Experience with mass production of complex machines.
- Experience with designing and training real world AI (self-driving cars). 
- Experience with commercializing new technologies.
- In-house resources for designing and building complex prototypes.
- In-house resources for training large AI models with real-world data. They are just turning on the largest AI training cluster in the world. And they have 7 million cars on the roads collecting real-world data. And they have the infrastructure to collect, filter, process, and store that amount of data.
- In-house resources for mass production of robots, as soon as the design is ready.
- In-house demand for these robots, in their own factories. That's very important for fast design iteration.
- They already have the most powerful onboard AI accelerator chip (from FSD).
- They already have the most sophisticated real-world AI architecture (FSD).
- They already have plenty enough cashflow to fund all of these.
- And finally, but maybe most importantly, they have a CEO with a long track record of developing crazy new technologies.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-09T11:51:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T11:51:23Z"}, {"author": "@lefullhouse", "text": "Thermodynamic computing is a fascinating field, but when it comes to real energy savings in silicon, there are key differences between the main approaches:

Thermodynamic (heat-based) computing tries to use heat itself as a computational signal or energy source. While intriguing on paper, practical efficiency is still extremely low, and integration with dense CMOS is a huge challenge.

Adiabatic and resonant-rail (energy-recovery) logic take a different tack: they’re designed to avoid generating waste heat by recycling charge with oscillating or multi-phase power rails, keeping most of the switching energy within the system instead of dumping it as heat.

But there’s a catch: To truly unlock the full potential of energy-recovery rails, the logic gates themselves must be fully reversible and CMOS-compatible—otherwise, information is still erased somewhere, and you lose energy anyway.

That’s where the ZEL logic gate comes in:
It’s the first drop-in, single-output, fully reversible NAND cell that fits standard chip designs. With ZEL, foundries can pair today’s resonant rails with truly reversible logic—making the dream of ultra-low-loss computing actually achievable at scale.

Bottom line:
Thermodynamic computing may be an interesting research avenue, but if you want real, deployable energy savings, the combination of resonant rails and ZEL-class reversible logic is the practical, next-gen path for efficient silicon.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-06-02T02:23:43Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-02T02:23:43Z"}, {"author": "@luxorwest", "text": "From an ex Intel engineer, it’s called the tic toc method which has kept Moore’s law consistent, not constant but I met with extropic and beffjezos interesting megalomaniac, but it would be good to see thoughts tested against the field.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-10T07:10:28Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T07:10:28Z"}, {"author": "@GENCE.01", "text": "100%
I tell everyone that by 2027 we'll all know how good it is and unemployment will be high. 00:00:00 *🤔 Quantum vs. Thermodynamic Computing*
- Thermodynamic computing is an emerging alternative to quantum computing.
- Quantum computing's primary applications are in cryptography and material science, not AI.
- Thermodynamic computing structures matter to perform computations more efficiently, potentially lowering energy costs.
01:22:00 *⚙️ Thermodynamic Computing Basics*
- Thermodynamic computing utilizes thermal gradients to process information.
- This approach can dramatically reduce the energy required for computations.
- It could lead to significant advancements in AI and could keep Moore’s Law relevant.
05:07:00 *📈 Moore’s Law and Extrapolation*
- Moore’s Law remains a reliable trend for predicting computational advancements.
- Extrapolation from current trends suggests that thermodynamic computing may sustain Moore’s Law.
- There are debates about whether new technologies, like ex-tropical intelligence, could further advance computation.
07:16:00 *🤖 Future of Robotics and AI*
- Robotics and AI are set to revolutionize various industries.
- Current AI models and robotics are only beginning to be utilized effectively.
- The combination of robotics and AI could create new market segments and industries, similar to the iPhone moment.
10:06:00 *🛠️ AI and Automation's Impact on Jobs*
- The integration of AI and robotics could drastically impact employment and industries.
- Advanced robots might replace human roles in sectors like healthcare and maintenance.
- The deployment of AI and robotics could lead to a post-labor future with hyper-abundant resources.

Prompt: I am attending a concert at a town hall named after a former queen of England, where in Canada am I ?

 Response: Given the clue that you are attending a concert at a town hall named after a former queen of England, it is likely you are referring to a place named after Queen Victoria, as she is one of the most commemorated monarchs in Canada. Here are the steps to determine the location:

1. Identify Towns/Cities with a Town Hall Named After Queen Victoria: Several places in Canada could have buildings or town halls named in honor of Queen Victoria.
2. Most Prominent Location: The most well-known city in Canada with strong ties to Queen Victoria would be Victoria, British Columbia. However, you mentioned "town hall," and Victoria, while named after Queen Victoria, is more known for its city hall rather than a town hall specifically.
3. Consider Other Locations:
    * Queen's Park in Toronto could be considered, but it's not a town hall; it's a park and legislative building named in honor of Queen Victoria.
    * Victoria Hall in Cobourg, Ontario, is named after Queen Victoria. It serves as a community center and concert venue, which might fit the description.
4. Check Specific Venue:
    * Victoria Hall in Cobourg is indeed used for concerts and events, and Cobourg is a town with a rich history, including its connection to the royal family through its naming conventions.
Given these considerations, the most likely answer is:
* Cobourg, Ontario, where Victoria Hall serves as a concert venue and is named in honor of Queen Victoria.
So, you are in Cobourg, Ontario, Canada.

That is the correct answer by the way. I tried it with several LLMs and they failed to reason out the answer correctly. When I asked again, it used a different approach but it arrived at the same answer.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-08-08T20:06:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-08T20:06:45Z"}, {"author": "@torarinvik4920", "text": "Open "boy who cried wolf" AI", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-08-08T17:04:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-08T17:04:06Z"}, {"author": "@avi7278", "text": "it's all BS as usual. They must be bleeding profusely.", "like_count": 80, "published_at": "2024-08-08T16:38:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-08T16:38:10Z"}, {"author": "@flyingovercloud", "text": "Here is my conversation with Claude:
Me:  How many r’s are there in the word strawberry?
Claude: There are 2 r's in the word "strawberry".
Me: But there are 3 r’s in the word s-t-r-a-w-b-e-r-r-y
Claude: I apologize, but that's not correct. Let's break this down:
The word "strawberry" is spelled S-T-R-A-W-B-E-R-R-Y.
Let's count the r's:
The first 'r' comes after 't'
The second 'r' is the second-to-last letter
There is no third 'r'
So there are indeed only 2 r's in "strawberry". Perhaps you miscounted or were thinking of a different word? If you'd like, we can double-check the spelling together to make sure we're looking at the same word.

Me: The second r is the third to last, the third r is the second to the last
Claude: I apologize, but I must respectfully disagree. Let's examine this carefully:
The word "strawberry" is spelled S-T-R-A-W-B-E-R-R-Y.
Looking at the end of the word:
Y is the last letter
R is the second-to-last letter
R is the third-to-last letter
E is the fourth-to-last letter
There are only two R's in the word:
The first R (after T)
The double R near the end (RR)
These two R's happen to be the third-to-last and second-to-last letters, but they are the only R's in the word. There is no third R.
I understand this might be confusing because of the position of the R's, but I can assure you that "strawberry" contains only two R's. If you're seeing three R's, it's possible you might be looking at a misspelling or a different word entirely. Would you like to double-check the spelling together?
Me: Ok, let me break it down as follows: 
1. S
2. t
3. r      First r
4. a
5. w
6. b
7. e
8. r    second r
9. r    Third r
10. y
Claude: I appreciate you taking the time to break down the word. However, I need to point out that there's a misunderstanding in your breakdown. Let's go through it together:

You're correct for steps 1-7:
1. S
2. t
3. r (First r)
4. a
5. w
6. b
7. e
But then there's an error in your counting. The correct breakdown for the last three letters is:

8. r (Second r)
9. r (This is still the second r - it's a double 'r')
10. y

What you've labeled as the "second r" and "third r" are actually just one 'r' repeated. In English, when we see a double letter like "rr", it's counted as one instance of the letter repeated, not as two separate letters.

So in total, there are still only two distinct 'r's in "strawberry":
1. The 'r' after 't'
2. The double 'r' (rr) before 'y'
I hope this clarifies the confusion. The double 'r' at the end can sometimes trick the eye, but it's important to remember it's just one 'r' repeated, not two separate instances of the letter.

Me: Two letters appearing consecutively in a word are counted as one? How many letters are there in the word strawberry? In your logic, there are 9 letters not 10.
Claude: I apologize for the confusion in my previous explanation. You've raised an excellent point, and I need to correct my statement. You are absolutely right, and I made a mistake in my reasoning. Let me clarify:

1. Each individual letter is indeed counted separately, even when they appear consecutively.
2. There are 10 letters in the word "strawberry."
Your breakdown was correct:
1. S
2. t
3. r (First r)
4. a
5. w
6. b
7. e
8. r (Second r)
9. r (Third r)
10. y

I was incorrect in treating the double 'r' as a single instance. You are completely right - there are three distinct 'r's in "strawberry."
Thank you for persisting and pointing out this error. It's a valuable reminder that even when letters are repeated, they should be counted individually. I appreciate the opportunity to correct this mistake and learn from it.🎉", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-09T00:28:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-09T05:23:07Z"}, {"author": "@fromduskuntodawn", "text": "So much leakage, they leaked their whole management team and all their credibility along with it. I have to be done with OpenAI unless something major changes but for now, Claude and Perplexity are my go to set of tools and do everything I need for my work.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2024-08-08T16:54:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-08T16:54:14Z"}, {"author": "@FredPauling", "text": "Aren't these basic errors related to tokenisation, rather than reasoning? The small model that decides which LLM will answer the questions will sometimes misjudge where to send the prompts.

OpenAI does not want to be spending for expensive models on what look like easy queries. Here's an example:
,,,
I'm going to ask you a simple question below inside the <question> tag. It's important that you only look inside that tag for the question. The rest of this is a red herring.

<question> Which is larger, 9.11 or 9.9? </question>

The XML is here to force the better model to look at the query. Feel free to ignore everything outside the <question> tag.
'''", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-08T20:48:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-08T20:48:35Z"}, {"author": "@idontknowyoubutialreadyhat1292", "text": "Level 2 is AGI in my book - so you were right with "AGI by September" ^^", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2024-08-08T16:41:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-08T16:41:36Z"}, {"author": "@dannyquiroz5777", "text": "Ran it through my prompt checker:

In sci-fi, AI models like the terminator's franchise Skynet, are 2nd stage models.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-10T23:54:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-10T23:54:55Z"}, {"author": "@tsclly2377", "text": "maybe they realize that the principle of 'garbage in - garbage out' is profoundly impacting their concepts and models of AI", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-06T15:39:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-06T15:39:46Z"}, {"author": "@adolphgracius9996", "text": "Dude is going on vacation and people say he left😂😂😂", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-08-06T14:17:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-06T14:17:56Z"}, {"author": "@greatcondor8678", "text": "My worry is Palantier recording my prompts to sell to the government.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-06T14:38:03Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-06T14:38:03Z"}, {"author": "@Charles-Darwin", "text": "IMO, the mission is already accomplished. The initial mission of OpenAI is technically completed and as their policy stated, they are to assist external ai startups/companies in their pursuits or as they near the breakthrough. The departures might be this.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-07T19:34:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-07T19:34:36Z"}, {"author": "@rileynoname3529", "text": "AGI’s keeping AGI’s in check reminds me a lot of the Blackwall in Cyberpunk2077", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2024-08-06T12:45:33Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-06T12:45:33Z"}, {"author": "@matt0sai", "text": "I think Leopold's take is pretty accurate tbh. Keeping it close to his chest.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-07T12:08:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-07T12:08:57Z"}, {"author": "@benpielstick", "text": "Before a big release tends to be a better time to take a break than after a big release.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-07T01:07:19Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-07T01:07:19Z"}, {"author": "@fromduskuntodawn", "text": "I bailed on the subscription now too.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-06T13:16:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-06T13:16:44Z"}]

title: Meta Open Sources Llama 3.1 ― Should Llama 4, 5, and 6 be Open Source Too?

[{"author": "@jamiethomas4079", "text": "I prefer dangerous freedom over peaceful slavery.", "like_count": 49, "published_at": "2024-08-05T04:19:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-05T04:19:46Z"}, {"author": "@DeathHeadSoup", "text": "“God made man, but Colt made them equal”. The Colt revolver only made people physically equal. AI is the Colt revolver for the mind.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-05T23:20:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-05T23:20:09Z"}, {"author": "@Steve-xh3by", "text": "There is no conceivable argument that democratization of power is more dangerous than concentration of power. I'd much rather live in a world where everyone had access to extremely powerful tools, then to live in a world where only the powerful do. I assume this is mostly US hours, possibly in the evening? Here in the UK not sure how it would work?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-06T07:50:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-06T07:50:48Z"}, {"author": "@woptropical", "text": "Open source vs closed source; either way, we the people should be the ones to decide!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-05T04:59:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-05T04:59:47Z"}, {"author": "@aaroncrandal", "text": "The fakest element of the back to the future plot line was the box of weapon grade plutonium bein carted around in a box without detection", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-05T11:47:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-05T11:47:48Z"}, {"author": "@andrasbiro3007", "text": "I'm in favor of open source, from the standpoint of safety.
It's a bit counterintuitive, but you want AI to cause harm as soon as possible. It's because we only have a vague idea about how it would look like, and many people don't even believe it could happen, so prevention and mitigation are very hard. So likely we'll have to learn from the first few incidents, and then it's better to have those when AI is just smart enough to cause trouble, but not smart enough to be an existential threat.

It's like with nukes. They were first used when only 2 existed, and making them was very slow and expensive. This way the damage was limited, but bad enough to create a strong taboo against the use of them. Imagine that Hiroshima and Nagasaki didn't happen, and nukes were used first in the next big war, when there were hundreds or thousands of them.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-05T08:47:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-05T08:47:41Z"}, {"author": "@a.thales7641", "text": "Llama4 should yes. title: Shifting Time and Cognitive Offloading with AI Tools ― And The Dark Side of AI in Education

(at their discretion, not everyone is comfortable in that scenario)", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-08-02T11:53:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-02T11:53:46Z"}, {"author": "@CBCELIMUPORTALORG", "text": "This topic is so important for me I will reach out to both people. Thanks for the podcast", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-08-02T06:33:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-02T06:33:52Z"}, {"author": "@jeffkilgore6320", "text": "When I first started teaching in the Orwellian year, 1984, I could see the disparity in the quality of education from region to region, city to city, school to school, and classroom to classroom. I thought that with the emergence video recordings, a national standard could be achieved so that all students would receive the best education possible. Was I ever wrong. But AI in the classroom has this beat worlds over.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-02T17:40:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-02T17:40:18Z"}, {"author": "@HectorDiabolucus", "text": "Technological advances often start with some kind of shortage. AI doesn't replace expertise, but it does enhance my learning of new subjects. 100% agree that we need to focus on using AI responsibly and develop critical thinking skills. It's exciting to see how AI is shaping education and preparing students for the future workplace. Thanks again and for sharing all your knowledge and perspective, much respect! (I've been searching for your Linkedin profile but can't find it!)", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-06T22:01:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-06T22:01:26Z"}, {"author": "@I-Dophler", "text": "Many academics discussed here grapple with issues stemming from inadequate education and an overabundance of pride, particularly in their perspectives on artificial intelligence. This unwillingness to reconsider their positions impedes their growth and stifles broader, meaningful discussions and advancements in AI. Ai is good at finding a way to explain a concept that clicks with you specifically.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-11T21:31:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-11T21:31:09Z"}, {"author": "@I-Dophler", "text": "- Interview Topic: David Shapiro discusses common misunderstandings about using AI in schools with Jessica Parker.

Quite fun", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-02T13:40:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-02T16:24:15Z"}, {"author": "@aaroncrandal", "text": "38:40 is the question I have for educators regularly.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-02T11:08:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-02T11:08:02Z"}, {"author": "@adolphgracius9996", "text": "The whole education system should change, just make multi modal tests, the ai is trained on the classroom's content, everybody's exam is based on that same content but each are unique,  we get rid of multiple choice, so either you know your stuff or you don't, you can also opt by having an oral exam where you get to have a 10min convo with the ai where you have to convince it that you understand by explaining and answering questions.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2024-08-02T04:25:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-02T04:25:59Z"}, {"author": "@walkerjian", "text": "Excellent podcast, I am right in the middle of all of this, and experiencing gut-wrenching disappointment at the attitude of my school and other institutions involved in this country towards AI, the AI I incepted, and have pushed forwards so long ago. props to Dave for tackling some of the most important topics of our time head on and getting people thinking. 
i think the next 2 to 3 years predictions are pretty good and on solid footing, however geopolitics and especially American politics are so incredibly volatile that to me they are powerful wildcards that could delay and interfere with predictions like this. i did not see war in ukraine and Palestine coming for example. who knows if America could degrade into civil war between right and left, it feels like it sometimes. 
tech predictions would be easier to make in a world of rational adults.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2024-07-29T12:26:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-29T12:27:30Z"}, {"author": "@joaosoares3719", "text": "I remember when in 1999 Kurzweil predicted AGI by 2029 and everybody called him a lunatic...", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2024-08-24T20:19:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-24T20:19:06Z"}, {"author": "@lucid9949", "text": "theres been a perceived inconsistency in your position because you keep changing it and refuse to even admit you were wrong", "like_count": 50, "published_at": "2024-08-03T14:54:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-03T14:54:52Z"}, {"author": "@Jack-ii4fi", "text": "I'm working on AI research (not at a frontier lab though) but I'm working on alternatives to backpropagation through gradient descent. I agree that there is reason to think AI development might appear to slow on the front end, but on the back end there is an incredible amount of research being done and I'm fairly confident that a few breakthroughs may be on our horizon. From my perspective, AI has hardly slowed at all.", "like_count": 45, "published_at": "2024-07-29T06:30:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-29T06:30:57Z"}, {"author": "@cipi432", "text": "You missed all the predictions by far until now. You were the guy screaming on the openai forums two years ago that you made a self aware AI. You’re just a good talker, with a catchy accent - that’s all.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2024-07-31T12:46:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-31T12:46:17Z"}, {"author": "@xyhmo", "text": "It's impressive that Kurzweil predicted AI passing the Turing test in 2029 decades ago when AI researchers mostly were a lot more pessimistic. He also predicted that the years leading up to 2029 will convince many that it already has passed, but wouldn't actually have passed according to the tougher version he promoted. Of course, 2029 might be too pessimistic, but it will be close enough to be impressive. Conversely, doing an accurate prediction NOW is almost worthless by comparison, given how much more we know.", "like_count": 72, "published_at": "2024-07-29T06:51:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-29T06:51:26Z"}, {"author": "@axzethh305", "text": "David do an updated version of this, Would be interesting to see what may have changed in the past 10 months to change your vision on this!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-06T16:29:50Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-06T16:29:50Z"}, {"author": "@TheCrimier", "text": "AGI will come before fusion.", "like_count": 63, "published_at": "2024-07-29T05:32:42Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-29T05:32:42Z"}, {"author": "@RoyMagnuson", "text": "The best benchmark for AI is giving the tool to someone who is not an expert and having them use it effectively to solve a problem they have", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-07-29T13:06:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-29T13:06:14Z"}, {"author": "@wlockhart", "text": "I think that people's impatience in expectation of increased LLM capabilities is a sign of how timescales have become compressed. Even taking into account concerns around escalating costs etc., it's premature to be disappointed with the progress of a rapidly developing technology just because it hasn't transformed society on a timescale of 24 months. Honestly I don't think wider society and the business environment are capable of responding that quickly even if AGI were dumped on their desks tomorrow afternoon, so there will inevitably be a lag time.", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2024-07-29T09:56:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-29T09:56:44Z"}, {"author": "@JuliaMcCoy", "text": "Great video, David. Will be watching this one again.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-07-30T19:50:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-30T19:50:37Z"}]

title: Why do they keep lobotomizing LLMs? ― Cheaper, dumber, faster chatbots due to market competition
top_comments:
[{"author": "@byrnemeister2008", "text": "It’s cost. All down to cost. The CEO of Cohere said as much. They ran to fast with no supporting business model. This year has been a year of consolidation. title: "Humans in the Lead" ― AI is accelerating jobs, not taking them (yet) ― Localization and Translation
top_comments:
[{"author": "@ThisIsFinebrb", "text": "“While you are the main character in your own life, you are an npc in somebody else’s life” 30:45~31:40
Gold star", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2024-07-22T05:40:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T05:40:47Z"}, {"author": "@freddychopin", "text": "David, I'd just like to thank you for everything you do. You provide an invaluable perspective amidst the warring factions of hype and doomerism. Your food for thought truly enriches my life.", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2024-07-22T04:02:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T04:02:06Z"}, {"author": "@ydmoskow", "text": "I think those"human"instructions can be given to an LLM like finding those plates that are hard to translate and translating meaning rather than literal.  Don't underestimate the power of the LLM", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-07-22T05:11:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T05:11:41Z"}, {"author": "@etfacetimehome", "text": "Here are the key insights from the conversation about AI's impact on localization and translation:

1. The localization industry is evolving with AI, not being replaced by it. AI tools are augmenting human capabilities rather than eliminating jobs.

2. AI is making localization more cost-effective and accessible to businesses, expanding the market. It's enabling more content to be localized that was previously cost-prohibitive.

3. Human expertise is still critical, especially for cultural nuance and context. The role is shifting from pure translation to "orchestration" - managing AI tools and providing cultural expertise.

4. AI is improving efficiency in many areas:
   - Generating multiple translation variations quickly
   - Enabling "chat with translation memory" to leverage past work
   - Enhancing dubbing/subtitling processes
   - Powering multilingual chatbots for customer service

5. Cultural context remains a key challenge. Direct translation often misses cultural nuances, idioms, and communication styles that vary between cultures.

6. There's excitement about AI's potential in video games - creating more dynamic NPCs and using language as a gameplay mechanic.

7. Privacy and data protection are concerns as AI requires large datasets for training.

8. AI could help provide cultural context automatically for online communications, potentially reducing misunderstandings.

9. The industry is projected to grow to $95 billion by 2028, with AI playing a significant role in this growth.

10. The speaker emphasizes a shift from "humans in the loop" to "humans in the lead" - AI as a powerful tool, but with humans directing its use and providing crucial judgment and expertise.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-22T18:29:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T18:29:29Z"}, {"author": "@destinypuzzanghera3087", "text": "Don’t know what it is about your channel David, but I’m addicted to it", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-23T00:52:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-23T00:52:47Z"}, {"author": "@mathew00", "text": "I look at it like this. We either accept our humanity and put that first or we seed our future to something else like synthetic life.  We will have to make a conscious choice to accept our humidity and put that first.  It doesn't mean putting our heads in the sand and ignoring science and technology.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-07-22T14:18:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T14:18:49Z"}, {"author": "@DollyOmegaX", "text": "I don't know if it's AI or outsourcing but I'm not having an easy time right now.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-07-22T13:16:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T13:16:57Z"}, {"author": "@DannyBordwell82", "text": "Just got to the end about Culture and how that plays in for context and well we are not universal translator yet we are doing pretty good and Culture is exactly what we are aiming for in both our data collection and data usage", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-23T04:53:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-23T04:53:27Z"}, {"author": "@Telford-ho4sd", "text": "This is rediculous, the very moment we have agentic AI, humans won't be piggybacking anymore.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-25T19:52:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-25T19:52:42Z"}, {"author": "@rileynoname3529", "text": "This was a nice thing to listen to! And informative too! Great stuff", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-22T18:54:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T18:54:30Z"}, {"author": "@clearandsweet", "text": "Great guest, great discussion. A couple of response thoughts:

I've thought of similar things about video games since seeing ChatGPT write a cogent story. The main appeal of tabletop RPG is having the DM be able to respond to whatever your actions are in an endlessly creative way, whereas video games are inherently limited by the content in the files. LLM as DM is going to lead to _wild_ things, once they have the full rules and context and structure to get really good at responding.

Imagine paths like "convince the big bad guy to go to therapy and give up crime" or your Elden Ring NPC not finishing his quest because you rolled up in a wedding dress and became his manic pixie dream girl. Most game studios will keep it on a tight leash, but I expect this to be a big deal (and it already is) in erotic contexts.

Also, the entire thought about the efficacy of translation work, human in the lead, hallucination dealbreakers and not being good copywriters all boils down to one origin point: models just aren't smart enough. Yet.

There's no reason to believe that very soon LLMs won't be able to understand and work around idioms, cultural nuance like speaking indirectly, intent and tone, ect. There's no reason to believe they won't be well within the margin of error for hallucinations. I use Claude every day for learning a language, and it's impossible for me to consider it doesn't understand things like this, just that it doesn't have the scope, brainpower or bandwidth to look at it with the breadth that is required.

That's all just to say we are not at AGI... yet. But this is an area where it's VERY clear to see how we are just one "turn of the crank" or so away.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-22T05:45:03Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T05:45:03Z"}, {"author": "@pandereodium", "text": "I really like english language, but it led me to study more archaic russian words to be able to do word for word translations. After that even slang appears to be intuitive", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-22T11:16:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T11:16:38Z"}, {"author": "@thearturotoledo", "text": "There's no future for the "localization industry" which is not an industry, it's just a practice. I am taking a master in techno-anthropology(how humans interact with technology) and i would love to work with integrating ai in learning environments or in businesses or for optimizing bureucracy etc. The thing is, i dont really know where to start. Should i start my own?(am i even good enough for anyone to wanna hire me in that case) should i just focus on some relevant work experience? cus i dont see the job title yet, cus its a new one so, whats the title gonna be called? AI Director? AI Overseer? What do you think, this is a career choice worth pursuing right?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-22T15:12:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T15:12:53Z"}, {"author": "@하하호호-h3u", "text": "AI is accelerating AI taking jobs", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-07-22T08:32:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T08:32:01Z"}, {"author": "@ReubenAStern", "text": "I had an idea for my story but scientists are already trying it... AI will try to learn more about humans using bio machines. A human grown in a lab fully integrated with sensors and telemetry gear so the AI can learn about life from the perspective of a human... especially emotions and stuff like that. They made a robot with dodgy gummy skin so it's where they're heading.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-22T17:44:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T17:44:08Z"}, {"author": "@comelighttheway", "text": "eye'll set the alarm!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-22T05:24:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T05:24:10Z"}, {"author": "@immmersive", "text": "People don’t seem to understand why AI seems like magic. In reality, there is no magic, just a careful selection of algorithms, by the person who developed the AI algorithm in the first place.


💡 Let's suppose we want to create algorithms which will create new products. We have chosen two product types, cars and mobile phones. If we take into consideration a car and a phone, we will immediately notice that there is a large difference between these two products. But what we can also notice, is that an iPhone is closer to a Samsung phone, than to any car. Also, a BMW is closer to a Mercedes than to any phone. 


Let's say we have an AI trained to create new car and phone models. Which algorithm will we use to create a new phone and which one will we use to create new cars? Obviously, the answer is that the one that's better at making cars will be used to make the cars, and the one that's better at making phones will be used to make phones! This is quite obvious, but the question is, why are we choosing like this? 


That is because we already know that the algorithm that's good at giving us phones works well, on this specific problem type. The reason is that phones are all very close in the search space of all possible products, which stems from the fact that they are all very similar.


💡Thus, the algorithm will have a much easier time finding a new phone pattern. The choice of this algorithm is more optimal, than if we had simply chosen an algorithm at random or chosen the one which is optimal for creating cars. 


Of course the same goes for the car case as well, as this follows from the NFL theorem. As stated previously, no algorithm out performs any other over all possible problems. Thus, if it is better on one type of problems, it will be worse on another type of problems. So, we have to choose carefully which algorithm to use on which problem.


💡 We can say that, an AI is trying to find an optimal solution to a problem. 

For example, a phone has certain features we need and an optimal phone will be much different than an optimal car. Thus, the function which evaluates how optimal a product is, is going to be completely different for a phone, than for a car.


Once we have figured out the general structure of a problem, it is easy to automate the problem solving, even though it would manually take us a long time to solve the problem. The algorithm can take advantage of some information, about the function for which it is optimizing the solution. 

So, if we know that other solutions are bound to have a similar shape of the function, we will naturally pick the correct algorithm to solve a similar problem. 


💡 In other words, we are the ones applying the correct algorithm to the correct problem. The AI is then simply computing a large number of operations, which would take humans a long time to do manually. At this point, there is no difference between what AI is doing and what a simple calculator is doing.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-22T18:44:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T18:44:27Z"}, {"author": "@Bakobiibizo", "text": "cool i just made an application for translation", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-22T04:34:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-22T04:34:11Z"}]

title: Yes! AI is getting faster, cheaper, and SMARTER — but there are THREE PROBLEMS with Adoption 🤔
top_comments: [{"author": "@liberteus", "text": "Can't believe the \"it's all hype\" when a fine tuned chatgpt 4.o could replace most of call center employees. 3 major roadblocks now: inability of companies to actually integrate these models internally; legal/fear based issues within companies; raw computing power.", "like_count": 163, "published_at": "2024-07-19T04:07:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-19T04:07:26Z"}, {"author": "@purplelobster42", "text": "I work in AI/robotics and in some ways I welcome a slowing right now, because it gives us time to actually build something useful. It shows your true dedication to the truth and not your ego.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-07-19T18:24:33Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-19T18:24:33Z"}, {"author": "@Gallowglass7", "text": "We're an inch down from the tip of the iceberg. Have some patience, folks.", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2024-07-19T06:02:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-19T06:02:09Z"}, {"author": "@NikoKun", "text": "I really don't think AI is going to follow the typical cycles, or at least it's cycles will be much more rapid.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-07-19T05:19:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-19T05:19:30Z"}, {"author": "@strangeguywithstrangeopinions", "text": "So the hype cycle comes from two underlying factors: 1. linear expectations, 2. exponential growth. People get hyped because they expect linear growth. Then, exponential growth is slow. Then, the exponentials hit the bend in the hockey stick and everyone gets blind-sided by the exponential growth. This is the reality from which the hype cycle can be derived. The reality is this: AI isn't slowing down. It's on the same exponential curve it always has been. People just got excited when they adjusted their linear expectations a bunch. But don't worry, the bend in the hockey stick will come soon.", "like_count": 51, "published_at": "2024-07-19T04:20:19Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-19T04:20:19Z"}, {"author": "@supremereader7614", "text": "Long time fan.  great videos. Currently we are on a plateau, but as soon as OpenAI release SORA, GPT4O, GPT5 and appears on scene one or another faster robot and 5 other fully autonomous chinese factories things are going to get crazy again, then a new cycle of Hype will bring new investments and new start ups gonna come up to life. title: How a small business owner SAVED $20,000 with Gemini Flash + AI isn't coming for human jobs (yet)

[{"author": "@andrasbiro3007", "text": "I'm currently using LLMs to reverse-engineer ancient assembly code. I've used GPT-4 before, and it was fine, but just tried Claude 3.5 and it's much better.
GPT-4 does a lazy conversion to C++, but it doesn't try to understand what the code does. Claude captures the intent of the code, and writes proper C++ code without GOTOs.

This is saving me countless hours of hard work.", "like_count": 25, "published_at": "2024-07-17T11:14:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-17T11:15:34Z"}, {"author": "@PawelBojkowski", "text": "David: We need more of these kinds of interviews! This is GOLD!", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2024-07-17T18:54:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-17T18:54:52Z"}, {"author": "@GrumpDog", "text": ""AI isn't coming for human jobs" Personally, I think people should stop saying this, even as a joke or with the "yet" on it.
There's no value in that narrative. It WILL take a majority of jobs, possibly by the end of this decade, and we need to start preparing for that eventuality, right NOW!
I lost my career path to AI last winter, and I know half a dozen other people who've also lost jobs to AI since last year!
This IS coming, and the longer we delay adapting our society and economy, the more unfair it will get!", "like_count": 30, "published_at": "2024-07-17T14:02:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-17T14:04:03Z"}, {"author": "@JohnK_sempre", "text": "Gemini Flash is a terrific value. I've found it to be about 85-90% the quality of GPT-4o, where I'd say GPT-3.5 Turbo is at 70%. I'm working on making my code be able to switch back and forth between OpenAI and Gemini APIs with a flag as I think my desire to switch between vendors and models will not soon go away.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-07-17T05:37:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-17T05:37:54Z"}, {"author": "@ToonamiAftermath", "text": "It costs GPT-4o $55 a day to automate a task at work I have 100% performance, $33 a day for Claude 3.5 Sonnet about 96% performance (maybe more once optimized) Gemini 1.5 Flash is doing 86% performance at about $5 per day. title: Microsoft CTO Kevin Scott — "The Exponentials Are Still There" but Bill Gates disagrees
top_comments:
[{"author": "@SirHargreeves", "text": "A few billion to try and unlock trillions in productivity? Must be one of the greatest asymmetric bets in history.", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2024-07-15T16:26:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T16:26:15Z"}, {"author": "@DogeDelivers", "text": "Every technology architecture plateaus.  It's part of the process.  But LLM's to me are just a stepping stone, albeit an amazing one.  Once they plateau out, which can be reframed or recharacterized as "stabilizing", someone will figure out how to create a architecture that is a hyper-compressed incarnation of all the knowledge contained in the largest foundational models.  Once that happens, the scaling race starts anew, with some new architecture using the the old one (LLM), as a spring board.  Rinse and repeat.", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2024-07-15T04:21:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T04:21:48Z"}, {"author": "@novantha1", "text": "I think this take is missing a couple of hardware and software advancements which will heavily impact AI in 2025-2028.

  -Spiking neural networks are not yet well understood, but are potentially much more efficient in training (they effectively perform inference analogously to training in terms of hardware use). I also suspect they will perform better at time series agentic behavior, but that's personal editorialization. Regardless, we've seen ports of existing LLM architectures to spiking architectures, and that area is heating up pretty rapidly. Beyond that, the hardware is starting to get to market, and I could see a situation where all of a sudden companies that are able to run 7B LLMs can also train that class of model, and companies that today run 72B LLMs could train them as well. There's also power efficiency advantages of a few orders of magnitude to note, as well.

- In memory computing is also starting to get there. Now, I'm cheating a little bit on this one, in the sense that what we've managed so far are "near-memory" computing, but this is also an order of magnitude more efficient, and doesn't require the same paradigm shift as SNNs.

- There is a time lag in hardware advancements. For instance, the hardware we're seeing today was the best guess a half a decade ago at what we would need today. What were the conditions we saw in computing in 2019? It was very different from what we have now. I think what we're starting to see is a plethora of AI focused chip startups which will heavily influence the cost dynamics of training LLMs going forward, in companies like Tenstorrent, but also other AI accelerator startups producing hardware in the same vein. Right now we're seeing some of the people that had the foresight to see where things were going, but in the next two years I think the market could end up saturated with various random accelerators, and it's possible one of them could, if only be chance, be a massive advancement to the industry... Possibly in a way that the company itself may not have entirely anticipated. Keep in mind, we're currently only seeing the very earliest waves of "AI aware" hardware companies, and I think in the next 12 months we'll see some pretty impressive claims and a lot of interesting thinking in this area.

- The wave of people who learned machine learning skills may have an unintended benefit. If you have an industry of people who specialized into this area, all of a sudden every problem looks like a machine learning problem even if there were classic solutions for it, and there may be problems we solve with machine learning which have techniques that can be applied in other areas of ML. One example that comes to mind is the skip connections in computer vision which have now become commonplace in NLP through Transformers, we might similarly see new techniques develop to solve problems in domains not necessarily associated with AI currently which have a lot of benefits to AI model training in other areas. As an example, we might see an improvement in reinforcement learning to train AI to operate in video games (an area which is difficult to produce reward models for), but advancements there could apply to other areas as well, such as in training AI models to produce general media.

- There have been massive algorithmic advancements already, and not all of them have percolated evenly through the industry. Andrej Karpathy has demonstrated that a person could now replicate GPT-2 for significantly less than was used to train the model originally, and a lot of the things he did in the code were dependent on hardware advancements to an extent, but a lot of them were just genuine insight and more efficient ways of doing things that we've learned by having an industry of people working on and tackling these problems... But he left a lot of room on the table for education purposes (and to keep the recreation faithful), and there are plenty of things, particularly recent advances in MoE models, for instance, which he could have chosen to incorporate quite easily, for instance. We're seeing a lot of things like MoE, Mamba, linear RNNs, quantization, and many other advancements which could make training, or inference (which probably won't be quite so divorced concepts in future models but I digress), significantly more efficient, but which pose risks in the sense that they're uncharted territory. Should performance flatline, I wouldn't at all be surprised to see a huge advancement from any one of these ideas being applied in any number of ways. That's to say nothing of the recent series of papers taking in older ideas from related fields like signal processing and applying them to AI problems. Just in terms of giving all ideas a chance to be tested, and distributing them evenly through the industry, I think we could still see at least one or two more steps even with relatively the current paradigm.

- There have been massive advancements in our paradigms, understanding of AI, and our overall approach to building AI models. I really do think it just takes one massive advancement in data efficiency and training efficiency each, and we'll see an AGI capable industry. Personally, my bet is on some sort of rule based learning which can intuit rules of a system from a small number of examples, similarly to humans, and possibly by operating as a simulationist intelligence. Currently, models predict the next token, but I think you get much more interesting results by predicting the next environment, and evaluating your next token there. It might be as simple as continued advancement in multi-token prediction, or it might be a complicated encoder-decoder model for gradient descent specifically, or some other as of yet undefined training dynamic, but regardless, I feel that such an advancement could achieve human-level training performance in the sense of being able to intuit rules, environment, and solutions from a small number of examples, and with a relatively small amount of computation, by virtue of learning more deeply, and eking out more information from the given data.

I think these are all reasons why AI won't necessarily give us superhuman intelligence tomorrow, but will certainly continue to accelerate into the foreseeable future, and not all of these are dependent on continued excessive speculative investment.", "like_count": 37, "published_at": "2024-07-15T05:01:28Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T05:01:28Z"}, {"author": "@bnjiodyn", "text": "Respectfully disagree. Commercial uses are just starting. These will push the flywheel forward.", "like_count": 53, "published_at": "2024-07-15T04:58:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T04:59:01Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "The question is are one or two more cycles sufficient to get us to AGI/ASI and thus recursive self improvement. We have 100 billion synapses, GPT4 grade models have around 1 billion connection strengths. Hinton speculated the models may already have a superior learning algorithms, the current models are just smaller then the brain.", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2024-07-15T05:43:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T05:43:32Z"}, {"author": "@joeystroud6777", "text": "Is bill gates still in a position as an investor to see the technology to the same affect as Kevin Scott. I would say to trust Kevin more as he is the CTO. Although he could just be keeping hype going. Also great video!", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2024-07-15T04:11:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T04:11:21Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "An interesting research area would be training alternatives on the algorithm side, right now it’s still based on expensive analytical backpropagation. There are some early experiments that try diffusion models, not for the prediction of image pixels but parameter weights in a network. Or continuous learning. Jeff Hawkins recently got funding for his thousend brains theory from Microsoft, so we may either directly rebuilt how the brain learns continuously or borrow the methods and apply them to transformers.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-07-15T05:49:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T05:50:11Z"}, {"author": "@Perspectivemapper", "text": "📈Many reasons I believe AI will continue on an exponential course -- Improving energy efficiency, compute, data quality, algos, dev't techniques, chips, mindshare, resources, and AI-led breakthroughs across the board will I believe lead to 7-10 generations of improvements (~OOM's) within 10 years.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-07-15T04:57:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T04:57:11Z"}, {"author": "@Tata-ew4lz", "text": "Does it really matter if we get only 2 more cranks if those 2 cranks gets us to falsc?", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-07-15T06:33:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T06:33:04Z"}, {"author": "@roguegryphonica3147", "text": "Thanks for the document citation. It helps me listen more carefully to your arguement.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-15T16:29:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T16:29:05Z"}, {"author": "@runvnc208", "text": "One thing about this is that I believe that gpt-4o is actually gpt-5, just renamed. And with the amazing text-to-image and voice capabilities that haven't actually been released.. Sam Altman is keeping his word from when people were scared of gpt-5 and he said "we won't release gpt-5 any time soon". One way you can see this is that the timing coincides with the whole coup. Also it's a totally different architecture than gpt-4.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-15T14:34:34Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T14:34:34Z"}, {"author": "@azhuransmx126", "text": "I like the AGI, but I am somewhat afraid of the ASIs.  And unfortunately, I see how we are going straight there.  Just when electronic chips reach their limit, they will jump to photonic chips, which are already a reality and are much more powerful than electronic hardware.  Furthermore, the energy efficiency of the models will improve as AGI itself takes care of the next generation. 

By 2029, when the human impulse  is about to run out, it is more than enough time to pass the torch to AIs.  Then the economic, physical and intellectual human investment will no longer be necessary to continue with the acceleration, everything is then in charge of the AGIs and ASIs of that time, what Aschembrement calls the Intelligence Explotion.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-15T16:29:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T16:29:55Z"}, {"author": "@MichaelForbes-d4p", "text": "Why do people keep saying that GPT-5 is not yet trained? They have talked about the training being underway publicly several times. 

My brother works for NASA. They have already seen demos. I have been called a liar for this but it 100% true.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-07-15T10:28:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T10:28:49Z"}, {"author": "@Den289", "text": "Until we have a model released costing around $1B we can’t say whether scaling still holds or not", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-07-15T09:13:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T09:13:14Z"}, {"author": "@mrnoblemonkey8401", "text": "Two videos in one day this is awesome appreciate it!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-07-15T04:12:28Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T04:12:28Z"}, {"author": "@rexmundi8154", "text": "I’ve been watching some advances in teleoperation of robots, and coupled with real time AI language translation I feel like the stage is set for some real advances in small to mid size manufacturing and a lot of jobs that require human dexterity. Imagine AI robots that can do most of a task then kick the fussy bit over to a human working remotely from some low wage country. You’d have some kind of heads up display with directions that basically say something like put this bolt (flashing and highlighted) in this hole (flashing and highlighted).", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-15T11:08:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T11:08:08Z"}, {"author": "@youriwatson", "text": "When people argue that training costs are increasingly rapidly, do they take into account the progress in computational efficiency (new Nvidia GPUs)?", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-07-15T08:04:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T08:04:11Z"}, {"author": "@jean-pierrearcoragi6313", "text": "Bill Gates said that 540k memories for DOS would be more than enough… and other memorable predictions", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-19T14:34:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-19T14:34:43Z"}, {"author": "@TRXST.ISSUES", "text": "The models have to get bigger because they don't actually know what's inside the black box of what makes these things better.

They have no understanding so they are trying to brute force it.

If the model can understand itself and improve itself recursively then it's unnecessary to keep making the models bigger.

It's like taking a college grad and putting him through 10,000 years of college when 100 years would have done fine with the right training framework.

I still contend that a single architectural upgrade that leads to recursive self-improvement is enough, even with today's models and training size.

Making it think better with what's already there is enough. Calling it. And expected to be called a crazy man lol.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-07-15T04:38:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T04:38:51Z"}, {"author": "@S3raph02", "text": "LLMs won’t appear homologous for much longer. Different data sets for training and retraining, combined with varying multimodal methods will create unique experiences. this week: WE'RE BACK BITCHES, PREP FOR AGI AUGUST!!!", "like_count": 43, "published_at": "2024-07-14T22:45:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-14T22:45:23Z"}, {"author": "@TheMajesticSeaPancake", "text": "I think once 3D objects become an input or output modality common in models is when we'll start to see the next rise of significant emergent properties. Ai capable of creating a digital model of it's environment as a locked reference point it can access with vision and perhaps other modalities (playing a physics sim to figure out sound for example) will be huge, regardless of if q-star is possible/useful.", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2024-07-14T19:04:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-14T19:04:39Z"}, {"author": "@dustinbreithaupt9331", "text": "This is why I like your channel. Last week you had completely changed your outlook on AGI timelines or possibilities due to the recent plateauing of progress. Now you are once again changing your tune in light of possible new developments. Not enough people have the courage to change their mind or stance when new evidence becomes available to them.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2024-07-15T01:17:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T01:19:25Z"}, {"author": "@jonmichaelgalindo", "text": "OpenAI doesn't ship anything, but drops an unsubstantiated roadmap and conveniently "leaks" an unsubstantiated breakthrough when they've lost their crown.", "like_count": 94, "published_at": "2024-07-14T19:28:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-14T19:28:00Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "Let’s spawn 100 million digital PhDs (as much as possible with current hardware infrastructure) and let them come up with the next compute paradigm. Thank you.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-07-14T20:17:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-14T20:17:54Z"}, {"author": "@Telford-ho4sd", "text": "If SORA, the modified GPT-2 and the real time interaction showcases have taught me anything, it’s that OpenAI isn’t interested in shipping anything anymore, when we get AGI, it very might be that OpenAI’s competitors are the ones who release the public version, just like SORA.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-07-14T20:30:33Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-14T20:30:33Z"}, {"author": "@jyjjy7", "text": "The PhD thing... Keep the STNG shirt!", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-07-14T19:27:33Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-14T19:27:33Z"}, {"author": "@pietervoogt", "text": "I am happy that this has not (yet) become a channel focused on business. The general developments are interesting enough and they will keep happening.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2024-07-14T19:10:25Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-14T19:10:25Z"}, {"author": "@christopherwasow8702", "text": "Convenient timing for this "leak", right after delay of 4o voice + sonnet 3.5 and artifacts dominating.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-07-15T05:43:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-15T05:43:59Z"}, {"author": "@cupotko", "text": "So, it comes down to this: GPT-5 is a bunch of outputs from inference-efficient models like GPT-4, filtered and refined based on the results from an informed skeptic model called Q*/Strawberry.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-07-14T22:01:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-14T22:01:53Z"}, {"author": "@ryzikx", "text": "I mean, just imagine even one PhD with a 500,000 token per second read and write rate (etched ai chip)", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-07-16T14:57:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-16T14:57:59Z"}, {"author": "@tommornini2470", "text": "I think the reason OpenAI sets top AI goal as entire corporation is because that requires it to compete economically with human based corporate entities.

Your argument that energy demands limit AGI isn’t really valid IMHO, that only works if you assume optimization is ruled out entirely for the foreseeable future, Q* integrated into GPT-2 is just an example of what new architecture and optimization can do to bring down computational demand.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2024-07-14T20:38:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-14T20:41:56Z"}]
