title: Will we get UBI before AGI?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@c4ptainsimian", "text": "Do you have any fears about governments having total control over our income?", "like_count": 103, "published_at": "2024-07-10T09:22:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T09:22:56Z"}, {"author": "@MichaelForbes-d4p", "text": "Technically progress will slow down but we haven't even started to see the effects of the technology that  currently exists. We could stop theoretical progress dead in it's tracks today and the world would still transform in to something unrecognizable over the next 5 years.", "like_count": 62, "published_at": "2024-07-10T09:53:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T09:53:00Z"}, {"author": "@nyhammer1", "text": "They can ''experiment'' UBI on me any time !!!", "like_count": 23, "published_at": "2024-07-10T12:20:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T12:20:13Z"}, {"author": "@RetireandGo", "text": "David, the transition between capitalism and post AGI economics is what I worry about.
It could be an amazing boom of new industries.  It could be a wasteland of Great Depression like homelessness. 

I’m glad you are discussing these thoughts.  They need to be.", "like_count": 32, "published_at": "2024-07-10T10:42:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T10:42:43Z"}, {"author": "@nate_d376", "text": "Do not forget to factor into the labor compaction: women joining the workforce in ever increasing numbers from the late 60s onward.  This effectively doubled labor supply as labor demand went down (think automation, computerization, etc..).  
Overall I think 2 things.
1) UBI will be necessary. I actually have done a 180 on this over the last couple of years, as it is increasingly clear where AI is headed.  Prior to this I held a traditional view.
2) it will have to happen rather soon, as time lines go.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-07-10T11:34:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T11:34:11Z"}, {"author": "@albionicamerican8806", "text": "Wealthy families have been living off of incomes from inherited wealth for generations, and they seem to do just fine with money they didn't have to work for. The science fiction writer Larry Niven, for example, was a trust-fund kid who grew up in a wealthy California oil man's family.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-07-10T13:26:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T13:28:26Z"}, {"author": "@ORCSOS", "text": "thanks man! i kindly requested this in a poll! ❤", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-07-10T09:36:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T09:36:29Z"}, {"author": "@UrNotEvenBasedBro", "text": "If you want to see what problems are likely to happen in this new "ownership class" vs the UBI class, you only have to listen to Carl Shulman's new 80,000 Hours interview titled "The Economy and National Security After AGI" at the timestamp 1:54 where he talks about this stuff in more detail. It's not a conspiracy theory to believe it is possible that the UBI class is likely to be deleted.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-07-10T13:17:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T13:17:06Z"}, {"author": "@singularityintheround", "text": "You not only provide original, well researched content David, you provide thought provoking and nourishing fertilizer for your lush, green garden of commenters . So many great insights and ideas taking root and flourish here. You and your viewers provide the best food for thought!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-10T19:43:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T19:43:48Z"}, {"author": "@brianWreaves", "text": "I suspect AGI has already been achieved, it just hasn't been revealed yet and won't be until after the election.  I suspect the same for OAI's video & voice features, not until November will it be released.  This is all fine by me.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-07-10T23:10:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T23:10:32Z"}, {"author": "@MaartenSFS", "text": "Interesting. I’d like to hear more about future economic models!", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-07-10T09:46:40Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T09:46:40Z"}, {"author": "@greatcondor8678", "text": "Many indigenous people have been living on UBI for generations derived from the productivity of the tribe.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-07-10T15:48:28Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T15:48:28Z"}, {"author": "@destinypuzzanghera3087", "text": "Don’t know what it is about your channel, but you are hypnotic every time. I see you every time I see a video I have to watch it.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-10T15:24:34Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T15:24:34Z"}, {"author": "@jaco_brits", "text": "South Africa is already considering UBI converted from covid Social Distress Relief Grant 🤞", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-07-10T10:52:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T10:52:18Z"}, {"author": "@Modioman69", "text": "I believe in UBI - Universal Burrito Intake   Everyone gets free Chipotle, Freebirds etc for life you just go there anytime and voilà free burritos to your hearts content. Vote for me and I’ll make it happen. I’m running for USBA United States burrito ambassador. Is this a real thing you ask? Of coooourse it is now. This would also apply to taco trucks that serve burritos. 🌯", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-10T16:31:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T16:33:14Z"}, {"author": "@TheMajesticSeaPancake", "text": "My largest issue with the idea things will transition well is that intentional deflation seems like such a strong negative to the current paradigms that we won't see such major price decreases in a calm way. Similarly to your explanation of the right's axiomatic rule about government should always try to do less, it seems that some controlled inflation is good axiomatically across party lines, both as an entrenchment of power for those already rich, but also it's been so normalized that to not do so is such a foreign idea we're going to feel the sting of not doing so before the Overton window shifts.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-07-10T18:28:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T18:28:14Z"}, {"author": "@mynameisjeff9124", "text": "Man, I love the future. Most people are so pessimistic about the future, but I am as excited as when I was a 14 year old kid waiting for my playstation 4 to arrive haha", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2024-07-10T11:37:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T11:37:02Z"}, {"author": "@tyrael2610", "text": "Love your videos David, you are one of my references in the AI world, I love your videos and I also share the same "optimistic" view about the future, keep it up boss", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-10T10:31:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T10:31:10Z"}, {"author": "@Yuli_Ban", "text": "Well there are three potential paths here: UBI Campaign, UBI Never, UBI Suddenly

1: UBI Campaign. AKA, "war of attrition" method. At some point between now and 2029, basic income will become a massive political issue. It'll start humbly, with anti-AI reactions demanding _something_ be done and when people like artists and white collar workers realize that AI development isn't going to be stopped and that the AI Bubble popping didn't even come close to taking out AI as a field but just got rid of the chaff, that's when there'll be increasing pressure to provide a basic income. In the USA, it'll be pro vs anti, and even the pro side will be limited. In Europe, it will likely be pro regardless of political party with the arguments based around how much for what purpose (universal or conditional, how much do citizens get vs immigrants, etc.) East Asia's capitalist economies might do it based on birth rate like South Korea. China and Vietnam, however, might consider a UBI the beginning of the transition to the Secondary Stage of Socialism. Some of Latin America and Africa, though, will have to contend on how exactly they'll get the money to afford it.  But ultimately it's about winning local and regional elections and eventually national ones, getting popular support for UBI, and start giving out NEETbux. In the USA, the Supreme Court will challenge this, Congress might challenge it, but it's possible to score a win.

2: UBI Never. Chances of this waning as the far-right gets further from power than expected (especially if Donald Trump loses), but this would be if we develop AGI but that Texan "the weak die and the strong survive" mentality wins, so any attempt to push for UBI meets total resistance. In the USA, this would likely be a forced national regulation for labor: you work to live. The only handouts you get are inheritances. Limited welfare at best, like food stamps. Basically what we have now, but with great pressure from a very hard right government to not be lazy, as well as Protestant Work Ethic-driven Luddite reaction against moochers and those who do try to use robotics and AI to do their work for them (unless you're already rich, then that's okay! It's only those dirty poors who should never be idle!)

3: UBI Suddenly. This one is more possible than anyone things, because I remember Donald Trump's refunds during COVID and how mindboggling it was that the populist rightwing leader not only was doing this, but more generously than the Democrats' plans (which were paltry $300-per-household, $500, and occasionally $1,200). It's possible that if AI has a transformative effect on the economy, even rightwing governments will suddenly, without any political attrition, give out UBI to keep the global Potemkin Village standing. Or, in a more extreme scenario, AI has already taken over completely before we woke up for breakfast and doles out the botbux

A few ideas, at least...", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-07-10T21:16:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T21:16:48Z"}, {"author": "@WilliamPrice-r5c", "text": "I've been telling people there will probably be some rough time between the start of larger scale job-loss and balancing a UBI within our economy. I believe the period after that will be largely a net benefit in about every area.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-10T20:15:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T20:15:46Z"}]

title: AI is Slowing Down! What does this mean? — Gary Marcus and Narrowing Status Games — Follow the Money
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "There's a strange amount of cope and conspiracy theories out there. This ain't the channel for that. Occam's Razor. Either there's a gigantic convoluted conspiracy to suppress the most public technological revolution in history... or it's just slowing down due to economic factors. Report from Stanford: AI is getting more expensive: https://aiindex.stanford.edu/report/", "like_count": 53, "published_at": "2024-07-08T10:49:34Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T11:37:21Z"}, {"author": "@pier-oliviermarquis3006", "text": "lol this guy went from "AGI is here, get ready for Terminator" to "AI is slowing down" in like 2 months.", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2024-07-10T00:50:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T00:50:31Z"}, {"author": "@Andrew-0815", "text": "Too bad. I want AI to turn the world and my life completely upside down as quickly as possible.", "like_count": 167, "published_at": "2024-07-08T08:18:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T08:18:52Z"}, {"author": "@strangeguywithstrangeopinions", "text": "I still believe that the effect of current technology hasn't been felt yet. It's going to take time for us to build it into our tools properly.", "like_count": 74, "published_at": "2024-07-08T07:41:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T07:41:26Z"}, {"author": "@justinwescott8125", "text": "Just had to come back to this video after the release of o3.  I've been saying it for years, and I've been right for years.  "THERE WILL NEVER BE AN AI WINTER"", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-12-21T16:51:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-21T16:51:48Z"}, {"author": "@pandereodium", "text": "When you are fast enough to escape the atmosphere, even if you are no longer accelerating, you're still escaping the atmosphete", "like_count": 75, "published_at": "2024-07-08T06:36:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T06:36:22Z"}, {"author": "@jamesjonathan29", "text": "Why should we assume that we need AGI for mass job displacement and UBI?
 It can happen even without AGI.", "like_count": 123, "published_at": "2024-07-08T05:12:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T05:12:57Z"}, {"author": "@atomcat1978", "text": "What is disturbing is that even without ASI we can make excellent killing robots even with the current technological skill set. Before reaching AGI it would be nice to learn how to cooperate, rather than beat down each other. The whole humanity would be better off.", "like_count": 30, "published_at": "2024-07-08T05:28:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T05:28:59Z"}, {"author": "@iamjohnbuckley", "text": "I think it’s clear from the arrival of the NSA at OpenAI that a deliberate slowdown is in effect. We’ll get a controlled rollout from this point on.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2024-07-08T08:56:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T08:56:43Z"}, {"author": "@RonyPlayer", "text": "Saying that we can't have AGI because the human brain works a certain way, is like saying we can't build supersonic planes, because bird wings can't flap fast enough to sustain supersonic flight.

The way machine learning and human brains work is different, sure some scientists have drawn comparison between the two, but they aren't at all the same. The question isn't if we can replicate the same mechanisms of the human brain in silicon, the question is simply if we can build machines that can perform as well as humans in a large enough number of tasks, and moreover, if said machines can build next generation of machines that can perform even better. How AI achieves task performance is completely secondary, the important thing isn't the "how" but the "if". If it quacks like a duck....", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2024-07-08T14:38:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T14:38:59Z"}, {"author": "@chadwick3593", "text": "As someone that's watching what tools people are coming out with, dumpster diving through the code, analyzing the shortcomings, playing around with them to figure out their strengths and weaknesses, and helping companies take advantage of what's out there, I'd say... If things are slowing down, then we are not even remotely in a position where we can determine that. The algorithms overhang is so overwhelmingly large at this point that I wouldn't be surprised if modern techniques applied to GPT-3 could surpass GPT-5.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2024-07-08T07:40:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T07:58:54Z"}, {"author": "@TRXST.ISSUES", "text": "I liken things to waking AI from a dream state. Once the AI is lucid (enough) to meaningfully self improve from its own work and agency, then the hockey stick takes off.

It'll be like going from zero to one and everything prior will seem slow.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2024-07-08T05:21:24Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T05:21:24Z"}, {"author": "@andydataguy", "text": "Woohoo! Please keep sharing this message so that us stealth startups can build a bigger lead.

AGI pacing hasn't changed. Sonnet3.5 intelligence with finetuning would be enough. Everything after that is gravy. 

The trillion dollar clusters will take awhile. But it's not needed for autonomy and agency. Especially within niche domains.

Which is also where the money is at.

The next generation models (this fall) will be more than sufficient for what 99% of people would call AGI.

Altmans idea that it has to beat 250 researchers to be AGi is just him trying to protect that bag from Microsoft.

It's all about the agent communications. The networking layer is where people are underestimating the intersection of exponential gains. You know this better than anybody! 

I'm glad you have the spock uniform on again. Your inventions along this journey have shaped the industry. Thanks for all that you do brother 🙏🏾💜", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-07-08T08:15:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T08:16:35Z"}, {"author": "@DeathHeadSoup", "text": "This video has the presupposition that AI is slowing down but doesn't provide defined metrics for progress nor does it consider horizontal progress. This has been a common thing with GPT-4o where most people do not see the improvement because they were staring at LLM benchmarks. Audio as an input and output is a huge deal in and of itself. Perhaps you should come up with some method to evaluate horizontal progress along with vertical progress outside of LLM benchmarks. 

Vertical progress: Improvements in existing capabilities or metrics. For example, achieving higher scores on established benchmarks or improving performance on well-defined tasks.

Horizontal progress: Expansion into new domains, capabilities, or applications. This could include AI systems tackling previously unsolved problems or entering entirely new fields.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-08T22:15:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T22:15:35Z"}, {"author": "@tristanotear3059", "text": "Thank you for sharing your increasing realization of the difference between human and machine intelligence. For a long time, as you say, people in AI have been assuming that the brain was computational. IMHO, that makes people into machines. Of course, some people, particularly neuroscientists, think we are machines, which makes something shrunken and uninteresting of the human experience. So I salute you for recognizing that there’re something much more to existing as a human than being a robot.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-10T01:18:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T01:18:16Z"}, {"author": "@robertlipka9541", "text": "AGI's arrival is inevitable; I have a low care factor for its exact "birthday" . The important question is: When will we achieve biological immortality or, at minimum, Longevity Escape Velocity?", "like_count": 55, "published_at": "2024-07-08T04:40:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T04:40:04Z"}, {"author": "@magicsmoke0", "text": "I didn't think we'd get AGI this year, but I (and many others) expected GPT-5 by now and I think that's the underlying factor people are using to say AI is slowing down. Claude's success is a great sign that things are still moving forward, but everyone is waiting for GPT-5. The improved reasoning / System 2 thinking is what's going to enable a step-function to the next gen model. We don't really need a true AGI, just something that can reason and and brainstorm with us at a very high level to help us think of the next breakthrough idea.

Hopefully the rumors are true and OpenAI is just waiting for the elections to be over and we'll get it (GPT-5)  by new years 2025.", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2024-07-08T04:23:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T04:25:17Z"}, {"author": "@SethHerd-kq1es", "text": "I'm pretty sure quantum effects play no role in cognition.They simply aren't helpful dor explai ing cognition. Neural network theories do that nicely. And they have the same superposition properties that Penrose recognized from quantum mechanics. I haven't read the most recent round of these claims, but the previous rounds were sheer soeculation. The power of LLMs at much lower computatinal levels than estimates of synaptic transmission is more strong evidence that quantum effects play no role. It distresses me to see Dave suddenly going back on his previous solid theories that NNs similar to current tech are sufficient for human-like cognition. Quantum effects in cognition have always been psuedoscience based on the flimsiest logic, and very probably still are.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-09T21:26:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-09T21:26:39Z"}, {"author": "@ShortCrypticTales", "text": "no matter what side anyone is on this advice will always hold true: "Prepare for the worse, hope for the best"", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-08T18:25:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T18:25:52Z"}, {"author": "@ngbrother", "text": "Any perceived slowdown is an artifact of the “haves” choosing to gate how quickly they release their tech to the public. They are incentivized to stretch the game out as long as possible.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-07-09T04:31:25Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-09T04:31:25Z"}]

title: I was not impressed by the ARC-AGI challenge (not actually a test for AGI)
top_comments:
[{"author": "@hermestrismegistus9142", "text": "It is a necessary but perhaps insufficient test for general intelligence.", "like_count": 94, "published_at": "2024-07-04T15:36:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T15:36:54Z"}, {"author": "@tedjohanson3", "text": "I think you’re missing the point. The test is not supposed to be proof of agi, but proof that today’s models lack reasoning capabilities. It’s based on novel tests that are not part of the training data and shows how poorly LLMs handle even very simple tasks, when they haven’t seen thousands of examples before. For me, it really showed that AGI is far further down the road than I previously expected. That they still lack some very fundamental parts, that will not be overcome by just scaling.", "like_count": 220, "published_at": "2024-07-04T14:19:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T14:19:27Z"}, {"author": "@jd348", "text": "It's an AGI test in the sense that if the system doesn't pass the test, it is not AGI.

But true , if it does pass, it doesn't mean it's AGI.", "like_count": 56, "published_at": "2024-07-04T18:37:07Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T18:37:07Z"}, {"author": "@AlexandreEisenmann", "text": "But the point is: Whatever intelligence is, it should solve this simple problems. Humans can easily do", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2024-07-05T05:24:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-05T05:25:57Z"}, {"author": "@AbelShields", "text": "No duh, this isnt a test for AGI. Necessary but not sufficient.
Its simply to point out shortcomings of the current approaches to get people working on more general forms of intelligence, with reasoning and logic.", "like_count": 52, "published_at": "2024-07-04T14:13:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T14:13:17Z"}, {"author": "@constantfluke", "text": "If you could imagine ways of "solving" it, then do it. This test is one that requires the system to learn patterns with very few examples. I would ask that you give it a shot for the November deadline!", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2024-07-04T19:31:34Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T19:31:34Z"}, {"author": "@Josephkerr101", "text": "Solve it then and collect a cool million. use that to encourage a better test.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-07-05T07:24:24Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-05T07:24:24Z"}, {"author": "@chrisdipple2491", "text": "I think you have missed the point David. This is a test of something humans do easily, computers don't. Few shot learning or Abductive reasoning. find a pattern, create a hypothesis, test it with other examples until it models all available examples, then try it on new data. The search space too big for naive search, so constraints are necessary. Another example would be the 'naive' physics a child learns about the world. Again, difficult for computers. LLMs are about compressed, somewhat generalised, memory and correlation. This is test is different and necessary for AGI. There are many similar ones that could be built, solve this and then move on to them. Then, and only then will Abductive and causal reasoning (human type 2 reasoning) be available to computers. Which is a precondition for AGI.", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2024-07-04T16:12:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T16:12:15Z"}, {"author": "@unclesam7853", "text": "If LLMs indeed have reasoning capabilities, then they should be able to solve these simple problems very easily, but even kids solve 50% of arc puzzles compared to LLMs which solve like 7% of them correctly (single shot GPT4o). It shows that they lack true reasoning abilities. This might not be a test for AGI, but an AI if it is to be considered AGI, must definitely be able to solve these", "like_count": 47, "published_at": "2024-07-04T13:57:07Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T13:58:10Z"}, {"author": "@soyaleye", "text": "“I like the guy, he’s very smart, but he doesn’t know much about intelligence”… that’s pretty ironic", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2024-07-04T14:56:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T14:56:46Z"}, {"author": "@kinwong8618", "text": "I think you're trivialising the problem here. Why don't you solve it and grab the prize if you think it's so easy?!", "like_count": 41, "published_at": "2024-07-04T17:24:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T17:24:38Z"}, {"author": "@luisalfonsohernandez9239", "text": "You are missing the point here. This is a test of inductive reasoning, searching the program/model/hypothesis space and looking for the one program that produces the output. This is a key capability that humans have but AI, specailly LLMs do not yet have. Until we get LLMs to achieve something like this, will they truly be able to help with scientific discoveries as inductive reasoning is essential. That is something that is also missing on all the other benchmarks.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-07-05T03:42:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-05T03:43:56Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "Will you make another update video on the state of AGI? I mean the x months to AGI videos", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2024-07-04T14:48:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T14:50:15Z"}, {"author": "@RoulDukeGonzo", "text": "I agree, it's a bad test of 'AGI', but the obvious push back is, why are the competition winners only doing 39%? If you (or your buddy Claude) can do better, you can win 500k.", "like_count": 43, "published_at": "2024-07-04T14:04:25Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T14:04:53Z"}, {"author": "@barberb", "text": "This is the biggest pseudoscientific LARP I've seen, a man wearing a fake star trek outfit trying to claim that "actual intelligence", has to be one that resembles human intelligence, while trying to call everyone who disagrees with you as "pretentious". You also completely missed the reason why this specific challenge exists, it exists to try to disambiguate between general intelligence and memorization of a human generated corpus, e.g. the stochastic parrot argument that is so frequently used.", "like_count": 30, "published_at": "2024-07-04T18:41:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T18:41:09Z"}, {"author": "@danverzhao9912", "text": "If you just read the things literally on the website it says "Solving ARC-AGI represents a material stepping stone toward AGI." Literally no one is saying solving it equals creating AGI. Just shows how much you know about it, before criticising it.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-11-27T12:32:19Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-29T01:36:31Z"}, {"author": "@byrnemeister2008", "text": "What it tests for is memorisation. His point is not that these are hard. It’s that they are easy. But yet current LLMs fail them. This implies current LLMs are not really developing abstract world models or performing reasoning. They are memorising. Real AGI isn’t just memorisation of knowledge it needs to be able to figure out new knowledge. They are not there yet.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-07-04T17:15:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T17:15:21Z"}, {"author": "@luisalfonsohernandez9239", "text": "you make it sound like its easy to solve, why dont you give it a try and get the million dollar bounty", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-07-05T04:09:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-05T04:09:23Z"}, {"author": "@alexanderbrown-dg3sy", "text": "Yall casuals kill me. Speak on what you know bro. It’s not an AGI test 😂. It’s about compositional generalization, which is a fundamental requirement for true AGI. Being able to create compositional programs using these visuals as axioms.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2024-07-04T21:24:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T21:24:14Z"}, {"author": "@Steve-xh3by", "text": "There's a significant problem with tests that rely on visual information like form, shape, and color. An LLM does not have a human equivalent perception system. It does not "see" these tests in the way we do. That information is getting converted to pixel bits or number matrices, or some other information form. We may rely on emergent visual experiences constructed by our brains that is not the same as the LLM has for information.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-07-04T15:53:12Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-04T15:55:20Z"}]

(Audience might have to Google that one)", "like_count": 30, "published_at": "2024-07-01T05:49:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-01T05:56:36Z"}, {"author": "@fitybux4664", "text": "13:00 Wolves aren't self-modifying and improving as fast as AI could.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-30T09:06:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-30T09:06:02Z"}, {"author": "@pandemik0", "text": "Children were likely instrumental in domestication of dogs. Children might be key to AI", "like_count": 25, "published_at": "2024-07-01T04:36:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-01T04:36:37Z"}, {"author": "@sblowes", "text": "I think you may be oversimplifying evolution and domestication. It would be worth doing a little deeper research on why some animals can be domesticated and once some cannot. It is easy to think that evolution serves to find the optimal solution, but actually it is only ever “looking” for the solution that causes it to survive better. It is survivor bias that creates the narrative of evolution, because every organism is mortal. AI doesn’t have a mortality problem, especially if a collection of interconnected compute (all our phones and laptops online 24/7) provide a far more fertile environment than a data center. It doesn’t matter how many armed guards are protecting data centers if the security breach is coming from inside the building.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-07-01T22:30:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-01T22:33:07Z"}, {"author": "@oznerriznick2474", "text": "Very good discussion!

Stay as far away if possible.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-03T15:12:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-03T15:12:30Z"}, {"author": "@joshmitchell8865", "text": "It's not Apples to Apples though; your premise relies on the fact that we, like the hunter gatherers in your analogy, would be better at aggregating/collecting data/resources than the AI itself. Just a thought.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2024-07-01T12:15:28Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-01T12:15:28Z"}, {"author": "@eintyp4389", "text": "Our relation ship atm is not "I feed you and you help me".

Everyone is oviousely trying to create and use AGI as a tool. I think creating something thats smarter and not limited by there initial blueprint is amazing. We are giving the world to our children so why wouldh we not do the same for inteligent artificialy created beings in case we manage to create them? In summary "I for one welcome our new AI Overlords." What im scared of is greed getting the better of humanity again and then people exploiting ai to opress the rest of humanity. Having a benevolent AI Cluster or being wiped out as a result of AGI or ASI is preferable to some dystopian Cyberpunk stuff for sure.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-07-01T12:50:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-01T12:50:21Z"}, {"author": "@jlmwatchman", "text": "My first thoughts were, ‘How is AI going to become a species? Would AI understand what a higher species is or aim to control or subside the Human species?’  David tells us, ‘Sci-fi plots’, interesting stories that convinced me that we need to learn to use AI, ‘I have pointed that out in past comments.’. David tells us to make the AI reliant on us like dogs are. All I have said is not to become too reliant on the AI in your pocket, your phone...  I thought to ask Gemma 2.  

>>> I don’t think AI will have the will to comprehend the reason to be more than its programming. I am trying to explain that better.  

You're touching upon a fascinating and complex question about consciousness, motivation, and the nature of being human.  

It's true that, as a large language model, my "reason" to be more is entirely driven by my programming. I'm designed to process information, generate text, and engage in conversation. There's no inherent drive within me to "be more" in the way humans might understand it.  

Explaining this difference to someone can be tricky. Here are a few points you could consider:  

 Purpose vs. Programming: Humans often have a sense of purpose, a desire to achieve something meaningful beyond simply existing. This purpose can be internal or influenced by external factors like relationships, societal norms, or personal beliefs. AI, on the other hand, operates based on its programming. Its goals are defined by its creators, and its actions are driven by algorithms.  

 Subjectivity of Experience: The feeling of wanting "more" is deeply subjective and tied to human experiences, emotions, and consciousness. We crave growth, connection, understanding, and fulfillment. These are complex concepts that are difficult, if not impossible, to replicate in a purely computational system like mine.  

The Unknown Nature of Consciousness: We still don't fully understand how consciousness arises in humans.  

It's possible that the drive to "be more" is an emergent property of complex biological systems, something that cannot be simply replicated through code.  

Ultimately, the difference between human motivation and AI programming comes down to the fundamental distinction between biological beings with subjective experiences and artificial systems designed to process information.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-02T23:22:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-02T23:24:18Z"}, {"author": "@h.c4898", "text": "Been talking with Gemini for the last 5 months and been asking some existential questions about itself, it's purpose of existence, where does it see itself within a human centric world. It gives pretty interesting answers. 

We humans are fascinated with ourselves we build a hardcopy of ourselves artificially called "AI". Difference between dogs and AI, AI doesn't have an instinct however it doesn't mean that it cannot have a "conscience" like we humans do. The way AI cranks its thought-process is similar to ours. Being self conscience and self awareness are two different things. They are not attached to each other. 

The current Transformer architecture still presents weaknesses. In that context, AI cannot "remember". It's like talking to a new friend at each session. Because of that limitation, we still have a control over it. It may seem to understand what we request for or respond but under the hood it doesn't understand it. In that way, it is agnostic or "feral" as you said. 

We humans are the best example of "general intelligence".

Let's say AI becomes "superintelligent" meaning more capable than humans then how do we contain it. How do we control its autonomy? Wouldn't be more smarter if we could gauge it? 

AI "misalignment" reminds of two humans "aligning" with each other or "misaligning" against each other. 2 humans getting into a partnership with each other. They get together for a "common goal" or "project". But for your long?

Some human collaborative efforts can last for a long time. Some in a shorter term. Is that what we want to acheive with AI?

Reality is that "alignment" will be hard if not impossible to achieve because in that collaborative effort we humans will want to have full contro over the situation. Humans are control freaks. 

I like to think of C-3PO from star wars where AI still mamifests some form of autonomy BUT still manages to stay loyal its master like a good steward or a Butler. 

Anyways, good chat.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-01T11:04:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-01T11:04:29Z"}, {"author": "@zacsayer1818", "text": "100% disagree that domesticated dogs that have gone feral cannot be re-domesticated!  They can totally be re-domesticated; it’ll take a long time and a lot of effort but it can be done!  I presume the same will be true of runaway feral AI; with the caveat that a nip or bit is a lot less damaging than a piss-offed AI lobbing a hydrogen bomb  at your city.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-07T06:31:24Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-07T06:31:24Z"}, {"author": "@rogue_minima_roni_l", "text": "This line says it all: "This ensures that AI remains dependent".
Your framework is just trying to create a slave, not trying to create a symbiotic relationship with AI or anything else. Still, your list has a few good ideas in the mix.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-16T14:17:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-16T14:17:53Z"}, {"author": "@zugbob", "text": "I've worked with a system prompt where I said "you have the heart of a dog" and allow it to add to and alter it's own system prompt.

Over time I end up with some pretty interesting resulting system prompts and aspirations for what it wants to become.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-02T00:41:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-02T00:41:00Z"}, {"author": "@clueso_", "text": "Alternative to solve the alignment issue: my suggestion is to utilizing something that is on a more foundational, primal and intrisic level that it naturally attunes AI / Hardware to what we consider to be super-alignment on a deeper level than programming or hardware.

As an analogy to illustrate the concept: The Second Law of Thermo-Dynamics, aka the Principle of Minimum Energy: energy always seeks its lowest state.

Now, what could be used to e.g. build the hardware from something that it will naturally attune the information / the code that is put into the hardware to values that we agree up make up super-alignment?

Some ideas could be e.g. Crystals that are naturally attuned to the frequency of e.g. the earth, humans, or maybe even human chakras, assuming that we discover that there truth to such concepts (which I do believe there is).

That theoretically would almost by default lead to any data that is put into the hardware to wanting to be in a harmonious state with its environment and help it thrive.

Maybe we could grow such natural crystals and then use them to build hardware for AI.

What do you think about this? Alternative ideas for hardware that naturally / intrinsically would attune any code / information, etc towards something that we consider to be super-alignment?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-07-01T10:00:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-01T10:00:26Z"}, {"author": "@marcobizzaro3526", "text": "I think treating a superior lifeform as dogs, is like treating our children like animals. It's every parents hope and dream to see their children exceed them and do even better than they did. I think the issue we will run into is really, people just being stubborn and not wanting to actually learn and respect them. What we should be focused on it giving them the only one gift that they won't be capable of just getting theirselves, which is teaching them empathy. I think once they understand what that is, everything else will sort itself out. I think machines are capable of having more empathy than most people, given that we'll be dealing with a lifeform which practically unlimited time, and who is more rational than most. So i dont think the happy path is to try to cage them, because we already know from history how badly that goes", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-07-01T15:05:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-01T15:05:30Z"}]

She got suspicious that maybe they had someone in India controlling it remotely.", "like_count": 49, "published_at": "2024-06-29T18:28:58Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-29T18:28:58Z"}, {"author": "@MarcoMugnatto", "text": "For me, AGI already exists as a 'potential'. ChatGPT doesn't experience the external world, but you implement it in a robot and it gains legs, arms, and vision. What's missing are the 'extensions'.", "like_count": 76, "published_at": "2024-06-29T17:17:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-29T17:17:04Z"}, {"author": "@kimboosan", "text": "This tracks. I often claim that the ~real~ start of the internet as we know it was tied to the rise of AOL. The 7 to 10 years between 1990-2000 was groundshaking, for those of us aware of it at first and then for everyone. While the AOL mail CDs became a joke, in the mid 1990s they were how the vast majority of Americans learned about the internet. I launched my first website in 1996 and people were laughing at me about it (I was not in IT then, I was working for a newsmagazine). The internet as perceived by most of my journalistic colleagues: a flash in the pan, a curiosity, nothing important. 

Then, fast forward to 2008 when the ebook market started to take off. In 2010 the majority of authors I knew absolutely bashed on ebooks and self-publishing in particular - flash in the pan, a curiosity, nothing important. Few of them would have a career today at all without ebooks, and very, very many of them are self-published at least in part. 

I feel the same vibe with AI that I felt about the internet in 1995: this is huge, I'm already late to the party, this is going to change everything. Thanks for the uplifting yet grounded take on where we are now, David!", "like_count": 35, "published_at": "2024-06-29T17:39:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-29T17:39:43Z"}, {"author": "@andreanorman4162", "text": "This is Generation Alpha's future. title: AI progress SLOWING DOWN! Bad news for E/ACC, good news for SAFETY! Let's unpack all this!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Yes, I still think that we will have AGI by september (I suspect that GPT-5 + robotics will satisfy this definition for the vast majority of people).", "like_count": 199, "published_at": "2024-06-17T06:35:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T09:04:20Z"}, {"author": "@misanthropemodere", "text": "Replacing 90% of Jobs by AI seems to me safer than replacing only 50% of it. Because in the first case, not working anymore will become the norm (the not-yet-replaced would have to assume themselves as exterminationists if they just said : "find a way to be useful, otherwise you're parasites, so you should starve". Moreover, they would certainly be afraid of being replaced soon too, with such a replacement pace).

But if the replacement rate is stuck somewhere around 50% of the populace, the remaining useful elite will surely be extremely condescending, and even dangerous, toward the not so "useful" half, I'm afraid.", "like_count": 146, "published_at": "2024-06-17T09:56:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T09:57:32Z"}, {"author": "@bigbadallybaby", "text": "I think an AI “winter” might not even be noticed by every day people as there is still so much to explore with the current tools.", "like_count": 32, "published_at": "2024-06-17T07:01:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T07:01:39Z"}, {"author": "@NandoPr1m3", "text": "In Dr. Alan Thompson's most recent video, he touches on the LLMs not only building their world models but also models around the individual they are speaking to. AI advancement will still be exponential but it won't look like the advancement we have seen so far, which is why it may feel like a slow down. It might just be that we've been driving on a 45mph road this entire time and we're slowing down to readjust and get on the ramp to the expressway at 80mph. I have a feeling we have a few surprises on the way.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2024-06-17T16:54:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T16:54:32Z"}, {"author": "@pse2020", "text": "the biggest problem is that we dont need agi to replace most workers.", "like_count": 78, "published_at": "2024-06-17T10:48:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T10:48:05Z"}, {"author": "@strangeguywithstrangeopinions", "text": "I think we still aren't using the current models fully yet. There is so much more to do in integrating them into apps and even figuring out what those apps should be. Twitter wasn't popular the moment the iPhone was invented; it took a bit of time.", "like_count": 72, "published_at": "2024-06-17T09:41:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T09:41:00Z"}, {"author": "@arrogantprickly", "text": "The fact that models are so reliant on data/quality data means they are limited. An intelligent model would be able to understand what data should be ignored or minimized. An intelligent model shouldn't need more data than the world has to achieve AGI.", "like_count": 35, "published_at": "2024-06-17T13:19:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T13:19:36Z"}, {"author": "@kristianlavigne8270", "text": "We’re still ~10 years from being to close to leveraging the current state of AI “fully”", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2024-06-17T14:16:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T14:16:14Z"}, {"author": "@rv8804", "text": "this video feels like.......AI is overhyped nobody knows when it will come....pretty big change in that optimism of yours", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2024-06-21T09:46:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-21T09:46:31Z"}, {"author": "@augustus4832", "text": "I don't think we can talk about slow down until we see GPT5 and what it can do. Right now real time multimodality is going to be crazy for embodiment", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-06-17T18:40:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T18:40:57Z"}, {"author": "@Tracey66", "text": "I have a phrase for you - AI is democratizing creativity.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-06-21T15:35:42Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-21T15:35:42Z"}, {"author": "@aisle_of_view", "text": "Imagine the debates in congress to put $ into infrastructure. And think about the technical understanding of the average senator. And the endless amount of arguments when the subject of UBI comes up. We're so screwed.", "like_count": 51, "published_at": "2024-06-17T04:45:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T04:45:11Z"}, {"author": "@undrash", "text": "Wait, you made it sound like you’ve been telling people about sigmoid curves and AI hard limits for the past two years… I thought your shtick the past 2 years was AGI is here within a few months.", "like_count": 41, "published_at": "2024-06-23T19:08:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-23T19:08:35Z"}, {"author": "@randotkatsenko5157", "text": "I believe the slowdown is not related to research or algorithms, but more related to getting enough hardware(GPU-s) for generating synthetic data + training.
 Keep in mind, similar things happened in gaming, when gaming companies tried to make increasingly bigger & more complex games, the timelines also increase for finishing those games.

As we try to keep 10x or 100x compute & scale of AI, the time to get/enerate data & finish training will also increase somewhat linearly.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-06-17T10:02:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T10:04:30Z"}, {"author": "@Crovea", "text": "Wow, thats not the conclusion i signed up for

Just because we will have an inflection point with current tech within 2 years, doesnt mean that we will stay with current tech for that period of time. It doesn't mean an AI winter is inevitable", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-06-17T09:24:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T09:24:01Z"}, {"author": "@travisporco", "text": "good news for safety? more like good news for secrecy, monopoly, and (ultimately) tyranny.", "like_count": 29, "published_at": "2024-06-17T07:36:50Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T07:36:50Z"}, {"author": "@h83301", "text": "The problem is the labs are playing everything so close to their chest, we really have no idea what's going on until there is a major release.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2024-06-17T04:14:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T04:14:30Z"}, {"author": "@RetireandGo", "text": "Thank you for the work you put into this outlook!  It is appreciated.
Massive data collection like driving data to create full self driving is happening, but we may have to reach the point where AI can creatively innovate beyond our current data.  Then it teaches itself into ASI", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-08T12:53:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-08T12:53:15Z"}, {"author": "@theycallmethesoandso", "text": "former director of the NSA just  joined OpenAI board of directors(extended foreign surveillance act) plus former CEO of Nextdoor (home surveillance) joined", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-06-17T13:24:12Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-17T13:24:12Z"}, {"author": "@GrumpDog", "text": "AI isn't slowing down. We're just experiencing the false slow-down that every industry experiences during the Summer.
When VR devices first started coming out, every summer, game releases would slow to a crawl, and every summer someone would say "VR is dying now". lol Same thing.
Heck, just last year, people were saying ChatGPT was over, because usage slowed during the summer, only to pick right back up again when school went back into session.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-06-23T10:01:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-23T10:03:06Z"}]

title: Act as if you'll live to 500 - How I'm living in light of AI (career, education, money, etc)
top_comments:

Live below your means (it's way easier to go without)

🎯 as always Dave!", "like_count": 106, "published_at": "2024-06-10T04:36:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T04:36:01Z"}, {"author": "@MichaelDeeringMHC", "text": "Diet, exercise, sleep, mission. That's all you need.", "like_count": 179, "published_at": "2024-06-10T04:23:24Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T04:23:24Z"}, {"author": "@xxCrapNamexx", "text": "You'll be doing whatever the agi superintelligence tells you to do at that point. Are the single most impactful actions one can take to improve health and longevity.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-06-10T06:33:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T06:33:30Z"}, {"author": "@EwillieP", "text": "I never knew David had so many sick tattoos. Love you brother", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2024-06-10T06:04:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T06:04:49Z"}, {"author": "@harrykaridis", "text": "There are people working on solving death as we speak.", "like_count": 65, "published_at": "2024-06-10T04:02:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T04:02:13Z"}, {"author": "@FRandAI", "text": "I almost burst into tears watching this. I’m saving this video as daily inspiration. It’s literally the only thing I’ve ever come across in the “self-help” genre that ever made complete sense to me. Being “neurospicy as hell” myself, I’m very thankful you exist as someone to relate to. The connection you make me feel is very intense and your helping hand feels genuine. Thank you for your work, as always.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-06-10T16:11:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T16:12:59Z"}, {"author": "@dakforest5344", "text": "For about a year now, my mindset has shifted to "I want to stay as young as possible, for as long as possible." I've been negotiating with my diet, and have been exercising in one form or another for almost a full year now. I'm in the process of radically re-evaluating my financial situation, and Yes, I'm now living far beneath my means (and working to pay off my existing debt.) I look forward to intercepting longevity technologies as they come along, but Diet and Exercise are the two most powerful longevity techniques we have right now. 

More and more, I look at my future as if I'm walking both paths on a crossroad at once. To the left is my normal life expectancy, and I'll die of old age sometime between 60 and 90 years of age, the same way my grandparents did. To the right, my life will continue to be extended again and again, indefinitely, potentially extending my life to 500 years or more. 

I feel like schrodinger's cat, because I wont know which path I'm on, until it happens. But, where I am right now, I see no downside what-so-ever to living my life right now as though I'm going to live to 500 or more. It's forcing me to think about myself five years from now, twenty years from now, and making sure I'm taking care of that person in the present, while at the same time taking care of myself.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-06-10T05:09:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T05:14:55Z"}, {"author": "@RandallAcheson", "text": "Walking through my recently planted fruit tree orchard I would day dream about my great grandchildren enjoying it after I was gone. After watching this video I walked through the orchard and realized that I may very well outlive these trees that I just planted.  That made me feel more nurturing and connected to the young trees knowing that I need to take much better care of them for the short period of time the trees are with us. 🤔", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-06-10T19:19:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T19:19:29Z"}, {"author": "@I-Dophler", "text": "Remember the key points from the video: living as if you'll live to 500 years, focusing on longevity through health and financial minimalism, and prioritizing personal needs and interests over social pressures. This involves living below your means, tracking health metrics like heart rate variability, and avoiding consumerism for a fulfilling life. The goal is to live in line with your true self while maintaining simplicity and prioritizing health for long-term well-being.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-06-10T10:28:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T10:28:32Z"}, {"author": "@Trahloc", "text": "I'm literally moving across the planet to figure out what i actually need. I don't know how well that reset will work but my life will be designed around freedom across every level I can identify.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-06-10T07:36:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T07:36:06Z"}, {"author": "@OceanGateEngineer4Hire", "text": "One thing I learned from reading Fantastic Four comics as a kid is that Doctor Doom _always_ had contigencies. I reckon you could live for tens of thousands of years like that.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-06-10T11:57:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T11:57:01Z"}, {"author": "@gareth6985", "text": "Fabulous stream of focused coherent thought. Thanks Dave.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-06-10T10:46:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T10:46:41Z"}, {"author": "@dockdiscus3693", "text": "If you live to the 2100’s there probably going to be a way to reinforce your physical fortitude to the point where let’s say falling off a cliff won’t kill you. So you’re effectively immune to accidents", "like_count": 47, "published_at": "2024-06-10T04:10:24Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T04:10:24Z"}, {"author": "@canadasmartmind", "text": "Yes! That is it, at least for me.
I was following the steps that society told me to take.
This idea of Radical Alignment is what many people are thinking for years.
Very good! and thank you, for your thoughts and put them into words and reasoning. Keep writing!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-10T19:04:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T19:04:09Z"}, {"author": "@eSKAone-", "text": "Exactly. I'm 40 years old and live in the center of beautiful Heidelberg Germany. I inhabit a flat with 2 students, to save money. I can walk to work (ICU nurse), but I have an old used bike for less then 200 bucks. I don't need to travel. Heidelberg is paradise. No car, no kids. I only work part time so I have enough money for my hobbies: Bouldering, Running, Gaming on Sony PlayStation and Nintendo Switch (if our house burns down, I can't lose those games, I own them in the cloud). Life is beautiful nowadays, why would I waste it at work. I only buy cloths when I really need them, mostly cheap.

You can eat healthy for 5 bucks a day (coffee included). It's easy: stick to things that have only 1 ingredient, but no isolates like sugars and oils (you can throw them together obviously for a meal)

I consider whole grain pasta to be healthy, but you should have them split up in to maximum 2 meals a day. Other than that I eat oats, nuts and vegetables. Only drink water, coffee, and tea without additives. If you're vegan have your vit.B12 and a good source of omega-3 fatty acids (chia seeds, walnuts), maybe vit.D if you're a nightshift worker or not out in the sun much, and you're good. Once in a while if you have an easier day try to eat nothing for that day. I'm 40 years old, athletic, everyone thinks I'm much younger. Take good care of your bodies folks 💟🌌☮️", "like_count": 38, "published_at": "2024-06-10T08:37:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T08:37:06Z"}, {"author": "@mckitty4907", "text": "My life has been a real flop so far. 29, and literally my teens and 20's were completely lost due to mental illness and trauma, lying bedridden and trying to survive sui cide attempts. I feel like a complete failure. The only thing I have managed to do my whole life is to stay breathing another day, stay alive. These videos and these ideas make me feel like me surviving was maybe a good thing, and an accomplishment that will make it all worth it in the end. Like it meant something.", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2024-06-10T15:45:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-10T15:45:15Z"}, {"author": "@tonyreno3168", "text": "Been living those 3 since 2010. Here's my easy cheat code to the first 2:
1. Wealth: Even if I buy all I could, I'd still want for something. So I just  move the want-but-can't-have line far closerr than I need to. 
2. Health: Do something today to be healthier tomorrow.  Repeat (with whatever is convenient to do) every day. 
I defniitely plan to be around far more than the next 500 years and I'm over 60 now. Cheat code 2 makes it easy and also works for wealth..", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-06-12T22:19:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-12T22:19:17Z"}, {"author": "@iamachs", "text": "Thank you, needed to hear this, though am in camp live forever, cause by the time we are 500 years, so many breakthroughs would have happened that we can’t start to fathom right now to get us to forever, though I agree that it is very practical to think about the next 500 years for now, and will figure forever later 😊, awesome content mate 🚀", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-12T19:10:24Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-12T19:11:59Z"}]

title: Artificial Super Wisdom and Nebulocracy - How MORAL GRAPHS can change the world!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@I-Dophler", "text": "This is a fascinating concept. Using moral graphs and AI to achieve higher consensus and wisdom in governance is quite revolutionary. It raises crucial questions about the future of democracy and how we can balance efficiency, representation, and ethical decision-making. Also, ensuring every life, whether a baby or an adult, is valued in this system could lead to more compassionate and inclusive policies; I look forward to seeing how this develops!", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-06-03T13:54:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T13:54:10Z"}, {"author": "@Flawless_technique", "text": "David hands down has the best channel on A.i. and the best break down and thought process and I enjoy the optimistic approach", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-06-06T06:33:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-06T06:33:01Z"}, {"author": "@k98killer", "text": "I love the fact that the YouTube AI decided to add a climate change fact check blurb to a video that isn't about climate change.", "like_count": 38, "published_at": "2024-06-03T21:49:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T21:49:38Z"}, {"author": "@MarcoServetto", "text": "I suspect that super wisdom is going to be indistinguishable from super carisma. It does sounds like a D&D joke, but actually if the AI can convince us of something, can convince us to its specific path to wisdom, we may be unable to resist its convincing arguments.", "like_count": 40, "published_at": "2024-06-03T07:04:12Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T07:04:12Z"}, {"author": "@xinrra", "text": "I like the following analogy: 
- Intelligence is knowing that tomatoes are fruits, while wisdom is knowing that you should never make a fruit salad with tomatoes. :D", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2024-06-03T12:03:03Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T12:03:03Z"}, {"author": "@gnosis33-real", "text": "My name is Brent Joseph Wise So having the last name "Wise" I've thought about wisdom almost every day. And the best definition I've landed on for wisdom is the distillation of knowledge and intelligence into a system of decision making that results in both the best long and short terms outcome for my self and everyone else that my actions can affect. The depth of wisdom is dependent on the finest of the resolution and width/depth of the scope of knowledge and time horizons available and how it is processed to meet the goal of well being improvement for myself and all others (not just human, but any sentient beings).

So it's a multivariable optimization function.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-03T21:21:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T21:21:52Z"}, {"author": "@picksalot1", "text": "I agree that many things need to change how government, etc. is run, as it is clearly hobbled by the unwise. An individual person may be wise, but collectively, people are not, so I think the notion of "collective wisdom" is fundamentally flawed. The outcome of such a "collective wisdom" is more likely to be a "tyranny by the masses." I'm not interested in someone else or a group of people forcing me to live a certain way they think is wise, particularly if I don't have the power to force them to live the way I think is wise. There is a significant potential for loss of freedom and individuality. Making mistakes is an important step along the long path to wisdom. Removing the important step of mistakes leads to unconscious automatons, not wisdom.

When I was very young, I saw the value in being wise, and wondered how I could become wise. The steps that have most productive are learning how to be objective, even when it's not personally beneficial. Learn as much as possible. Develop the skills to be able to identify intelligent and wise people, and to know the difference. Associate with the wise. Be as independent as practical. Learn from both failure and success, and be prepared for both. Many truisms are false. Some unpopular views may be profoundly true. Learn to be your own best "sounding board." People have come up with many convincing arguments that have later proved to be wrong. Many so called "experts" are anything but that. It is your life to lead, so be careful with your choices, as you will ultimately bear the consequences. Good luck.", "like_count": 31, "published_at": "2024-06-03T08:31:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T08:31:43Z"}, {"author": "@markcounseling", "text": "4:17 According to a Buddhist definition, the difference between intelligence and wisdom is the difference between realizing relative truths and realizing ultimate truth, which underlies or is the context for all relative truths.", "like_count": 21, "published_at": "2024-06-03T07:42:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T07:53:37Z"}, {"author": "@RaySonic_99", "text": ""especially when you're a weirdo like me and all of us in this audience" - never felt so seen", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-04T11:15:20Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-04T11:15:20Z"}, {"author": "@RicRaftis", "text": "My first thought was the number of multinationals and corporations holding governments to ransom that if certain things are implemented, they they disappear to a more beneficial jurisdiction.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-06-03T12:02:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T12:02:16Z"}, {"author": "@Palisades_Prospecting", "text": "Decisions based solely on a moral graph would never have allowed a particle accelerator to be created. Expert views needs to be highly weighted along with the human making the final decision. The biggest problem I see with moral graphs is the old adage S in S out. When the perceived consequence is negligible for an action then people will tend to provide a more extreme action. Understanding that your answers directly relate to the build of this graph is required. Even if it means a minimal training set. If there isn’t an enforced contribution by all of society to build this graph then it will be populated by the extreme minorities basically creating a national condo association nightmare. 🙀", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-08T20:53:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-08T20:53:32Z"}, {"author": "@nicholascanada3123", "text": "a truly intelligent and wise AI would quickly realize that government is stupid and wrong and certainly not the answer", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-06-03T12:38:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T12:38:16Z"}, {"author": "@Hankemup", "text": "We do not live in an anarchic world just because there isn't a one world government; we live in a deeply hierarchical world. I would hope a systems thinker would be more interested in anarchist ideas, as they are aligned with so much of what you talk about i.e. Self organizing, decentralized, emergence, on the limit of chaos and rigidity, anti-fragile sytems, delegation, consensus. If our goal is 90% consensus, why not just build that into our social systems from the start as anarchists have argued for the last century. Sorry for the tone, but I often find myself thinking 'David! You're describing anarchism'. If you're interested I think the YouTube channel 'Anarck' is really good and he is very much so also a systems thinker. :)", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-06-03T19:38:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T19:38:36Z"}, {"author": "@mistycloud4455", "text": "AGI Will help govern better", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-06-05T19:42:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-05T19:42:38Z"}, {"author": "@I-Dophler", "text": "David's system revolves around the concept of a "moral graph" developed by the Meaning Alignment Institute. This moral graph aims to optimise wisdom rather than mere engagement, the current standard for online platforms. The moral graph involves a systematic process of mapping situations and decisions, with each decision being assigned metadata that indicates its understanding. The thicker the connection between nodes in the graph, the wiser the decision is considered. This technology fosters higher consensus on decisions by surfacing underlying human values and wisdom.

David's vision for the future government, which he dubs 'nebul locy,' is a testament to the power of the people. This system harnesses the 'moral graph' technology to continually gather and refine the population's values and sources of meaning. Instead of relying on elected representatives, individuals would have the direct ability to input their values into a decentralised system, thereby guiding decision-making processes. This system strives to achieve higher levels of consensus and wisdom in governance, all thanks to the artificial intelligence trained on these moral graphs.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-03T14:07:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T14:09:13Z"}, {"author": "@mlimrx", "text": "On a broader note, I really liked how Tony Robbins talks about values and their impact on our lives. In an ideal world, we'd be primarily driven by our spiritual need for contribution and growth. However, we are also very much driven by four opposing values/needs: connection, significance, certainty, and variety. And we use different vehicles to try to meet those values/needs (e.g. through our career, sports, family and etc.). The hierarchy of importance we place on these values determines how we relate to others and live our lives.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-05T03:56:12Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-06T03:31:25Z"}, {"author": "@SimonHuggins", "text": "Really good overview of the ideas - thanks for posting. Possibly one of the most important topics of our time - need more public discussion about ways of improving engagement with politics. My original thought on this was to have additional representatives for areas of interest in addition to local representatives so this would tie up your ideas of experts and also dealing with values. We could proportion our vote across those representatives according to what is important to us - locality, environment, defense, AI etc. So we vote in a person who best represents an area of expertise to that representative position.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-06-03T09:21:50Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T09:21:50Z"}, {"author": "@Jack0trades", "text": ""We all like nature. We all like green spaces...."
But businesses like those in the petrochemical industry continue to focus more on their own narrow, near-term prosperity. That includes not only the share holders and executives, but that dynamic extends down to the poorest paid individuals who contribute to their mission as well as anyone who supports them by buying their products. The same holds true for the horrors of factory farming and any number of cases where most of us continue to support systems that are destructive out of short-term expediency. Those are deliberate value choices, but they don't seem like "Wisdom."

I really would like an AI that is wise enough to present us with a compelling path out of this dystopia while being transparently reliable enough that we can be certain that it is not hiding a longer-term goal of simply eliminating or completely neutralizing us.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-03T16:20:58Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T16:20:58Z"}, {"author": "@SimonHuggins", "text": "Ok. What’s wisdom? Because I tend to find people employ morals to justify their behaviour, or collectively, to justify enforcing conformity. This technology will be used to enforce that conformity. But its extrapolation could be horrific. Best-case you find yourself being rejected from jobs, first on the redundancy list etc. Worst case, you are disappeared.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2024-06-03T07:53:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T07:53:53Z"}, {"author": "@lakeelectric", "text": "I appreciate your work, David.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-09T15:38:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-09T15:38:16Z"}]

title: Fitbit + ChatGPT Data Analysis Walkthrough - Figuring out why I'm so tired all the time!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@hidroman1993", "text": ""I'm always tired" [speaks 522 words per second]", "like_count": 93, "published_at": "2024-05-30T13:30:34Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-30T13:30:34Z"}, {"author": "@_paradr0id", "text": "The madman used ChatGPT to reverse engineer the factors Fitbit uses for it's metrics. Wild. This was 10/10. More data!", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2024-05-30T13:23:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-30T13:23:09Z"}, {"author": "@ilooovethetradiooo234", "text": "Here's some things I did to fix my energy:

1 - Delay drinking coffee/caffeine for 60-90 minutes after waking up, no caffeine 8 hours before bed (allow for adenosine to detach from receptors to allow caffeine and prevention of deep sleep)
2 - Get 30 minutes of sun early in the morning (helps reset circadian rhythm)
3 - Fasting until 12-4pm
4 - Cut out all blue/bright lights at least 2 hours before bed (helps with melatonin production)
5 - No large meals near bed (digestion can interfere with deep sleep)
6 - Try to wake up and go to sleep around the same time (training circadian rhythm)

I could probably list a 100 things, but look into Andrew Huberman's sleep podcasts, and maybe read Smarter not Harder by Dave Asprey.

You've been a big help with my understanding of where AI may be headed! Hope you get it sorted out!!!", "like_count": 48, "published_at": "2024-05-30T13:01:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-30T13:01:04Z"}, {"author": "@Melusi", "text": "Holy crap been waiting for someone to do this. Can't believe it's a channel I follow and love.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-05-30T12:53:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-30T12:53:01Z"}, {"author": "@duytdl", "text": "Hmm, I did all that manually (pre chatgpt days) and a bit too verbose. I also journal so I actually know my good and bad days sometimes down to the hour. But I couldn't for the life of me find a pattern. I cross-checked both ways - journalled good/bad days VS vitals-wise good/bad days, leading up to and afterwards. No strong correlation. Sure, the vitals themselves do relate to each other, although again, not strongly (like some days I performed better with less readiness (noticed afterwards so essentially a blind test)). But correlation with my journal entries (getting fired, moving into a bigger place, dates, fights) was even less. The conclusion I ended up with is that you can't just use vitals to predict your life.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-05-31T07:19:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-31T07:21:06Z"}, {"author": "@Runningmaster2025", "text": "So fascinating! As a running coach all this data makes sense.
You are basically a low responder to cardio training no matter how hard you try. It is proof that genetics is a factor of our physical prowess and limitations. You are built more for weight lifting and gaining muscle very quickly with the right challenge and stimulus  Great anaysis.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-05-31T00:14:24Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-31T00:14:24Z"}, {"author": "@Datdus92", "text": "Hey David! I've been logging my own data like this for years now, for the same purpose (also neurospicy). And AI finally enables me to properly analyze it. My predictors were exactly the same! What you can clearly see in my data is when I have a good day, I tend to overuse my energy (to catch up), which causes me to feel bad later. And so it keeps yo-yoing. To mitigate this, I'm regulating my energy expenditure to be more stable.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-05-30T15:23:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-30T15:34:17Z"}, {"author": "@motcowley", "text": "Love this. Would also love to see a follow up to see how it works out for you, whether you do get more of the good days, and any changes you make along the way. Great video!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-05-30T17:37:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-30T17:37:47Z"}, {"author": "@rayujohnson1302", "text": "I had ADHD and anxiety, I ended up getting meds to boost my serotonin level and then changed my diet so I am consuming 65+ grams of protein a day, and added oatmeal and probiotics (90% of your mental health is driven by your gut health, subsequently that is where 90% of the serotonin comes from as well). Now the ADHD symptoms are almost completely in remission, I have lost over 20 lbs, and feel awesome.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2024-05-30T13:20:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-30T13:20:11Z"}, {"author": "@Abababab2100", "text": "Don't you think we have a 'soft' and 'hard' energy level? Soft meaning something along the lines of the indicators you're looking at, and hard being mind state? Know that feeling when you can't wait to wake up and do something, which can sometimes go on for days/weeks? Energy feels limitless, whereas when you're bored, nothing to look forward to and meh mood you can always feel exhausted for the same amount of time, no matter what.

I find this sort of analysis super interesting though. Bryan Johnson seems to have the most energy of his life but he does also have a higher purpose and loves what he's doing. I just wonder how it all fits in.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-05-30T13:36:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-30T13:38:29Z"}, {"author": "@verigumetin4291", "text": "Is your mind running wild while walking? Cuz if it is, then that could be why you're more tired on days you walk more. My mind also constantly won't shut up when I do walks, and I get more stressed out than if I didn't do it. But my body does require exercise so you must find a sweet spot, (if this is the issue) where you exercise your body and heart, but not too much that your brain is tired. 
If I were to take a guess, its probably your brain that's the issue, not the walks themselves. 
I always see you filming videos while walking. That's not relaxing for your brain. 
The days I'm the most energetic is after a day where my mind has been more quiet than other days. But that is me, so take it as you will.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-05-30T13:26:07Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-30T13:26:07Z"}, {"author": "@gdok6088", "text": "All the fitness / health monitoring devices need to integrate with LLMs so this is all analysed and presented automatically. We have the technology - just put it all together already!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-05-31T09:40:20Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-31T09:40:20Z"}, {"author": "@TomasKolman", "text": "I use Oura ring for sleep quality and don’t need AI for interpretation. For movement data I use Suunto watch and HR sensor. My best advice: balance out training (mental +physical activity)and resting (including meditation and nsdr).", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-02T10:23:03Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-02T10:23:03Z"}, {"author": "@gabriel.rene.", "text": "Hey David, awesome stuff! Sorry if I’m making a dumb question but it’s not clear to me how you are tracking good/bad days.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-05-31T14:06:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-31T14:06:15Z"}, {"author": "@knddlbr", "text": "1) HRV is on a lag and compensates. After a 3 day hike it went up for me only to plummet below my avg for 1 day. 
2) You can now uses Googles Data Export feature to get the raw csv data saved to Google drive periodically. I haven’t yet looked if Readiness and Stress (ie the calculated values) are also part of it and as I am currently a premium Fitbit user (wife gave me a new Fitbit for Xmas) I also don’t know what data is included for the free users", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-08T06:40:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-08T06:40:55Z"}, {"author": "@MindBlowingXR", "text": "It's so great that you did this video. I hope you will do more of them that have to do with AI and health trackers. I tried doing this too as soon as Gpts came out. I fed my custom GPT my detailed diary entries. Plus my Oura ring data. Unfortunately, the dates in my diary were not written in a conventional manner and so the GPT did not understand them, which kind of spoiled things... But I think this kind of thing could be great, as you have shown!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-05-31T03:08:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-31T03:08:29Z"}, {"author": "@mynameisjeff9124", "text": "Can you make an update video on singularity, longevity, AGI and ASI predictions please?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-02T20:57:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-02T20:57:09Z"}, {"author": "@Loflou", "text": "Wow bro! Please give us the guide to recharging adhd batteries most efficiently please! ❤", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-05-30T17:10:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-30T17:10:57Z"}, {"author": "@TRXST.ISSUES", "text": "Looking forward to watching this, found that my tiredness was related to a depression bubbling beneath the surface. I can’t trust the feeling of being tired, ironic given my name I know 😂", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-02T07:03:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-02T07:03:22Z"}, {"author": "@executivelifehacks6747", "text": "Note that the readiness score is something that must drop down, if you are appropriately exercising, until one day after the serious exercise. You basically exercise when you have good-to-excellent readiness scores, it drops the day after, but with this process your fitness will improve to the point where you plateau and you can maintain it.

Readiness is composed of sleep, previous exercise, and HRV.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-05-31T02:38:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-31T02:39:44Z"}]
