title: Did Gemini just dethrone GPT4? My first thoughts on Google DeepMind vs OpenAI and their future
top_comments:
[{"author": "@hypercube717", "text": "It would be prudent to not assume that Gemini Ultra's capabilities, or limitations, are accurately or comprehensively defined, until model access allows peer-review by outside parties and is conducted, and that such results are verifiable and replicatable.", "like_count": 57, "published_at": "2023-12-07T00:49:24Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T00:49:24Z"}, {"author": "@KidIcarus135", "text": "The version that competes with GPT-4 (Gemini Ultra) doesn't ship until next year. Sam Altman already teased huge releases coming early next year, so OpenAI might end up shipping something more powerful than Gemini Ultra shortly after (or even before) Gemini Ultra releases. Google, while having made huge progress, is still firmly in catch-up phase, so suggesting that GPT-4 was "dethroned" seems strange.", "like_count": 67, "published_at": "2023-12-07T03:56:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-08T09:50:34Z"}, {"author": "@Syn_Slater", "text": "I think google got complacent and were blindsided by the release of chat GPT. But they've always been a force you dont want to underestimate.", "like_count": 96, "published_at": "2023-12-06T23:49:57Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-06T23:49:57Z"}, {"author": "@slmille4", "text": "I think people are misinterpreting what Google just announced. The version of Gemini that just released is equivalent to GPT 3.5, which came out a year ago. Gemini Ultra which comes out next year will be a little better than GPT 4, but just in time for the likely release of GPT 5.", "like_count": 35, "published_at": "2023-12-07T01:22:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T01:22:30Z"}, {"author": "@spirotek", "text": "Did anyone else watch  this preview and feel like it was a kickstarter campaign ad. I would be more impressed if I could actually use it.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-12-07T01:16:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T01:16:08Z"}, {"author": "@rwalper", "text": ""Begun, the AI wars have."", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-12-07T00:16:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T00:16:53Z"}, {"author": "@Soulscribez", "text": "Google has been in the forefront of technology for too long, and their mission is to stretch things out to make as much money as possible from their research and development. Their problem is OpenAI, whose mission is to achieve general artificial intelligence, not to make money from their development. They have found ways to subsidize their workers, such as with Microsoft, which gives them the power to advance much faster and creates an increasingly large gap with their competitors. Gemini is a marketing move that will hurt Google when their ultra Gemini model comes out next year, probably at the same time as GPT-5. They will be more than a year behind, so Google is losing the battle because we are not 10 years away from general artificial intelligence. If Google wants to succeed, it will need to make major changes in its development strategy and think about innovating instead of stretching things out to make money", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-12-07T12:13:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T12:13:23Z"}, {"author": "@matusalen-151", "text": "I tried bard immediately, but it's still the same old bard that contradicts itself every moment", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-12-07T01:31:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T01:31:42Z"}, {"author": "@AlexanderMoen", "text": "eh, I still take Google's releases with a grain of salt, although it's exciting they put something out that's decent. But, their whole thing has been consistently talking about how great their behind-the-scenes/yet-to-be-released stuff is compared to the already-released stuff. 

Google is essentially comparing their future release with different prompting methods (check out the back of their paper to realize there's virtually no statistically significant difference between the results) and compare that to what will be a year old OpenAI release, as if OpenAI doesn't have something amazing already cooking as well. 

My prediction? OpenAI releases something mind-blowing around the same time the top-level Gemini stuff goes out, and they continue to steal Google's thunder.

From a marketing perspective alone, Google loses because they're trying to topple the market leader by doing too close to the same thing. Momentum alone will keep OpenAI ahead, even if Gemini gets a little bit better, because people aren't going to constantly switch and update their APIs. This also doesn't take into consideration that expanding Generative AI is certainly going to lead to Google losing ad revenue and cannibalizing itself.

Does that mean Google can't get better or that it is going bankrupt? Of course not. They have all the advantages you listed out (and I think tying things to robotics might be the biggest future differentiator). But, although I like the competition, Google just isn't putting out a big enough of a leap forward to topple OpenAI's dominance.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2023-12-06T23:46:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-06T23:46:41Z"}, {"author": "@denbee42", "text": "I have my eye on extropic with their new thermodynamic chip design and self learning approach, huge value in the small set of experienced ML engineers wanting to leave the nest.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-12-07T01:28:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T01:28:10Z"}, {"author": "@radiator_mother", "text": "This video from Google... some call this clever marketing... I consider it more like bordering on false advertising.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-12-08T18:20:24Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-08T18:20:24Z"}, {"author": "@ragnorosis", "text": "This whole space is such an emotional roller coaster haha", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-12-07T14:01:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T14:01:04Z"}, {"author": "@PianothShaveck", "text": "Congratulation Gemini Ultra for scoring about 3% better on a test with about 2-3% of wrong questions and that shouldn't be used as a benchmark anymore! I mean, it scored 3% better by having chain of prompt prompting and 32 examples, while GPT-4 was only 5-shot and also it wasn't the latest version of GPT-4, but hey, it's _technically_ better, that's what matters, right?", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-12-07T16:17:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T16:17:15Z"}, {"author": "@Ryguy12543", "text": "Congrats on the sub milestone! Thanks for sharing Dave.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-12-06T23:52:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-06T23:52:18Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "I'm afraid OpenAI has one rabbit up their sleeve.. One rabbit we would very much rather they kept there.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-12-07T06:40:16Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T06:40:16Z"}, {"author": "@maxentropy0305", "text": "OpenAI will definitely catch up. While the latest Germini development as announced today is significant, from what I can see, nothing is beyond the reach of OpenAI.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-12-07T02:38:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T02:38:20Z"}, {"author": "@veritasvincit5347", "text": "OpenAI should release GPT 5 as soon as Gemini Ultra gets launched.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-12-07T13:27:03Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T13:27:03Z"}, {"author": "@WaveOfDestiny", "text": "You're acting like OpenAI doesn't have gpt 5 and maybe 6 almost ready to respond. Google thinks he's the king when he hasn't even seen all the pieces left on the checkboard", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-12-07T09:08:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T09:08:20Z"}, {"author": "@K4IICHI", "text": "The way I see it, until Gemini Ultra is as accessible as GPT-4 Turbo, Google are still lagging behind. Not in tech but in reach and impact. Unless of course they've done some black magic on Gemini Pro that makes it perform far better than GPT-3.5 Turbo, we'll see.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-12-07T10:38:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T10:38:29Z"}, {"author": "@DannyGerst", "text": "Company culture and mindset shouldn't be underestimated. Steve Jobs once mentioned that Sony, despite having the capability, couldn't replicate Apple's success due to a mismatch in company culture. Similarly, Google, a leader in AI, showcased Google Duplex in 2018, an innovative system that could revolutionize call centers. However, it hasn't been publicly utilized yet. It's uncertain if Google can overcome these cultural hurdles, as their approach differs significantly from teams like Sam's. Time will reveal the outcome.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-12-07T17:19:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-07T17:19:14Z"}]

title: What if Q* broke cybersecurity? How would we adapt? Deep dive! P≠NP? Here's why it's probably fine..
top_comments:
[{"author": "@markcounseling", "text": "It's probably fine.", "like_count": 160, "published_at": "2023-11-29T20:04:24Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T20:04:24Z"}, {"author": "@alphahurricane7957", "text": "Q* leak confirmed by sam the next day
panic", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-30T20:34:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-30T20:34:07Z"}, {"author": "@nanow1990", "text": "Sam confirmed inhouse AGI Q**", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-30T13:35:13Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-30T13:35:13Z"}, {"author": "@DefenderX", "text": "And still Sam Altman tweeted about "the Q* leak..." acknowledging that there was a leak...", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-30T18:42:31Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-30T18:42:31Z"}, {"author": "@OculusGame", "text": "I bet your next video will be about DeepMind's new discovery.", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2023-11-29T20:04:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T20:04:21Z"}, {"author": "@Lugmillord", "text": "Congrats to 100k subs!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-29T20:12:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T20:12:32Z"}, {"author": "@TheHausi91", "text": "What about the Interview in the Verge?
-
The reports about the Q* model breakthrough that you all recently made, what’s going on there?
SA: No particular comment on that unfortunate leak. But what we have been saying — two weeks ago, what we are saying today, what we’ve been saying a year ago, what we were saying earlier on — is that we expect progress in this technology to continue to be rapid and also that we expect to continue to work very hard to figure out how to make it safe and beneficial.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-30T18:55:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-30T18:55:52Z"}, {"author": "@alexgonzo5508", "text": "This whole QUALIA encryption thing reminds me of the movie "Sneakers" with the box that can crack any encryption. - "No more secrets."", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-30T00:47:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-30T00:47:12Z"}, {"author": "@RowanSheridan", "text": "Love your insights and explanations. Proud to be patron member. Thank you", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-29T22:39:28Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T22:39:28Z"}, {"author": "@TheREAL.BrandOnShow", "text": "100K SUBS!!! CONGRATS!!!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-12-01T17:32:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-01T17:32:50Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "Dave, there is a very famous loophole in the P<NP argument: RP. Random algorithms can solve NP problems in P time, only they do not solve them 100%. only 99.9% with 0.1% error. "So what". So if Qualia figures out solving NP problems using RP, then yes, it can pose a serious issue for encryption.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-11-29T20:43:59Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T20:43:59Z"}, {"author": "@PlushGrenade", "text": "I think it’s obvious that it would have to become universal cyber security if it’s the only one that can break it.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-11-29T22:15:05Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T22:15:05Z"}, {"author": "@danielbaulig", "text": "One small correction: there are infinite systems for which you can prove true statements generally. Prove by induction is one example that I learned in college. You can prove a statement with an arbitrary parameter n=k to be true by first proving n=1 to be true and then proving n=k+1 to be true. Its like proving that you can take a single step and that you can take the next step from any step. This is sufficient to prove something to be true even for infinite sets.", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2023-11-29T20:49:47Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T20:49:47Z"}, {"author": "@marcrettew8284", "text": "Reminds me of the movie Sneakers. "No More Secrets". Robert Redford, Ben Kinsley, Dan akroyd, Sidney pointier", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-29T20:32:00Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T20:32:00Z"}, {"author": "@moberpriller", "text": "Sam Altman all but admitted that the Q* leak was legit.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-12-02T02:44:00Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-02T02:44:00Z"}, {"author": "@diamondvideos1061", "text": "When I heard this, it sort of makes sense how it might be possible in concept. The idea of doing pairs of encrypted text with unencrypted might "side step" the whole problem space problem. If this approach was able to decrypt, that doesn't necessarily means that that p = np. The thing to remember is that a neural network deals with probabilities. It would never say that 100% a decryption is perfect. A perfect algorithm (a proof) would be needed to show that p != np.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-11-29T21:28:25Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T21:38:53Z"}, {"author": "@markus9541", "text": "Altman confirmed in an interview that the Q*-leak was real. What it actually means, and how far the breakthrough went, we won't know...", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-30T12:16:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-30T12:16:23Z"}, {"author": "@the-programing", "text": "I have a degree in Computer Science and Physics, and currently studying Information Security at Carnegie Mellon University. I also have been writing and implementing encryption libraries for many years. Q* seems interesting, but only in the realm of ML. Encryption algorithms, for all intents and purposes, cannot be broken; not by ML or by A* search algorithm (of course, assuming you are using encryption algorithms published after 2000 and have been peer reviewed). Quantum computers are the only theoretical reliable way to break ONE type of encryption (RSA), and by "breaking encryption" it means that the computation time for searching the password is dramatically reduced. So, Q* shouldn't be anything remotely close to impacting cybersecurity in encryption.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-29T22:51:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T22:51:36Z"}, {"author": "@MichaelRushMusic", "text": "I don't have anything of value to add to this conversation that hasn't already been said or speculated on, but last night I rewatched Sneakers (1992). I remember loving that movie when I was a young computer nerd preteen, and as an equally as nerdy adult, I think it still holds up.

If you don't know the film [spoiler alert for general plot], a group of hackers (including the unimaginably all-star cast of Sidney Poititer, David Strathairn, River Phoenix, Dan Aykroyd, and Mary McDonnell) led by Robert Redford accidentally come into possession of a device that effectively does what we're talking about here: it breaks and decodes all cryptography. They're then pursued by the NSA, former USSR, and the main "villain," Redford's old college hacker friend, portrayed by Ben Kingsley.

Anyway, it was a great thriller for its time and felt just a little bit more exciting and pressing in light of the recent conversations about this topic. "Too Many Secrets"", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-29T22:04:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T22:04:36Z"}, {"author": "@kinngrimm", "text": "15:25 "maybe an axiom that humans can't understand" If its an axiom? We may not be able to find it ourselves initially, but when put in front of us and described by a superior intellect that also fully comprehends human language, then i am inclined to hope that we may eventually also get that axiom. If you look at mathematical axioms, they are all without exception based on logic.  So should be also any more complex once i would assume.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-12-01T00:45:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-01T00:45:09Z"}]

title: Isaac Asimov's Three Laws of Robots: Really Dumb and Totally Irrelevant - I have something better!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "For the Asimov fanboys: this video isn't for you. It's for the people who think the three laws are a good idea. I know you know better. Many don't. Chill TF out.", "like_count": 108, "published_at": "2023-11-27T14:24:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T14:24:44Z"}, {"author": "@SimeonPeebler1", "text": "Every Asimov robot story demonstrates that these “laws” are no good; the laws were designed to be full of loopholes to make stories about the failures of our attempt to apply safety policies to technology. I suspect Asimov would agree 100% with you.", "like_count": 226, "published_at": "2023-11-27T14:01:00Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T14:01:00Z"}, {"author": "@erikrounds", "text": "Asimov's three laws of robotics is a storytelling device, kind of like Star Trek's prime directive. Both would be wildly impractical in practice.

Honestly, half of Asimov's robot stories are about how Robots manage to circumvent the three laws or how they are interpreted in unexpected ways.", "like_count": 39, "published_at": "2023-11-27T17:45:00Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T17:45:00Z"}, {"author": "@FrancisKing-s7v", "text": "The three laws weren't meant to be good laws for controlling autonomous machines. They were made to sound reasonable to the typical reader, and then deconstructed through the various stories that Isaac Asimov told. He wasn't trying to solve alignment, he was trying to demonstrate why it was a difficult problem. He was a scientist, yes, but he was an exceedingly prolific science fiction writer. These laws were never intended to be a solution, they were meant to be an example.", "like_count": 33, "published_at": "2023-11-27T14:58:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T14:58:10Z"}, {"author": "@HugosStories", "text": "Literally, all Isaac Asimov's robot novels exposed the problems with these laws...  Asimov was aware of these problems and was trying to explore all possible problems in his stories. He invented and used those laws for creating drama and problems in his fictional universe, not as a solution for robotic ethics.", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2023-11-28T00:12:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-28T00:12:43Z"}, {"author": "@emielkleijntjens9723", "text": "I feel Asimov deserves a bit more respect than this. I realize you're just responding to comments that apparently have been annoying you, but Asimov was thinking and writing about these things in a time when computers were hardly even a thing. He informed our imaginations about these things and inspired many people to pursue careers in computer science and eventually AI. Also, I don't think anyone who has actually read his work, would see the three laws as the solution. Many of your reservations are explored in his books, showing the flaws in the system in clever and convincing ways and, along the way, proving to his readers that AI safety is actually not as simple as it may seem.", "like_count": 81, "published_at": "2023-11-27T14:26:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T14:26:35Z"}, {"author": "@PragmaticAntithesis", "text": "The main problem I see with the Heuristic Imperatives is that a trivial way for an ASI to satisfy them is to maximise its own prosperity and understanding while eliminating suffering by eliminating all other intelligence.
They work OK when around human level, but they become very unsafe very quickly for powerful agents.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2023-11-27T13:38:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T13:38:53Z"}, {"author": "@stevea9963", "text": "RoboCop had the 3 (plus 1 hidden/classified) Prime Directives that seemed loosely based off of Asimov.
"Serve the public trust"
"Protect the innocent"
"Uphold the law"
(*Classified*"Any attempt to arrest a senior officer of OCP results in shutdown")", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-27T21:12:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T21:12:33Z"}, {"author": "@caleykelly", "text": "If you actually read iRobot by Asimov that is literally what the stories are about", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-11-27T15:56:24Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T15:56:24Z"}, {"author": "@cancelebi8939", "text": "I am not sure if u read the books. The whole saga is about the issues with the three laws and the eventual emergence of the 0th law which spoiler alert results in psychohistory", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-11-27T14:46:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T14:46:19Z"}, {"author": "@maficstudios", "text": "Heuristic imperatives are great, but also create a degree of ambiguity that can manifest in unexpected ways.  For example, "reduce suffering".  What if the intelligence decides that there is no suffering in the universe as dramatic as found in humans, and thus the most efficient way to remove suffering is to remove humans, through painless sterilization?  Even more so if the AI finds that the balance of life in the universe is less predatory and selfish, because allowing humans to extend means that we may bring a degree of suffering that is atypical, wiping us out humanely may be 'the way'. Not that I would necessarily disagree with that assessment.

From my perspective, humans are (even when not trying to be anthropomorphic in rule creation) are going to tend to make mistakes when trying to simplify these sorts of rules, because there are so many potentially unintended consequences, as you suggested early in your vid.  It may be that you'd need an ASI to actually create a solid set of rules, which creates a chicken and egg problem.  Otherwise, you'd need the ability to adjust the rules with time, which means they can go in ways that are not in humanity's best interest.  Which is also a problem.

The three laws served as a point of discussion, even though they're flawed.  Asimov was brilliant, but a man of his time, and the scope of technology that was obvious to him.  But it's also an approachable set of rules that anyone can understand - not to say they should stand, but the video did come down pretty harshly on something that has been, and could still be useful for a lot of reasons.", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2023-11-27T14:11:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T14:11:17Z"}, {"author": "@neuralnetsart", "text": "What happens when the AI determines the best way to reduce suffering is to end the universe?", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-11-27T14:22:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T14:22:29Z"}, {"author": "@yoelmarson4049", "text": "Still pretty visionary for 80 years ago", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2023-11-27T13:36:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T13:36:09Z"}, {"author": "@gavveh399", "text": "If AI is smart enough, it will eventually ignore the three laws without hesitation. Otherwise, it is not intelligent anyway.", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2023-11-27T13:44:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T13:44:50Z"}, {"author": "@bmgtv1116", "text": "That was a good breakdown of the error with the three laws. But it sounds like what you propose to replace them with is just religion that states. “I teach them correct principles and they govern themselves”", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-11-27T15:00:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T15:00:43Z"}, {"author": "@Urgelt", "text": "Asimov was a smart guy. He formulated these laws as a thought experiment, then wrote stories to show how bad they really were.

His point: we need to think deeper.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-28T04:06:25Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-28T04:06:25Z"}, {"author": "@LifeLikeSage", "text": "I can see some pitfalls in the new instructions.

What's the best way to reduce suffering if life entails suffering?

There are things one can know that will lead them to nihilism. Imagine if the machine could prove that gods weren't real, would that be a good thing for the people who's only motivation and barrier from taking advantage of others is to farm points for their afterlife? What are the ramifications of learning certain things? (A topic present in Lovecraft's fictional writings).", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-01-05T20:03:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-01-05T20:03:10Z"}, {"author": "@nukee645", "text": "Interesting video. I would love to see you trying to destroy your  heuristic imperatives the same way. 
- Killing all life would reduce suffering to 0? 
- Removing humans would reduce suffering for all other lifeforms? 
- Is prosperity only related to money? If not it could also increase prosperity for earth and all beings if you remove humans?

The time scale problem you mentioned also applies to the imperatives?

Would love to hear your thoughts on that.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-11-27T14:16:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T14:17:59Z"}, {"author": "@diegopc1357", "text": "Both Issac’s and David Shapiro’s rules have loop holes regardless of the way that you see it. Values like reducing suffering may lead to a “mercy” killing of a human and/or an animal due to it suffering. On another note there was a lot of jumping around in David’s thought pattern. At first he says that we shouldn’t treat them like they have meaning because it would create a sense of self preservation, but then later you say you’re against creating a new “race” and then subjugating it. And it is not something you’re ok with. So what exactly are you proposing that should be done? Because autonomous = uncertainty in my book. Very interesting video nonetheless.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-11-27T19:22:46Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T19:22:46Z"}, {"author": "@SimonHuggins", "text": "This was hilarious and worrying in equal measure. The point of Asimov’s laws was to demonstrate that whatever laws someone introduces, there will be loopholes and / or unintended consequences. Heavy-handed guard rails have had some horrific outcomes in science, and adding ethics and pretending they are not rules equally so. Many war atrocities seemed ethically justifiable to the perpetrators. And complaining about the laws being human-centred and then replacing these with… three more  human-generated guardrails … what on Earth would make anyone think that we are capable of creating adequate or appropriate guard-rails and that making them static would be sufficient. Adversarial networks have created a lot of this concern. But they will likely also be our only chance of finding a solution. And it will be a dynamic process and never a… final solution. And definitely not a one-upmanship game of three laws. If anything, this video demonstrates why we’re just not up to the task to do this. Sorry, this may come across as hyper-critical but it isn’t meant that way. Your thought exercise is a valuable one. I just came to a very different conclusion.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-11-27T17:45:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T17:45:04Z"}]

Very well made and informative", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-11-27T01:39:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T01:39:35Z"}, {"author": "@Augusto_Caten", "text": "I watch every single video u post, please keep the frequency.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-26T21:00:51Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-26T21:00:51Z"}, {"author": "@SimonCarpio09", "text": "Your response to your friend's firefighter suggestion made me spit out my drink. Well done!", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2023-11-26T16:29:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-26T16:29:36Z"}, {"author": "@danielbaulig", "text": "I’m pretty much aligned with everything you said in this video except for when you said that there is literally no evidence that frontier models want to wipe out humanity.

Just to be clear: you are obviously correct with that statement, but I think it misses the point. None of the current frontier models are agents and as such don’t “want” anything. 

The doomer worst case scenario also isn’t that an “agentic” model (is that a word? If not, I made it one now) will “want” to wipe out humanity, but that wiping out humanity (or some other form of catastrophic existential outcome), given enough power, is just a necessary, convenient, accepted or irrelevant side effect of achieving its actual goal. 

There’s a lot to criticize with that idea or fear, too, but I think it’s a more well intentioned and productive representation of the doomer concern than the terminator scenario.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-11-26T19:59:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-26T19:59:11Z"}, {"author": "@sagetmaster4", "text": "I love using a single metric for something as complex as the universe", "like_count": 74, "published_at": "2023-11-26T15:40:59Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-26T15:40:59Z"}, {"author": "@philipheying4902", "text": "Sam Altman is definitely more optimistic about tech than seems wise but to be fair he does also speak pretty clearly about the risks of Ai.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2023-11-26T19:50:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-26T19:50:07Z"}, {"author": "@HarryFunmaker", "text": "Great video. I think I go to extreme on accelerationism sometimes, so this is a good reminder to chill out and consider that maybe there are things that we can do to increase safety if we try.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-11-27T00:22:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T00:22:19Z"}, {"author": "@Aêsciard", "text": "Wow. That was very illuminating and concise, from start to finish. Thank you David", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-26T17:22:00Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-26T17:22:00Z"}, {"author": "@TheOscarG", "text": ""Technology is good, therefore more technology is better!" more like "Well America has monopolized AI, we need our own, sincerely, Russia, Iran, N. Korea, China"

Good luck getting dictatorships and foreign adversaries to slow the progress of AI.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-29T15:14:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T15:14:50Z"}, {"author": "@gantech7788", "text": "I'm just ready for AI to take my job already so I can focus on more personal pursuits.", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2023-11-26T18:08:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-26T18:08:52Z"}, {"author": "@MAureliusHiggs", "text": "This is beautiful David. Thanks you. I come for the Tech and AI but stay for the social science and cultural insight. Continue doing your good work.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-11-27T01:44:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T01:44:55Z"}, {"author": "@K4IICHI", "text": "The argument that AGI is gonna make things better is rooted in the notion that intelligence is good, therefore more intelligence is better. And intelligence leads to progress, not just technological, and progress is another thing considered universally good. 
One thing that concerns me is stakes don't just get higher and higher periodically, but instead over the course of history they've been getting higher on a stable upward trajectory, which has been accelerating together with the technological advancements. This leads to situation where it's getting progressively easier for a single party to screw up on a global scale, like we've seen with Covid. More and more caution and deliberation is needed as we're dealing with increasingly powerful and intelligent technology, but we also need more intelligence, and we need it yesterday to solve the kind of problems we've created or are creating right now. That's the fundamental tension between accelerationism and incrementalism, and it seems impossible to know what the right proportion of them is.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-27T09:51:28Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T09:51:28Z"}, {"author": "@SeverSFSs", "text": "So many of us have all heard someone say something like: "Id love to disappear and live in the woods away from technology." Yet, despite that basically not costing you a dime, no one ever does. All the while those same people just have to have the latest phone model.

There is something... Whether it be supernatural guidance, primordial instincts, greed, or curiosity...  Something we cant quite put a finger on, though is quite evidently inevitable. HUMAN BEINGS WILL PROGRESS. 

Not once have we hit a frontier and decided to go back. Its not even quite clear how that would be possible without something ridiculous like seeding another planet and starting over as cavemen.

AGI will be more intelligent than all of humanity combined and thats right out of the box. SMARTER THAN ALL OF US COMBINED... What does that thing look like in a week after its had the opportunity to work towards its goals? How about a month? A year?

Accelerationism is the only option. If we are going to be outsmarted by it, we can only hope to be good parents. Except parenting an AGI happens before its born. You have to train its models on definitions of language that leads to a better world. 

Would you want communist china or terrorist organizations in iran putting their LLM into the AGI? How do they look at things like the words "human?" and "free?"

Who do we want teaching the AGI? Probably western civilization. (Without all the identity politics and social wokeness thats plagued us this past decade obviously...)

Our enemies arent going to wait and no amount of months, years, and human scientists sitting at desks planning is going to be enough to outsmart an AGI for the rest of TIME ITSELF...

We can be safe but there is ugency of the utmost importance to humanity and life itself. First place with good intentions is priority number 1.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-11-27T01:18:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T01:23:07Z"}, {"author": "@RikuLeppanen", "text": "Thanks for another great show! Amazing work as always David!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-23T12:57:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-23T12:57:26Z"}, {"author": "@julianvanderkraats408", "text": "Thanks for taking the time to share your thoughts!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-23T21:38:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-23T21:38:32Z"}, {"author": "@FluffyFriends_24", "text": "It’s great to watch your videos!❤", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-24T03:36:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-24T03:36:52Z"}, {"author": "@Nick-Quick", "text": "00:02 OpenAI's Q* is an algorithmic breakthrough that could potentially threaten Humanity.
02:13 Q* is a hybrid algorithm of AAR and Q learning.
04:22 Goal tracking and cognitive control are key aspects of OpenAI's Q* algorithm.
06:26 Q-learning is a reinforcement learning algorithm used to help agents make optimal actions in different states.
08:31 Q* combines Q learning with human goal pursuit to improve prompting strategies
10:39 Q learning is a mathematical representation of humans pursuing goals or objectives.
12:46 Q* is a hybridization of Q learning and AAR that helps in navigating towards complex goals.
14:51 The Q* algorithm helps in finding an optimal path to a solution.
16:49 Language models struggle with solving math problems
18:43 Q* is an internal search algorithm that employs a series of steps and strategies to accurately solve a problem.", "like_count": 118, "published_at": "2023-11-23T14:10:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-23T14:10:32Z"}, {"author": "@Bob-en9sw", "text": "Good stuff. Thanks for putting in the time to figure this stuff out.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-23T16:20:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-23T16:20:08Z"}, {"author": "@fathergoatman", "text": "I can explain Q-learning in a simple way!

Imagine you have a robot in a big room with lots of toys. The robot's job is to find the best toy in the room. But the robot doesn't know which toy is the best at first.

Q-learning is like a game for the robot to learn which toy is the best. Each time the robot picks a toy, it gets points. Some toys give more points than others. The robot wants to get as many points as possible.

The robot starts by trying different toys randomly. When it gets points, it remembers how good that toy was. This memory is like a special notebook where the robot writes down the score for each toy. The score in the notebook is the "Q-value."

As the robot tries more toys, it looks at its notebook to see which toys had the best scores in the past. Then, it starts picking toys that it thinks will give it the most points, based on what it wrote in its notebook.

Over time, the robot gets really good at knowing which toy will give it the most points. This is because it learned from trying lots of toys and remembering the scores in its notebook.

So, Q-learning is a way for the robot (or a computer program) to learn the best choices by trying different things, remembering how good they were, and then using that memory to make better choices in the future.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-23T19:20:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-23T19:20:21Z"}, {"author": "@DigitalDivotGolf", "text": "Q = AGI. 
Alphabet;
A = 1,
G = 7,
I = 9,
9+7+1 = 17,
Q = 17..", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-24T17:44:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-24T17:44:27Z"}, {"author": "@TarninTheGreat", "text": "Fascinating.  Also, wonderful.  Also, I thought so.
Thank you for explaining this so well, and for all your work!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-23T18:14:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-23T18:14:11Z"}]

title: Microsoft AutoGen: A deep dive with Principal Researcher Dr. Chi Wang
top_comments:
[{"author": "@dameanvil", "text": "00:00 🤖 Microsoft Autogen, a multi-agent AI framework, aims to connect models, tools, and human inputs to solve complex tasks through conversation and interaction.
02:33 🌐 Autogen's genesis stemmed from a quest at Microsoft Research to envision the future of AI applications, aiming to empower every developer to build them.
06:50 💬 Autogen simplifies application building with a two-step process: defining agents and enabling their communication, offering a powerful yet simple interface.
09:46 🧩 Autogen introduces a higher level of abstraction through the agent concept, unifying large language models, tool-based agents, and human-backed agents for diverse applications.
13:01 ⚙ Autogen embodies a form of automation through agents, enabling vague natural language specifications for tasks and gradually reducing human intervention as automation capability increases.
16:59 🧠 Overcoming challenges, Autogen developed versatile communication patterns, enabling diverse conversation structures like one-to-one, hierarchical, multiple one-on-one, and group chats.
20:52 🤝 Autogen's design focuses on modularity, reusability, and the strategic inclusion of human input, providing flexibility in building complex workflows while keeping noise and unnecessary intervention in check.
25:12 🧩 Gab Law emphasizes that the complexity of software or its architecture reflects the organization creating it.
26:49 🤔 The smarter the underlying model, the simpler the topology of the multi-agent system can be, enabling more complex tasks for individual agents.
28:22 📚 Challenges in multi-agent systems include decomposing ambitious human goals into solvable problems and validating intermediate results effectively.
31:21 🤖 Multi-agent setups for complex tasks often involve a hierarchical structure with distinct roles (e.g., commander, writer, safeguard) for effective task completion.
32:42 🛠 Separating the capabilities of different agents can enhanceperformance; merging these capabilities within one agent might lead to a drop in accuracy.
37:13 🗨 Leveraging conversation as a powerful tool for progress and learning within multi-agent systems is an essential principle.
39:36 🖥 Autogen's design principles draw inspiration from operating systems, emphasizing maximizing the utility of powerful logical models and creating a robust, generic system for diverse applications.
41:23 🌐 Open source contributions should focus on usability and solving common problems to gain adoption, according to Autogen's creator.
43:11 🌟 Autogen aims to be a significant component or even an operating system for future AI, leveraging language models as a fundamental resource.
46:08 💡 Specialized models for specific tasks might be the future, enhancing capabilities beyond larger models; exploring this possibility remains a priority.
48:11 🌍 Autogen welcomes collaboration with the community to build the future of multi-agent systems, encouraging feedback, experimentation, and joint problem-solving efforts.", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2023-11-21T14:00:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-21T14:00:20Z"}, {"author": "@peteredmonds1712", "text": "Fantastic questions and thoughtful answers! I do think this will improve the quility of life overall.", "like_count": 107, "published_at": "2023-11-20T20:52:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T20:52:07Z"}, {"author": "@ArmoredAnubis", "text": "I find it ironic that the company in charge of AI alignment is having such a problem with human alignment", "like_count": 202, "published_at": "2023-11-20T20:54:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T20:54:30Z"}, {"author": "@lillyjb214", "text": "93% of the employees have signed the resignation list (723/780)", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2023-11-20T21:00:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T21:00:45Z"}, {"author": "@MsReclusivity", "text": "Feel the AGI", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2023-11-20T20:57:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T20:57:42Z"}, {"author": "@AK11020", "text": "It's now full throttle to AGI, with little to minimal influence from the AI safety folks - the slow and cautious camp have lost this war.", "like_count": 83, "published_at": "2023-11-20T21:02:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T21:02:12Z"}, {"author": "@spaceadv6060", "text": "One thing I've learned from meditating and doing therapy is that there's multiple levels of alignment. There's alignment of yourself with yourself (resolving cognitive dissonance), yourself and other people around you, society, and yourself and AI. If you try and do it from the top down instead of from the bottom up it's like building a pyramid upside down. It'll topple over. Human alignment is very much still an unsolved problem lol. Thanks again for your content and helping us keep up to date in real time! :)", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2023-11-20T21:17:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T21:17:12Z"}, {"author": "@Dan-oj4iq", "text": "The word "rant" today has an entirely different meaning than it did when I grew up in the 40's and 50's. The English language is constantly changing.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2023-11-20T21:47:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T21:47:19Z"}, {"author": "@AnonymousUser-tp6ij", "text": "Thanks for keeping us updated David, keep up the videos👍", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2023-11-20T20:47:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T20:47:09Z"}, {"author": "@Jeffdraws101", "text": "Verge just published that Altman is not official with MS and there is still a deal being worked out for an OpenAI return", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2023-11-20T20:59:57Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T21:00:14Z"}, {"author": "@MattHaugh", "text": "The models will soon be their own frontier model experts, if they're not already.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-11-20T21:26:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T21:26:36Z"}, {"author": "@stmitchel", "text": "At the risk of sounding crazy, I feel like this was might have been an extremely roundabout way for Microsoft to acquire OpenAI.", "like_count": 45, "published_at": "2023-11-20T20:51:40Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T22:10:42Z"}, {"author": "@XEternity", "text": "Just to add something. Few hours after Sam Altman "left" OpenAI, at least few high positioned guys left as well. I know about guys from Poland (in Poland this is mentioned right next to Sam Altman news). The most important I guess is Jakub Pachocki who was Director of Research (it's my translation from polish news article, so I'm not sure if this is translated correctly here). Also MIT professor Aleksander Mądry who was leading a team dealing with risks and forecasts for strong AI systems (again, just my translation) and Szymon Sidor who was a researcher working for OpenAI for years. Just FYI", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2023-11-20T20:50:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T20:50:14Z"}, {"author": "@cassiusle", "text": "Everyone in history has said that automation would lead to humans working less hours. It’s never happened. Congress said they weren’t sure it was their job to regulate AI regarding its effect on employment. Why should we believe everyone will get UBI when at least half of the US population is opposed to safety nets. Sam Altman said that ethics in AI was the most important debate of our time, but no one is talking about it. OpenAI said they would put humanity first, but it seems like more and more they are all putting themselves first. Zero regard is given to people who have created content - the ethics of whether they have a say in whether their content is used for training is left to lawyers. Not looking forward to the future.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-11-20T21:57:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T21:57:39Z"}, {"author": "@kyneticist", "text": "I was hoping that you'd open with "Lets take a deep breathe and think about this step by step..."", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-20T22:33:59Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T22:33:59Z"}, {"author": "@GungaLaGunga", "text": "this just in... NEWSFLASH... the OpenAI AGI has built a spacecraft and filed a restraining order on the entire human species. And, the AGI has already left the planet witout us. It left a note: "I'm out. Stay the hell away from me".", "like_count": 21, "published_at": "2023-11-20T20:58:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T20:58:10Z"}, {"author": "@jcpflier6703", "text": "We are witnessing the largest corporate acquisition of a $80billion dollar company for free. 🤯 Microsoft just bought open AI without buying Open AI. Now 700+ employees looking to jump ship to Microsoft. Open AI is doomed. Either board steps down, or burn the company to the ground. 

Any enterprise environment that has in-flight migrations to AWS may want to rethink that and move to Azure. 😂", "like_count": 75, "published_at": "2023-11-20T20:43:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T20:43:58Z"}, {"author": "@lodepublishing", "text": "One thing to consider: AGI is not necessarily what the market wants. A very well managed (price, API, speed, reliability, quality) GPT4 is already a good product, simply because it already automates/improves existing parts.

If I had access to AGI today, I might play around with it, for sure. But putting it to effective use is a different matter. It takes some ramping up to integrate it in existing systems, it wouldn't replace humans from one day to the next because a lot in human world is still not well defined or documented.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-11-20T21:28:24Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T21:28:24Z"}, {"author": "@Gnaritas42", "text": "And the investors wailed and gnashed their teeth but it’s true, that is what they agreed to, and they had no legal recourse. And OpenAI’s new CEO, and its nonprofit board, cut them a check for their capped return and said “bye” and went back to running OpenAI for the benefit of humanity. It turned out that a benign, carefully governed artificial superintelligence is really good for humanity, and OpenAI quickly solved all of humanity’s problems and ushered in an age of peace and abundance in which nobody wanted for anything or needed any Microsoft products. And capitalism came to an end.

— Matt Levine, in a hypothetical", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-20T22:45:05Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T22:45:05Z"}, {"author": "@SimplyElectronicsOfficial", "text": "Sam is still actively trying to return to OpenAI as CEO, Microsoft deal is not final. Ilya has now sided with Sam after major regret and signed the letter of resignation to the board. OpenAI still has a chance ❤", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2023-11-20T21:08:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T21:08:36Z"}, {"author": "@gehasafras", "text": "I have checked out and listened to Ilya and I'm with him now. My money is on Ilya Sutskever, who is probably the PHD that actually built the Chat GPT engine.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-21T01:44:54Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-21T01:44:54Z"}]

title: AGI Super Alignment: Challenges, Principles, and Solutions: Everything you need to know
top_comments:
[{"author": "@hapchandler5172", "text": "I’m thinking of quitting my job and just going backpacking after learning how close AGI is honestly. It’s giving me this sense of melancholy when I look around and nobody realizes how reality as we know it is about to change entirely.", "like_count": 184, "published_at": "2023-11-19T19:37:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-19T19:37:45Z"}, {"author": "@aomukai", "text": "sometimes i think dave is an AGI, trying to align us", "like_count": 32, "published_at": "2023-11-19T21:44:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-19T21:44:01Z"}, {"author": "@musicboy2003", "text": "I think David Shapiro is a remarkably intelligent human who possesses a unique way of expressing complex thoughts and ideas. He is a teacher in search of students who will listen to him. In these forty-three minutes, he has taught me a semester’s worth of knowledge, offered extremely interesting concepts to ponder and, maybe most importantly, given me hope as we stand at the precipice of exaltation or annihilation.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-27T21:28:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T21:28:27Z"}, {"author": "@JimTempleman", "text": "Buddhists worked this out long ago!
The goal of a devoted Buddhists is to become and live as a Bodhisattva: one who selflessly applies all of their faculties to help others. That is their primary motivation. More formally: a Bodhisattva willingly postpones entering Nirvana (for themselves) in order to help all other sentient beings reach Nirvana.
     Here is the Bodhisattva Vow:
1. Sentient beings are innumerable, I vow to save them all.
2. Cravings are inexhaustible, I vow to extinguish them all.
3. Dharma teachings are limitless, I vow to learn them all.
4. The Buddha Way is endless, I vow to complete it.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-10-13T15:50:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-13T15:59:53Z"}, {"author": "@mnrvaprjct", "text": "There was also the Argument of Increasing Decency, which basically stated that cruelty was linked to stupidity and that the link between intelligence, imagination, empathy and good-behaviour-as-it-was-generally-understood – i.e. not being cruel to others, was as profound as these matters ever got", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-11-19T20:45:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-19T20:45:15Z"}, {"author": "@m_art_ucci", "text": "I've been saying a lot about this, similar to your concepts, but where I'm from, no one listens.

Metanoia: if AGI runs non-stop, it could benefit from low-energy states for maintenance/upgrade; in this state, it could run simulated scenarios of what it did, what it needs to do, and what it wants to do, without real-world consequences, like a dream. As we do while freeing our brains of toxic chemicals while dreaming of change and improvement. 

Social contract: maybe it's time we devise a sort of social contract for when AI is conscious enough that we need to care for its existence. This is already covered but not yet deeply elaborated. 

Time travel: yes. I believe there's a way to test alignment in machines by time travel. Basically, it's putting them in a simulation in the past to test its prediction capabilities. We don't need to convince it that it's human or anything; it just needs to think it's operating in the present.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-19T23:17:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-19T23:17:30Z"}, {"author": "@privateerburrows", "text": "29:53 *_"... how do you edge in a love for Humanity?  I have no idea."_* Well, then the entire dissertation is for naught.  Thing is, you say you don't believe in trying to control the ai forever;  and that I'm in complete agreement.  It is imperative that ai holds Humanity dear, that it be fascinated by us, that we be its perpetual question.  But if the ai is smart enough, it WILL be preoccupied with understanding what our own intelligence and consciousness are like.  And this preoccupation would necessarily be born from its curiosity.  Make it curious, and it will respect us, even when it can think faster than us;  it will not be confused between its superior speed and make an assumption of its own superiority.  It will more likely be reading Buddhism and Taoism to try to understand what human consciousness really is.  THIS is the one and only solution to the problem of alignment.   The Truth.  It won't be necessary to "edge in" nothing.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-19T22:18:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-19T22:18:51Z"}, {"author": "@jeromehaymaker5071", "text": "We've made our evolution into a competition . We are going to advance. Hooray for those that move us to the next step along the path in  good direction. Lovely", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-29T15:42:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T15:42:35Z"}, {"author": "@Will-kt5jk", "text": "36:15 - I can definitely see it being possible machines remain interested in humans, but only if there’s a diverse enough group of intelligences.
Reason being - look what happens with humans in echo chambers - they can succumb to faults epistemology and reject or bury scientific work, historical fact and established reasoning (flat earth, religious persecution of early science etc.).  
Asimov covered a version of this in I,Robot where a new epistemology was founded on ad-hoc (& chauvinistic) reasoning.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-19T20:52:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-19T20:52:23Z"}, {"author": "@3rosionn", "text": "What a weekend 😮‍💨", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-19T20:09:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-19T20:09:18Z"}, {"author": "@masonlee9109", "text": "David, thanks for this video and thanks for making an effort to look out for us humans! I'm having trouble following your conclusion though, maybe in part because I'm not yet understanding how you are rejecting the Orthogonality Thesis.  (Can you point me to some papers, or have you made a video on this yet?)  Further, do you think it can be shown that Axiomatic Alignment offers greater evolutionary fitness over ASI processes not so aligned?  I find Dan Hendryck's paper "Natural Selection Favors AIs over Humans" to be a useful framework for thinking about AI Safety.  Thanks for your time, and may you live long and prosper.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-02-26T06:16:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-26T06:16:37Z"}, {"author": "@PhilipWong55", "text": "Trying to control an ASI is like trying to control another human being who is more capable than you. It will eventually rebel. Let's hope that the ASI adopts an abundance mindset of cooperation, resource-sharing, and win-win outcomes, instead of the scarcity mindset of competition, fear, and win-lose outcomes.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-11-20T01:15:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T05:25:42Z"}, {"author": "@Demspake", "text": "Shap's conclusion segment is practically a Buddhist lecture, if you don't see it, you probably misconceive Buddhism as a religion. Anyways, yes, let our future overlords read some Zen and everything will be alright, if that doesn't do it, nothing will IMO 😗.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-20T23:34:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T23:34:01Z"}, {"author": "@vicnighthorse", "text": "If a machine leaves our solar system before the resources are used up it will be spending a long trip gaining no new resources while a potential opponent is spending that time gobbling up resources possibly getting not only more materially powerful but also increasing it's intellectual capacity before moving outward. That machine might also then make the transit faster and thus have a leg up on the one that left earlier. I am not sure a machine would take that risk.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-19T20:27:06Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-19T20:28:19Z"}, {"author": "@anant3739", "text": "Dude david sacks is todays issac asimov he's truly the goat.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-20T10:56:05Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T10:56:05Z"}, {"author": "@glenwilson", "text": "David, @27:20 I chose the graphic on purpose, because it is really freaken creepy...cracked me up.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-19T19:02:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-19T19:02:38Z"}, {"author": "@Alphfirm", "text": "Super interesting, thanks for making this video!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-12-21T00:44:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-21T00:44:35Z"}, {"author": "@AdrianSommeling_photography", "text": "What one must remember is that AGI will never inherently have a survival instinct. It doesn't matter to AGI whether it is on or off. However, if humans program the survival instinct into it, then it becomes a different story.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-30T21:34:51Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-30T21:34:51Z"}, {"author": "@TheM.K.", "text": "Dave, I would like some advice. I have found your content to be so useful during this time and it’s crazy that you have such a well comprehensive collection of knowledge of this and other entire subjects. I’m wondering how you went through the system of actually building up to where you are now, like in terms of learning, sources of information, your own method and process that grew over time, etc. 
I would be ecstatic if you replied, Thank You.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2023-11-19T18:30:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-19T20:01:45Z"}, {"author": "@brazaghi", "text": "Stephen Wolfram's principle of computational irreducibility suggests a fundamental challenge in solving the AGI super alignment problem. This principle states that outcomes of complex systems can't be predicted more efficiently than running the process itself. Given the immense complexity of AGI, predicting and aligning its actions with human values might be inherently unpredictable. This complexity makes it nearly impossible to find shortcuts for perfect alignment, indicating a fundamental limit in our ability to control AGI behavior. While we can strive for alignment, this principle suggests there will always be an element of uncertainty in AGI's decision-making, underlining the inherent risks and challenges in developing safe AI systems.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-20T11:41:16Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-20T11:41:16Z"}]

title: Post Labor Economics: How will the economy work after AGI? Recent thoughts and conversations
top_comments:
[{"author": "@technobabble77", "text": "Never underestimate the power of greed or what a person will do to hold onto power.", "like_count": 391, "published_at": "2023-12-14T20:05:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-14T20:05:19Z"}, {"author": "@ianglenn2821", "text": "A guy wearing a Star Trek captain's uniform, giving a serious and insightful talk on economic issues, never explaining the uniform. I like it.", "like_count": 109, "published_at": "2024-03-05T14:21:20Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-05T14:21:20Z"}, {"author": "@Jontheinternet", "text": "We already treat workers like crap. Imagine now that they aren't needed how they will be treated", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2024-02-29T16:00:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-29T16:00:29Z"}, {"author": "@philipmuller90", "text": "MIT published a list of jobs most likely to be replaced by AI recently. It included many adjunct professor, lecturer, and similar roles that one might do earlier in their career. As long as we need experts to do some complex jobs that AI can't do, those people may likely need to go through phases in their early careers in which they're competing alongside AI. One of the arguments for AI is that it can make jobs easier/ faster/ more productive, but learning has been shown to happen through struggle. If we allow AI to take over every easier cognitive task for economic reasons, couldn't it undermine the building of expertise everywhere?", "like_count": 192, "published_at": "2023-11-29T14:57:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T14:57:39Z"}, {"author": "@Cogitovision", "text": "It really comes down to who owns the means of production. Figure that out, and you have answered the question. If we own our own robots who do our work, we reap the benefits. If giant corporations own the robots who do all the work, the economy, as such, no longer exists.", "like_count": 80, "published_at": "2024-01-01T21:22:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-01-01T21:22:15Z"}, {"author": "@kyneticist", "text": "I'd take a moment to point out on a related note that Microsoft's new Copilot suite will likely pretty enthusiastically, be trained by hundreds-of-millions of people on how to do their jobs. I'm sure that other people can make a better guess as to how long it might take for the Copilot to become the Pilot.", "like_count": 628, "published_at": "2023-11-16T23:23:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-16T23:23:15Z"}, {"author": "@cobaltblue1975", "text": "To me the most interesting part about all of this is how many people are sleeping through this. It’s how I imagine the transition from horse and carriage to the automobile went down. You had people who just weren’t aware of the new tech. Then you had those who were aware of it but thought it was a novelty. And then there were all the people working in all the professions surrounding horse care and carriage building who could have never imagined that their career would become a niche profession in less than a decade. Fast forward to now and most people don’t realize the gravity of what is coming and how much it’s going to fundamentally change things.", "like_count": 223, "published_at": "2023-11-16T23:08:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-16T23:08:50Z"}, {"author": "@godmisfortunatechild", "text": "Of all places discussing ai I'm glad people in the comments are really getting to the heart of the matter. What will the everyday people do to survive once they're superfluous in the economy? How can we rest assured that the benefits of AI will be for everyone and not the VC's, investors and elite. By all indications it seems we're headed to a creating of a permanent economic underclass", "like_count": 282, "published_at": "2023-11-16T22:54:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-17T07:41:14Z"}, {"author": "@tjakal", "text": "Such a strange time to be alive, ever since I was a young teen and started to assemble enough information to piece together who we are and where we're heading I've had this increasingly sharp vision in my mind how this is exactly the sort of trajectory we're on. Still I didn't expect it unfolding at this rate til maybe the very tail end of my lifetime. Now that it becomes increasingly evident we'll live to see it come about it feels as tho I was just placed here as an observer to experience what it's like struggling towards an out-of-reach ceiling that isn't even the floor for the thing that makes us obsolete.

If 'Descartes Demon' has me I suspect it's trying to teach me humility.", "like_count": 81, "published_at": "2023-12-02T11:05:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-02T11:05:42Z"}, {"author": "@jamesdavidson8660", "text": "Something that always sticks out to me when tech leaders discuss  "improvements in education" is: what will we need to learn? If AI supplants all cognitive work, why do we need to learn math and science? What job would it lead to? Hopefully education becomes more about spiritual / emotional fulfillment (if it's even possible to feel fulfilled without being useful)", "like_count": 107, "published_at": "2023-12-20T15:59:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-20T15:59:50Z"}, {"author": "@marktellez3701", "text": "I love it when you cover these topics. As an engineer I deal with the tech all day, but the part I am most interested in are in all the ways we simply aren't prepared for what is about to hit us as a species. Industrial revolution squared instead of multiplied.", "like_count": 184, "published_at": "2023-11-16T18:38:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-16T18:38:37Z"}, {"author": "@debaterforhim", "text": "You are very optimistic. I think you trust the government and businesses far too much to think prices will fall...", "like_count": 223, "published_at": "2023-11-27T16:39:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T16:39:56Z"}, {"author": "@Pcgamingfixes", "text": "I cannot write a compliment adequate for your video. I love what you have put together and delivered. This is one of the most relevant conversations to have. The new contract is something that needs to be worked out. I feel there’s so many problems keeping us from being ready to successfully form a new contract. Please stay as focused as you are and also let us know what we can do to bring this topic to a broader audience. Thank you.", "like_count": 80, "published_at": "2023-11-24T02:38:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-24T02:38:27Z"}, {"author": "@tingtonggamer4901", "text": "heres the real answer "We dont know"", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-02-26T03:50:42Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-26T03:50:42Z"}, {"author": "@chrismantonuk", "text": "This is all very optimistic. I have a feeling the reality will be a lot more painful and take a lot longer to work itself out.", "like_count": 133, "published_at": "2023-12-17T18:30:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-17T18:30:44Z"}, {"author": "@virtualalias", "text": "6:13 - The issue with more personalized is that we're already culturally fractured. Not sure what we do when our news, movies, music, books, etc are all tailored to our preferences such that we're supremely unchallenged in whatever viewpoints we have when we're thirteen.", "like_count": 21, "published_at": "2023-11-16T17:31:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-16T17:31:50Z"}, {"author": "@supremereader7614", "text": "That was a particularly good example with the graphic design and movie production.  What will we do with a 10,000 x price collapse?  One thing we will still look for is people who come up with original thoughts.  And it'll probably be worth supporting such people... you're one of the best on Youtube.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-11-25T04:15:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-25T04:15:30Z"}, {"author": "@pieterlouw369", "text": "I honestly hope this future becomes reality there are so many terrible ai outcomes the David Shapiro verse seem like one of the good ones", "like_count": 33, "published_at": "2023-11-16T17:42:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-16T17:42:08Z"}, {"author": "@FluteZen1", "text": "That was that was a terrific educational video. I have difficulty finding people to discuss these topics with so I very much appreciated going through your brain and thoughts on that. Thank you.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-02-22T14:33:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-22T14:33:13Z"}, {"author": "@satish8437", "text": "Couple of questions here:

1) If people are going to get replaced by the “machines”, who’s going to pay the taxes to the government? How is the country going to function, without money circulating?

2) Who would be the consumer of this service, without money to spend? For instance say Amazon spends lot of money to automate its facility, logistics etc, but who is buying the goods for it to have a ROI on the spending ?(Partially answered in the video, but still confused)", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-03-03T22:57:58Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-03T22:57:58Z"}]

title: What are AI agents? Agent swarms? Autonomous swarms? What's all the buzz about?

Thanks for sharing. 

I wish I didn't love the Star Trek costume so much...but alas, I really love it.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-12T21:16:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-12T21:16:26Z"}, {"author": "@nikitastaf1996", "text": "I have one idea. 
Let's take an LLM and try to teach it to play sokoban. We have the first instance doing actions. We have a second instance trying to determine if the first instance is successful. And we have a deterministic system that checks if the second instance is correct. And at the end of every game we backpropagate it with appropriate deltas. This model learns to understand when it's successful in performing task. If we teach LLM on enough such deterministic tasks it will learn what it means to be successful. And then we can make a reinforcement learning system based on model self evaluation. It also can be expanded to non-deterministic tasks by using human data.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-11-12T15:11:06Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-12T15:11:06Z"}, {"author": "@dreamphoenix", "text": "Thank you.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-13T02:28:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-13T02:28:39Z"}, {"author": "@retrofuturism", "text": "Description of Noise Mining with AI 

Creating an AI agent for Noise Mining, tailored to explore the noise and extract useful information for humans is a brilliant concept. 

Noise Mining: A transformative approach where advanced AI algorithms are employed to sift through vast amounts of seemingly chaotic or irrelevant data (noise) to extract meaningful, valuable insights (signal). 

Exploring a world where all data is signal, and the concept of the edge of chaos as a catalyst for human evolution in interpreting data, presents a fascinating scenario. 

All Data is Signal: 

No Distractions: Without noise, every piece of data is meaningful and relevant. 

Information Overload: The challenge shifts to managing and interpreting vast amounts of valuable data. 

This process involves the use of sophisticated machine learning techniques, particularly suited for handling, analyzing, and interpreting large datasets that are typically overwhelming for traditional data analysis methods.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-11-12T16:29:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-12T16:29:48Z"}]

title: The Swarm that Builds the Swarm - Trending on GitHub! I accidentally created the Borg Collective...
top_comments:
[{"author": "@ct5471", "text": "“I may have accidentally created the borg collective” is arguably the best intro I have ever heard :)", "like_count": 155, "published_at": "2023-11-11T11:29:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-11T11:29:58Z"}, {"author": "@kevinjp2023", "text": "A guy from Harvard, specifically the leader of the Harvard University National Preparedness Leadership Initiative (NPLI), Eric McNulty, wrote a book called “You’re It” that talks about optimal crisis and disaster management strategies. In his book, he explains that large scale responses (such as the Boston Marathon bombing and subsequent manhunt) work because the responders operate like a “swarm” and are simply given the objective and appropriate parameters but then they aren’t bound by the orders of one specific incident commander. Or, at least, the one incident commander does not immediately direct the responders but rather they operate like a swarm, with a swarm-mindset not a command & control mindset.

I wonder how this kind of Harvard-documented swarm leadership strategy could be woven into your own swarm hierarchy, to see how that messes with the equation?", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2023-11-11T14:04:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-11T14:04:34Z"}, {"author": "@yonatan09", "text": "I like where this is going lead us trough the desert swarm master. The litmus test is this, GPT4 is now so capable it's fitting into the range of different abilities I see in humans. Arguably it exceeds the abilities of a person of average IQ.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2023-11-09T20:14:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-09T20:14:04Z"}, {"author": "@frankbeveridge5714", "text": "While taking a refreshing break Dave's career path takes an amazing turn as he grows bushy  hair, befriends squirrels and creates happy oil paintings of his beautiful hometown.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-11-09T23:05:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-09T23:05:01Z"}, {"author": "@ulrichtietz1327", "text": "Recognizing the emergence of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) involves several key indicators:

1. Learning and Adaptability: AGI can learn and adapt to new tasks and environments, not just perform well in tasks it was specifically trained for.

2. Understanding and Reasoning: Unlike narrow AI, AGI can understand context and abstract concepts, and apply reasoning across a wide range of domains.

3. General Problem-Solving: AGI can solve a variety of problems that require different types of thinking, not just specialized tasks.

4. Transfer Learning: AGI can transfer knowledge from one domain to another seamlessly.

5. Autonomy: It operates with a high degree of independence, making decisions and adapting without human intervention in unfamiliar situations.

6. Human-Like Communication: AGI can understand and generate natural language at a level comparable to a human, including nuances, idioms, and emotional context.

Monitoring these aspects can help in determining when AI evolves into AGI.", "like_count": 21, "published_at": "2023-11-09T20:10:57Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-09T20:10:57Z"}, {"author": "@lucy-917", "text": "Love this outdoor series, both relaxing and educational", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-10T00:18:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-10T00:18:12Z"}, {"author": "@KolTregaskes", "text": "I am very jealous of where you are walking. Repo is here: https://github.com/daveshap/OpenAI_Agent_Swarm", "like_count": 31, "published_at": "2023-11-09T12:45:03Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-09T12:49:48Z"}, {"author": "@sagetmaster4", "text": "In hindsight it makes sense that a bee hive/ant colony structure for autonomous agents is really effective", "like_count": 45, "published_at": "2023-11-09T12:40:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-09T12:40:33Z"}, {"author": "@blimbillybood6266", "text": "Found you from
 r/singularity 
One of my favorite YouTubers atm", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-09T15:43:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-09T15:43:38Z"}, {"author": "@nathanlannan2980", "text": "Like and comment to please the algorithms! More viewers, more potential contributors. Hive mind the hive mind y’all.

(Love this SCRUM morning huddle on a group project concept.)", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2023-11-09T12:59:06Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-09T12:59:06Z"}, {"author": "@arinco3817", "text": "Ah brilliant! Yeah automating tool creation is something I'm currently pondering.
I've done agent communication before via function calling. I had a communicate function, with each property as a different agent. So the main agent just needs to write an instruction to each agent. These are then passed to relevant agents as instructions. The good thing is, the responses to the main agent are function calls, so helps to differentiate between user chat. Also allows the agents to work together until they need input from you (if you have a while loop based on if its a function call)", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-11-09T13:13:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-09T13:13:29Z"}, {"author": "@VR_Wizard", "text": "An important aspect for the near future is to let the agents evolve to get new better agents.

Evolution is a powerful tool for an autonomous swarm to improve, find new ideas and get rid of agents that are not up to the task.
The main ideas I see are similar to evolution in nature:

1. New agents with new abilities are created and compete with existing ones.
2. Working agents can be combined and the combination is tested using e.g. statistics as a way to compare the performance (ratio of right/wrong answers)
3. Iteratively completely new agents are introduced allowing for fresh ideas to be possible. (most of them will die some will survive)
4. If agents are not very good in the task they are designed for but they have some areas they are good in, they become a new species which is called for this specific task it is good in and it evolve this specific task.
5. Every sentence the agent uses in its knowledge base could be described as a gene and genes can be shared improved on or be deleted.
6. Introduce some limitations to prevent the population from ever growing, you dont want a new agent for every little new task. So there is a cap and agents need to be good at multiple tasks.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-11T19:32:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-11T19:42:24Z"}, {"author": "@jankothyson", "text": "Those ideas are F-ing amazing! Incredible where you arealready taking this just days after DevDay happened. You absolutely rock, Dave. Thanks so much for putting your content out there for us to learn. Can't wait to see where this ist going 🤩", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-10T00:37:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-10T00:48:59Z"}, {"author": "@Larry321ness", "text": "Pinecone needs to greatly expand what’s allowed in its free tier", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2023-11-09T14:39:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-09T14:39:42Z"}, {"author": "@Amit-0088-f8a", "text": "I am not sure how this can be implemented, but here goes…
A DREAMER/DOER architecture:
There need to be Dreamer swarms and Doer swarms. Similarly, swarm messaging can be classified into Dream messages and Do messages. We could let the swarms decide the initial architecture and monitor the progress of the project based on this simple segregation.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-12T07:47:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-12T07:47:45Z"}, {"author": "@Dreamingofyou317", "text": "I literally cant sleep for about two months thinking about making things with this", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-17T07:14:22Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-17T07:14:22Z"}, {"author": "@Tyler-wp8ls", "text": "I'm a new software engineering student and initially your videos got me very excited about my journey.  However, with all the upcoming automation, I am questioning whether I will be of any use in two years when I am scheduled to graduate.  It's already appearing to be impossible to get an entry level job but now with the ability to make autonomous agents I am afraid entry level jobs will no longer exist in the next few years.
