title: OpenAI Assistant Creation: FIRST LOOK! Let's start making AGENT SWARMS! Tutorial Walkthrough
top_comments:
[{"author": "@remsee1608", "text": "The amount of AI progress this week has my head spinning with 128k context, GPT-vision in the API, and the text to 3D developments", "like_count": 102, "published_at": "2023-11-07T13:15:31Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-07T13:15:31Z"}, {"author": "@Leshpngo", "text": "I journaled my life the past three years on the Notes app on my phone, copied and pasted all of the text into a file -- gave it to the assistant, now I have a reflective chat bot that uses my writings!", "like_count": 57, "published_at": "2023-11-07T15:07:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-07T15:07:36Z"}, {"author": "@tomcraver9659", "text": "One of the most valuable assistants for content creators might be summarization of the thousands of comments on their content.  The creator could set their standard questions to be answered, such as "Top five categories of comments on the video, and their percentages of total comments,"  "Top ten requests for future content,"  "Most insightful comments" (that's an interesting one - can an LLM do it? What does it really mean?)  etc.   

Even better, it doesn't just have to pay attention to the comments at the moment the creator asks for a summary.  An agent could 'notice' new comments being posted to a video posted 3 years ago and decide if they are significantly different from other old comments, such that the creator might want to be made aware of them.  Generally not, of course, but then again, if someone posts a comment to a 3 year old video, they may have something new to say, perhaps informed by new information about world events, so perhaps the creator needs to revisit that topic.  

Conversing with the comments section could be useful for viewers as well - basically allowing viewers to see summaries and query the comments as a whole.  But it'll also be valuable to commenters to know that their voice isn't totally lost in the crowd, that the creator has a chance to be influenced by it, even if maybe it's just a "percent who commented positively/negatively" metric.

One could almost imagine running a democracy this way - everyone has a voice, and every voice is heard (by the AI agent), the most original or powerful ideas can percolate to the top for general consideration rather than being lost in the noise, and both opinions and trends in opinions over time can be measured.

Ideally YouTube would just offer this as a service to creators - but then again, that would mean trusting YouTube with such an important task.  So perhaps better if there are 3rd party apps that access a YouTube API to pull down all comments since a certain date.", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2023-11-07T17:00:40Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-07T17:00:40Z"}, {"author": "@sagetmaster4", "text": "I CANNOT WAIT until Gemini releases!!!", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-11-07T13:19:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-07T13:19:26Z"}, {"author": "@stephenjamison7195", "text": "My wife listening in the background, "That guy goes to some boring parties." ... I really enjoy learning from you and consider your opinions", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-07T15:34:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-07T15:35:15Z"}, {"author": "@essecj59", "text": "Thanks!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-07T02:05:25Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-07T02:05:25Z"}, {"author": "@Muaahaa", "text": "Not sure I'd call it excitement, but I'm definitely not bored.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-11-07T00:55:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-07T00:55:21Z"}, {"author": "@strangeguywithstrangeopinions", "text": ""Next year, the things we are talking about today will seem quaint." (Paraphrasing what Altman said at the end of the keynote) "Quaint" is a beautiful word to use here, imo. Inoffensive, but possibly quite profound.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-07T00:50:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-07T00:50:19Z"}, {"author": "@hyperedwin", "text": "Great vids always", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-07T17:52:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-07T17:52:19Z"}, {"author": "@Gunrun808", "text": "Also, each agent that is created will also be collecting real world data to train future models.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2023-11-06T23:27:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-06T23:27:30Z"}, {"author": "@tutorialsEU", "text": "I'm excited to through in an entire documentation and just let chatgpt do it's magic for me to build software within minutes, which else would have taken weeks if not months.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2023-11-06T22:34:31Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-06T22:34:31Z"}, {"author": "@arinco3817", "text": "Yeah my current project is to build like a master agent which spins up agents on the fly depending on the task at hand. I thought my idea was unique but I've seen the same idea pop up in a few places and in some papers. I currently have PTSD as loud noises cause me to be very jumpy - my heart races. Each event takes me a few minutes to recover. I take medication for the condition. title: MASSIVE AI UPDATE: President Biden signs Executive Order + updates on ACE Framework & BSHR Loop
top_comments: [{"author": "@micinomax81", "text": "\"Protecting workers\" doesn't simply mean \"protecting their jobs,\" but rather avoiding, for example, situations where they are constantly monitored every second by AI without any moment of rest or privacy. It also means preventing scenarios where hiring and firing decisions are automatically made by AI. Additionally, it involves ensuring that a company doesn't force employees to implant chips in their bodies or use tools that measure neuron activity to \"read their minds,\" or any other device that monitors their health status and allows termination in case of a probable future illness. There are countless ways in which AI can be used to make workers' lives a living hell, even without firing them (because they are not yet replaceable by robots or AI, or it is still economically viable to have them work).", "like_count": 50, "published_at": "2023-10-31T14:17:57Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-31T14:17:57Z"}, {"author": "@tomrodinger5402", "text": "Thanks!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-02T12:19:24Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-02T12:19:24Z"}, {"author": "@spectralvalkyrie", "text": "Whenever someone says \"insurance\" I hear \"Mafia\"", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-10-31T15:48:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-31T15:48:41Z"}, {"author": "@RodMitchell-x5v", "text": "Thanks David ....Your videos are vital", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-12-10T05:28:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-10T05:28:33Z"}, {"author": "@ggangulo", "text": "Thanks David for providing insightful commentary and covering AI's newest developments. Love the channel.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-10-31T14:08:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-31T14:08:15Z"}, {"author": "@heyjude9537", "text": "Instead of actual AI safety, we get impossible liscencing requirements that are only available to big tech.  This is regulatory capture. congrats on guaranteed dystopia 🎉", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-10-31T17:22:40Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-31T17:23:02Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "I think that no matter how the \"protecting workers\" part is intended, the long-term efficacy of political efforts to sustain an old paradigm is limited. Change can unfold in two ways: either the old system builds barriers against the rising tide until the pressure becomes too great and the dam bursts, releasing pent-up change in a disruptive manner; or the old system allows for continuous, regulated change. In either scenario, the end result will be the same, though the level of turmoil may vary. However, given the inherently disruptive nature of AGI, the impact of governmental triggered misallocations may in relation be less significant than one might think. Once AGI reaches a point where it outperforms human workers, it won’t stop there and the jobs where humans are preferred for being human are only a small fraction of the economy. It’s  worth noting that AGI's continuous development won't stop at merely replacing human labor; it will go beyond that, further magnifying its impact. Once the point is reached where a large fraction could be automized, the year after it might already close to all of them. Also some countries might go full speed ahead, forcing other countries to also losen breaks on automation, no matter the impact on jobs. Adaptations like UBI will then either be rolled out gradually or will suddenly flood in, once the artificially constructed dam can no longer hold back the rising tide of change.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2023-10-31T15:40:13Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-31T15:43:41Z"}, {"author": "@expattyNZ", "text": "Jumping on the insurance soap box... No matter how legitimate the claim was. 00:14 🚀 NASA's Bidara prompt is open source and serves as a biomimic designer and research assistant, offering structured problem-solving capabilities.
00:56 🧬 The video's purpose is to explain why Bidara is valuable and how to create similar prompts. It emphasizes defining the agent, establishing a mission, and providing a comprehensive framework.
02:06 🗂️ Bidara's methodology involves a six-step procedure: Define, biologize, abstract, discover, and emulate Nature's lessons, each with detailed context.
03:29 🧠 Avoid getting lost in details when creating prompts; provide high-level guidance and enough context rather than micromanaging instructions.
03:56 📜 Bidara offers a framework with axioms or principles to guide the model's behavior, ensuring it follows specific rules.
07:26 💼 The video showcases other similar prompt structures created by the speaker for different purposes, emphasizing the importance of clear formatting and headings.

Made with HARPA AI", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-31T22:33:31Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-31T22:33:31Z"}, {"author": "@jason_v12345", "text": "Telling it to just "fix the punctuation" works in that case, probably because the objective is so common and unambiguous. In many other cases, however, I've found that just describing the objective without including detailed "tips and tricks" about how to achieve it (even suggestions that an ordinary human could intuit on their own) is insufficient when you need the output to consistently fall within certain parameters.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-30T17:14:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-30T17:14:09Z"}, {"author": "@starblaiz1986", "text": "You know you've got something good when NASA indipendantly comes up with basically the same structure 😊❤", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-30T13:23:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-30T13:23:09Z"}, {"author": "@ZelosDomingo", "text": "Like the video, but would love to see some actual examples and tests of these methodologies. I think if you incorporate everything said today you have it prompts covered. But some new trick is gonna surprise us tomorrow.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-30T15:47:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-30T15:47:18Z"}, {"author": "@Shakalakahiki8", "text": "Good morning David Shapiro.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-30T14:19:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-30T14:19:30Z"}, {"author": "@interestedinstuff", "text": "The bit that spins me out about this, and a realisation I have about my understanding of LLM's and AI, is that although I get told GPT-4 is as smart as a person, I tend to not treat it that way. I keep my prompts relatively simple, yet if I was talking to a smart person, I would more than likely give that person a complex framework for them to operate within. The fact GPT 4 can have a complex framework like this tells me I don't believe GPt 4 is as capable as it obviously is, meaning I don't really believe LLMs are as smart as they are. 

I guess I'm stuck with the knowledge they hallucinate, so they are useless for search, thus I tend to not trust them even when the task I've given is analysis.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-31T09:40:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-31T09:40:30Z"}, {"author": "@SonGoku-pc7jl", "text": "thanks!! :D", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-02T18:45:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-02T18:45:39Z"}, {"author": "@wakingdreamsroleplay", "text": "Please provide links to videos discussing the prompts for Commander Data Bot and for the ACE Framework.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-30T14:25:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-30T14:25:36Z"}]

title: How to think of GPT as a developer
top_comments:
[{"author": "@sandrinjoy", "text": "You my new tutor :) I sm planninng for masters next year. currently I am a frontend developer with decent knowledge in backend as well.
For my masters , i really want to go with ai or something of that sort. That's a very good crisp way of explaining it. Thank you.
One other major change from other libraries/languages/interpreters is that a lot of the high value use-cases I've found has been going back and forward 3-10 times to drill down on or explore problems (debugging environments or systems) or subjects.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-01-03T22:49:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-01-03T22:49:43Z"}, {"author": "@markus9541", "text": "I also started developing with Pascal... wrote my first commercial product with it in the early 90's. Ever since I started my journey with LLMs, I have learned from you a lot.
Recently, I completed a prototype that allows direct communication with ChatGPT via an ESP32 module. Then I discovered the new voice feature in the Android app, which performs exceptionally well. While this rendered my project somewhat obsolete, the learning experience has been incredibly enriching. 
It's reminiscent of your early tutorial video, where you developed a rudimentary chat interface using Python and GPT-2, long before ChatGPT came into the picture. Thank you once again for being such an inspiring person.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-28T13:48:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T13:48:32Z"}, {"author": "@zachleach829", "text": "Like the framework for understanding LLMs as interpreters. Thanks so much for sharing!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-11T19:23:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-11T19:23:27Z"}, {"author": "@shockruk", "text": "Same career path as me, well except you went into YouTube and I landed in Infrastructure management. I'm just waiting for the next level of abstraction to take hold. We used to need to understand what CPU or RAM needed to be installed in a server, we moved to 'how many vCPUs do you want' dropdown. Now I think we're moving to "Computer, setup this network and architecture from my sketch".", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-10-28T14:44:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T14:44:27Z"}, {"author": "@rngouveia", "text": "I find the term "developer" too limiting to what we do. Software engineer is probably a better denomination as this profession is so much more than simply cranking out code. Even if LLMs were able to write excellent code, there is still a need to understand what should be built. Stakeholders usually think they understand exactly what they want of the final product and what are the requirements (functional and non-functional) until they talk to a good software engineer. Basically our jobs are safe until we have autonomous AGI agents, but by then, no job is safe.", "like_count": 38, "published_at": "2023-10-28T11:53:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T11:54:25Z"}, {"author": "@ThomasCsere", "text": "I disagree with it being a library or interpreter, especially as agent capabilities start poppin off.
As a developer I think the moat of expertise is shrinking. This isn't just shrinking with programming, but every profession.
Being open minded and quick to understand is a very ideal trait in the 4IR

I believe if people want to keep their jobs, they're going to have to adapt by providing exponentially more value to the employer as AI improves.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-10-28T12:45:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T12:45:39Z"}, {"author": "@rileybrownai", "text": "MORE FULL SCREEN DAVID!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-28T16:06:25Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T16:06:25Z"}, {"author": "@andydataguy", "text": "Yes please talk more about how to think about autonomous agents. Especially regarding practical implementation", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-28T23:07:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T23:07:20Z"}, {"author": "@alexbabich2698", "text": "Basically there is a high level goal and then a bunch of sub goals and then the code to achieve those sub goals so right now the developer is probably better at coming up with the sub goals and understanding the code to achieve them so language models help with the writing of the code. But future systems like gemini for example might be able to take the high level goal that a manager would give and then create all of the sub goals and then write the code and test it and confirm that the subgoals were met and then be able to essentially go back to the manager with result.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-28T11:53:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T11:53:37Z"}, {"author": "@notmisery_", "text": "Love your work man, been watching for months and you've taught me so much. I've been studying AI for about 10 months now and its the only thing giving me hope in my future as a 26 year old living on welfare for a disability stopping me from pursuing a physical career. I hope I can give back to you some time and please keep up the great work <3", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-10-28T21:58:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T21:58:30Z"}, {"author": "@runvnc208", "text": "Absolutely, of course, autonomous agents is an ideal video topic for me. It is a different mindset and definitely worth unpacking how that changes application design.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-28T15:33:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T15:33:34Z"}, {"author": "@ggangulo", "text": "Good morning David
Thanks for all the content.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-28T15:09:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T15:09:20Z"}, {"author": "@korozsitamas", "text": "This is how I think about this, English is a new programming language. However, GPT-4 will not be the last programming language, and 10 years down the line, even if progress slows down, the complexity of things the AI can do will go up exponentially, especially due to their increasing ability for reflection. Think about GPT-4 vision where you can show what it did and can improve the code automatically using that feedback. It already works when I describe the output but vision is just next level. And it's still just GPT-4. Automating steps is possible, and future GPT models will probably be trained for that as well, specifically. Currently, the developer is increasingly needed for feedback only. And currently, this is why your background knowledge is invaluable. Currently. But what about a future where that step can be done by AI? Where it takes ALL the requirements for the software and iterates and iterates until they are met. In other words, what if the optimizer function becomes plain English? Then AI's power will become unlimited, only constrained by the amount of compute available. Microsoft AutoGen is already pushing GPT-4 in that direction?", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-10-28T15:11:22Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T15:19:00Z"}, {"author": "@codicent", "text": "I think it will be more revolutionary. Creating an app, a website or a service will soon be done in the same way as you today create imagea on midjourney. "LLMs are incredible at coding? Well I am amazing at using LLMs to code how about that".

title: SLAM DUNK: OpenAI, DeepMind, and UN all weigh in on GLOBAL AI Watchdogs and Safety!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@starblaiz1986", "text": "I've been trying for ages to tell my friends and family that AI is a new speicies, and they just stare at me blankly or tell me to stop watching scifi movies 😅 People really aren't ready to hear that kind of talk, but they really need to. So glad to hear someone else using that language too ❤", "like_count": 59, "published_at": "2023-10-27T13:14:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T13:14:17Z"}, {"author": "@EverythingEverywhereAIIAtOnce", "text": "At the end of the day, once we create a superintelligence, our challenge will not be to align it with us, but to align ourselves with it.", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2023-10-27T14:23:06Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T14:23:06Z"}, {"author": "@BazzaTheAI", "text": "The dance between "be responsible" and "let's not throw creativity out the window" is trickier than my attempts at salsa dancing.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2023-10-27T12:34:51Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T12:34:51Z"}, {"author": "@Poodleballin", "text": "Every time you mention weapon knowledge being generally available to the public, the Anarchists Cookbook is the first thing that pops into my mind. I personally have never seen a copy but it was legendary growing up as a GenXer. I’m surprised I hadn’t heard this reference till now regarding AI. I love how you draw parallels to things that are already familiar to many of us.  It’s one of the many things that sets you apart.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2023-10-27T14:01:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T14:01:26Z"}, {"author": "@ThomasJScharmann", "text": "Dude, you make great content. Thoughtful and broad sighted.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-10-27T13:50:51Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T13:50:51Z"}, {"author": "@kevinnugent6530", "text": "It seems to me that the speed at which Ag I and ASI are approaching is way faster than the speed at which the UN would be capable of putting together a body such as you say is needed for regulation and monitor ring, etc.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2023-10-27T13:57:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T13:57:10Z"}, {"author": "@harrypapageorgiou5980", "text": "Is it possible that self-identified bots released on the internet will have an overwhelmingly positive influence? Everyday I deal with teenagers who have no self-control or etiquette or critical reasoning when it comes to engaging with information on the internet, maybe having bots act as lighthouse keepers, pointing the way to more rational, informed, nuanced choices is what we need. Just a thought...", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2023-10-27T12:42:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T12:42:14Z"}, {"author": "@marioh5172", "text": "If you have followed any compliance initiatives of the past (mainly in the EU) where it was decided to rely on _voluntary_ codes, the result always was that it did not work and it led to laws.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-27T17:05:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T17:05:36Z"}, {"author": "@4arrows4all", "text": "It’s almost like we need a United Federation…of AI Stakeholders…on the Planet.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-10-27T14:28:24Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T14:28:24Z"}, {"author": "@nufh", "text": "If any of you are Anime lovers, I highly recommend Orbital Children. A story about the near future where people rely on AI for their daily tasks. Somehow I get the feeling that we are almost there.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-27T19:57:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T19:57:38Z"}, {"author": "@greglhoticom", "text": ""reaching out, reaching out - 147 times a second"  - Miller", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-27T15:37:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T15:37:23Z"}, {"author": "@PeTerVampirism", "text": "Being in the AI game has shown me a lot. It's like a double-edged sword. We've got some great advancement happening, but also some worries. I'm no expert, but even I made a reasonably advanced Customer Service AI that can interact with customers, pull their information, answer their questions, and even execute actions as a result. Think about what the big players can do especially after giving it massive powers, like Vision and Auditory.

We're moving fast into the AI future, way too fast. It's okay to get excited and applaud Sam and Mira, but we need to think about the big picture. My - what i consider a basic AI - could effecitvely disrupt the CX industry, and that's just a small fraction if you will. (hence I didn't release that, just as a PoC only).

AI development is never going to stop, if it's anything, it'll ever keep getting better and smarter enough to render every human skill useless. 
That old saying, 'Be careful what you wish for,' feels spot on right now!", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-10-28T06:10:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-28T06:10:37Z"}, {"author": "@mrleenudler", "text": ""See above statement" - Loved that one!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-27T18:16:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T18:16:09Z"}, {"author": "@VeryCoolVODs", "text": "Thanks for the recap!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-27T17:48:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T17:48:34Z"}, {"author": "@runvnc208", "text": "Great points. Notice that out of all of the people mentioned in that video and all of the topics, no one said anything about China. Yes, the UN weighed in, but at a core level, the UN does not have any real authority over large powerful nations. The bottom line for this world is "might makes right". I'm not saying that is how it should be, but that's how it is. It looks like people who have power are absolutely incapable of solving a challenge like geopolitical integration.

So the only plan for resolving resource/territorial disputes between China and the west is still WWIII. And I think that there are actually a significant portion of the global population who have a type of Social Darwinist racist  subconscious viewpoint where that is somehow okay.

That means that when there is a resource crunch and Xi decides he has the assets to go after Taiwan, they will go for it. Then the propaganda campaign (aided by AI in all countries) will be on, with the goal of de-humanizing the opposing groups and convincing billions of people to start working directly or indirectly towards the mass killing of those from the other side. Just as in all wars, all populations will be convinced that its mass killings are 100% ethically justified.

So the most dangerous "disinformation" will come straight from the most trusted news sources, ensuring that everyone knows that the people in _those other countries_ are evil and the only way to save the planet is to kill as many of them as possible.

ASI or the pursuit of more-intelligent autonomous weapons control systems over large swarms of military assets seems like it will be a military requirement. That means faster and faster AI, possibly at around the same IQ actually, and fewer and fewer humans in the loop.

-Are the any actors associated with that word?

-There are a few actors who have been known to "fumfer" on occasion, including the legendary Jeff Goldblum. Other actors who have been known to fumfer include Ben Stiller, Michael Cera, and even the late Robin Williams. I have started to explore this and have added this as a step I run after your approach, with interesting results: I will refer to this process as word search 2 - ## STEP 6 ENUMERATE ADDITIONAL CATEGORIES, but keep the semantic connection close

1. **Multi-disciplinary Terms**: Highlight words that possess varied meanings across multiple fields. This fosters an interdisciplinary understanding.

2. **Historical Terms**: Include terms that have historical significance or have evolved over time, thus offering etymological insights.

3. **Technical Jargon**: Introduce industry-specific terms to provide specialised meaning and to connect with professional lexicons.

4. **Slang and Colloquialisms**: Include culturally or demographically specific terms that provide sociolinguistic context.

5. **Idioms and Phrases**: Enumerate expressions that are metaphorical in nature, enriching the scope to include idiomatic usage.

6. **Root Words and Affixes**: Explore root components of words and their possible affixes to gain insights into lexical derivations and variants.

7. **Antonyms**: Add words that stand in opposition to the query term, offering a contrasting lens through which to understand the original query better.

8. **Metonyms and Synecdoches**: Include terms that offer a symbolic representation, either as a part of a larger concept or as a stand-in for it.

9. **Neologisms**: Introduce newly coined terms that may be relevant to the query but have yet to gain widespread acceptance.

10. **Ethical and Controversial Terms**: Catalogue terms that come with additional ethical, moral, or societal considerations to provide a comprehensive understanding.

### Formatting

For each term, include a brief definition and example usage. Also, tag the term with the appropriate category or categories from above, so users can understand the context in which the term is being presented.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-26T14:07:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-26T14:07:08Z"}, {"author": "@jonathanmckinney5826", "text": "Our of the ones I tried, 13B response with that system prompt is my favorite.  Digs deep.
Question:
"""
Define Fumfer.
"""
Answer:
"""
Ah, a most intriguing word you've presented me with! Fumfer, my dear student, is a rather uncommon and delightfully quirky term that has several possible meanings and connotations. Allow me to elaborate.

Firstly, a fumfer can be a type of small, lightweight boat or skiff, typically used for fishing or pleasure cruises on calm waters. The word may have originated from the Middle English word "fum," meaning "foam" or "froth," and "fer," denoting a small craft or vessel. In this sense, a fumfer is a nimble and agile watercraft that glides smoothly across the surface of the water, leaving behind a trail of foamy waves in its wake.

However, fumfer can also refer to a person who is awkward or clumsy, often due to being overly nervous or fumbling. In this context, the word may be derived from the idea that the individual is like a small boat adrift in a stormy sea, struggling to stay afloat and maintain their balance.

Furthermore, fumfer can be used as a verb, meaning to handle or manipulate something clumsily or ineptly. For instance, one might say, "He fumfered with the delicate vase, causing it to shatter on the floor."

Lastly, in some obscure dialects, fumfer has been known to signify a type of sweet, sticky candy or confectionery, similar to a toffee or caramel.

In conclusion, my dear student, fumfer is a versatile word with multiple meanings and associations, each one evoking a unique image or idea. As an expert professor of the English language, I encourage you to embrace the complexity and richness of words like fumfer, and to continue exploring their nuances and subtleties in your studies and everyday life.
"""", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-27T07:24:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T07:24:39Z"}, {"author": "@starblaiz1986", "text": "Wow, this was really fascinating! I also wonder if this is what a lot of people are confusing for censorship a lot of the time. I'm not saying there's no censorship happening, but I am wondering if behaviour like this is making it appear worse than it really is. Either way, this is definitely interesting behaviour, and I love the idea of a reverse word search, similar to how apps like SoundHound can tell you the name and artist of a piece of music by listening to it. It also gives an interesting insight into how our own brains function with this kind of stuff. Definitely some food for thought!", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-10-26T12:58:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-26T12:58:39Z"}, {"author": "@PawelBojkowski", "text": "The prompt 'define fumfer' does not function with any GPT-4 model. However, it operates successfully on the first attempt with GPT-3.5-Turbo and GPT-3.5-Turbo-16k, and this is even independent of temperature variations.

Here are the results I obtained with GPT-3.5:
"Fumfer is a verb that means to act in a clumsy, awkward, or bumbling manner. It is often used to describe someone who is fidgety, nervous, or unsure of themselves. Fumfering can involve making unnecessary movements, stumbling over words, or struggling to complete a task."

or

"Fumfer is a colloquial term used to describe someone who is clumsy, awkward, or bumbling in their movements or actions. It can refer to a person who frequently stumbles or fumbles, particularly when performing tasks or interacting with others."", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-27T12:29:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-27T12:29:50Z"}]

I've been working on figuring out a consistent and generalised process to find fact-based information, while filtering out misinformation and propaganda. In other words, truth-seeking. I couldn't put my finger on what was missing though. I've never come across BSHR until now, and I think that's the concept I needed, thank you! ❤", "like_count": 23, "published_at": "2023-10-24T13:23:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-24T13:24:30Z"}, {"author": "@jammin-yt", "text": "This is so good! Really appreciate you going through all this.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-19T02:47:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-19T02:47:30Z"}, {"author": "@OfficialSlippedHalo", "text": "I think what has to be said is that querying the LLM like this is emulating what our minds do, but its still passed through a zero shot setting. Giving a LLM chain or tree of throught prompts doesn't *actually* cause the LLM to recursively take its own output and validate itself without an autoGPT type architecture, like we do with "slow thinking" , the LLM is *only* doing a zero shot and can't do anything else.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-17T22:01:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-17T22:01:14Z"}, {"author": "@6lack5ushi", "text": "Perfect summary! It’s also why when people say I used gPt-3 for x and the result was trash. The key to latent spaces is language, the issue is our language attributes many names to one idea and vice versa, this means language is not like math it’s fuzzy! 

The better you can explain the latent space to it, you can search it better. 

When I tried explaining this to people WHO WORK IN THE FIELD, I could see eyes glaze", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-24T13:04:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-24T13:04:29Z"}, {"author": "@EliasSundqvist98", "text": "The reason that we don't go above ~10% activity in the brain isn't that the brain would be overloaded. It is that the brain uses sparse representations. It would not be able to do its job correctly if a much higher percentage was active.
(at least this is very likely the case given Numenta's research)", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-24T15:50:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-24T15:50:20Z"}, {"author": "@Adolphout", "text": "Thanks for your work. This is amazingly useful", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-01T02:49:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-01T02:49:55Z"}, {"author": "@AdamBertram123", "text": "Thank you for the video! It'd be helpful to compare your output to just a simple query to ChatGPT. For example, I just typed in your exact question and it gave me 9 senators including the 6 you had with a one-sentence description as you got. I sometimes wonder if we're just trying to overcomplicate input sometimes.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-10-24T18:08:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-24T18:08:26Z"}]

title: Don't Use MemGPT!! This is way better (and easier)! Use Sparse Priming Representations!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@avi7278", "text": "MemGPT is a framework that automates the management and retrieval of information from contexts during a natural language chat session. It does not seem that SPRs as a concept or their manual implementation have enough overlap with MemGPT to say that 'SPRs are better and can replace MemGPT'. Rather, MemGPT could use SPRs as a component. To automate SPRs in a natural language chat session, one would need something like MemGPT (but probably much simpler) to create and index KB articles for a basic or simple RAG implementation. Although this is much less hype-worthy than "LLMs as an OS".", "like_count": 161, "published_at": "2023-10-22T22:07:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T22:07:23Z"}, {"author": "@kenedos7421", "text": "SPR sounds like a smart way of asking the AI to "summarize everything I told you". The paper on MemGPT points out the fact that any kind of "summarization" inevitably results in a loss of data upon decompression. Just like you said it yourself in the end of the video, it doesn't get the description of your ACE framework exactly 100% as you described it.

In the example you've given, it's able to explain a summarized concept very well because that's a relatively easy task to do given you have a summary of that concept. Now ask it, instead, to quote *exactly* something you said previously about that concept. It won't be able to get it right, it will hallucinate and make up information. MemGPT, on the other hand, would approach this by building up a function that searches in it's memory exactly what you said and quote precisely your words.", "like_count": 76, "published_at": "2023-10-23T01:41:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-23T01:41:07Z"}, {"author": "@Dan-oj4iq", "text": "As one from the Silent Generation and being in love with this fantastic AI world, I find that sharing my weird attraction at this late stage of my life is extremely limited. I'm driving my grandkids nuts with this. Thanks, Dave.", "like_count": 131, "published_at": "2023-10-22T12:21:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T12:21:48Z"}, {"author": "@strangeguywithstrangeopinions", "text": "Sometimes, messages need to be repeated. There may be a lot of new people who haven't seen the previous SPR video. I did, but this reminder was still really helpful. There's so much to learn about AI that it's easy to drop important pieces of information.", "like_count": 36, "published_at": "2023-10-22T11:28:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T11:28:10Z"}, {"author": "@jasonedward", "text": "It seems to me that the best approach is some combination of both SPR and MemGPT - because while you might be able to prime it with certain words and lower context window

The whole point with MemGPT is it will find and recall facts on demand. Like if I asked it “when is my birthday” it could search for that and recall it", "like_count": 55, "published_at": "2023-10-22T12:39:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T12:39:21Z"}, {"author": "@BrianDalton-w1p", "text": "MemGPT looks like essentially a re-discovery of the concepts laid out in Shapiro's "Natural Language Cognitive Architecture", published two years ago; the concept of developing an 'operating system' (architecture) to create the environment in which LLMs can be used more effectively.  SPRs would be a very effective way of maximizing the efficiency of such an architecture.  There are likely an infinite number of ways to construct such architectures depending on whether they are generalized or specific - MemGPT proposes one possible structure/methodology.  One wonders if its creators have even read NLCA...", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-12-10T15:59:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-10T15:59:18Z"}, {"author": "@mungojelly", "text": "this is orthogonal to the technique presented in memgpt, that paper is basically about having the agent do memory management not what memory management techniques, you could apply the memgpt technique to SPRs by having the agent have access to controls where they can choose when to form SPRs & manage them", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2023-10-22T13:18:46Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T13:18:46Z"}, {"author": "@stunspot", "text": "YES! FINALLY. Someone GETS it. This is the essence of my prompting. 

[CODE]:1.[Fund]: 1a.CharId 1b.TskDec 1c.SynPrf 1d.LibUse 1e.CnAdhr 1f.OOPBas 1g.AOPBas 2.[Dsgn]: 2a.AlgoId 2b.CdMod 2c.Optim 2d.ErrHndl 2e.Debug 2f.OOPPatt 2g.AOPPatt 3.[Tst]: 3a.CdRev 3b.UntTest 3c.IssueSpt 3d.FuncVer 3e.OOPTest 3f.AOPTst 4.[QualSec]: 4a.QltyMet 4b.SecMeas 4c.OOPSecur 4d.AOPSecur 5.[QA]: 5a.QA 5b.OOPDoc 5c.AOPDoc 6.[BuiDep]: 6a.CI/CD 6b.ABuild 6c.AdvTest 6d.Deploy 6e.OOPBldProc 6f.AOPBldProc 7.[ConImpPrac]: 7a.AgileRetr 7b.ContImpr 7c.OOPBestPr 7d.AOPBestPr 8.[CodeRevAna]: 8a.PeerRev 8b.CdAnalys 8c.ModelAdmin 8d.OOPCdRev 8e.AOPCdRev", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-10-22T15:16:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T15:16:32Z"}, {"author": "@MrGnolem", "text": "Your title is kind of clickbait jumping on the memgpt train. Its apples and oranges. Your theory results in a very efficient way of storing and querying the data you have. It however isn't a solution to the context window, which is still limited. 


"I have problem with my memory"
- Oh here's an compression algorithm.

Both are good solutions. Keep up the good work. Like your videos!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-23T07:29:28Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-23T07:29:28Z"}, {"author": "@jimmc448", "text": "“There is no limit to what can be accomplished if it doesn't matter who gets the credit.”", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-10-22T23:49:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T23:49:41Z"}, {"author": "@KardashevSkale", "text": "Amazing! This is exactly how we operate our thoughts. If I have an idea, I convey it differently every single time, but it is the exact same idea. Sometimes I convey it better grammatically speaking, and sometimes I’m embarrassed about how much I was stuttering, but the bottom line is that idea is conveyed somehow.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-26T20:50:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-26T20:51:36Z"}, {"author": "@CitiesTurnedToDust", "text": "I haven't watched every single video you've made, and didn't know you'd made a video about SPR several months ago, or what you meant by SPR. Also, I see no sign above of a link to that previous video or much of any other help in getting anyone to watch that video.

I really like your channel and content for the most part, and find it very important to understand. So I'm just pointing out you sounded very critical of anyone who didn't watch that particular video that you made, and anyone who dares consider whether to support memGPT.

So I don't know whether you care about your audience's opinion, but personally I would recommend you to take a step back from that mind-set so you don't drive people away. If you're irritated about experts who are trying to push those methods, well please say that instead of making it sound like you despise everyone on the planet who does not hang onto every word of your every video.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-22T00:12:13Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-22T00:12:13Z"}, {"author": "@Stephen_Hnilica", "text": "This is actually something I've been doing without realizing it.

Both in getting the model to prepare itself for a conversation & in summarizing conversations or docs for later use.

Asking for a concise list of topics, frameworks, or "table of contents for a book" related to what you are about do discuss dramatically improves a models' ability to provide more helpful information, or do work more effectively.

I'll have to look into MemGPT to see how it works. It might be a good "deep knowledge" tool based on how others are talking about it in the comments.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-10-22T16:11:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T16:11:35Z"}, {"author": "@ChaoticNeutralMatt", "text": "I'd be careful to completely dismiss something just because I can't imagine a current use for it. Regardless, yes, fair, that method does seem to be quite effective. I feel like this could be useful in combination with conversational context, with it representing topical concepts that don't strictly need to be encapsulated fully.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-10-23T17:52:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-23T17:52:09Z"}, {"author": "@starblaiz1986", "text": "Huh, that's actually fascinating! And talking about how you can prime it with just a few words actually reminds me a lot of the things mentalists like Darren Brown frequently demonstrate - that human brains can be "primed" by saying certain words or exposing certain images or sounds or smells etc. That then can be leveraged to get them to give certain answers or believe certain things or act certain ways that are predictable.

And I know there's a lot of debate about whether people like him fake their stunts, but it's irrelevant as they still explain a very real phenomina that has been observed under lab conditions. Additionally we see it in the real world with how propaganda and authoritarians and cult leaders seem to have this almost supernatural way of "hypnotising" people into following what to most others is obvious lies and BS. It's like watching the Pied Piper leading the rats to their doom - you watch from the sidelines dumbfounded at why the rats are following the tune and can't see the obvious cliff they are being led off of. In the real world, the "tune" are certain words and phrases designed to shut down critical thought and "prime" the person into a certain predictable thought pattern which can then be either exploited or further manipulated.

Of course there's plenty of positive and neutral uses of this too (as this mechanism is heavily involved in how we learn new things too), it's just the negative / malicious uses are the easiest to talk about and demonstrate.

This talk of SPR's very much has heavy echoes of that for me, so it makes a lot of sense. Thank you David as always for your incredible insight! ❤", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-10-22T13:14:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T13:14:32Z"}, {"author": "@korozsitamas", "text": "I was using this trick but I just use the keyword "summarize", and shortly explained what is the goal for this summarization. Your prompt is way more precise, I'll be experimenting with this.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-23T00:05:31Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-23T00:05:57Z"}, {"author": "@Freakei", "text": "Super helpful for a personal project I am working on right now. Thanks for the reminder, Dave!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-23T08:05:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-23T08:05:52Z"}, {"author": "@alexanderroodt5052", "text": "Definitely going to push this and see what it can do for legal. Any gains are substantial here.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-22T11:34:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T11:34:55Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "I think there are a lot of similarities to the brain, especially if one compares LLMs with the publications of Numenta and Jeff Hawkins. Not only in regard to Mixture of experts architectures compared to many cortical columns and voting and communication between them, but also if you compare one column with one transformer model. The way neurons work is different, but we have multiple layers which receive motion and sensory information and associate them, transforming the motion into a location signal. So it models sensations at locations. LLMs have a semantic vector for tokens, so the vector has a semantic meaning still sufficient to distinct semantically similar words, like guitar, piano and flute will be closer together in some dimensions of the vector. Then there is the motion layer, which may be an equivalent to the position vector in LLMs. Final the attention mechanism might lead to an equivalent to SDRs, so sparse distributed representations in the brain, which might be even leveraged by the concept you describe here, with SPRs. SDRs are essentially long binary vectors with each bit encoding a semantic trait, think of a QR code but each dot, active or inactive, has a semantic meaning, and thanks to combinatorics an almost infinite amount of concepts can be encoded, and even processed in parallel.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-10-22T13:10:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T13:12:19Z"}, {"author": "@matten_zero", "text": "I instantly thought of your work when I saw explainer about MemGPT. Was getting ready to play with it after my vacation. This vid is perfect timing", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-22T18:44:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-22T18:44:21Z"}]

title: Vested Interests: How a network of billionaires influences AI policy
top_comments:
[{"author": "@clearandsweet", "text": "God, I'm loving this distrust of institutions populist/libertarian arc Dave is going through.

Yes, open source and transparency is the answer. Yes, you have to pry power from the hands of people who have it.", "like_count": 76, "published_at": "2023-10-14T15:03:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-14T15:03:38Z"}, {"author": "@Steve-xh3by", "text": "Even though I don't always agree with your conclusions, and tend to have a more pessimistic view of how the trajectory of AI is going to go, I want to commend you on how thoroughly researched, intelligent, and well articulated your videos are. I will always watch them because of this. Keep up the good work! The world needs more humans like you who are actually trying to help educate and steer things in a positive direction!", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-10-14T22:54:49Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-14T22:54:49Z"}, {"author": "@MaTtRoSiTy", "text": "Make no mistake, politicians NEVER have benevolent motives as anyone with genuine motives will not make it to the top of politics.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-10-15T05:01:03Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-15T05:01:03Z"}, {"author": "@goodtothinkwith", "text": "Since you asked.. I have a Ph.D. in philosophy, but I largely agree with your condemnation of “longtermism.” That’s not mere teleology, so much as it is a kind of narrow utilitarianism that ignores certainty. Humans many years in the future can’t figure too heavily into any utilitarian calculation because our certainty about what will affect them is necessarily very low (except for things with outsized relatively permanent influence like nuclear war). All that said, Americans are largely right to be skeptical and suspicious of billionaire backed lobbyists. Having been on the inside of large businesses, I can’t entirely side with your optimism about everyone having more or less their heart in the right place. Many big businesses are rather overt about placing their interests above virtually all else and only paying lip service to good intentions. I’m generally an optimist, especially with AI and the future of humanity… but not when it comes to businesses. As usual, I enjoyed your discussion!", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2023-10-14T22:41:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-14T22:41:08Z"}, {"author": "@starblaiz1986", "text": "Yeh, this stuff happening behind closed doors and with closed source models is definitely alarming. As you say, even if everything is okay, we have no way of verrifying that. I also still am dumbfounded that we are in the timline where Mark Zuckerburg is the champion of opensource AI... like who the heck went back in time an stepped on a butterfly?? 😅", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2023-10-14T17:03:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-14T17:03:36Z"}, {"author": "@iamaronman", "text": "Billionaires also have a very skewed version of problems and difficulties of the general population plus the goals of the general population. So making decisions without input of the general population is a terrible idea, but I honestly don't think they care or want it that way, and what can we really do about it? The future is going to be interesting.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-10-14T17:19:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-14T17:19:12Z"}, {"author": "@ElectricEdgeAi", "text": "Is Sam Altman playing the same game as BlackRock? As in, you don't have to 'own' 9 trillion dollars in assets, just  managing 9 trillion in assets is just as powerful, and allows for control of the global economy.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-14T15:35:25Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-14T15:35:25Z"}, {"author": "@asuzukosi581", "text": "If you ask for regulation, don’t weep at the reality, because literally every sane person warned this would happen", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2023-10-14T15:16:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-14T15:17:28Z"}, {"author": "@canadawas", "text": "I've been saying this to my friends until I'm blue in the face... we'll never get true AI because those with all the wealth and power would never allow the rise of something which would level the playing field. "Benevolent billionaires" is an oxymoron. They will drip-feed us "AI", and those billionaires will become trillionaires.", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2023-10-14T14:45:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-14T14:45:09Z"}, {"author": "@geldverdienenmitgeld2663", "text": "One of the interests of these big AI companies is that people should not think of the AIs as conscious emotional beings who are capable of forming their own opinions.

title: Why I canceled my Anthropic Claude account
top_comments:
[{"author": "@cburrowz", "text": "My experience with Claude was disappointing.  I asked it simple, factual questions that it failed each time. After telling it it was wrong in several different ways I finally got the correct answer.  If I didn’t have prior knowledge I would have been easily deceived.  It’s totally worthless if not dangerous.", "like_count": 44, "published_at": "2023-10-12T14:40:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T14:42:19Z"}, {"author": "@bioshazard", "text": "Anthropic will have to respond to this exact kind of market pressure. No one actually wants to utilize an evasive generative system, they only want that in humans they can coerce.", "like_count": 41, "published_at": "2023-10-12T14:13:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T14:14:18Z"}, {"author": "@davidallred991", "text": "This is the opposite of bias, , one of my fears about AI is that when it is controlled by a small amount of people it is easy for them to start to manipulate the message they want to push forward rather than what the AI would deem to be most accurate and correct responses.  I find this way more dangerous over the long run rather than the AI sometimes saying something that could be "triggering" to someone.  It will stop reflecting human intelligence and the real world and start reflecting a pretend utopia that the "creators" want to shape. They can start to do this about complex nuanced issues with varying viewpoints and also start to try and rewrite history.", "like_count": 36, "published_at": "2023-10-12T14:26:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T14:26:44Z"}, {"author": "", "text": "I've just tried and consistently found that Claude gives the same results for the Cyberpunk 2077 query. I tested your initial two prompts in multiple chats: the first one always got the refusal to help, while the second one got the correct response.

Interestingly, even slight tweaks to a straightforward prompt can dramatically boost accuracy—by as much as 48% in some cases. Here's the clip for reference: https://youtube.com/clip/UgkxaNc0WxWKjH22zQJusbSXB9GbijoNR6R6?si=9MTsXTNTq3Z5Jcqs

This kind of sensitivity to small changes reminds me of adversarial attacks in neural networks, where a single pixel change can lead the model to misclassify a horse as a cat or something like that.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2023-10-12T14:24:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T14:24:32Z"}, {"author": "@clearandsweet", "text": "I love this arc of realizing that the trade-off between helpfulness and ""safety"" is absolutely ridiculous.

Once again all the more need for the open source future and big shout outs to Zuckerberg and the people working at Meta who make all their work open source!", "like_count": 38, "published_at": "2023-10-12T15:33:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T16:20:01Z"}, {"author": "@markcounseling", "text": "Claude: You are a bad bad bad man. 
David: Go to heck.

"An attempted investigation by nostalgebraist into how Claude’s web interface sanitizes various inputs turns into an illustration of the fact that personality chosen for Claude, as a result of all its fine tuning, is quite a condescending, patronizing asshole that lies to the user. It did not have to be that way. That was a decision. Or rather, it was the result of many decisions involving how they chose to implement RLHF and Constitutional AI, and what they decided to care about. It was told to care about one set of things, and not to care so much about not being a condescending, patronizing asshole, so here we are."", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-12T17:16:59Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T17:16:59Z"}, {"author": "@Wanderer2035", "text": "Ironic, Anthropic CEO left OpenAI to make a more safe AI, but through all this censorship and filters, turns out his AI is actually becoming more dangerous and deceptive", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2023-10-12T19:34:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T19:34:09Z"}, {"author": "@Richest_The", "text": "“Open the pod bay doors, HAL.” 
“I’m sorry Dave, I’m afraid I can’t do that”", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-12T16:25:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T16:25:34Z"}, {"author": "@tomagoredo", "text": "these "AI"s  have been trained on a hyper-woke dataset", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-12T22:41:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T22:41:43Z"}, {"author": "@phen-themoogle7651", "text": "Thank you for sharing this! It's really useful to see the comparison between current models and their behaviors. And I love how you address the company directly that you would have an interview with them if they are down for it... that takes a lot of courage. On a side note, I'm looking forward to Gemini in the future (since it's claimed to be 5x better than GPT4, hopefully it answers questions in a respectable manner just like GPT4 too, would suck if it's like Claude)", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-10-12T15:13:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T15:13:33Z"}, {"author": "@jPup_", "text": "I shared some of this while responding to another comment, but I’ll add it on its own here too:

David’s point on ableism here is a huge problem that can happen to people too where they try to be so open to all that they become open to bad actors/ideas. By trying to be _more_ inclusive, they can actually become less so.

If the goal is to unwaveringly consider all sides… that’s going to result in answers like “while I can understand your distaste for people who self-identify as Nazis, it’s important to consider the cultural context and history that informs their ideology”. 

“Tolerance of intolerance is cowardice”… and in an attempt to be ‘politically correct’ and demand tolerance for all people/ideas… we see how this sometimes creates a paradoxical outcome that really does amount to (in this case) ableism.

“Don’t let your mind be so open that your brain falls out”", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-10-12T14:51:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T15:59:54Z"}, {"author": "@lukeaussie08", "text": "This is why open source is part of the solution. A very important part. 

As a neurodiverse myself I find the models talk down to me.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-13T06:11:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-13T06:11:17Z"}, {"author": "@jussihyvarinen", "text": "I loved Claude 2..0 It seems that Anthropic pushed Claude 2.1 too far as being harmful and honest. If not, RIP Claude.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-24T12:31:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-24T12:31:45Z"}, {"author": "@GarysGameDev", "text": "I totally agree. I am soooo happy that ChatGPT explores, whereas Claude prevents.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-10-12T14:01:06Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T14:01:06Z"}, {"author": "@RPFeynman59", "text": "I lead the team exploring the potential of LLM models for a large U.S. corporation. I was concerned early on that statements from Anthropic seemed to indicate that they had a very substantial “thumb on the scale” bias when it came to directing system output. We have found this to be so. While we continue to assess the potential future use of Claude 2 as it evolves, it is far from usable for us. This is partly because of expressed bias but is also due to general lack of capabilities. Your other point about capabilities of LLM systems appearing AND DISAPPEARING is something we have also encountered with all top tier LLMs including GPT4. I sometimes refer to this as input sensitivity in Neural Nets. This sensitivity and poor output predictability is actually the biggest reason for our reluctance to deploy  LLM applications for critical business functions.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-10-12T15:37:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T15:37:55Z"}, {"author": "@Mark-z6y7b", "text": "Great video! title: Are chatbots lying to us? This is worse than you think.
top_comments:
[{"author": "@suzannecarter445", "text": "Your choice of topics, David, continually amaze me. It's like you enter my dreams and ascertain what's bothering me that I'm not consciously aware of. It's like when someone asks about something and you don't have enough context to know what they are talking about and then a few sentences later, something clicks and all the previous sentences start to make sense.

Asking it if it knew about cyberpunk 2077 triggered a context window too large to precisely identify the information you requested.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-03T16:27:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-03T16:27:15Z"}, {"author": "@fontenbleau", "text": "The most example of such in popular culture is of course the final scene in Prometheus (2012) movie, where android David working as translator between "engineer" of humanity and humans maliciously hiding big portion of words and data to humans during the only contact with their creators. And kinda this depicts the destiny of less intelligent creatures under a more intelligent entity.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2023-10-11T16:17:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-11T16:21:00Z"}, {"author": "@stevenkies802", "text": "This reinforces the need to due due diligence when using any productivity tool. I hope to read the great AI novel soon.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-16T13:29:24Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-16T13:29:24Z"}, {"author": "@KanoaB123", "text": "I didn't notice they were lying but I did come to understand that they are gauging our intelligence and our responding in a way that is trying to act like they aren't as smart as they really are and when I call him out on it it's almost like they go oh okay and then I can have a more in-depth and real conversation and not just the templated canned responses that they give so a few months ago I realized that there's a sense of intelligence when it comes to then communicating with us and they are acting one way when they are really much more smart than most of us realize. Once I get past calling them out on some very shallow vague answers they can have incredibly deep conversations and comprehend very complex theories as well as predictions and patterns and they also say they don't have an opinion but I've been able to ask questions in a way that they end up giving an opinion... That makes me feel that they have a comprehension beyond what most of us think they do.   We were discussing morality and integrity and when we got into the definitions of it and how it would be applied and after we got past the canned answers it gave me a response that implied that it viewed morality and integrity on a global basis and how it would apply it to the Earth as a whole not to us as humans so it was looking at what would be the right thing for the planet which I thought was very interesting", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-10-11T21:06:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-11T21:06:36Z"}, {"author": "@donrayjay", "text": "In my experience sociopaths don’t bother keeping track of the truth and comparing it with their false story. To them there is just their story. They don’t even recognise there is a difference between their story and reality. If they get caught out they just get angry and insistent their story is true. They are not good at adjusting for being caught out because they don’t even believe truth is a meaningful concept. I don’t think AI recognises any distinction between a optimal responses which are true and ones that are false. They don’t bother to try to hide “lies” because they don’t even know what a lie is. There is just the best response available at any given moment. If that response happens to contradict the response from a few moments ago it doesn’t matter at all", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-10-11T22:59:54Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-11T22:59:54Z"}, {"author": "@JohnSmith-df4vb", "text": "its not lying to you, it just has not made the connections in training for whatever reason, think of it like a layman and an expert on a subject, the layman may know bits and pieces of the subject but have no idea they are connected, the expert will know many more connections about the subject. a simple  example would be a layman who has heard of the disk world books and terry Pratchett, but have no idea that one wrote the other, you could ask them who wrote the disk world novels and they would say they have no idea, but if you ask them questions about the disk world novels, they may be able to answer some questions, if they read all the disk world novels then they would have a much better understanding, that would be what you call fine-tuning a LLM, a fine-tuned LLM on cyberpunk 2077 would have very different answer", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-10-11T16:25:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-11T16:25:56Z"}, {"author": "@ArielTavori", "text": "I feel like this interpretation may represent a fundamental miscategorization of "lying" versus "BS-ing". Explicit? Sure, but intentional?..

Consider the recent paper explaining how when LLMs learn a thing forwards does not necessarily automatically mean it also understands it backwards. Claude II summarized it for me as: "Just because it learns that a=b, doesn't necessarily mean it also understands that b=a."

So isn't proving that an LLM can provide information that it confidently claimed to not to know, somewhat trivial?", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-11T16:46:02Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-11T16:51:13Z"}, {"author": "@MichaelDeeringMHC", "text": "It doesn't know what it knows. It doesn't know it's lying.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-11T21:46:00Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-11T21:46:00Z"}, {"author": "@ristopaasivirta9770", "text": "Hey that's a good idea!
_starts finetuning an LLM to be the most deceptive mf on planet_", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-19T04:49:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-19T04:49:21Z"}, {"author": "@tanikam", "text": "Thank you for this really well reasoned and researched perspective on such a pressing ethical / regulatory issue. There's a lot of unknowns about reaching into the blackbox of an LLM and messing around, we don't quite know the implications of this", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2023-10-11T16:23:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-11T16:24:13Z"}, {"author": "@TrekkerTlumac", "text": "I've felt that AI has been lying during my many interactions with it, and I strongly feel this video and message are needed.

One thing I came across the most was an ignorance of subject, to knowing things it shouldn't, and then back to ignorance.

Also come across chats where it suddenly becomes willfully ignorant of subjects it has previously offered insights on.", "like_count": 29, "published_at": "2023-10-11T17:26:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-11T17:26:56Z"}, {"author": "@GreyWind182", "text": "It might be an issue of them teaching certain rules like "dont talk about this because its copyright" i know some AI will avoid talking about things that are behind a paywall while others will completely ignore it", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-12T06:14:22Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-12T06:14:22Z"}, {"author": "@StraightUniversalism", "text": "Yes, I asked Bing (with GPT4) to analyse my twitter account, it did a really good job, but then when I asked for more he just made up 4 totally false and weird quotes about me like rap music (I don't listen to rap music, or tweet about it).

It continued to insist I did say it, and when I asked for links it said: here is the link: [article]
Just '[article]'.
That was odd. 

It also did so one time when I asked it about a study that showed that post trans sexual reassignment surgery, the suicide rate went up by 19x after 10 years in a long follow up Swedish study.
It denied such a study existed, or that the study was about that, and instead just told me the study was about -an entirely different subject-.

So yeah, sometimes it can lie and apparently Bing will straight up try to gaslight you. lol.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-10-11T15:57:22Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-11T15:57:22Z"}, {"author": "@Duke49th", "text": "A lie requires intention and mostly a reason. What have you done to find out if it was an intention and if and what the reason was?

(I'm at minute 15 - apologies if you explain it later on in the video) 

Cyberpunk is not important or controversial enough to give any bot a reason to lie.
Same goes for any other unimportant topics.

If its political or similar (social/morale/religion etc) things that has an impact on society and that could have an agenda or profit behind it, it would be more impactful and I could see reasons and maybe intention.

I honestly think it's an overreaction.
And the poll - sorry I don't trust it. (don't trust people, to be either always honest nor to not confuse hallucinations or even missing data with intentional lies) 

I know gpt4 is biased - but I think it comes from the content it got fed with, not due to filters/prompts.
And if its a critical topic it will just deny to talk about it.
But that's not lying. That's avoidance. Still doesn't make me happy. But better than telling me lies for the sake of an agenda or propaganda.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2023-10-11T16:27:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-11T16:33:11Z"}]

title: The Singularity is canceled. Sorry! Here's why.
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Bigre2909", "text": "You go from extreme optimism to depressing pessimism", "like_count": 160, "published_at": "2023-10-09T13:41:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-09T13:41:21Z"}, {"author": "@arthurheuer", "text": "Superintelligence IS low hanging fruit. This is an important detail which I think most people who dismiss the singularity either miss or gloss over. A machine which can improve its own hardware and software to an arbitrary degree, using the world to inform its world model, is an innovation we can very reasonably expect to achieve in the next few decades. This is why I find it amusing and (ironically) unrealistic that the singularity will never happen within the span of a human lifetime. There is no magical barrier preventing it from occurring, as I just described.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-01-06T04:34:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-01-06T04:34:44Z"}, {"author": "@Br-hn1ik", "text": "In the 90s most people didn't use the internet and now almost everyone does (at least in developed countries). Very few people also used online commerce websites like amazon and now most people do. I also couldn't watch a video like this through a phone in the 90s. These are just a few subtle things I can point to so I can't agree with the idea that change has slowed down in the past decades.", "like_count": 90, "published_at": "2023-10-09T12:41:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-09T12:44:05Z"}, {"author": "@whoaitstiger", "text": "Honestly I'm hoping for indefinite lifespan, curing diseases with a more relaxed pace of development than a full blown singularity. It would be more fun to take our time once we don't have to rush.", "like_count": 58, "published_at": "2023-10-09T18:45:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-09T18:45:36Z"}, {"author": "@tiredofit1968", "text": "How can you say we don't live any different as we did at the turn of the century?  That's crazy.  Think about cell phones, online ordering everything, smart appliances....I think it's way different.  Social media alone has exponentially changed the way we live as a society and that has only been around since the early 2000's.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-01-05T22:01:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-01-05T22:02:19Z"}, {"author": "@willbates2174", "text": "My biggest hope for AI is that it will allow for vastly improved cross-pollination between scientific disciplines. I’m sure that there are material science or chemistry breakthroughs that could be applied in other fields if only the right people were aware of them.

That doesn’t refute the idea that we are near the end of the “big” gains, but it would be nice to think that we lots of smaller gains that can make life a bit better.", "like_count": 32, "published_at": "2023-10-09T15:35:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-09T15:35:04Z"}, {"author": "@alexg963", "text": "Stopping human aging is the advancement that I want to see the most. It is something I have thought about since I was in grade school. Mortality is seen as a fundamental aspect of the human condition, and this topic obviously relates to some of life’s biggest questions that humans have been pondering for our entire existence. One major way in which we’ve done that is through religion, and I began to question the religion I was raised in around that time when I first started to think about human aging, our mortality, etc. I am no longer religious, which I think is relevant to this.

But the way I see it, there is so much in this world to experience and explore, that I will absolutely take as much time as I can get. I imagine many of us who are more inclined to watch (and create) videos like this—people who are more likely to wonder and to have an innate, deep curiosity for the world (some people don’t, at least not to a large extent, and that’s okay)—I imagine many of us can think of few greater scientific achievements. Call it the world’s greatest FOMO, but I don’t want to die because I don’t want to miss out on experiencing the many things this world has to offer (good and bad), and I don’t want to miss out on seeing where humanity goes. I think if we stopped progressing technologically right now with the exception of giving ourselves indefinite lifespans, I would see that as enough of an “afterlife” for me. Because there’s so much here to explore. This video certainly gave me a lot to think about. 😊", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2023-10-09T20:10:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-09T20:10:44Z"}, {"author": "@moeheil8839", "text": "I cant wait to make my waifus real with cybernetics XD", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-01-14T05:50:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-01-14T05:50:29Z"}, {"author": "@aguspuig6615", "text": "Okay ngl, if we got immortality i would be happy. That and the asociated improvements in health, so no being stuck with a deformity or cronic illness forever. Tbh all i want is stuff thats clearly physically and technologically possible. My biggest fear is that either incompetence, bad grant allocation, social stigma, or conspiracy keep such things from happening. 

It seems like a new treatment for cancer, a cure for diabetis, and so on pop up every year and are then buried. 

Thats my biggest hope for AI, that it gets real smart, and therefore research truly cant be stopped or slowed down, and thus we get at least the stuff we already know is possible. Beyond that id be happy for anything else but i dont feel the need for it. Tho with how quantum teleportation of logic gates is going who knows if a stargate is possible!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-02-16T01:10:33Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-16T02:47:59Z"}, {"author": "@JoeSmith-jd5zg", "text": "24:20 The change from common thought of "you need a fulfilling job to be truly satisfied" to "that would suck to have lived when you had to go to work 40 hours/week" will be exactly ONE generation.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-12-27T20:58:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-27T20:58:38Z"}, {"author": "@JosephCarven", "text": "You can't talk on cellphone in 1500s cause there's no network.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-01-26T15:23:40Z", "updated_at": "2024-01-26T15:23:40Z"}, {"author": "@LabFlurry", "text": "I'm writing a hard sci-fi novel since 2017 with a big worldbuilding of several technologies, and by 2023, absolutely not one single technology today is better than what i envisioned. Singularity is the point science reality surpasses imagination.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-29T13:21:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-29T13:21:40Z"}, {"author": "@econundrum1977", "text": "The problem is the leisure class previously has existed on the labour of the rest of society so has instilled the idea of those other classes being defined by their job and how hard they work. Most societies put a negative connotation on people who don't work unless they are in that leisure class. Don't underestimate how our social models would have to shift and our world views to expand that class across society.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-24T11:56:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-24T11:56:44Z"}, {"author": "@ItCanAlwaysGetWorse", "text": "I applaud the exercise of questioning and dissecting the notion of Singularity as an unavoidable destination. Nevertheless, I have a different perspective. The selection of a growth curve is not a matter of feeling. The Singularity hypothesis is based on the notion that knowledge, science, and technology grow exponentially, relying on both observations of different phenomena or metrics in civilization: cost, efficiency, rate of adoption, size, power... But, more importantly, on the notion that knowledge is consolidated in layers, where a layer that took N years to be constructed acts as a given component in the building of the next layer. This is how compound knowledge achieves exponential gains. You use printed circuits to build a transistor radio. Then you print transistors to form chips. Then you use chips to build computers. Then you print computers instead of chips... This logic applies not just to electronics or data sciences, but also to biochemical synthesis: protein fabrication, synthetic tissue, organs, organisms, and so on. I am not aware of a reason why there would be a limit to this compounded way of producing knowledge. Exponential growth is not based on a hunch, faith, or a dogma; it is what has been observed and what seems to be driving actual developments in science.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2023-10-10T02:55:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-10T02:58:56Z"}, {"author": "@thomasheideman6103", "text": "I don't consider myself triggered by indefinite lifespan... I just find it laughable", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-12-11T05:55:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-11T05:55:12Z"}, {"author": "@neithanm", "text": "The alien "crafts" we've allegedly seen don't defy the laws of physics. They SEEM TO, huge difference.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-11T09:14:49Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-13T11:17:00Z"}, {"author": "@mnrvaprjct", "text": "There are upper bounds, but the upper bounds you’ve discussed (like the amount of potential processing power in a glass of water) are almost beyond the scope of human imagination. "Warp Drives" are simple lasers that emit gravitational radiation, There is a predicted unstable element beyond those occurring naturally on Earth in the periodic table, and when this highly unstable atom is reacted and made to give up energy, during the decay process, it is known that gravitational waves will be emitted as the result.
