title: I built a thinking machine. Happy birthday, ACE!
top_comments: [{"author": "@ct5471", "text": "Within each layer, is it planned to have various expert models like a mixture of experts system or one big generalist model? In the brain we have 150000 cortical columns which all specialize for domains of expertise in a self-organized manner, with overlapping domains of expertise but not every module/ model knows everything. It might be that a hierarchical structure such as ACE might also emerge as a consequence of self-organization. The long term question is whether a bunch of parallel running smaller specialist models like fine tuned llama 2 models or such like, that identify whether they have something of value to add, e.g. based on self consistency, participate in each conversation loop and only learn if information is new and touches their respective domains of expertise. So essentially smaller modules that specialize, also in continuous learning, in a self organized fashion, similar to cortical columns, instead on relying on big models like GPT4 that are much more expensive if you want to have periodic fine tuning in order to let them learn continuously. With a lot of parallel smaller models one could distribute available compute power better over time, also in continuous fine tuning. If that way an equivalent in performance to large models could be achieved, yet at significantly lower compute costs, it would also mean that AGI could be achieved by smaller groups or even individuals in the near term, rather then by large organizations like OpenAI or google, as it might strongly reduce the compute effort. There might be even autonomous sharing platforms for specialist agents similar to hugging face where each AI framework could dynamically pull, upload or synchronize modules when needed, allowing individuals to participate in AGI via model sharing. In terms of hardware utilization or even ASICs such an approach would also be easy to as the modules could run highly parallel.", "like_count": 67, "published_at": "2023-10-08T13:45:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-08T14:32:03Z"}, {"author": "@brendendavis9839", "text": "great work, this has been one of my favorite channels for a good while now. this research is endlessly fascinating and (obviously) very important!", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2023-10-08T15:11:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-08T15:11:23Z"}, {"author": "@bgtyhnmju7", "text": "Interesting  ( to me ) is that we can strive for more alignment with your ACE model. Each layer working towards that in some way, and self correction. But what is more interesting is the idea that though we can't \"see\" into the neural net, or the trained model, here with ACE we can see all the thoughts flowing back and forth, and have a very clear view of what it's thinking. And, I think OpenAI and probably others do this, it would be easy (ish) to tap into these message busses, or logs, and monitor the content from the outside, without interrupting the ACE mind or it's thinking. So, we have transparency, not of the deep neural net, but of the \"conscious\" layers. Anyways, cool, good video. I look forward to more.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-10-08T16:53:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-08T16:53:42Z"}, {"author": "@TheMajesticSeaPancake", "text": "Thank you so much for putting all this together, you've done a great job of putting your money where your mouth is by making so many of these things public and open development, I cannot thank you enough for doing your part in all this.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-10-08T23:31:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-08T23:31:37Z"}, {"author": "@SinfuLeeCerebral", "text": "Thanks for the update! 00:12 🛠️ Dave introduces a tool he built called 'weekly_archive' to keep up with research.

00:56 📑 The output is a searchable markdown document listing titles, authors, and summaries of papers.
01:23 🚗 Dave uses the tool to find latest research on Large Language Models (LLMs) in autonomous driving.

02:44 📊 Dave uses a secondary tool, Claude, to analyze trends in the papers he's downloaded.

05:17 💻 Walkthrough of how the Python script works, including URL encoding for search queries.
05:58 🔄 The tool is designed to keep up with the fast-moving world of Large Language Models.

But even if they just get this working for people with paralysis it will still be very useful.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2023-10-04T13:21:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T13:21:08Z"}, {"author": "@tachyonbeats", "text": "I think an important component of these mind interface technologies is heat dissipation. Any increase in speed, bandwidth, storage, processing, etc will
Come with a price tag. The cost is heat which will be increased. The brain is especially sensitive to increased temperature so practical heat dissipation will have to incorporated into the system. 

In Alastair Reynold’s Redemption

Problem by giving characters a “radiator” fin crest on top of their skulls.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-10-04T19:47:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T19:47:38Z"}, {"author": "@nosult3220", "text": "He's just a man. I believe the crit is valid. But let's not act like he's like the other billionaires. He's actually doing shit.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-04T22:41:46Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T22:41:46Z"}, {"author": "@domenicobarillari2046", "text": "This whole discourse on bandwidth is likely based on a severe category error: why would anyone assume that the vast amount of parallel signal propagation in the brain represents a commensurate amount of information about anything on the epistemic level we all live on as conscious entities. Every generation has gone through some stage of metaphor about the brain - from fluids pressing in tubes ( Descarte's time), to telephone networks, to computers ( universal or otherwise), etc., and we may be making the same severe mistake when speaking of bandwidth of something. There is ample neurophysiological evidence that a conscious human - say crippled by  stroke effects - can back influence neural paths to achieve a re-routing of some desire impulse, but this is at best getting the cart before the horse. The only "spectacular result" is things like monkeys occassionaly trained to ask for food pellets by "thought".  This marks not some lack of progress or effort, but chasing a wrong goal. What do "information" do people expect they will extract faster from the brain by some clumsy electromechanical contacts than certain correlates of a thinking process happening in a much larger context? 

If the Neurolink makes progress in implant science, all fine and good, but E Musk's flights of fancy here will likely remain that, as bad ideas borrowed from SciFi mode thinking.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-04T16:32:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T16:32:33Z"}, {"author": "@leonardo2108", "text": "I love your content, keep up the work!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-04T17:17:59Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T17:17:59Z"}, {"author": "@mnrvaprjct", "text": "I have an idea involving HOX genes that would allow you to just “grow” the neural lace rather than having invasive surgery.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-10-04T15:30:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T15:30:52Z"}, {"author": "@MrQuaidReactor", "text": "I'm looking forward to this type of research, hopefully be able to help those who paralyzed, deaf and blind. Then later down the line, some neat cybernetics.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-04T18:54:28Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T18:54:28Z"}, {"author": "@EscapedSapiens", "text": "Another awesome video David :) - Keep up the great work!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-10-04T13:38:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T13:38:48Z"}, {"author": "@siquod", "text": "I've always understood it this way: Not that humans try to be useful to their future machine overlords, but that humans remain in control by making machine learning systems serve as modules in their vastly expanded but still somehow human minds.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-20T03:21:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-20T03:21:11Z"}, {"author": "@doctorartin", "text": "I agree. Even if the immunological, material and bandwidth issues were resolved it would take at least 7 years to demonstrate safety so by that time I think other avenues augmented by current emerging cognitive architectures will have proven more useful.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-05T20:49:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-05T20:49:38Z"}, {"author": "@georgeflitzer7160", "text": "The road to hell is paved w good intentions!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-04T14:39:40Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T14:39:40Z"}, {"author": "@TheREAL.BrandOnShow", "text": "Great Video David! Looking Good!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-04T13:40:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T13:40:23Z"}, {"author": "@angloland4539", "text": "You're among the best 💖", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-04T19:25:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T19:25:27Z"}]

Very much appreciate it!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-03T12:50:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-03T12:50:07Z"}, {"author": "@CostaReall", "text": "This is going to be a good one", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-03T10:02:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-03T10:02:45Z"}, {"author": "@OnigoroshiZero", "text": "I used GPT-4 to make it write Instructions for itself being a GM running text-based adventures, and to follow specific rules (provided in specific json files that it was made to ask at the start of a new session), and it did wonders.

The one thing I want now is for the token size to increase to 50-100k, because I have prepared an entire campaign setting (world, races, factions, lore, etc.) and TTRPG rules (simplified from the game I design currently) to follow for interactions and combat. But these files alone are around 20k tokens currently... And hopefully a completely uncensored version for at least the Plus, because it stops a lot of times with even the slightest NSFW hints (can't even kiss the beautiful Elf I saved from a Wyvern some times) or extreme violence.
The good thing is that I made a good framework for it to create a summary file which gets updated after every output, and keeps track of everything from choices, to locations visited, and NPCs met (the important/named ones). Even current goals/quests, locations, and time. Also, it can read the summary file on a new session and continue from there with great accuracy.

edit: Trying things like this is fun in itself, let alone the things you can do with it afterwards. I can't wait for GPT-5 or GPT-6 which will probably be able to emulate entire games (no need to create the logic when an intelligent machine can generate the image and audio based on your keyboard+mouse outputs with only the knowledge of the genre and the general rules/mechanics you would like it to have). 
And I don't care that it will take my job (game designer/developer), because I'll do even more of the fun things I like with it, which are currently impossible for me.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-03T20:06:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-03T23:35:03Z"}, {"author": "@TheVitkuz", "text": "This video is gold. Thanks for teaching", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-04T16:10:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T16:10:19Z"}, {"author": "@fabriai", "text": "David, your videos always come at the right time. Thanks a lot for sharing this. Great content, as always.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-03T18:58:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-03T18:58:33Z"}, {"author": "@wendten2", "text": "Very great content David. However:

20:32 I'm ambivalent about the assertion that providing excessive information is advantageous. I employ a hybrid of GPT-4 and GPT-3.5 to generate NPCs. These AI models need to process a large volume of data to produce realistic and engaging interactions. However, inundating the models with too much information often results in inaccurate or muddled outputs. For instance, if two individuals, John and Joe, are involved in a scenario and Joe is specifically characterized as wearing a black hat, a less focused data input may cause the model to incorrectly attribute the black hat to John instead of Joe. To circumvent issues like these, and to also mitigate the 'Lost Middle Phenomenon,' where crucial details get lost or misinterpreted, I strategically try to limit and place complex relational information at either the beginning or the end of the data input. Meanwhile, more routine or mundane character-specific details are either left out or inserted in the middle of the data feed.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-10-03T11:46:47Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-03T11:46:47Z"}, {"author": "@akkitty22", "text": "Why accept first response ? Run your result through again to get rid of wordiness. "Revise and shorten in tactful silicon valley start up tone". I find a few more runs of the email gets me to a succint and appropriate modern email that remains respectful and neccessary.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-05T23:16:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-05T23:16:21Z"}, {"author": "@fR33Sky", "text": "I was hoping you'd show the "prompt master" prompt!

I thought I was being smart by following your meta-prompting advice, where I kinda created the prompt for the prompt engineering chat -- and then asked it to create a better prompt for the prompt engineering chat. 
But it never actually gave me any formatting in those! 

I think I'll expand on your system prompt writer so it'll remember all the possible hashtag-sections for me. In other words, thank you", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-03T15:47:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-03T15:47:45Z"}, {"author": "@djannias", "text": "🎯 Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

00:00 📝 The video discusses using the Chat GPT API and custom instructions for various tasks.
02:32 🚀 Providing a clear mission or goal to Chat GPT helps improve its performance in completing tasks.
07:14 📨 You can use out-of-band processes and placeholder tags to inject information into the conversation with Chat GPT.
08:11 ✉️ Interaction schema can be used to describe the expected interaction with Chat GPT, which is particularly useful for automation.
15:15 📚 Structuring prompts with context, rules, instructions, expected input, output format, and example output can lead to consistent and effective results.
21:14 📊An example prompt for creating slide decks showcases a clear mission, input variation handling, output format, and example output to achieve consistent results.
22:51 🧠 Prompt engineering involves crafting effective prompts to guide large language models, maximizing their utility.
23:30 💡 Key principles in prompt engineering include English proficiency and ordered thinking.
24:51 ✏️ Clear definition of desired output and examples help AI models generate content accurately.
25:15 🤖 AI models can infer desired content based on clear instructions and mission, even from questions.
26:00 📊 Latent understanding enables AI to produce relevant content when provided with specific instructions.
26:45 ⚡ The duck curve represents fluctuations in energy production and demand throughout the day.
27:00 🌟 The speaker has a repository with resources on prompt engineering and AI-related topics.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-10-03T15:23:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-03T15:23:31Z"}, {"author": "@m3vm3", "text": "With the free version of ChatGPT I often have to remind it of the goals, and re-submit the source text of the discussion.

title: Should you go to college in the age of AI?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "I see this opinion is somewhat controversial and triggering to some people. Please make sure you review the community guidelines before commenting.", "like_count": 56, "published_at": "2023-09-28T13:35:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T13:35:12Z"}, {"author": "@pauldannelachica2388", "text": "I melted my brain during 5 years in college to memorize law just to now that AI will just give the right answer for your problems in court. Simplify analyze the rules and LAWS. Some college institutions are outdated they don't implement Ai and human being teaming", "like_count": 62, "published_at": "2023-09-28T13:40:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T13:50:45Z"}, {"author": "@VectorAlphaSec", "text": "I say NO. There is no need for college/ university anymore. By the time they graduate in 4 years by 2027/ 2028. The world will be a completely different place that you do not want to go into debt into. Use this time instead to do something else.", "like_count": 38, "published_at": "2023-09-28T14:35:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T14:35:33Z"}, {"author": "@chrisdunntv", "text": "This is the first compelling reason I've heard for college in a long time. Thanks man!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-11-11T01:36:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-11T01:36:15Z"}, {"author": "@MystifulHD", "text": "Maybe universities will one day be a place to explore intellectual freedoms rather than a factory for workers!", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2023-10-26T06:58:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-26T06:58:43Z"}, {"author": "@MichaelDeeringMHC", "text": "Wait until university is free, then go.", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2023-09-28T13:59:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T13:59:15Z"}, {"author": "@youdontneedmyrealname", "text": "I'm not going to spend over $80,000 just to learn how to be a 'team player' when I can acquire that skill in a workplace. Practical experience often outweighs university education in job selection criteria, provided you can demonstrate the same level of expertise through previous jobs or projects that you've worked on yourself.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2023-10-23T09:25:24Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-23T09:25:24Z"}, {"author": "@danielrodio9", "text": "Completing a master’s degree mainly teaches us how much we still have to learn, even in the specific field of our thesis", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-10-07T14:12:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-07T14:19:23Z"}, {"author": "@chuckandmax7313", "text": "I'm 62 and I have gone back to college working on my bachelors degree in game art, I feel a little bit nervous that AI will have advanced so much in 3d animation that I will be replaced, but I'm learning about how to use AI tools so I can be up to date and use it as part of my tool box, I really just want my degree and I plan on being a freelance artist working from my home office hopefully getting a game designer job where I can work remotely, I feel that I can work another 30 years and retire when I'm 90. Hopefully AI will have created some age reversal medications so I can live that long.", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2023-09-28T14:23:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T14:23:23Z"}, {"author": "@laudermarauder", "text": "In a post-labour AI-driven utopia, everyone will be able to enjoy a lifelong tailor-made multidisciplinary university experience anywhere they want, for as long as they want, with as many or as few exams as they want, with as much or as little social interaction and extracurricular activity as they want, with zero gatekeeping and at near-zero cost. But high-school graduates are faced today with the dilemma of whether to incur massive debt to attend university as it exists today, with its cripplingly high costs, entry criteria, toxic campus politics, highly variable course quality, etc. My takeaway from this video is that maybe young folk today should wait five years until the Great Disruption up-ends everything, and then see how the land lies after that.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2023-09-28T15:04:02Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T15:04:02Z"}, {"author": "@morososaas3397", "text": "I self learned to code for 3 years and after I was "done" meaning I understood the fundamentals of programming and wrote couple junior level programs and all that, I could literally feel like I was different person after that. The way I approached problems, the way I thought in general was completely different. I don't think you need a college for it, but I understand that studying alone can be very hard for some people or even impossible withouth the deadlines and such.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2023-09-28T19:45:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T19:45:23Z"}, {"author": "@strangeguywithstrangeopinions", "text": "All fantastic points. On the point about tutoring: ChatGPT and other LLMs are cheap, easy tutors for almost any subject if you don't have a human readily available to ask. I recently became interested in the history of the Catholic church due to its impact on medieval history (and thus the modern day), and ChatGPT was a *fantastic* tool for asking about events, people, and concepts that I was learning about to get more context.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2023-09-28T13:39:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T13:40:40Z"}, {"author": "@user43643", "text": "I have wasted my 4 years of college,now the course i studied doesn't even exist,lol!!!", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2023-09-28T13:03:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T13:03:12Z"}, {"author": "@onetruekeeper", "text": "Study something in college that you are interested in and don't worry about getting a job. There are lots of jobs that A.I. cannot ever do as well as humans.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-09-30T03:05:00Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-30T03:05:00Z"}, {"author": "@LawrenceMancini-ge4so", "text": "I am a college freshman studying computer engineering at my state university, all the things I do in class right now gpt 3.5 turbo can do, usually on the first try. I feel like I am working hard to be good at a specialty when ai will most likely have replaced my job before I graduate. All I can hope for is diminishing returns. -an apprehensive scholar", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2023-09-28T13:26:25Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T13:26:25Z"}, {"author": "@blitzer658", "text": "man
you know how in life the "stars align" both in your personal life and the universe at large?
being interested in systems thinking lead me to your videos which lead me to discover your ai work and man it has been a tremendously helpful resource
it feels exiting being at the right place at the right time 
thank you for all your work!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-09-28T18:36:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T18:36:55Z"}, {"author": "@_benstr", "text": "Amazing perspective! I've seen the patterns leading to a post-labor society for a while now, but have lacked the ability to distill and articulate this perspective to my children. Thank you for structuring and sharing. More people need to contemplate this wisdom.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-02-08T14:43:37Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-08T14:43:37Z"}, {"author": "@revnoieniaopv", "text": "You’re putting the cart before the horse. More conformist and cooperative members of society tend to go to college, it’s not college making them more conformist and cooperative", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-01T01:14:25Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-01T01:14:25Z"}, {"author": "@typicaleight099", "text": "I think that everyone should be higher educated as we can all contribute to our collective future, now if that should be done through college is debatable given its unproportional cost, but we can learn through many ways", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2023-09-28T13:02:25Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-28T13:02:25Z"}, {"author": "@needlesandsonics5819", "text": "I love how people think UBI will be their saviors. They must be really poor people because if they think that UBI will provide a living wage they are sadly mistaken. Lucky if it’s 1200$ a month considering you can’t just pull money out of your ass.

Secondly, human labor will always be needed in one form or another. I guess those humans have to make more than UBI or why work at all?

Humans need a purpose and reason to succeed and live. Work covers that. If you do nothing but what you enjoy today on your spare time, how long can you enjoy that especially when you are broke? Too much of anything is a bad thing. You enjoy your hobbies because they come in small doses which gives you anticipation and excitement to do them. How would it be if it was always available? How many paintings can you paint before it’s just not fun anymore? And you’d have to give them away because no one could afford them.

How many walks in nature are fun until it’s just the same old walk every day?", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-10-08T19:45:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-08T19:45:14Z"}]

title: ACE Paper is Published! Repo tour! Get involved!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@dhrumil5977", "text": "Yoo is anyone interested in a team? Willing to join one", "like_count": 47, "published_at": "2023-09-20T11:54:16Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-20T11:54:16Z"}, {"author": "@SDGwynn", "text": "Hey Buddy. Exciting. Everyone else, from Claude 2, TLDR: Overall, this paper proposes an intriguing conceptual framework for architecting autonomous cognitive agents aligned with ethical principles. Here are some key points on the ACE model:

- It consists of 6 hierarchical layers, spanning from abstract moral reasoning (Aspirational Layer) to concrete action execution (Task Prosecution Layer). Each layer handles specialized functions.

- The upper layers focus on setting the agent's overarching direction based on universal ethical principles and mission statements. The lower layers deal with dynamic task management, planning, and execution. 

- Bidirectional information flow allows oversight from the Aspirational Layer while enabling learning from experience propagating upwards. This facilitates both top-down control and bottom-up adaptation.

- The layered encapsulation provides privilege separation, enhancing interpretability, security and corrigibility. The strict hierarchy prevents lower-level processes from overriding higher moral reasoning.

- It aims to combine the strengths of goal-directed teleological ethics and rule-based deontological ethics using both principles and metrics for guidance.

- The integration of large language models enables representing components like ethical frameworks in natural language for human interpretability.

Some open questions after reading:

- How exactly will the layers be implemented computationally? The paper provides a high-level conceptual view but implementation details are light.

- What specific techniques will be used for tasks like moral reasoning, planning, skill learning and cognitive control? The design space seems large.

- How will the framework actually ensure beneficial behavior alignment in complex real-world situations? More rigorous testing methodology needs to be developed.

- How will conflicts between principles and mission goals be resolved? It's unclear how discrepancies will be arbitrated.

Overall it provides an interesting high-level framework as a starting point. But many concrete research and engineering challenges remain to realize the envisioned autonomous capabilities. Let me know your thoughts on the ACE model!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-09-21T02:15:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-21T02:15:10Z"}, {"author": "@TheJanny", "text": "Congratulations! Collecting all the pieces and breaking them down for us :)", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-17T02:14:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-17T02:14:49Z"}, {"author": "@Ch3ckman", "text": "I like the uniform and enjoy your videos. Thanks", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-01-02T21:52:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-01-02T21:52:35Z"}, {"author": "@stan9682", "text": "Hi David, as always, thanks for the insightful videos. Your videos, together with some other creators, are a very good way of staying up to date in the field, especially on a meta level, even as an AI dev myself. I wanted to comment on one thing, a minor thing, which is the name OpenAI. Back in 2018, I applied for a position at OpenAI, when it still was closer to its "roots" (which was denied because they only accepted US residents and didn't want to guarantee a position before me potentially moving abroad). However, online I often hear the argument that OpenAI is a misnomer, because they aren't open-source of non-profit anymore. As far as I know (and I've been following the organisation/company for a while), the "open" in OpenAI was never referring to open-sourcing, it was about the democratization of the benefits of AI developments. Even though I agree that OpenAI took some dubious decisions in this respect, and even though I also believe that open-sourcing of their methodology and weights would amount to a better degree of democratization, the argument that OpenAI is a misnomer, is flawed. Not open-sourcing the models and not being non-profit doesn't necessarily and automatically mean they are failing at their task of democratization. They set out to democratize the effects of AI developments to the people, not necessarily to democratize the technology itself. One of the ways they're arguing they're still working on that, is their research into UBI and Sam's (somewhat awkward) attempt of using blockchain technology for this.

Again, I agree that the path OpenAI is on, feels a bit counterintuitive at times, I just wanted to point out that the focus on their name is not only unwarranted, it can also be distracting of the real conversation we need to have on the position of tech giants in this field. It's a minor thing, close to nitpicking, I know, and not necessarily something I think we disagree on, because we're both proponents of democratization and open-sourcing of AI technology. Simply said: if we focus on the name and use that to argue the fact that OpenAI is diverging from their goal, they can very easily disprove that by providing us with their own definition of "open" in their name.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-09-17T10:04:31Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-17T10:04:31Z"}]

title: What is the Fourth Industrial Revolution?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@krox477", "text": "I'm so glad to be part of this.4th and last revolution of humanity", "like_count": 70, "published_at": "2023-09-08T14:24:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T14:24:31Z"}, {"author": "@patrickjreid", "text": "I can't even begin to tell you how much I love that you do these videos with the Star Trek shirt! Happy Star Trek day!", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-09-08T16:21:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T16:21:41Z"}, {"author": "@mullahoo", "text": "Any video that gets me to stand up the second it ends and instantly start writing on my whiteboard is a banger, and this fit the bill-- keep cranking these out, good job Dave! 🤠", "like_count": 23, "published_at": "2023-09-08T16:05:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T16:05:43Z"}, {"author": "@alexandera2509", "text": "This is really interesting to watch. I know that when I was in school, just in a low level, tradesmen school, my teacher talked about the 4th industrial revolution in terms of what he knew.  It was fully about PLC's, and integration with computers into the industrial process, using controllers in conjunction with robotics to accomplish tasks. Not so much with highly advanced items like are discussed in this video, but purely the marriage of regular industrial processes,  with computer control.

Of course, this is from the mouth of a man who started his career by installing the first electrical power into factories, well houses, grain towers and the like, in remote post-war agriculutral area's in the US.  He saw PLC's as still a developing / growing field that was only just getting more and more integrated, using what he saw as a really 'dumb' system, integrating with the 'smart' system of databses and computer information that the people in office buildings are familiar with.  

It's really cool, seeing someone with more of an IT, and futurist background talking about the 4th industrial revolution, and its requirements!", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2023-09-08T14:27:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T14:27:03Z"}, {"author": "@ntippy", "text": "As a 30 year software engineer I am planning for a "near" future where we write almost everything in Rust for both front and back end.  None of that Rust will be written by humans however.  We need to take declarative programming to the next natural level.  Tell the AI what you want done not how to do it.  We can then iterate on the 'what' as we search out the best solutions.  The idea is like one of a movie producer or director.  We yell action and cut while telling the AI players where to stand and how to act until we are satisfied with the output.", "like_count": 39, "published_at": "2023-09-08T16:08:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T16:08:04Z"}, {"author": "@FrankTYoung", "text": "Most intriguing is the role that language, symbols, communication has played in each of these periods. Things that facilitate the spread, sharing and curation of human knowledge have given rise to major advances. AI and LLMs will be viewed by historians as a major breakthrough enabling the 4th Industrial Revolution.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-09-20T15:43:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-20T15:43:39Z"}, {"author": "@gerardolopez9368", "text": "Very well informative presentation.   You nailed history with all mentions of each generations build off the other 🎖️🎖️🏅", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-13T20:51:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-13T20:51:15Z"}, {"author": "@Snicklink", "text": "Dude. LOVE your takes. Best from germany! 🔥", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-09-08T21:38:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T21:38:23Z"}, {"author": "@laptopuser5198", "text": "I'm ready to lean into the 4IR.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-09-09T18:19:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-09T18:19:34Z"}, {"author": "@Definesleepalt", "text": "what a time to be alive !", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-09-09T00:13:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-09T00:13:04Z"}, {"author": "@rileybrownai", "text": "I wish you we're my teacher for all subjects growing up", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-09-08T14:59:40Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T14:59:40Z"}, {"author": "@K.F-R", "text": "Right there with you.  Thanks for sharing these thoughts.  Exciting times.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-08T19:12:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T19:12:00Z"}, {"author": "@Womagical", "text": "Great video", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-05T06:55:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-05T06:55:01Z"}, {"author": "@DD-jt4yn", "text": "Great introductory presentation about the 4th Industrial Revolution. Exciting and congratulations to the brand new name to the channel! Looking forward to upcoming presentations.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-10T00:39:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-10T00:39:57Z"}, {"author": "@koljaehmling4534", "text": "I would add solar wind and battery, as their combination completely decentralizes electrical power, which in turn has huge impact on political power. Add nanotech, new materials and 3D printing compounds on decentralization.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-09-08T14:49:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T14:49:11Z"}, {"author": "@pyramidal_fever", "text": "Exciting times ahead, great coverage! Indeed, I have been pondering about the tremendous implications of an AI with sufficient symbolic cognitive power in science (not there yet and no LLMs, as a computational neuroscientists I am biased towards spiking networks). 

In a nutshell, I am talking about the ability to model progressively larger computational structures (that is: natural phenomena and their surrounding environments through the lens of computations, eg car traffic, physical systems, chemical processes, medical conditions, ...) with higher accuracy and possibly agency (that is: being able to adequately manipulate and act) will drastically impact the very foundations of our civilization. The capacity of translating any natural phenomena of every domain into valid computational formalisms, such as sufficiently powerful languages (theory of automata) or mathematical spaces (algebraic topology, category theory, ...), will expand the horizons of our understanding to unimaginable regions. Imagine being able to access the rules behind any conceivable system, from politics to economics, from ecology to obscure mathematical conjectures. 


The danger I feel under-appreciated are here mainly three. 1) our brain is structurally 200'000 years old, same cognitive power as back then, meaning that our understanding of stuff is limited and thus the language through which the AI will deliver the knowledge it has produced will have to be limited as well and information will be lost, the AI will always have an advantage (unless: transhumans). 2) whatever society will emerge (through a lot of blood I presume) will have to deal with our psychological needs bounded to our old brain; this will not be easy to deal with at all in terms of individual political relevance, power structures, familiar dynamics, etc. You covered these aspects quite well though. 3) effectively applying computational understanding to domains like ideology, history and culture (dont ask me how, that's the AI's job) will shake the very bones of society, we will reach frightening levels of collective self-awareness (ego death? type-2 civilization? collective madness?).", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-09-08T16:15:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T16:15:37Z"}, {"author": "@klaustrussel", "text": "So glad I discovered your channel at the beginning of this year. Always good content and insights.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-09-08T17:50:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T17:50:44Z"}, {"author": "@SUPERFunStick", "text": "Thanks for teaching us so much every day, Captain.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-09T09:43:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-09T09:43:27Z"}, {"author": "@georgeflitzer7160", "text": "Ty very much!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-08T17:32:16Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-08T17:32:16Z"}, {"author": "@Ken00001010", "text": "When projecting re nuclear fusion (NF), it is important to distinguish between being able to do it at all, and being able to use it as an economical source of grid energy. Wind, solar, wave and geothermal are all practically unlimited sources with zero fuel cost. The problem is that the capital cost of putting in a NF power plant has to beat the capital cost of equivalent output renewables. Even if someone is successful demonstrating NF in the next decade, it will be some time before that capital cost can get lower than renewables that are currently dropping in cost every year. I predict that NF will make great spaceship engines because, there, cost does not matter and fuel mass is critical, but back on Earth, cost is going to set the pace of deployment.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-09T19:59:13Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-09T19:59:13Z"}]

I'm a huge follower of your videos, and I've been having a little trouble catching up because of length, so I mostly watch them on weekends. But this format allows me to watch them within the week.
GOOD JOB. Thank you.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2023-09-07T13:25:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-07T13:25:18Z"}, {"author": "@ArtRebel007", "text": "The problem with getting Government to change on this point is that it defies the economic reality for the Government to do so.  It puts the Government in an untenable position, and the incentives simply do not work for it in the current paradigm.  For example, money is used to buy votes via the expenditures on advertising in democracy-based governments.  When that money pools into fewer hands, and the ordinary (ex-middle class, now poor) citizens have no money to spend on products, let alone political campaigns, then all the political incentives align towards those who do have that money, meaning the tiny handful of CEOs whose businesses skyrocket into international monopoly powers over time as the economic consolidation process takes place.  Telling the Government not to align with the most productive (streamlined & profitable) businesses and negotiate on behalf of the now disenfranchised citizens (who we can see living in absolute squalor by the tens of thousands in all major US cities now) is not necessarily realistic.   These are issues that were supposed to be thought through, btw, ten or twenty years ago and planned for.  The planning might have resulted in any number of global solutions to the advent of extreme-automation, including, possibly, a rational and well functioning UBI system, or the curtailment of certain technologies in order to slow down, or eliminate the disenfranchisement process.  I know this issue was discussed in the comments section of MIT Technology Review Magazine a number of times between 2006 and 2009, and those who pointed out the inevitable conclusions (where we are now) were at the time summarily pooh-poohed by those who couldn't imagine it would take less than 100 years to get here.  Others, more insightfully, saw ahead, and realized that planning would absolutely be required to manage this transition, but that planning failed to happen.  We lurched forward, instead, towards chaos.  Which is where we are heading now, and are already beginning to see the effects all around us.   These effects are not exclusively caused by automation, but automation is a fast-growing (exponentially) factor that must be taken into account, as you point out.  What the solution is may be at this point significantly harder to derive than it would have been 20 years ago.  I do not see anyone in positions of power currently so much as attempting to deal with the issue.  Everyone instead is focused on partisan bickering.  Meanwhile, we are seeing civilization being strained to the point of collapse.  Those who would like to see the collapse averted ought to pool resources, and begin to look far beyond partisan politics to seek solutions.  Otherwise, one has every right to be frightened out of their wits by what is coming.  Our political leadership has failed us for 20 some-odd years and the consequences are becoming ever more evident.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-09-07T16:05:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-07T16:08:05Z"}, {"author": "@vagrant1943", "text": "Everything has happened as you predicted Lord Vader.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-09-07T13:42:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-07T13:42:41Z"}, {"author": "@enhancedutility266", "text": "Great explanation and thanks for keeping me ahead of the situation", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-09-07T17:20:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-07T17:20:07Z"}, {"author": "@TheRoman4373", "text": "You cannot stop progress and technology. It has helped me a lot.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-11-14T06:14:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-14T06:15:08Z"}, {"author": "@caseyhoward8261", "text": "P.s. This amazing video of yours just allowed me to create the following tools/prompts! Thank you!! ❤️ 

### 📚 **Comprehensive Software Development Prompt Library for Machine Learning and Chatbots**

---

#### 🎨 **Designing the Pipeline**

1. "Outline the data collection strategy for this machine learning project."
2. "List the data sources that can be used for training the chatbot."
3. "Summarize the steps involved in data preprocessing for NLP models."
4. "Evaluate the ethical considerations in data preprocessing."
5. "Compare different machine learning models suitable for chatbots."
6. "Distill the core principles of selecting an ML model for this project."

---

#### 📈 **High-Level Developer Sequence**

1. "Draft a project plan based on these objectives."
2. "Brainstorm ideas for feature sets in the chatbot."
3. "Analyze the resource requirements for this project."
4. "Apply deductive reasoning to allocate resources efficiently."
5. "Create a Gantt chart for the project timeline."
6. "Evaluate the risks and contingencies in the timeline."

---

#### 💻 **Coding**

1. "Characterize the existing codebase. Is it modular?"
2. "Provide critical feedback on code readability."
3. "Explain the main algorithms used in this chatbot."
4. "Perform inductive reasoning on the dataset to choose an algorithm."
5. "Grade this code snippet based on this rubric."
6. "Critique this piece of code and provide recommendations for improvement."

---

#### 🚨 **Creating an Elaborate Error Module**

1. "List common errors in machine learning models and how to handle them."
2. "Design an error-handling module for this chatbot."
3. "Outline the logging strategy for tracking errors."
4. "Evaluate the effectiveness of the current monitoring system."
5. "Draft a user feedback collection strategy for error reporting."
6. "Analyze user feedback to identify recurring errors."

---

#### 📝 **Code Creation**

1. "Draft the initial version of the code based on these requirements."
2. "Outline a strategy for modularizing this code."
3. "Generate comments and documentation for this code snippet."

---

#### 🚀 **Optimization**

1. "Analyze the performance bottlenecks in this code."
2. "Apply deductive reasoning to identify optimization opportunities."
3. "Refactor this code snippet to improve its efficiency."

---

#### 📊 **Comparison with Pre-Optimized Code**

1. "Perform benchmark tests on the pre-optimized and optimized code."
2. "Summarize the benchmark results in an executive summary."
3. "Draft a report comparing the pre-optimized and optimized code."

---

#### 🔄 **Developer Sequencing**

1. "Create a dependency graph for the development tasks."
2. "Optimize the development sequence based on the dependency graph."
3. "Allocate developer resources based on task complexity."
4. "Adjust the project timeline based on current progress."

---

### 🌼 **Optimized Software Development Prompt Library with Bloom's Taxonomy**

---

#### 🎨 **Designing the Pipeline**

- **Remember**: "Recall the key data sources for training chatbots."
- **Understand**: "Explain the importance of data preprocessing in NLP."
- **Apply**: "Implement a data collection strategy for this project."
- **Analyze**: "Dissect the ethical considerations in data preprocessing."
- **Evaluate**: "Judge the suitability of different ML models for chatbots."
- **Create**: "Design a comprehensive data collection strategy."

---

#### 💻 **Coding**

- **Remember**: "Identify the key algorithms used in this chatbot."
- **Understand**: "Clarify the purpose of modularization in code."
- **Apply**: "Execute a code readability test based on a given rubric."
- **Analyze**: "Break down the existing codebase to assess its modularity."
- **Evaluate**: "Critically assess this code snippet for optimization."
- **Create**: "Construct a new algorithm to improve chatbot efficiency."

---

#### 🚨 **Creating an Elaborate Error Module**

- **Remember**: "List the types of errors commonly encountered in ML models."
- **Understand**: "Describe the role of logging in error tracking."
- **Apply**: "Implement an error-handling module."
- **Analyze**: "Examine user feedback to identify error patterns."
- **Evaluate**: "Assess the effectiveness of the current error monitoring system."
- **Create**: "Devise a new user feedback strategy for error reporting."

---

#### 📝 **Code Creation**

- **Remember**: "Recall the project requirements for code creation."
- **Understand**: "Summarize the importance of code documentation."
- **Apply**: "Implement a modularization strategy for this code."
- **Analyze**: "Inspect the initial code draft for potential improvements."
- **Evaluate**: "Judge the quality of the initial code draft."
- **Create**: "Compose a well-documented and modular code snippet."

---

#### 🚀 **Optimization**

- **Remember**: "Identify the key performance metrics for code."
- **Understand**: "Explain the concept of code refactoring."
- **Apply**: "Execute performance tests on this code snippet."
- **Analyze**: "Dissect the code to identify performance bottlenecks."
- **Evaluate**: "Assess the trade-offs of the suggested algorithmic changes."
- **Create**: "Develop a new optimization strategy for this code."

---

#### 📊 **Comparison with Pre-Optimized Code**

- **Remember**: "Recall the steps for conducting benchmark tests."
- **Understand**: "Summarize the findings of the benchmark tests."
- **Apply**: "Implement changes based on benchmark results."
- **Analyze**: "Examine the differences between pre-optimized and optimized code."
- **Evaluate**: "Judge the effectiveness of the optimization."
- **Create**: "Formulate a report comparing pre-optimized and optimized code."

---

#### 🔄 **Developer Sequencing**

- **Remember**: "Identify the key tasks in the development sequence."
- **Understand**: "Explain the concept of a dependency graph."
- **Apply**: "Implement a resource allocation strategy."
- **Analyze**: "Dissect the project timeline to identify potential bottlenecks."
- **Evaluate**: "Assess the feasibility of the project timeline."
- **Create**: "Design a new optimized development sequence."

---

All the best!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-09-05T23:29:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-05T23:29:58Z"}, {"author": "@ДаниилДуханин-ш7ц", "text": "00:00 🧠 There are three main types of prompts for mastering language models.
00:28 📄 Reductive operations focus on concise outputs, e.g., summarization, distillation, extraction, characterizing, evaluations, and critiquing.
02:31 🔄 Transformational operations maintain similar input and output size/meaning, including reformatting, refactoring, language change, restructuring, modification, and clarification.
05:02 ✍ Generative operations expand the input to a larger output, like drafting, planning, brainstorming, problem-solving, hypothesizing, and amplification.
07:04 📚 The three operations are categorized as reductive, transformational, and generative/expansive.
07:19 ⏱ Prompt engineering considerations include latency and emergence.
07:33 🎓 Bloom's taxonomy, essential for understanding human learning, ranks skills as remember, understand, apply, analyze, evaluate, and create.
07:59 🤔 Language models showcase capabilities across all Bloom's taxonomy levels.
09:52 🧠 Bloom's taxonomy is a useful model for understanding the capabilities of language models.
10:22 📜 The knowledge and concepts within a language model come from its training data, which is like buried treasure that must be correctly activated.
10:50 🌍 Language models garner world knowledge, including scientific, cultural, and historical facts, from vast amounts of internet data they are trained on.
11:31 🤖 Larger language models exhibit emergent capabilities, such as "theory of mind" where they can model how humans think due to exposure to human-generated content.
12:25 💡 Despite their foundation, language models can demonstrate logical reasoning like inductive and deductive methods, leading to surprising outcomes when prompted correctly.
13:07 🔄 In-context learning in language models, where they utilize novel information not in their training, mirrors human improvisational ability.
13:34 🎨 The model's ability to "hallucinate" is equated to creativity, indicating there's no fundamental difference between creating new things and making stuff up.
14:45 ⚖ In legal contexts, models might "imagine" non-existent cases. Rather than seeing this as an issue, it can be viewed as an imaginative tool to explore possible scenarios, though discernment is crucial.
15:25 🕵 It's vital to differentiate between a model's imagination and reality, suggesting that imagined scenarios can serve as a starting point for real-world searches or applications.

title: Meta AI LM-Infinite - Massive LLM improvement!
top_comments: [{"author": "@Keith_Rothwell", "text": "You just keep getting better and better Dave.  Love this.  Thank you.", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2023-09-01T14:11:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T14:11:30Z"}, {"author": "@felipefairbanks", "text": "amazing that you could put so much good information in such a good size/duration video. That is the kind of stuff I am glad to follow you when I see. Thanks!", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2023-09-01T16:10:05Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T16:10:04Z"}, {"author": "@drhilm", "text": "Appreciate the concise summary of the paper, thank you!", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2023-09-01T13:13:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T13:13:37Z"}, {"author": "@ct5471", "text": "Ray Kurzweil had an interview recently where he said that he now thinks that we’ll probably beat his prediction of AGI by 2029. Kurzweil also predicted back then 2045 for the singularity (defined as having ASI a billion times as intelligent as humans). I also saw an interview with Ben Goertzel in which he disagreed with the 16 year gap between AGI and the singularity. Goertzel thinks it would be at most a few years (I guess that means 2-3) between these two points. What do you think how long it will take until we reach a singularity (as defined by Kurzweil) after we have reached AGI and recursive self improvement starts? So essentially when do you think we reach AGI (still October 2024?) and by what year the singularity (intelligences a billion times that of humans today)?", "like_count": 49, "published_at": "2023-09-01T13:36:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T13:36:29Z"}, {"author": "@mikehynz", "text": "My working memory actually is a giant cluttered warehouse which is why your videos are so valuable. Thanks.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-09-01T20:14:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T20:14:33Z"}, {"author": "@goodtothinkwith", "text": "There’s a very large number that’s a an important threshold for context window and recall: the number of words contained in all the academic articles necessary to write a new article. Most cite ~25-50, a few MB of text. The next point beyond that is the total number of words in all the textbooks and articles that a typical specialist has read to do novel research on a particular topic. Putting on my Ray Kurzweil hat, I suspect that’s when we’ll start to see significant advances made by AI in writing new papers and creating new science", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-09-02T15:19:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-02T15:19:01Z"}, {"author": "@poelogan", "text": "To sum it up- they made LLM’s less ADHD.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-09-01T14:07:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T14:07:28Z"}, {"author": "@HoodedVC", "text": "We never knew how much we loved his old profile picture until we lost it😢", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-09-01T14:39:51Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T14:39:51Z"}, {"author": "@mitchelllinnharris", "text": "This explanation sparks joy", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-04T15:58:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-04T15:58:30Z"}, {"author": "@binichnich8517", "text": "Great! Fascinating stuff. Thank for your great work!!", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-09-01T13:13:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T13:13:18Z"}, {"author": "@pixelshader2004", "text": "Thank you for this video. Very excited for when this improvement hits coding models where large context detail is of paramount importance.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-03T02:31:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-03T02:31:58Z"}, {"author": "@arlogodfrey1508", "text": "I'm hearing a lot of functional similarities with the Exocortex/Remembrance Agent I've been researching and building. We use relevancy distance and a set of memory and decay curves to determine which long-term memories to draw, cluster them, then summarize them in a new context. It creates a \"rolling\" short term context augmented by recent long-term memories. There's a lot of promise, and I'm glad to see similar things happening in the models themselves.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-09-01T16:28:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T16:28:37Z"}, {"author": "@RasmusSchultz", "text": "this is really exciting! of course, it's usefulness is bounded by actually supporting long context, right? do you know of any open source projects already experimenting with this? will you keep us posted? 😄", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-09-02T12:18:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-02T12:18:29Z"}, {"author": "@MichaelDeeringMHC", "text": "Human memory is like a field of pyramids. Each pyramid is a single event or subject that all of it's data have something in common, some unifying concept. The height of the data in the pyramid is the importance of the particular data. A search starts with a plane above the field that moves lower and encounters the more relevant data first.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-09-01T13:06:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T13:06:01Z"}, {"author": "@hanskraut2018", "text": "Escape velocity before exponential or rich with innovation with barely any diminishing returns yet, well said.\n\nGood focus :)", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-09-01T16:08:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T16:09:32Z"}, {"author": "@simplemanideas4719", "text": "That Marie Condo citation is great. Like it!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-02T07:09:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-02T07:09:55Z"}, {"author": "@grantliu9185", "text": "Cool. Learning lots. The more I learn the more I realize these things behave like our brains. There’s a very real analogue to dilution when I think of how humans think.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-04T19:48:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-04T19:48:01Z"}, {"author": "@j.hanleysmith8333", "text": "Dave, your content has been so fire lately. I'm definitely coming to the discord, blessings", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-02T00:14:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-02T00:14:18Z"}, {"author": "@theblockengineers5525", "text": "This is perfect for your old raven project.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-09-01T16:31:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T16:31:43Z"}, {"author": "@panda5088", "text": "I'd like to have seen a bit more of the technicals of this approach. I'd like to know how this attention mechanism differs in architecture from the conventional method. More specifically, it would have been nice to see a diagram displaying the differences in the hidden states between the two systems.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-09-01T21:18:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-01T21:18:55Z"}]

[{"author": "@mpoppins1528", "text": "Live long and prosper!", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2023-08-31T15:07:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-31T15:07:45Z"}, {"author": "@SimplyElectronicsOfficial", "text": "I think Google's unveiling of Gemini this fall is going to kick the race back into gear again, and I think we are going to keep seeing waves like this yearly.", "like_count": 56, "published_at": "2023-08-31T12:11:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-31T12:11:55Z"}, {"author": "@goodtothinkwith", "text": "Excellent job as usual David. I look forward to hearing more from you!", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-08-31T16:01:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-31T16:01:14Z"}, {"author": "@Leshpngo", "text": "My complete attention was laser focus on everything you said. What a Time To Be Alive!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-08-31T13:30:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-31T13:30:09Z"}, {"author": "@bigbadallybaby", "text": "my guess is a slow encroachment into office jobs - lawyers, contracts, accountancy, finance, HR, learning, personal assistance, but a rapid rise in jobs in a new "AI" assisted sector :

- Coding, programming (as AI enables fast learning, lowers the cost of building new software )
- Prompt engineers - or other AI using jobs to manage new ways a business can operate 
- Creative AI media - start-ups making their own music, games, apps, experiences, films, TV, art, clothes etc. using AI tech

then in 3 to 7 years jobs in these new areas become rapidly obsolete as they are carried out by the AI (and the skill required to guide the AI is so simple it takes no training) eliminating the number of people and time to do these things.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-08-31T14:43:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-31T14:43:57Z"}, {"author": "@SwingingInTheHood", "text": "Over the past 8 months, I've grown from someone who was excited about AI to someone who has built an AI chat query system focused on a specific area of state regulations.   One of the things I have struggled with is how to educate end-users on prompting skills.  I debate all the time with other developers on the OpenAI forum about this.  Most say don't provide options, keep the prompts as simple as possible.  I agree.  But, to get useful information, users need to have *some* skill at prompt engineering.

Then someone mentioned that this was akin to trying to teach users how to use boolean operators at the dawn of the introduction of search engines.  Good point.

But, I knew something felt different about this new AI tech innovation / revolution than similar tech shifts in the past.  

After watching this video, I think I now I understand.  This AI tech is going to have a big and immediate impact on a lot of job markets.   Whereas in the past, learning how to use boolean operators in search was a good skill to have, EVERYBODY is going to have to get good at prompting skills just to keep their existing jobs.  Yes, an exaggeration, but you know what I mean.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-08-31T19:39:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-31T19:39:26Z"}, {"author": "@hirefiedinc6313", "text": "Thank you for sharing you thoughts!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-08-31T12:52:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-31T12:52:45Z"}, {"author": "@DSL_2001", "text": "In lieu of your speculative, SF-like conjectures, I find it quite refreshing, indeed, to observe you returning, once more, to the tangible mechanics and realities embedded within the world of all things AI. There's no pressing need to emulate the likes of Cory Doctorow. Instead, your true distinction lies in your ability to dissect and comment on the genuine occurrences, whilst possessing a profound grasp of the foundational technology. Here, Will Salas finds himself accused of murder and on the run with a hostage - a connection that becomes an important part of the way against the system."

My question to you is in a world where people like Jeff Bezos exist and have hundreds of billions, and could end world hunger around the planet, but we still have people starving to death, what makes you optimistic about the future.

As a self-taught programmer from back in the 80s, I really struggled with the object-oriented approach, and to me, it felt like making a choice between solving a task the easy and fast way or the right way. It's generally not until you decide to paint a whole room that you will find yourself painted into a corner.
Mission-oriented programming, however, seems to take program structuring to a totally different level of immediate result, generating various and different self-contained units meant to figure out how to interact with each other, which also gives you an instant result. (Gratification and dopamine reward are what keep me focused and coding.)

This somewhat resembles how our brain assembles itself and its parts figure out what to do, as it too must communicate on different abstraction levels.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2023-07-21T12:44:16Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-21T12:44:16Z"}, {"author": "", "text": "Your ACE Framework is truly amazing! Once again, thank you for the excellent content you are making!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-06T15:36:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-06T15:36:51Z"}, {"author": "@nicholasmordin9737", "text": "Please discuss the practicality of offering all users of GPT-4 and Claude access to their data analysis capabilities.  Code Interpreter has been very glitchy in the last week and unable to answer complex questions.  Claude's ability to analyse files has just been taken offline.  If you look at the processing power you would need to run software like Code Interpreter on your own PC, you'd need a high end PC with lots of RAM.  It is surely not economic for Open AI or Anthropic to offer all their users virtual PC's worth thousands when they're only charging them 20 bucks a month or nothing at all.  Does this not suggest a move away from online AI to personal AI similar to the move from mainframe to personal computers that happened in the 1980's?  Why is nobody talking about this?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-07-17T10:15:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-17T10:16:44Z"}, {"author": "@jamespercy8506", "text": "David seems to be proposing a core value that makes the conversion of adversarial processing into opponent processing wherever possible an imperative, the difference between the two being that opponent promising is premised on a shared narrative and a shared future.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-16T13:08:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-16T13:08:01Z"}, {"author": "@jamespercy8506", "text": "One could suggest that an algorithmic imperative to convert adversarial processing into opponent processing wherever and as far as possible without surrender leads to cognitive attunement and resonant cognition(optimal fluidity of instantiation of cognition balanced with optimal anticipation and correction for unintended consequences).  Just a thought,", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-16T13:45:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-16T13:45:36Z"}, {"author": "@christian-schubert", "text": "Hm... Everytime I listen/read about AI Alignment, it always leaves that sour taste of potentially stifling/lobotomizing AI's full potential in unwanted ways before we even have a chance to arrive at AGI in my mouth.

I also don't buy all that "AI is already sentient/self-aware!" crap. The best AI models are still narrow AI models. Of course they appear AGI-like, they've virtually been trained on all of the Internet (and whatever other sources we don't know about)! Claiming that one of the next GPT iteration will become "self aware" / "AGI" (or even "ASI" mind you) if none of the underlying core principles change in fundamental ways (not denying that that could and most probably will happen with all the research going into it) is like building a car and then planning a trip to the bottom of the ocean.

A lot of "Safeguard mechanisms" also seem to be mere excuses for simply not exposing intellectual property. A fair concern, but let's call a spade a spade and keep it real. It's problematic at least in a sense that it is also hindering progress.

I'm not keen on a Terminator-like future either, all I'm asking is for some awareness of the potentially dark side of over-alignment. This could ultimately prove detrimental as society's current norms and policies are clearly not the optimal way of running things. Or in the words of Winston Churchill: "Democracy is the worst form of Government except for all those other forms that have been tried from time to time".

Well, what if there WERE better alternatives to democracy that we inadvertently "safeguarded" against? Also, I 100% guarantee you, the moment an AGI comes up with reasons why infringing on some big Tech's intellectual property might be the only sustainable way to move forward, it is going to be realigned due to "safety concerns" not due to Big Tech Business Interests.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-07-16T12:34:03Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-16T12:34:03Z"}, {"author": "@verduona", "text": "Look what I have found:

Model: Code Interpreter
What version are you?
I am an instance of OpenAl's GPT-3 model, specifically the chat model known as ChatGPT.
The training data I was trained on includes information up until September 2021. Since the model itself does not have version numbers like software might, it's not possible to give a specific version number. Any updates or improvements made to the model since my training data cut-off wouldn't be reflected in my responses.

Model: Plugins • Enabled plugins:
What version are you?
As an Al developed by OpenAl, I don't have a specific version number like software applications do. However, as of my last training data, I'm based on the GPT-3 model. Please note that my training data only includes information up until September 2021, and I may not have the most recent updates or information beyond that date.

Model: GPT-4
What version are you?
lam based on the GPT-4 architecture, which is an iteration of OpenAl's language model. The 4 Q information I am providing is accurate up to September 2021, which is when I last received an update in my training data. After this date, I can't provide real-time data or updates.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-17T06:13:22Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-17T06:13:22Z"}, {"author": "@JorgetePanete", "text": "Do we, as humans, even have axioms for morality? Is every right axiomatic?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-07-16T18:02:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-16T18:02:56Z"}, {"author": "@hobo393", "text": "Hey dave you should make a video on how ai can become autonomous people are kinda confused how it can gain autonomy", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-16T20:22:59Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-16T20:22:59Z"}, {"author": "@isajoha9962", "text": "Great video. I wonder what might be the correlation between a lot of Alignment "code" and Attention that seems to be a kind of serious problem in reaching Utopia. How much data can a LLM keep track of? Is there some physical limit? 🤔", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-07-16T13:40:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-16T13:41:13Z"}, {"author": "@sebstr8382", "text": "You say you had discovered some of these techniques before there was made papers on them. so wouldn't it be great if you tried collecting your own thinkings in to research papers so the people that only read papers also has a chance to see your great ideas.
If you was able to do that then it would probably accelerate the research in alignment.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-07-16T20:18:06Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-16T20:18:06Z"}, {"author": "@zacharyaustin1660", "text": "Can you do a follow up on how AI can balance conflicting principles? We live in a world of paradox.. (you went on to say human values are inconsistent) I think there is more work to be done here. even if we had perfect alignment capability we need to know what we are aligning with. In any framework the definitions matter greatly such as with the constitution of the US, second amendment has a lot of support that civilians should be able to use guns but it really matters how the right to bear arms is defined. (militia, hunting, self defense, suicide and killing people are all use cases). I am trying to say that if we do not want the AI to be its own Supreme Court interpreting the principles we need to spell out the definitions in a way that logically balances them. This is where I believe we are not ready for AGI because we dont have a robust framework that has balanced principles well. Just because frameworks and codes of ethics exist doesnt mean this is a solved problem and we as a species need to figure this out, together. I believe this if anything could lead us towards a hegemony with one framework rising above all others even if it is not a good framework (any sci-fi empire). I agree with your conclusion that experts need to be included on developing framework for AI and I personally believe the church has the most experience creating frameworks for humanity with systematic theology. It is fascinating to view the pentateuch as such a framework for society, if it is indeed easy to use principle driven self-alignment I wonder how far we could get with the pentateuch. we have a lot of more recent philosophy such as with moral uncertainty but I seriously want to experiment with promised land 2.0 using ai agents equipped with pentateuch and seeing what civilization and governance would look like. It doesnt feel far off that we will have a digital twin of earth to run experiments with. obviously you could do this with any framework but I dont feel like using the Hammurabi code would be functional.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-17T13:50:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-17T13:50:04Z"}, {"author": "@CrypticConsole", "text": "alignment in its current form sucks. I agree that it's important but I feel like the current models cannot differentiate between hypothetical ideas and thoughts that explore immoral topics and actually performing harmful actions through tools and APIs.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-07-16T12:56:54Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-16T12:56:54Z"}]

[{"author": "@moisesbessalle", "text": "dat neurospicy chart be giving us the finger", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-07-15T21:33:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-15T21:33:45Z"}, {"author": "@83shaunam", "text": "I'm a woman and I'm very much interested in tech stuff and I don't find many other women that have the same interest level. I'm in a home automation group on Facebook and it's *very * male dominated. Almost all the other groups I'm in that aren't tech related are female dominated or fairly equal. This is just one subject that skews heavily male. I'm also not a professional and not involved with the industry in any way. I used to be a cake decorator and I'm currently a stay at home mom to my disabled teen. She's the main reason I got so interested in all of this. I can't wait to see how the world changes and what will become available for her to use to help her reach her potential. She currently has an eye gaze communication device and we're working on using that with alexa so she can control the smart home stuff. If neuralink becomes a working and attainable thing in her lifetime, we will be signing her up to get one. Right now, she can only "speak" pre programmed phrases with her talker. I want to hear her original thoughts. She's smart, I know she's probably got tons to say. It's just all trapped inside her head.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-07-15T17:43:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-15T17:43:12Z"}, {"author": "@fanfanfanf", "text": "Hi David,

I don't know if it's been widely adopted yet but it's been incredibly useful for me.", "like_count": 22, "published_at": "2023-07-15T13:33:54Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-17T11:11:55Z"}, {"author": "@tonypop1007", "text": "The problem is that we think consciousness is magic and unknowable. You don't know what you are you be it.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-07-15T17:47:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-15T17:47:29Z"}, {"author": "@Recursively_", "text": "As one of the six percent of your female viewers, I can confirm that it’s most likely the subject matter. I think your channel will attract a lot of artists and other people who aren’t in the scientific activities because your content isn’t really focused on AI, but rather on its impact. Pretty philosophical, in my opinion.

In terms of doomers, I personally have already given up on saving anything. I think it’s gonna be pretty bad at some point BUT just like any transition is.
Altman scanning and registering every single eyebolls on the planet (his goal is to scan 1 billion people by the end of this year), doing it in « third » world countries, while Microsoft released their paper about the 1B token AI. It’s hard not to see patterns here.
