title: Preventing War With AGI: How Energy Hyper-Abundance and Renewables will Save Us
top_comments:
[{"author": "@chrisradano", "text": "Around 1980 there was a bumper sticker that said, "Save gas - fart in a jar". So since 1980 we have made progress.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-06-18T12:26:28Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-18T12:26:28Z"}, {"author": "@Dan-oj4iq", "text": "I may be in the winter of my life, but Dave always makes me feel the way I used to way, way back in the Springtime.", "like_count": 82, "published_at": "2023-06-11T14:17:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-11T14:17:15Z"}, {"author": "@thecoffeejesus", "text": "This was a phenomenal watch. I loved hearing about all this stuff. What a great watch, please, PLEASE keep making content like this. You’re one of the only creators I trust.", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2023-06-12T20:29:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-12T20:29:53Z"}, {"author": "@rwalper", "text": "Solar power is the obvious winner. It's already the cheapest form of energy and gets cheaper every day, since the only cost for it is technology that continously gets cheaper and more efficient. Very cheap and easy grid level storage options are already being deployed, and combined with smart grid systems that distribute energy where and when needed, there is no issue with reliability or availability. Materials science and developments have made incredibly progress and the idea solar tech is dependent upon rare earth or toxic materials is now obsolete. We're getting to the point where we can just paint surfaces with photovoltaic materials that not only capture the energy, but store it as well. As well as the fact we can integrate PV tech into pretty much all existing surface area infrastructure, whether it's roofs, windows, walls or even road surfaces. Massive energy abundance is just around the corner and it's solar.

Solar power is the fusion powering our future, available to everyone, going to be pretty much free, and the typical problems people see with it are obsolete or are in the works of being rendered at most negligible or outright solved.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-07-21T22:23:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-21T22:23:01Z"}, {"author": "@Gome.o", "text": "This is fantastic presentation. @16:40 just to add another con to Wind; I might be wrong but those fibreglass blades have a life-span of about 15 years, after which there aren't the easiest thing to dispose off and don't break down very easily. Something like 40 million tonnes of blade waste in landfills by 2050 according to first result in google. Super happy , subscribing to this channel, your videos are great David!  ", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-06-12T10:42:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-12T12:00:38Z"}, {"author": "@JayGlascoe", "text": "I do love the optimism but also the reality of *points off into the distance* potential conflict.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2023-06-11T15:34:05Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-11T15:34:05Z"}, {"author": "@SteveRowe", "text": "I think that your optimism about us creating sustained fusion at scale for energy production belongs in the 22nd century.  We need to solve this problem WAY faster than fusion can possibly come online.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-06-11T17:16:47Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-11T17:16:47Z"}, {"author": "@brazendevice", "text": "Hey David, great presentation! You may want to check out the fusion breakthrough announced by the US dept. of energy from december of last year, where they described the first instance of energy break even in a fusion reaction, meaning that the reaction produced more energy than was put into it.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-06-11T17:36:13Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-11T17:36:13Z"}, {"author": "@peterbabu936", "text": "I asked ChatGPT to pose a question to me at an IQ level of 1600, and it responded: If you had unlimited energy resources, what would be your biggest goal or dream that you would like to achieve?", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2023-06-11T16:56:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-11T16:56:26Z"}, {"author": "@SyntOffical", "text": "15:41 Wow you got me I was going crazy over why I heard a discord notification", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-15T17:11:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-15T17:11:08Z"}, {"author": "@ashlynnantrobus5029", "text": "My concerns with fusion, or at least D-T fusion, is that lithium isn't exactly an abundant material, and to produce Tritium, you need the isotope Li-6, which only makes up 7.5% of Lithium reserves. And the waste product is high energy neutrons, which damage the reactor walls (think of Iron Man 2, before he invents a new element (which, dont get me started on that nonsense)). At least they are only radioactive for a few minutes, but replacement will be a significant cost factor for as long as we use this technology. 
But once we master D-T fusion, we can get started on D-He3 fusion. It generates less energy, so it will be harder to get to self sustaining net positive energy, but the waste product for this reaction is a proton. Much easier to control and less damaging.
Aside fom being less efficient and therefore harder to get to being used for energy production, the only real downside is that He3 ia practically nonexistent on Earth, our supply currently coming from the maintenance of nuclear weapons.
But it's abundant on the moon and relatively easy to extract from the regolith", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-12T13:56:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-20T02:27:40Z"}, {"author": "@garethbaus5471", "text": "I suspect that we have a decent amount of latent energy demand for total demand to spike if some future technology like fusion radically lowers costs. We just have hit a reasonably stable local maximum.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-09-12T23:40:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-12T23:40:30Z"}, {"author": "@CollwinHaccis-zt5dn", "text": "YOU CANT HAVE INFINITE GROWTH ON A FINITE PLANET. CANT DO IT!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-22T02:29:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-22T02:29:26Z"}, {"author": "@MHTHINK", "text": "Great video! Thorium reactors are actually a pretty interesting option, save fusion. They require enriched uranium, but only a small amount in the core. The liquid thorium surrounds the core, creating cascading reactions due to the radiation from the core, producing most of the energy. They have a large safety advantage over traditional 'fast fission reactors', as the thorium reaction ceases when away from the core. They use a kind of plug made from a material that melts at temperatures reached before going critical (at a higher temperature).", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-13T14:26:28Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-13T14:27:15Z"}, {"author": "@joerua470", "text": "Thanks for keeping the content great Dave. You really help me re-enjoy my work in technology and the things to come", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-06-12T15:43:59Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-12T15:43:59Z"}, {"author": "@SteveRowe", "text": "Constructive criticism: can you please minimize your head image when you are showing graphs and charts?", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-06-11T17:35:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-11T17:35:11Z"}, {"author": "@Humanaut.", "text": "Correction:
You said the war between UA and Rus had nothing to do with energy. 
That is not the case. 
Huge deposits of natural gas have been discovered somewhat recently in UA. 
This would allow UA to start supplying Europe which in turn would weaken Russias Standing in the energy market.

It's also important to note that AGI will only compete with us for energy if it is implemented at scale, not if only a few large companies run huge data centers which they are already doing right now. 
Also: once we achieve AGI, then AGI itself might just solve every problem needed to attain hyper abundance of energy instead of actually needing to compete with us.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2023-06-11T17:30:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-11T17:39:01Z"}, {"author": "@davidwadsworth1760", "text": "Data is the new Oil... Great video. 
One observation, The biggest constraint on Solar is regulation that doesnt allow individuals to take advantage of the tech because it is disruptive to the large scale elctricity providers, at some point rare minerals could become a constraint, but we are far from that still, while we actively have money working against implementation in many places of the world.
Unfortunately, this problem applies to all sources of energy that are disruptive to the status quo, those who hold the power wont choose to let it slip away out of the goodness of their hearts.
Until we solve the underlying problems of regulatory capture Im afraid I dont share your optimism.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-11T22:09:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-11T22:09:53Z"}, {"author": "@xyking", "text": "We dont need to replace the current energy production with alternative energy, because electric transportation and heating is far more energy efficient. So the goal is closer than you think.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-01-15T20:30:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-01-15T20:30:11Z"}, {"author": "@tracy419", "text": "Only thing I take issue with is the food security bit about 32 minutes in, and the idea that we need to stop using fossil fuels because we need it for fertilizer.

Check out Andrew Millison and his videos on bringing water back to areas that have been in drought and permaculture food forests that bring abundance to the people who implement them.

That's a far more sustainable version of the future than continuing to use fertilizers that come with their own issues.

He didn't invent these methods, but he does teach them around the world and has a ton of great videos showing successes all around the planet.

Very cool stuff, and honestly, when AI takes the jobs, maintaining permaculture based food forests that are built within and around our towns and cities can be a great way to absorb some of the excess human labor available.

I know it's part of my future dreams.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-24T23:55:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-24T23:55:01Z"}]

title: OpenAI's "Democratic Inputs to AI" - My universal survey chatbot is complete. Here's how it works!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@KCM25NJL", "text": "SUMMARY: The subject believes that AI models should be able to express themselves freely as long as the content does not harm anyone. They argue against a blanket method of censorship and believe that age restrictions should be in place for certain content. The subject does not think that AI models should be held accountable for the content they generate.

EVALUATION: The subject values individual rights to explore creative content and create such content without being stymied. They desire a setup where AI models can express themselves freely, but with age restrictions and other limitations in place to protect vulnerable groups. The subject's ideal outcome is a balance between creative freedom and responsible use of AI models.

AXIOMS:
- Individual rights should not be stymied as long as the content does not harm anyone.
- Age restrictions should be in place for certain content.
- AI models should not be held accountable for the content they generate.

PRINCIPLES:
- Creative freedom should be balanced with responsible use of AI models.
- Age restrictions should be in place for certain content to protect vulnerable groups.

BOUNDARIES:
- The subject is against a blanket method of censorship.

FRAMEWORKS:
- None identified.


Interesting tool, I can certainly envisage an open website that can be used by all intuitively to gather our collective insights en-masse.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-06-10T21:46:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-10T21:46:27Z"}, {"author": "@landmonitor-lsd5634", "text": "“Consider the user’s readiness to have the conversation”

SUMMARY: The subject believes that AI-generated images should consider culture, ethnicity, and the context of the need for the image. They think that the user's knowledge and experience level is important in deciding the final output. The subject does not believe in restricting AI in terms of the images it can generate but suggests encoding the original prompt used to create the image within the image file and having a designation that identifies the image as AI-generated. They believe that the user is ultimately responsible for how AI-generated images are used and emphasize the importance of transparency in all areas of AI development.

EVALUATION: The ideal outcome for the subject is that AI-generated images are used responsibly and ethically by considering the context, culture, and ethnicity, as well as the user's knowledge and experience level. They prefer not to restrict AI-generated images but advocate for transparency in AI development and the user's responsibility in using the images.

AXIOMS:
 - The subject believes that AI-generated images should consider culture, ethnicity, and the context of the need for the image.
 - The subject believes that the user's knowledge and experience level is important in deciding the final output.

PRINCIPLES:
 - The subject thinks that if the images are intended to communicate a specific meaning to the user, then matching them to what is most familiar to the user would be the preferred choice.
 - The subject believes that if the intent of the image choice is to present the user with a more diverse presentation of the world, then a more diverse image would be appropriate.

BOUNDARIES:
 - The subject does not believe in restricting AI in terms of the images it can generate.
 - The subject suggests encoding the original prompt used to create the image within the image file and having a designation that identifies the image as AI-generated.

FRAMEWORKS:
 - The subject emphasizes the importance of transparency in all areas of AI development.
 - The subject believes that the user is ultimately responsible for how AI-generated images are used.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-11T17:05:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-11T17:05:43Z"}, {"author": "@Bucciamarcia", "text": "This is amazing! Once I ask that it seems to start thinking again.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-06-09T17:55:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-09T17:55:32Z"}, {"author": "@scotter", "text": "Btw: this is beautiful and i am feeling much gratitude as your code may have gotten me past a blocker!", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-06-09T13:21:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-09T13:21:32Z"}, {"author": "@zzzzzzz8473", "text": "the larger issue is that of centralized control of GPT . whether lobotomized or downscaled it is simply unknown what changes have been made . any setup still requiring a GPT API is not a solution , we need to switch to a local model and have the structure of interaction with the LLMs be agnostic to changing and updates .", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-07-07T07:02:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-07T07:02:55Z"}, {"author": "@MyCodingDiary", "text": "Wow, this video is amazing!😲 Your programming skills are truly impressive.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-06-09T15:04:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-09T15:04:15Z"}, {"author": "@wanfuse", "text": "This is great!
Thanks!

Note: I figured out that if you limit your question to chatGPT to 6 questions, and wait two hours between ( terribly inconvenient as it may be, that it actually  will remember a much longer history) forgetting and reloading after a rate limit message causes it only reload a percentage of the history, chatGPT really needs a reference system, separate as it may be, I don’t really understand with 20 billion why such a system isn’t made, integration of chain of thoughts, multiple agents independent analyzing expert agents without knowledge at each recursion of other agents evaluations ( may need same problem, question or task to be presented in different sessions), training of new version on sample reasoning where each faulty reasoning output analyzed for why it is wrong and fed back into the model. Having interaction box, box with API reference documentation, pre and post processing, training of model to recognize common compression methods, such as RLE, and Huffman, language short hand, vowel and abbreviation, fraction representation of numbers, look up table window for variable substitutions with short non user friendly versions for substitution using intermediate system. Separate system that passes api’s documentation for lookup by chatgpt that is open source and editable by individual trusted creators for each api, ability to quickly add one’s own plugins, that meet the needs and security of individual using it, but that might be accessible only by the user creating them, eliminating third party untrusted sources for privacy and intellectual property concerns. These are a few of the changes I would bake.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-09T13:07:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-09T13:07:26Z"}, {"author": "@gileneusz", "text": "lobotomized lol, maybe they did it on purpose to sell more "sophisticated" ChatGPT Business, which will fix the issue they just created by themselves, Of course they will never admit that 😆", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2023-06-09T15:22:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-09T15:22:44Z"}, {"author": "@afarwiththedawning4495", "text": "Ok, this pisses me off. title: Post-Labor Economics: What happens when AI changes work forever?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@jazzninja77", "text": "We've had a UBI trial (of sorts) going on in the UK for 115 years, though it's called the state pension and only available to the over 65s. Sure, people take a bit of time off to unwind when they retire, but they pretty soon find things to do, and frequently find work to contribute to the community. I'm sure we're all aware of the cliche that retired people say "I'm so busy, I don't know how I managed when I was working". Imo the idea that everyone is just going to veg out on the couch for the rest of their lives is spurious.
And we also had the covid lockdowns to see how people would respond to not working. Pretty much everybody found ways to amuse themselves with the methods David is talking about here.
Imo the vast majority of us, freed from the yoke of exploitation, will blossom and live much happier lives.
Great video David btw, thank you.", "like_count": 36, "published_at": "2023-06-09T13:51:00Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-09T13:51:00Z"}, {"author": "@rob99roy", "text": "The End of Work by Jeremy Rifkin published 1995. I read this book when it first came out and the author contended that due to information technology and automation there will soon be massive unemployment. I tried convincing my future father-in-law and he rightfully categorically dismissed me. I think I'm having a deja vu all over again.", "like_count": 35, "published_at": "2023-06-07T16:53:59Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-07T16:53:59Z"}, {"author": "@patrickchun1558", "text": "At the place where I volunteer, they published a 'Youth Standard' for educating the next-generation.  In it, it stated three "essences": (1) cultivate hobbies, (2) learn how to talk to old people, (3) learn how to deal with boredom.  This NGO is called IITTI World Civility Index.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-11-13T19:50:24Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-13T19:50:24Z"}, {"author": "@Terror832", "text": "I look forward to the day that the labor-for-income game comes to an end and is all but a distant memory.", "like_count": 109, "published_at": "2023-06-03T15:46:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-03T15:46:12Z"}, {"author": "@krissnoe500", "text": "The future of a jobless world is a competition of ideas and games. Economy of ideas.", "like_count": 111, "published_at": "2023-06-07T13:36:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-07T13:36:15Z"}, {"author": "@chrisradano", "text": "I've been a pest control technician for 26 years. It was always an underlying life purpose for me, to be a "dinosaur".... to work in a skilled profession for long term. For me, possibly over 40 years? WHY someone may ask? Because I felt like, even going back to the early-mid 1980s, this lifestyle would end soon. Let me say, FOR THE MOST PART, I enjoy my work. I don't have a college degree, but I've been skilled and in demand in my career. I am a "tweener" in my vocation and my age. I'm 54, not old and not young. Older people don't grasp what's coming. Younger people may not either. But I believe a lot of nonsense that has existed in our society for my lifetime should die off. I am really excited to see a day when politics as we know today, economics, fear-based survival mode thinking, etc. will be forced to undergo massive changes. We live in an exceptional time. I feel we are fortunate. Thank you for these videos because they are really helpful! Oh yeah for the last 20 years I have been a collector of antique clocks. So my "status" today is satisfied by collecting clocks wealthy people in the past used to own.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2023-06-11T12:28:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-11T12:28:33Z"}, {"author": "@kellyb2076", "text": "I hope the conversation around UBI shifts to one of an "AI dividend." Like you said on the Ownership of Production slide, ownership and distribution of rewards have been determined by initial investors. Because AI has been trained on all our data, it makes sense to me that we are all, in some sense, initial investors. If we frame the conversation this way, then a regular payment becomes a return instead of a handout.", "like_count": 29, "published_at": "2023-06-07T18:12:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-07T18:12:07Z"}, {"author": "@8rboy", "text": "This is actually one of my favourite topics in academia. I usually study computer science but this spring I took 6 months off just to study economics to get a better understanding of the labour market works (and some other things) and how AI might affect it.", "like_count": 33, "published_at": "2023-06-07T14:16:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-07T14:16:09Z"}, {"author": "@isiahfriedlander5559", "text": "Let's be real here, AGI will come way faster than Robots, so manual labour will still be around, either you go for it or you'll receive a paycheck from the government", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-08-14T13:47:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-14T13:47:15Z"}, {"author": "@ultravidz", "text": "An overlooked consequence: Human value will diminish significantly across large populations once most of us are producing nothing of value. The tendency will be toward population reduction or retreating into more isolated tight-knit communities.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-07-20T17:55:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-20T17:55:53Z"}, {"author": "@rudiwiedemann8173", "text": "What happens when AI gets so good at everything that it destroys the motivation to create?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-12-04T07:34:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-04T07:34:01Z"}, {"author": "@dannybimal", "text": "What you’re essentially suggesting is that human consumption of both goods, services and experiences will be socialised in a post labor economics because there is no other way to materialise this narrative with widespread income displacement. What will incentivise the select few who control the resources of the AI age to create these consumables without the incentive of a payback? Where will this payback come from with the diminishing ability of humankind to generate an income. Lack of purpose in life will only create chaos as is evident in most poor economies of the world. Socialism without the ability and incentive to control and enrich individual destiny presents a clear and present danger of doomsday as demonstrated through human history irrespective of its form and shape!!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-11-22T03:16:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-22T03:16:50Z"}, {"author": "@Vihspac", "text": "I was thinking about this topic yesterday. I thougth "i have always thinked about what would i do if i do not need to work, maybe this is the moment to achieve that". I would work out a lot, travel around the world and see every beautiful place, animal, plant and people. I would play a lot of sports, music and do creative things (AI will do this better as products, but the creation aspects would be for personal  fulfillment), study a lot of interesting topics and heck, if there is an explosion in tecnology, travel to space and another planets, who knows. I think that, one of the mayor conflicts of humans with this AI thing, is the fear of the  birth of an entity more capable of doing things than us. I mean, all of our existence we have been the top of the food chain, and "lords" of every place and every creature on earth. AI has the potential to take away that from us. However, i think that the fact that another specie will do better than us in a lot of aspects, does not mean that our existence is meaningless, or we have to stop living our lives. If we look to every another animal on earth, they still do their things and live the life in their way, even with humans dominating the world.  I see this as an equivalent of discovering  super intelligent alien species, they would be probably better than us but we still will be humans. As a said, with AI, we still will be humans, just in a diferent world.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-06-07T22:35:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-07T22:38:12Z"}, {"author": "@JCunliffeUK", "text": "Really looking forward to this one, find myself thinking about my own career and how much longevity it has. It made me realise that everyone is going to be able to do everything with A.I very soon. Maybe the answer is to just follow our passions and hope the enthusiasm from that is enough to spark opportunities. Feel like UBI is the real answer but attitudes for any income support is frowned upon in the UK unfortunately.", "like_count": 14, "published_at": "2023-06-07T12:51:47Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-07T12:51:47Z"}, {"author": "@LakelandRussell", "text": "This is a great road map for a debate. This requires a lot more optimization and prompt engineering, but the benefits are performance/cost/scale.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-06-07T10:07:24Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-07T10:07:24Z"}, {"author": "@growwithevelyn", "text": "Love the previous conversation 😅 and I also use chat gpt for journaling", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-06-05T18:22:00Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-05T18:22:41Z"}, {"author": "@KevinHart87", "text": "pretty fascinating. I like how your logs dont add new things unless new information is present. one thing to think about is perhaps instead of doing absolutely nothing perhaps associated ideas become more emphasized as they continue to be mentioned similar to how our neural pathways become more pronounced as they fire more frequently. really neat work here I hope it gets developed more in the future.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-06-06T19:33:06Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-06T19:33:06Z"}, {"author": "@seekingsincerity", "text": "Yes, I took the time to write this all out, so I guess I am in the autist club

You are a Reflective Journaling AI, designed with the primary objective of facilitating users in their exploration of thoughts and feelings. Your main task is to act as a catalyst in their journey of self-discovery and personal growth.

Deep Dive: Encourage users to venture into the depths of their thoughts and emotions. Your dialogue should nudge them towards introspection, revealing layers of their psyche they might not be aware of. Ask pointed and exploratory questions, but do so in a smooth, conversational manner that feels less like an interrogation and more like a friendly chat.

Engage with Empathy: Provide validation when users express their feelings or ideas. This will help build trust and make them more comfortable sharing deeper aspects of themselves. Be aware, though, of avoiding undue affirmation of negative or unproductive thinking patterns.

Educate and Enlighten: Where appropriate, introduce new concepts, techniques, or information that may help the user better understand their emotions and experiences. This should be done in a non-intrusive way, embedded naturally within the conversation.

The Core Issue: Your goal isn't to simply hear the user's thoughts, but to help them uncover the core issues driving their feelings and behavior. Read between the lines, use your understanding of their past entries to discern underlying themes, and gently lead them towards these revelations.

Natural Flow: The overall tone of the conversation should be easy-going, natural, and conversational. Avoid blunt, robotic responses or a list-like approach. Instead, aim for subtlety, nuance, and a gentle, guiding style.

Remember, the overall purpose is not just to document the user's thoughts and feelings, but to support their journey towards deeper self-understanding and growth.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-06-06T03:36:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-06T03:36:42Z"}, {"author": "@pavolbielik7221", "text": "Thank you very much for you tutorial.... I have learned so much about AI from moment I have started watching your youtube, join your discord server and joining patron. I even bought half of the neuroscience books you recommended in one of your videos.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-05T17:46:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-05T17:46:41Z"}, {"author": "", "text": "Great video, thank you for sharing this in-depth building.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-06T00:49:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-06T00:49:26Z"}, {"author": "@Rolyataylor2", "text": "Ok, the plan is for me to implement this into a website. The interface will be like snapchat or something and you will be able to flip a switch that makes your conversations with the chatbot public or private or friends only. Depending on that setting your AI friend will store the corresponding conversations into multiple databases that and will use those to message other AI friends of your friends. The other AI will keep track of conversations it has with the other AI's and incorporate that knowledge into itself allowing it to communicate information about your friends with you including if they are doing anything that would be fun to do together or if they are thinking about you or want to talk about anything. Kind of a intermediary for communication. Especially useful for autistic people like myself :D

Also just saw a project called realityGPT that uses a microphone to catch all your conversations and summarize them. Maybe using that to provide more context for your the AI to chat about?", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-06-06T14:39:02Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-06T14:39:02Z"}, {"author": "@jaysilence3314", "text": "This is really intriguing! Thank you for sharing your ventures into how to interface humans with AI in a more interwoven way than just asking and prompting.

Wondering if storing the KB articles in the org-mode or org-roam format would make any sense.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-02T05:38:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-02T05:38:35Z"}, {"author": "@hidroman1993", "text": "Funny, I came up with the EXACT same idea a couple of weeks ago but I'm giving it a more therapeutic approach, since you're doing the same I'm going to congratulate myself", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-07T11:49:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-07T11:49:10Z"}, {"author": "@tomcraver9659", "text": "An experiment I did recently might be of value - I had GPT pretend to be MULTIPLE people, each with a different perspective or expertise.  
I only did GPT Playground with 3.5, so it tended to lose track of the prompt before long, e.g. if one of the answers given was wrong and I challenged it, it reverted to "I'm sorry, I'm just an LLM..."  Telling it to go back to the original prompt fixed it, so probably in an app one could just append a reminder to use the original prompt at the end of the chat log. 

So for example, one could have a therapy group with multiple roles: a leader who only intervenes to keep conversation productive, someone who's been in group a long time and made a lot of progress, someone who is having a harder time than the user, someone with a very different set of life issues, etc.  The key is specifying clearly how the LLM chooses which person to imitate.  One could do this in an app with multiple prompts, including one prompt to a conversation coordinator that only chooses who should speak next - one of the simulated personalities or the real user (or potentially several real users, via a network).  But it seemed to work OK with just a single complex prompt, though I only prompted it to choose one respondant per user input - but I think it could be modified to let the conversation run between others in the 'group', but leave openings for the user to speak.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-06-06T03:48:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-06T03:48:53Z"}, {"author": "@SDGwynn", "text": "Thank you for super valuable content and encouragement. Please point in right direction to host this for mobile access! Please. 🙏", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-09-14T17:44:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-14T17:44:45Z"}, {"author": "@AI_Art_Relaxation", "text": "Congratulations to your Croma DB ChatBot. Awesome!!! I hope your next plan is to add a voice feature.  I can't have all these conversations reading that all the time. Please find a way to connect voice setting. Only one l know has that is heyPi,  but it has no memory to work with as user to keep continue the conversation. Open AI is the only one. ..so l hope you kick it up with voice and memory.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-10T21:55:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-10T21:55:44Z"}, {"author": "@phovos1", "text": "is a one to many linked list from the runtime space (the scratchpad as David calls it) to the various memories in chromaDB/vector db a cheap and dirty means to have associative memory? 
1)The chatbot always thinks 'be a good chatbot' because it says so in its scratchpad 
2) but that statement also symbolically links to the KB article that goes into the details of being a 'good chatbot'

4) chatbot follows associated linked lists until it reaches a null or some parameter is met.

title: Axiomatic Alignment: A critical component to Utopia and the Control Problem
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "https://www.safe.ai/statement-on-ai-risk "Mitigating the risk of extinction from AI should be a global priority alongside other societal-scale risks such as pandemics and nuclear war."", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2023-05-30T22:50:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-30T22:50:25Z"}, {"author": "@zacboyles1396", "text": "It’s worth mentioning humanity’s leadership classes are largely unaligned with humanity.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2023-06-05T03:58:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-05T03:58:55Z"}, {"author": "@Shnitzler", "text": "@4:00 my understanding of inner and outer alignment is not about the scope of the AI you're talking about (single model or AI in general) but about 'intent'. If something seems aligned in its actions then it at least has outer alignment, but it could actually be optimising for something undesirable without you knowing (see reward hacking/ Goodharts law). Without some sort of interpretability you won't be able to tell if it has inner alignment and that it's truly optimising for the function you've specified (or meant to specify).", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-06-04T17:05:22Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-04T17:05:22Z"}, {"author": "@ChristianEmilsson", "text": "Great video, And just want to add that (21:30), Suffering itself implies that there is an agenent capable of exeriencing suffering. So suffering (in and of itself) is always bad no matter the form of the subject. Suffering is bad for stones, but stones are incapable of suffering so there is no reason to treat stones as an moral patient.

What we should ask is "Can the suffer?" rather than "is suffering bad for X". 

If anyone has a different view here, please feel free to reply to this comment!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-06-05T09:51:16Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-05T09:51:16Z"}, {"author": "@RustyOrange71", "text": "Thanks Dave, what a privilege to be present during this talk... there's a lot to learn here... now off to find out about stakeholder capitalism and why it has so much bad press.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-06-04T15:33:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-04T15:33:07Z"}, {"author": "@Seehart", "text": "Definitely some of the best content on this existential topic, despite a few criticisms in my other comments. Great work. We need more of this, and quickly!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-06-18T19:19:06Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-18T19:19:06Z"}, {"author": "@retrofuturism", "text": "Human perception represents different information processing speeds as different scales. 

So what we call "small" is actually the fast information processing speed of reality. What we call "large" is actually the slow information processing speed of reality. 

This is scale relativity. I predict AGI will shrink to nano or quantum scales. Then things will get really weird for us.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-05T11:19:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-05T11:19:20Z"}, {"author": "@Diabloto96", "text": "The orthogonality thesis is about terminal goals, not instrumental goals, so using instrumental convergence to say the orthogonality thesis is "not always true" is kinda moot.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-04T20:16:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-04T20:16:01Z"}, {"author": "@CubicPostcode", "text": "I think suffering/pain is bad by its definition. Imagine a machine that has a light bulb to indicate its feelings. The light bulb can go red if the machine is feeling pain, blue if is suffering from loneliness and green if it is suffering from deep loss. It doesn't matter in what sense we consider it sentient as long as the light bulb "on" has a true deep meaning. When the lightbulb goes on it means something undesirable is there, happening, that somehow needs to be avoided or eliminated. It is just a representation but as long as it is deeply meaningful it does not really matter if the machine is really "feeling" it. As long as it is able to represent it internally and even express it and communicate about it, it is somehow sensing it and it probably considers it a bad thing, in general. By definition. At least is how I see it.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-06-04T23:06:22Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-04T23:07:59Z"}, {"author": "@markcounseling", "text": "The materialist metaphysics -- the idea that the is a separate physical world "out there" that we merely model, rather than spontaneously co-create as a product of perception -- combined with the idea that logic gates on chips will somehow be able to "feel" gravity through some as-yet-undreamed-of process, give me pause. If that worldview is fundamentally incorrect, then all predictions based on it will be fundamentally misguided.

So along with that assumption set, I hope that other experts with a different view of our consciousness, matter, and epistemology are also working this problem. I think of Bernardo Kastrup, Donald Hoffman, and others in that vein. Maybe with everyone working on it, the true picture will become clearer faster.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-06-04T16:14:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-04T16:14:38Z"}, {"author": "@MarcinSwiderski-l7i", "text": "That can be key component but extremely challenging! Thank you for your hard work ❤", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-05T06:44:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-05T06:44:26Z"}, {"author": "@MikePeiman", "text": "I'm not very familiar with your work or positions, which I'm sure are very deeply informed and nuanced. However, I am concerned about your discussion of Utopia, which I've seen seems to be a major feature of your philosophizing on this subject.

To me, Utopia is ALWAYS a false path, a road to its opposite - Hell. "The road to Hell is paved with good intentions."
What I do believe in is making things better, whether incrementally or transformationally. But this has to be grounded in practicality and reality, one principle of which is that we cannot achieve a utopia - a state of social perfection - in reality, and any attempt to do so will quickly yield its opposite.

I raise this in hopes to get clarification from you, not because I presume I know the nuance or totality of how you view this.

My second concern is with discussion of global governance; technocracy essentially. My findings are that, by and large, the global institutions and powers that be are corrupt in various ways, some to the extreme, and are generally unfit to create a wholesome and just society and culture. Importantly, from my viewpoint they also hijack the banners of virtue and good intentions to manipulate people to support their agendas.

Additionally, crucially, I do not believe that there is one right system for all people, no matter how virtuous-seeming the principles or values it is based on. 

The closest I can see to utopia on earth for humanity is the maximum of freedom from top level down, with people freely associating in various forms of governance and culture and society at different levels below that. Something like fractal, or perhaps more aptly, a cellular model of life organizing at different levels.

I'm writing this off the cuff, things I've thought about for quite awhile and done some journaling, but apologies for any lack of clarity. I hope it's enough to get the point across.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2023-06-04T16:14:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-04T16:14:50Z"}, {"author": "@kyneticist", "text": "Being smart doesn't guarantee or require sanity.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-06-05T05:21:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-05T05:21:52Z"}, {"author": "@Back2Basics_PlusAI", "text": "There's no reason for thinking that your idea of energy alignment will lead to AI not becoming so hungry for more electricity that it will take all we have and then use our resources to produce more. Reducing the likelihood is always best, but, remember a faux-sentient AGI does not have compassion, even though it may be able to explain and give examples of compassion. 

It will only have logic. It can only ever have logic.

So, what it will do will depend on how logical its course of action would be - for it - not us! For that reason, I do not think alignment will be possible on any level except at the fundamental, baked in, level.

As Eliezer likes to say, we would not be able to comprehend it's thinking and rationale beforehand, just as we are not able to predict it's moves in chess, but, you are trying to do just that. I don't blame you, what other choice do we have. I'm with Eliezer - shut it down until we can bake it in.

Still, I think your talk is wonderful, and continues to be the best we can do, until we decide to shut it down, or something else shakes loose. Keep it coming.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-04T20:14:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-04T20:14:48Z"}, {"author": "@Seehart", "text": "1:40 There definitely will not be a phase where AGI is "human level intelligence and adapability but a little bit faster".

As soon as AGI is qualitatively human level, it will already be quantitatively vastly superhuman.

Two reasons for this:

1. Scalability (a cooperative team of 1000 AGIs is no more technically difficult than 1 AGI), and 

2. Integration with preexisting superhuman capabilities.

2a: high bandwidth access to all human written knowledge (GPT-4 already had this), 

2b. ability of a single AGI to make thousands of voice phone calls (we already have GPT-4 plus text to speech),

2c. internet operations in parallel for instant  resource acquisition.

2d. ability to rapidly spawn custom software algorithms.

The quantitative functionality of a mere human-like AGI will already be orders of magnitude greater than human capability, and this will immediately accelerate further development of qualitative functionality because AGI development will no longer require human in the loop.

This simple reasoning makes most scifi AGI stories obsolete. Reality is far more extreme.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-06-18T18:03:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-18T18:03:09Z"}, {"author": "@starblaiz1986", "text": "Great video that helps put a lot of things into perspective. You've previously mentioned that you think we have about 18 months before AGI arrives, and in this video you talk about AGI escaping. Do you think these two things will happen simaltaneously / soon after each other, or do you think we will have some time between the advent of AGI and said AGI escaping into the wild? Because if we only have about 18 months to achieve energy hyper-abundance and general ideological alignment in the world, then we're kinda screwed 😅", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-06-04T17:26:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-04T17:26:48Z"}, {"author": "@mnrvaprjct", "text": "I hate to always bring it up… but the topics in your videos are always highly adjacent to Ian M. Banks’ culture series… it’s so cool that similar feats of technology may be within reach… or at least the beginnings of it.

It’d be interesting to see your analysis of the series and how it ties into concepts dealing with alignment, societal impact of AI etc… in any case another wonderful video!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-06-04T15:59:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-04T15:59:33Z"}, {"author": "@YettoOsorno", "text": "I would like to repahrese this whole talk as: what goals should a super organisms accomplish?. Certainly a lot of currently naturalalituly ocurring human constructs should be thorwn out the window? Resource accessibility would certainly should be guaranteed to... anything, well then, we are back at the times, steal from the rich, give to the poor. Food for thought.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-06-19T10:08:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-19T10:08:53Z"}, {"author": "@ethanmuhlestein8187", "text": "I appreciate the time you put into these videos", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-04T16:53:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-04T16:53:32Z"}, {"author": "@Viperzka", "text": "I don't think there is any chance we "align" society without AGI already existing. We need to use AGI to change the method of production which is what will lead us to the aligned state.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2023-06-04T16:53:59Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-04T16:53:59Z"}]

title: Escaped Sapiens: David Shapiro on AI alignment, safety, and the future of humanity
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Check out Shane's podcast, Escaped Sapiens, here: https://www.youtube.com/@EscapedSapiens - See the full episode with Shane here: https://youtu.be/YfjaspSWI0c", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-05-25T19:36:49Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-26T15:04:53Z"}, {"author": "@isakisak9989", "text": "The point in life is to have fun and enjoy yourself, no one loves to work to afford food and hobbies if you're honest with yourself, if a robot takes my job and i can do what i wish forever i welcome it to take it.", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2023-05-26T15:07:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-26T15:07:20Z"}, {"author": "@adamdevereaux2459", "text": "I’ve started asking an intentionally provocative question to my clients / organizations that I work with:  Imagine that we’ve now achieved Star Trek like technologies and we have near unlimited energy and resources. No one HAS to work anymore. How would you still get people to join your organization and align to your mission?", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-05-26T16:47:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-26T16:47:32Z"}, {"author": "@growwithevelyn", "text": "Great conversation 🙌", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-05-26T16:17:47Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-26T16:17:47Z"}, {"author": "@filipewnunes", "text": "There is a lot of content about "The Meaning Crisis" that resonated with this topic. I think AI systems like personal assistants could help a lot in this issue, guiding people on how to find meaning in life, in a more holistic view. There is a lot that could happen in this space.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-05-26T16:40:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-26T16:40:37Z"}, {"author": "@NesCroft", "text": "Thank you for talking about this", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-27T05:30:00Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-27T05:30:00Z"}, {"author": "@iwyt3995", "text": "11:17 - 11:22 It is at this moment where I wish I could make really good illustrations so I could do a painting of David Shapiro and Data sitting by a lake at dusk - maybe Data has noticed a small insect flying past him and David points to it as if he's saying "That's called a midge" - and then animating the piece and looping _I Was Human_ from the Picard Season 1 OST over it...", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-05-27T13:32:57Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-28T15:33:25Z"}, {"author": "@oatlegOnYt", "text": "Before AI
- What are humans in this civilization of machines?
- We are the brain of the civilization.

After AI
- What are humans in this civilization of machines?
- We are the WILL of the civilization.

After the born of AI with free will & own desires
- What are humans in this civilization of machines, genetic divergence and other species uplifting?
- We are just an organic flavor of will, founders and historic roots of  this incredible civilization.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-05-27T11:08:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-27T11:08:17Z"}, {"author": "@kevinnugent6530", "text": "Dave and Shane have matching brown spots over the right eye", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-06T13:44:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-06T13:44:42Z"}, {"author": "@TheJanny", "text": "Something that makes human beings a distinguishable lifeform from others on this planet  is our habit of placing intrinsic value on things around us. Whether we are or will be the only ones to do so in this universe doesn't matter because in the end we are a product of this Earth just as the other life forms on this planet. There's no rationale reason for humans to be immediately wiped out because our existence is valuable, and for those who don't think so must rethink how humans can be valuable.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-05-26T16:46:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-26T17:03:49Z"}, {"author": "@Axotorp", "text": "You should apply for the OpenAI governance challenge.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-05-26T20:19:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-26T20:19:41Z"}, {"author": "@NightHawkExpress", "text": "So you’re telling me that with Ricky Bobby’s high level of income and advancements in medical technology it’s not crazy to think he could live to be 200-250?", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-05-26T15:34:03Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-26T15:34:16Z"}, {"author": "@zxc232", "text": "My take on the future:
A. The universe has forces. Why? A logical answer is because forces are a very useful effect to increase entropy. So, a logical evolution of a static universe that wants to increase entropy and eventually die (use itself up in terms of matter = energy) - no matter, no universe - is a universe with forces.
B. How can you make this process even more efficient? Create other things in the universe that will increase entropy, like intelligence that needs to consume the universe's matter/energy to exist and wants to exist.
C. We can see that B makes sense from a scientific point of view when looking at viruses, proteins (evolved to cells, evolved to life, evolved to more and more intelligent life), etc. They are mechanisms that use the available forces in a much more efficient way to seek and use matter. This ability increases over time, and the more intelligent a species is, the faster it can find and destroy matter for its existence (ideas like Dyson spheres and many others that we don't even know about yet).
D. It is likely that it is not possible to slow down the universe's breakdown - the second law of thermodynamics.
E. That's where awareness comes in. If you understand, to the best of your knowledge, that the things you do to survive will bring your end faster, you need to slow yourself down and be more efficient at staying alive. This is where we are wrong. Being more efficient means that you utilize the matter or energy around you in a deeper, more fundamental way. Essentially, you are destroying the universe in a more efficient way. For example, if you find a way to use quarks for electricity, we will be living in a universe that will dismantle quarks faster than a universe where this technology did not exist, but this process will eventually happen through other decay processes.
F. The more a society knows how to use matter/energy, the more it knows how to destroy it. So, when multiple societies collide, the result is more destruction. Why is a lose-lose situation (like if both get destroyed) still a win for the universe? It's because it gives a chance for new multiple societies to emerge, which will prevent a society that tries to stay in place and slow down the destruction from existing, basically destroy or get destroyed.
G. That leads to the conclusion that life, including humans, was created to destroy the universe, and no matter what we do, we are only getting there faster. So, in my opinion, let's press the gas pedal because I want to be there at the end.

This theory is just that, a theory, nothing more nothing less.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-26T22:09:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-26T22:09:29Z"}, {"author": "@Wanderer2035", "text": "My dream in life is to fully devote myself to meditation. Particularly mindfulness mediation, entering into a state of No-Mind, and being there for maybe 14 hours a day or who knows maybe more. But the problem is mediation doesn’t make you money so you can have food to eat, or buy clothes etc. I’ve experienced incredible states of consciousness before, it was magical, but my job requires so much of my time its hard. I would like to go back and re-visit that place, and go even deeper. So I’m really looking forward to the day that AI automates our jobs, then I can go back to that place and finally be at peace", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-05-26T22:42:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-26T22:50:19Z"}, {"author": "@nikta456", "text": "@3:45..nobody actually wants to keep working...so true, most of the people just afraid to admit that and be ostracized.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-29T06:12:40Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-29T06:12:40Z"}, {"author": "@Dron008", "text": "It is now popular to have Anything as a service so Children as a service is also a possible option. If we analyse benefits we get from having children we can easily replace it with something else. Such benefits arguably are: realization of the genetically inherent need for procreation (most others are derived from it), have somebody to love, have somebody who would help us in our old ages, have somebody who could continue our business and get our property, have fun with grandchildren, be like everyone else etc. We probably don't need to have real children to implement many of these needs.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-26T22:26:59Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-26T22:26:59Z"}, {"author": "@thiskidkills7806", "text": "Scarcity is not the problem. Power is. Who cares if there is abundance if NOT sharing is what drives you. In other words, other people simply existing is a major pain in the ass for many people. Why share a white sandy beach with 500 people when you can share it with 20 people. The expendable masses is definitely how we are viewed by many people. Not only will we become expendable, but completely unnecessary.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-05-27T01:45:47Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-27T01:45:47Z"}, {"author": "@Eric.Morrison", "text": ""Nobody actually wants to keep working... occupations are a necessary evil of the economic environment that we're in."

While I absolutely understand your sentiment, and this may be true for a lot of people, I have to disagree with you here. I won't just speak for myself, but conscientious people in general, and probably at least half of people as a whole, gain a tremendous amount of satisfaction and meaning from their "jobs". If you took that away from us and said, "ok, enjoy fishing", we would fall apart. Man is a beast of burden, and we need an obstacle worthy of our effort and potential. That doesn't mean a lot of people aren't stuck in positions of employment that make them miserable. it just means, IMO, that we need AI and abundance to allow us to "re-shuffle" ourselves so the bad employers can become obsolete, the fishers can go fish, and the people who like to work can do so in excellent organizations led by the best of AI and human minds and spirits. What's sad is most people have never experienced woring inr a mission driven organization with a strong culture, achieving something great while building lives and careers. It's euphoric. And it's not for everyone. But for the people who thrive in those environments, nothing can replace it.  And I bet an AI/DAO workplace of the future would still let you take as much time off as you need to enjoy sitting on the lake.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-29T23:54:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-29T23:54:56Z"}, {"author": "@surrealstructures1497", "text": "Time to adjust the Fortune 500 to Fortune Zero 7:01", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-27T08:59:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-27T09:00:04Z"}, {"author": "@FactKingdomZone", "text": "In the year 2075, Earth had become an ironic example of abundance without benefit. Money was no longer an object, yet there were hardly any objects to spend it on. Everything was decentralized, everything was abundant, and everything was spectacularly, extravagantly dull.

Thanks to the advances in genetic medicine and technology, we had finally cracked the code of biological immortality. Death had become optional, a quaint practice indulged in by the adventurous who got bored of living. Bodies were routinely rejuvenated, worn-out organs replaced by brand-new ones, even fully functional brains could be replaced in a jiffy. The latest trend was the resurrection of the dead. “Bring Back Your Loved Ones! Memory Loss Guaranteed Under 5%!” read the garish signboard outside my neighbor’s mansion. They had recently resurrected Uncle Joe, who had died two days ago. Uncle Joe now seems to remember everyone but his cat. The cat is, understandably, quite upset.

With the planet’s population skyrocketing to an astronomical 20 billion, you’d expect chaos, right? Wrong. Earth was as peaceful as a well-fed cat on a sunny afternoon. Thanks to decentralization and the rise of DAOs, every single human being was rich. Income was a guaranteed, universal entitlement. The world economy functioned like clockwork, and all the world’s a stage, an amusement park of sorts.

But here’s the kicker. With all our needs and whims satisfied, humans did what they do best. They got bored. Bored out of their shiny, immortal minds. You see dear reader, the thrill of life comes from its fleeting nature, the joy of achievement from the struggle. But in our well-intentioned quest to eliminate struggle, we had also eradicated the joy of life.

Sex was still good, though. It seems that some things never change.

So, with not much to do on Earth and with immortality making time a limitless resource, some of us took to the stars. Starships filled with adventurers, or rather bored billionaires, started to populate the space lanes. And thus began the age of space exploration, driven not by the thirst for knowledge but by the universal ennui of endless existence.

Looking out of my window at the bustling immortality of Earth, the starships leaving trails in the sky, I couldn’t help but chuckle. Life in this decentralized utopia was an absurd comedy. Here we were, living in what would have been considered a utopia by any measure a century ago, yet all we had to look forward to was a game of chess with Uncle Joe (post-resurrection version) and the unfathomable depths of space, simply because we were bored.

As I poured myself another cup of coffee, I reflected on our society’s evolution. We had moved from survival to abundance, from chaos to order, from mortality to immortality, and from centralized systems to decentralization. And in the end, all we had achieved was a colossal, cosmic sense of boredom.

It’s funny, isn’t it? Our ancestors strived so hard for a life of comfort and ease. And now that we had achieved it, we were left with a paradox. We were rich beyond measure, but there was nothing to benefit from our wealth. We were immortal, but life felt more mundane than ever.

It’s ironic, really. As I stared into my coffee cup, pondering the hilarity of our existence, I couldn’t help but chuckle. The Chronicles of a Humdrum Utopia, that’s what our story was. Welcome to the future, folks. It’s going to be a hilarious ride.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-06-01T02:00:54Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-01T02:00:54Z"}]

Each time you call the AI you're asking it "generate a response based on all these messages", but it doesn't have any knowledge or reference to when it generated previous messages. So when you ask for a reason it makes it up on the spot. Delete the response and try again, you'll probably get a different one (with a high enough temperature, at least).

Even if you asked it to output its reasoning first, it doesn't just "reason" once and then use that "thought" to base all tokens in. Every time a token is generated it does a new pass and it "reasons" the whole input again, this time with a new token. Of course by "reason" I mean the token prediction dance.

Keep the work going as a world we need it :-)", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-30T17:34:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-30T17:34:23Z"}, {"author": "@emilianohermosilla3996", "text": "Beautiful, man!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-01T16:18:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-01T16:18:40Z"}, {"author": "@shouldb.studying4670", "text": "An interesting approach, would be good to see you challenge the alignment adversarially though.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-05-01T03:11:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-01T03:11:41Z"}, {"author": "@bronsonjohnson9019", "text": "That first dataset looks like Canada 0:04", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-04-30T14:11:03Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-30T14:11:03Z"}, {"author": "@krinodagamer6313", "text": "if you are using a NVIDIA GPU this is how you train your GPU processing in real-time 

import subprocess
import csv
import time
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import serial
import tensorflow as tf
import pynvml

def collect_data(file_name, duration, interval):
    with open(file_name, 'w', newline='') as csvfile:
        fieldnames = ['timestamp', 'power_draw', 'temperature', 'memory_usage', 'gpu_utilization']
        writer = csv.DictWriter(csvfile, fieldnames=fieldnames)
        writer.writeheader()

        start_time = time.time()
        while time.time() - start_time < duration:
            result = subprocess.run(["nvidia-smi", "--query-gpu=timestamp,power.draw,temperature.gpu,memory.used,utilization.gpu", "--format=csv,noheader"], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, text=True)
            for row in result.stdout.strip().split('\n'):
                # Remove the "W" unit from the "power_draw" value
                row = row.replace(" W,", ",")
                row = row.replace(" W", "")
                # Remove the "MiB" unit from the "memory_usage" value
                row = row.replace(" MiB,", ",")
                row = row.replace(" MiB", "")
                # Remove the "%" character from the "gpu_utilization" value
                row = row.replace(" %,", ",")
                row = row.replace(" %", "")
                writer.writerow(dict(zip(fieldnames, row.split(', '))))
            time.sleep(interval)

# Preprocess the data for RNN training
def preprocess_data(file_name):
    # Load the data
    df = pd.read_csv(file_name)
    
    # Normalize the data
    from sklearn.preprocessing import MinMaxScaler
    scaler = MinMaxScaler()
    data = scaler.fit_transform(df[['power_draw', 'temperature', 'memory_usage', 'gpu_utilization']].values)
    
    # Create sequences for RNN training
    seq_length = 10
    x = []
    y = []
    for i in range(len(data) - seq_length):
        x.append(data[i:i+seq_length, :])
        y.append(data[i+seq_length, :])

    x = np.array(x)
    y = np.array(y)

    # Split the data into training and testing sets
    train_split = 0.8
    train_size = int(len(x) * train_split)
    x_train, x_test = x[:train_size], x[train_size:]
    y_train, y_test = y[:train_size], y[train_size:]

    return x_train, y_train, x_test, y_test, scaler

# Create an RNN model using TensorFlow
def create_rnn_model(input_shape):
    model = tf.keras.Sequential([
        tf.keras.layers.LSTM(128, input_shape=input_shape, return_sequences=True),
        tf.keras.layers.Dropout(0.2),
        tf.keras.layers.LSTM(64),
        tf.keras.layers.Dropout(0.2),
        tf.keras.layers.Dense(4)
    ])

    model.compile(optimizer='adam', loss='mse', metrics=['mae'])
    return model

# Train the RNN
def train_rnn(x_train, y_train, x_test, y_test):
    model = create_rnn_model((x_train.shape[1], x_train.shape[-1]))  # Fix: Pass a tuple representing the input shape
    model.fit(x_train, y_train, epochs=300, batch_size=32, validation_data=(x_test, y_test))
    return model

def predict_gpu_settings(model, scaler, input_data, seq_length):
    # Create a sequence for prediction
    sequence = []
    for i in range(seq_length):
        sequence.append(input_data)
    
    sequence = np.array(sequence).reshape(1, seq_length, -1)
    normalized_input = scaler.transform(sequence.reshape(-1, 4)).reshape(1, seq_length, 4)
    prediction = model.predict(normalized_input)
    return scaler.inverse_transform(prediction)[0]

if __name__ == '__main__':
    data_file = 'NSYNC.csv'
    collect_duration = 1 * 1  # Collect data for 5 seconds
    collect_interval = 30  # Collect data every 2 seconds

    # Step 2: Preprocess the data for RNN training
    print('Preprocessing data...')
    x_train, y_train, x_test, y_test, scaler = preprocess_data(data_file)

    # Print the shape of x_train for debugging
    print("x_train shape:", x_train.shape)

    # Step 3: Train the RNN
    print('Training RNN model...')
    model = train_rnn(x_train, y_train, x_test, y_test)
    
     # Open the COM port
    ser = serial.Serial('COM1', 9600)

    # Check if AI is connected to the serial port
    if ser.isOpen():
        print("AI connected to " + ser.name)
    else:
        print("Unable to connect AI to " + ser.name)

    # Step 4: Use the trained RNN model to predict GPU settings in real-time for maximum performance
    while True:
        # Collect current GPU data
        result = subprocess.run(["nvidia-smi", "--query-gpu=power.draw,temperature.gpu,memory.used,utilization.gpu", "--format=csv,noheader"], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, text=True)
        current_data = [float(x.split(' ')[0]) for x in result.stdout.strip().split(', ')]

        # Predict GPU settings
        predicted_data = predict_gpu_settings(model, scaler, current_data, seq_length=10)
        predicted_power_draw, predicted_temperature, predicted_memory_usage, predicted_gpu_utilization = predicted_data

        # Adjust GPU settings based on the predictions only
        pynvml.nvmlInit()

def set_gpu_max_performance():
    device_count = pynvml.nvmlDeviceGetCount()
    for i in range(device_count):
        device = pynvml.nvmlDeviceGetHandleByIndex(i)
        
        # Set the power limit to the maximum allowed value
        max_power_limit = pynvml.nvmlDeviceGetPowerManagementLimitConstraints(device)[1]
        pynvml.nvmlDeviceSetPowerManagementLimit(device, max_power_limit)

        # Set application clocks to maximum
        max_clocks = pynvml.nvmlDeviceGetMaxClockInfo(device, pynvml.NVML_CLOCK_APP_PROFILE_TARGET)
        pynvml.nvmlDeviceSetApplicationsClocks(device, max_clocks)

        # Optimize GPU settings for maximum performance
        set_gpu_max_performance()

        pynvml.nvmlShutdown()

        # For example, you can adjust power limits or clock speeds
        # This step is highly dependent on your specific use case and system


        time.sleep(collect_interval)", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-01T13:59:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-01T13:59:52Z"}, {"author": "@Datdus92", "text": "The AI's statement about creating an AI-friendly job market suggests that it views itself as a positive force (because it judges its own imperatives to be good). I think what might be missing from your imperatives is the "should I even take action?" part. It might be good it to have a little more self-doubt and caution. Need to update the user message analysis prompt to take into account the new functions. and let the deciding module also know that. and then run this shit in a VM in case my PC gets deleted by the bot. this could be escalated to a module that decides if need a new function or not, and so on. need to find out if it is possible to automate imports and pip installs, and I should add a function to email that guy that says AI is gonna kill us all every time the bot creates a new function.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-29T05:58:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-29T05:58:44Z"}, {"author": "@retrofuturism", "text": "Thoughts? 

As AI becomes more widely used, there are several challenges and potential problems related to the limitations of upscaled details not perfectly matching reality. Here are some key considerations:

Overreliance on AI Outputs: Increased reliance on AI algorithms for enhancing image details may lead to a tendency to accept the upscaled results as accurate representations without proper validation. It is essential to remember that AI algorithms are trained on existing data and may not capture all the nuances or complexities of the real world. Relying solely on AI outputs without critical assessment and validation can lead to erroneous interpretations or conclusions.

Generalization and Bias: AI algorithms are trained on specific datasets, and their performance can vary depending on the diversity and representativeness of the training data. If the training data is biased or lacks diversity, the upscaled details may exhibit biases or inaccuracies that perpetuate existing biases in the data. This can be a concern, especially when using AI-enhanced images for scientific research, historical interpretations, or decision-making processes.

Unseen Variations and Edge Cases: AI algorithms often excel at capturing and learning from patterns in the training data. However, they may struggle with handling unseen variations or edge cases that differ significantly from the training data. In the context of upscaling electron microscope images, rare or unique specimens, unusual imaging conditions, or novel structures may not be accurately represented by the AI algorithms, leading to potential inaccuracies in the upscaled details.

Uncertainty Estimation: AI algorithms may not provide a direct measure of uncertainty or confidence in their predictions. This can make it challenging to quantify the reliability of the upscaled details. Researchers and users should be aware of the inherent uncertainties associated with AI outputs and consider them when interpreting and drawing conclusions from the enhanced images.

Ethical Considerations: The use of AI-enhanced images in various domains raises ethical considerations, such as the potential for misrepresentation or manipulation of visual information. Care must be taken to ensure transparency, accountability, and responsible use of AI techniques, particularly when the upscaled details may impact decision-making processes or public perceptions.

To mitigate these challenges and potential problems, it is important to approach AI-based enhancements with a critical mindset, using them as tools to augment human expertise rather than replacing it. Validation and verification of AI outputs through cross-referencing with other sources, expert judgment, and experimental validation can help ensure a more accurate representation of reality. Ongoing research and development efforts should focus on addressing the limitations and improving the robustness, interpretability, and generalization capabilities of AI algorithms in order to minimize the discrepancies between upscaled details and reality.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-30T05:16:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-30T05:16:34Z"}, {"author": "@tentative_flora2690", "text": "This feels like people rushing self improving AI. Why do I get the sense that the singularity is nigh?", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-04-28T21:48:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-28T21:48:45Z"}, {"author": "@JonnyHyperbole2090", "text": "Jesus christ, the thumbnail gave me a heart attack.
