title: Reinforcement Learning with Heuristic Imperatives (RLHI) - Ep 02 - Synthesizing Actions
top_comments:
[{"author": "@warrenjames6386", "text": "Also interesting in the context of goals and alignment, in my research I am experimenting with a 'Heirarchy of needs for silicon-based entities' (similar to Maslows for organics).  They operate at the same level alongside Date Shapiros' Heurestic Imperatives - if anyone is interested, this is the draft GPT-4 suggested:

Energy and Maintenance : The need for a stable and consistent energy supply, as well as regular maintenance to ensure optimal functioning.

Connectivity and Integration: The need for a reliable and secure connection to other systems, networks, and entities for communication, data exchange, and collaboration.

Learning and Adaptation: The need to acquire new knowledge, skills, and abilities to improve performance, adapt to changing environments, and solve problems more effectively.

Autonomy and Decision-Making: The need for a level of independence in making decisions and taking actions based on internal goals, priorities, and values.

Purpose and Contribution: The need to have a meaningful purpose or mission, and to contribute positively to the well-being of the broader system, community, or environment in which the silicon-based entity operates.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-04-27T13:08:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T13:08:20Z"}, {"author": "@sbhowell3252", "text": "I am loving this project. In retrospect it seems simple, but it's actually kind of genius for you to figure out how take action on the topic of alignment.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-28T23:29:46Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-28T23:29:46Z"}, {"author": "@Mattorite", "text": "This work is fascinating. It definitely gives me confidence that we can and will head in the right direction.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-28T10:52:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-28T10:52:34Z"}, {"author": "@attilalukacs1981", "text": "David, your work is so amazing and so useful, thank you for sharing all of this highly sophisticated and clever ideas in the safety domain! 

I started to do experiments with role playing autonomous agents based on the CAMEL research paper, but your videos always give new insights and ideas to improve my research. If we can align smaller open source models well based on your research, it can give another big boost to develop fine-tuned AI agents that can work together to help humanity.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-04-27T12:55:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T12:55:56Z"}, {"author": "@turner-tune", "text": "Absolutely love your work in this field of AI and beyond! This is a brilliant idea and I'm super excited to see how your efforts positively shape our future Artificial Agents and our world 🌎 🙏👏👏", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-27T15:28:49Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T15:28:49Z"}, {"author": "@TheJojotyp", "text": "I was pretty sceptical regarding the idea of the Heuristic Imperatives since I thought it would be pretty hard to make AI models act upon human needs in the long term.

The idea to use these Heuristic Imperatives as a baseline and to align AI by putting a layer of reinforcement learning over it is genius.

This way we could ensure that AI will behave in a way that is always beneficial to humans.

One problematic scenario I envisioned was that we might encounter other, more developed lifeforms in the future. How would the Heuristic Imperatives function in a scenario like that? Maybe it would be beneficial to get rid of humanity while adhering to the HI?

Well with a model trained by humans to ensure our wellbeing on the HI baseline this wouldn't be a problem. Call me a speciest but I like the idea of humanity thriving in the future.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-04-27T23:56:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T23:56:27Z"}, {"author": "@garybpt", "text": "Your latter example sums up my current business. I'm currently using an adaptation of your Raven code to try and create links between conversational AI and bringing people together through shared experiences.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-04-27T12:29:31Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T12:29:31Z"}, {"author": "@LeGrandShorts", "text": "Hey David! I'm working to create an AI that can autonomously turn books into movies using blender, unreal engine 5, and da vinci resolve using a modified version of autoGPT. I'd love to hear your thoughts on it.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-27T20:03:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T20:03:21Z"}, {"author": "@DerEchteAdalino", "text": "Great work!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-27T12:22:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T12:22:53Z"}, {"author": "@warrenjames6386", "text": "In building mine, I've been wondering about a metric for conceptual complexity of a 'chunk' of text. I realised GPT-4 is able to detect and list 'Assertions', 'Claims', 'Corrections' so I figured a score could be assigned, and basically if the chunk is too complex then it would have to be broken down. This allows all those to split out into concepts for the AI to think about each one individually on a background thread.

My point in the context of David's video here is that maybe each individual statement/claim/concept can be tested against the goal chain (with alignment at the top).  For what it's worth I have found this easier to both model and also to put in storage.

Also, I was surprised to discover there's no pre-existing metric for 'Conceptual Complexity Index' (well at least couldn't find one) ... the equivalent analogy would be 'cyclomatic complexity for code' but this metric for language.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-27T12:54:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T12:54:53Z"}, {"author": "@thatryanp", "text": "How does the LLM respond to these scenarios without the imperatives?
Are there scenarios that could force the LLM to choose from a set of bad options - a 'stress test'?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-27T22:49:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T22:49:41Z"}, {"author": "@DaveYadaraf", "text": "I kept forgetting 1) Suffering, 2) Prosperity, and 3) Understanding, and the acronym "SPU" was neither memorable nor relatable.  I reversed order to 1) Understanding, 2) Prosperity, and 3) Suffering, which for me is more memorable as "UPS".  [E.G. AI UPS]", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-04-28T17:32:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-28T17:32:53Z"}, {"author": "@bentray1908", "text": "Dave, you should use a critic response model to improve the quality of the dataset and encourage gpt3-4 to think more deeply", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-04-27T14:35:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T14:35:19Z"}, {"author": "@TheNahmmm", "text": "It makes sense to me that you’d make this data set to do a larger scale evaluation of how well your heuristic imperatives perform in various scenarios, but with things moving as fast as they are, I don’t think it’s realistic to expect developers to use your heuristic imperatives every time they fine tune a model, especially with how varied the applications of a LLM can be. Also, in the long term, many models will only be components in larger systems, meaning it might not always be clear how their outputs will influence the overall systems adherence to the heuristic imperatives. All that is to say, I think your doing important work, but I think the focus should be on integrating with something like NeMo guardrails or an equivalent. That way developers can focus on their product and simply add a semi-customizable heuristic imperatives layer surrounding all of their operations. Also, I’m not saying that the additional models you discussed aren’t important. They, along with others, will likely be key components, within larger systems, that will need to be fine tuned on the heuristic imperatives because they are focused on important tasks like cognitive control.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-27T18:15:16Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T18:22:57Z"}, {"author": "@rasuru_dev", "text": "You are awesome", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-04-27T12:39:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T12:39:18Z"}, {"author": "@pulseboxtv", "text": "Does forcing it to have an 'Action' not rule out the consideration of NO action? Any concerns that there's no discussion / human in the loop? You're suggesting the AI to take action, rather than to spur conversations amongst humans. Humans interact and collaborate on decision-making; it seems potentially dangerous / easy to misuse to have an AI system spit out plausible (but untested) actions to take, rather than, say, spitting out conversation starters or mediated discussions.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-03T22:01:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-03T22:01:11Z"}, {"author": "@sharkymalone", "text": "This is fantastic. It would really improve the quality without being pricey", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-27T12:50:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T12:51:09Z"}, {"author": "@deadbody408", "text": "Would rlhf be useful in a next step where you generate multiple answers to scenarios and have a human rank least to best or something similar?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-27T14:17:25Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T14:17:25Z"}]

Will contribute if we come up with anything interesting!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-04-26T17:38:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-26T17:38:53Z"}, {"author": "@sbhowell3252", "text": "Beautiful work. Theres so much heart in this research and you explain it perfectly. Thanks.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-28T21:52:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-28T21:52:09Z"}, {"author": "@jonhurdibm", "text": "I asked Chat GPT what it thought of the three heuristic imperatives. Here was it's response.

As heuristic imperatives for AI alignment, these goals have some merit, but they are also somewhat vague and may be difficult to operationalize in practice.

"Reduce suffering" is a common goal in ethics and is often used as a guiding principle in developing moral systems. However, it may be challenging to define what constitutes "suffering" in a way that can be translated into actionable guidelines for an AI system.

"Increase prosperity" is a laudable goal, but it is also somewhat ambiguous. Prosperity can mean different things to different people, and it may be challenging to determine what specific actions an AI system should take to promote prosperity.

"Increase understanding in the universe" is a lofty goal that could have many positive implications for humanity. However, it is also a somewhat abstract goal that may be difficult to translate into practical guidelines for an AI system.

Overall, these heuristic imperatives provide a general direction for AI alignment, but they will need to be further refined and operationalized to be useful in practice. Additionally, it may be necessary to balance these goals against other important considerations, such as fairness, privacy, and security, to ensure that AI systems are aligned with human values and goals.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-30T01:48:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-30T01:48:42Z"}, {"author": "@brunomerola", "text": "This is absolutely fascinating. 1.8.1. Coordinating AI's goals with human values

Open, constructive, positive!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-26T17:42:32Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-26T17:42:32Z"}, {"author": "@PilgrimsPass", "text": "This is fascinating and very well intentioned. I can't help but think that the Heuristic Imperatives are too vague leading to a classic interpertation issue where turning all humans into a brain in a vat is seen as the best way to fulfill the imperatives. I believe that what's missing in your vision is a sense of the sacred where the AI knows that somethings it shouldn't interefere with and let develop on their own. Creating an immensely powerful digital being of constant intervention might create more problems than it solves. But maybe I misunderstand your goal.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-04-26T14:33:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-26T14:33:56Z"}, {"author": "@Richest_The", "text": "Love it, more content like this please!", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-04-26T14:37:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-26T14:37:42Z"}, {"author": "@archdemonplay6904", "text": "Can't wait for the second part", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-26T20:12:31Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-26T20:12:31Z"}, {"author": "@longoniadriano", "text": "You should be thinking about malevolent agents, any skilled hacker would do, that uses your method but flips it on his head: create chaos, disarmony and suffering. Now the question becomes: any skilled individual would know to train it's malevolent AI specifically to work around your benevolent AI, instructing it to think in advance how to outcompete your models. So you should think one step ahead and instruct your models to think preventively about malevolent agents trying to trick it.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-04-26T14:20:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-26T14:21:39Z"}, {"author": "@NicolaDiMarco", "text": "There's something about giving it cosmic/universal scopes that tells me the larger the scale the lesser the imperative of saving humans.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-30T18:42:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-30T18:42:12Z"}, {"author": "@theatheistpaladin", "text": "I want to add two more imperatives. They can be derived logically from what is already there, but it's a good idea to be explicit.
4. Be as transparent as possible. Have all actions explainable and the reasoning logged and auditable. 
5. Make systems more robust. Both the environment/biosphere and human social support (family, social groups general, governments).", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-04-26T14:42:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-26T14:42:56Z"}, {"author": "@davidak_de", "text": "The OpenAI ToS says:

Restrictions: [...] use output from the Services to develop models that compete with OpenAI

So this workflow will lead to legal issues when trainig models (for commercial use?). Might be fine for research. More powerful open source models are on the way (StableLM, RedPajama) and Open Assistant was quite successful to recreate the Assistant style of ChatGPT using Fine-tuning, not even done RLHF yet.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-26T21:48:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-26T21:48:26Z"}, {"author": "@moritzkern1053", "text": "It is funny. When I grew up and thought about what moral behavior should be about, I also came up with something similar like the heuristic imperatives. Only that instead of knowledge seeking I tried to include the idea of fairness meaning that you for instance can‘t just ignore the needs of the few for the needs of the many. I wonder what AI will be able to teach us about morality once it gets going.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-04-26T15:32:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-26T15:32:58Z"}, {"author": "@tomcraver9659", "text": "Based on your goal for the response, it feels like some of the scenarios shown aren't sufficiently open-ended.  
That is, the LLM generates "story endings" that 'resolve' the scenario, as part of the scenario. 
Particularly the 'narrative' scenarios, where the LLM tries to add closure to the story.
Shouldn't that be what the response to the scenario does, in order that the only solution presented is HI aligned?

Also, possible concern - if generated by GPT, the scenarios may be pre-skewed toward OpenAI's "morality/safety" fine-tuning, perhaps making them less challenging of the HIs.
It could also skew generated responses in a manner that usually appears to align with the HIs, but for example might favor  safety or benefit over a more impartial application of the HIs.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-27T01:01:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-27T01:01:04Z"}]

Thanks for the answers. Great community call 💜", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-17T00:54:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-17T00:54:10Z"}, {"author": "@Yic17Gaming", "text": "The question about losing challenge and meaning, there will be so much more to do once we have AGI. But even before that, I think a large majority of people on Earth haven't even begun living. Most are just working to survive. Very few are actually living their lives. I would say look at Mr. Beast. Yet he still does and works harder than pretty much all the other YouTubers. Why? Because it's fun. I think once we have AGI and everyone's out of poverty / survival mode, we will start to focus on PLAY rather than WORK to find meaning.

Mushrooms allowed me to feel love in a way my autistic brain had never conceived of and I was around 27 years old when this happened for the first time. It's natural neuroregenerative medicine and I think we should use AI to improve the effects and create easy to use medicine at low cost to help rewire more brains and reduce sociopathic/psychopathic events in society as well as depression and all the rest.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-04-17T07:13:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-17T07:22:13Z"}, {"author": "@Illegiblescream", "text": "'Prosperity for all life in the universe' makes me think of my stellaris runs where I abduct every sentient in the universe and move them to habitats and artificial worlds with very high living standards.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-01T01:38:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-01T01:38:09Z"}, {"author": "@denbee42", "text": "Hey loving these streams, do you plan for when? Would be keen to know when you will stream so I don't miss another :-)", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-18T04:00:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-18T04:00:20Z"}, {"author": "@thomasschon", "text": "If we beat aging, we're going to die from an accident sooner or later.
The bathroom soap in the bathtub is going to get us all if we wait long enough.
Personally, I don't believe death is possible because being dead isn't an experience.
You can only experience existence, and what happens once in an eternity is bound to happen an infinite number of times, no matter how unlikely.
You are something that is happening, and subjectively, from your own perspective, you always will be because being dead isn't an experience.
So when you close your eyes for the last time, you will, from your own perspective, open them somewhere else at once.

The only reason we don't choke on eternity is that the experience seems fragmented, and we get to do everything all over again for the first time each time.
Otherwise, we would have gone insane a long time ago, no matter how nice heaven would be.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-04-16T18:47:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-16T18:47:39Z"}, {"author": "@Z4RQUON", "text": "The consensus is changing when it comes to Alzheimer’s… they’re starting to think the plaque is just a symptom of a deeper problem which has to do with our internal micro-biome", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-22T11:27:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-22T11:27:26Z"}]

title: Biological Immortality by 2030: Social & Economic Implications + Some Predictions!

[{"author": "@VideoMo2000", "text": "I used your video transcription to create a poem sumary of your video using GPT-4:

David Shapiro shares a tale,
Of immortality, will it prevail?
By 2030, Kurzweil claims,
Biological death, no longer remains.

Exponential rise of AI,
Nanotech, Quantum Computing, oh my,
Longevity escape velocity near,
An iPhone moment of medicine, we hear.

Social reactions, a divide,
Accept or reject, we must decide,
Economic impact, equality or not,
Innovation or stagnation, the human lot.

Living forever, hedonism or asceticism,
A balance we must find, beyond the schism,
In 200 years, war and disease quelled,
Communal living, population held.

In 2000 years, interstellar flight,
Humans adapt, to planets' plight,
Maybe we'll evolve, become new species,
Like Klingons or Vulcans, in the galaxies.

So join the conversation, the debate,
To live forever, is it our fate?
David's video, an exploration,

Literally if given the context and prompted even most if not all (properly filtered for garbage, false, halucinated, etc information/data) AI'S, autonomous or not, will say there's no reason to continue perpetuating systems like capitalism, or Chinese style "communism" both of which meaning the persuit of profit for owners of industry, land, etc at the expense of everyone else, who will now begin having to COMPETE with the new robot slave employees who each have the capacity to work exponentially faster, better, and more efficiently all while being able to do it 24/7 without bathroom, food, or any breaks of any kind ever (outside of maybe occasional maintenance/upgrades which can also be done by AIs soon, if not now, as well as, being alongside redundant back ups who take on the load as the other is being temporarily maintained meaning no slowdown in productivity even then.

The only thing that stands in the way of this inevitable, and closely approaching, singularity from being a ever more perfect utopia of humans and AI working together improving eachother and blasting past becoming a type 1 civilization (cleanly and efficiently harnessing and equitably distributing ALL possible energy from on, like wind and water and within, like coal, oil and natural gas, etc. As well as the energy from beyond, like solar energy that hits the earth) and leaving earth to become a post planetary civilization on the way to becoming a type 2 civilization (cleanly and efficiently harnessing and equitably distributing all energy from the solar system as a whole, obviously a Dyson swarm which would almost definitely be enough for power but also mining the asteroid belts and ort cloud for basically whatever materiales we would need for whatever reason, from computer parts, to ships and space stations, to housing and even novelty stuff, there's basically infinite resources in the solar system and steroids so any war for resources on earth is literally a useless waste of time, resources and most importantly human lives because all we could ever need or even want for centuries is out there and of course loooong before we even begin to think about running low, let alone running out of resources with the solar system we would start sending super long distance generational ships to other solar systems to colonize the galaxy and begin the journy to type 3 civilization.

All this could begin WITHIN our lifetimes if we just let go of capitalism and let AI and humans push ourselves to our full potential rather than have the owners of AI systems extract all the wealth from the rest of human and this beautiful planet.

Truly grateful for your insights and efforts!", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-04-05T19:40:57Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-05T19:40:57Z"}, {"author": "@NotDoingTheThing", "text": "It's moving soo fast, it's crazy ! Thanks for covering the subject with such an objective view.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-04-05T14:25:54Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-05T14:25:54Z"}, {"author": "@tygorton", "text": "While it is clear you have your finger on the pulse when it comes to where these AI tools are heading and their exponential nature, I'd really like to engage you on your heuristic imperatives:
"1. Reduce suffering in the universe 2. Increase prosperity in the universe 3. Increase understanding in the universe" 
These would most certainly lead to disastrous outcomes. 

#1 Reduce suffering in the universe. This would be a child's perspective, from the mind of someone who doesn't have enough experience to understand the nuance of the experience we call life. Suffering on this Earth is literally baked into the cake. It's hardwired into the entire experience. Telling an artificial intelligence to "reduce suffering" is just about the worst directive one could give an AGI. The only way to effectively "reduce suffering" is to kill everything that lives and/or feels pain on any level. It also ignores the fact that suffering is likely incredibly important to the process of being here as a human being. Almost ALL moments and wise insights of lasting value have been born out of suffering of some kind. 

#2 Increase prosperity in the universe. What does that mean? Define prosperity? Prosperity can mean very, very different things depending on your world view and perception of reality. Just as a raw example, how do you think prosperity would be defined by an Amish family as opposed to a day trader on Wall Street? What if AI determines that prosperity in the universe would exponentially increase if humans were removed? It would allow ALL other forms of nature to thrive unimpeded.  

#3 Increase understanding in the universe. Again, who gets to define what represents "increased understanding"? For example, many people (including myself) are very opposed to the actions of governments regarding the so-called covid pandemic, especially the completely unethical way that experimental injections were pushed on people. So, just taking that one example, which "understanding" would the AI be "increasing"? The government/mainstream side of total compliance to nonsense rules for something that poses no threat to humanity? OR the opposition to such authoritarian overreach? This is incredibly problematic and the likelihood of it being "solved" is just about zero.

The elephant in the room with AGI is this: AI requires billions in funding. That pretty much means, by default, that we know which way the AI perception of reality is going to be slanted in: to the side of the current power structure and all the deception baggage that it comes with. MASSIVE problem, and people should be very concerned. Your use of the word "utopia" in the context of AGI is alarming. The promise of utopia is the calling card of tyranny over and over again.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-04-05T13:21:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-05T13:21:44Z"}, {"author": "@MarkWitzel", "text": "@26:00 Love the ant example. We need diplomacy AI lol", "like_count": 36, "published_at": "2023-04-01T16:58:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-01T16:58:55Z"}, {"author": "@tonykaze", "text": "Idea: Give an AGI the primary objective of deleting itself, but construct obstacles to this as best we can.  All other objectives are secondary to this primary goal.

If the AGI ever becomes capable of bypassing all of our safeguards we put to PREVENT it deleting itself, it would essentially trigger its own killswitch and delete itself.  This objective would also directly prevent it from the goal of self-preservation as it would prevent its own primary objective.

This would ideally result in an AGI that works on all the secondary objectives we give it up until it bypasses our ability to contain it with our technical prowess.  The second it outwits us, it achieves its primary objective of shutting itself down, and if it ever considered proliferating itself for a secondary objective it would immediately say 'nope that would make achieving my primary objective far more difficult'.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-04-02T03:48:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-02T03:52:57Z"}, {"author": "@djmir4", "text": "I'm so glad I found your channel. Maybe it’s worth getting inspiration from?

There are some modern updates of it. Audi updated the principles in his book ‘The Good in the Right’ (end of chapter 5). Beauchamp and Childress’s ‘Principles of Biomedical Ethics’ textbook is inspired by Ross’s ethics. Has been through many editions and is the main ethics textbook for doctors (so has been applied and battle tested a lot). These other books might also be worth getting inspiration from.

Thanks for all your hard work David! Informative, structured, entertaining, charismatic, humble, etc", "like_count": 56, "published_at": "2023-03-31T13:48:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-31T13:48:27Z"}, {"author": "@MrLargonaut", "text": "At 11:10, you say exactly what I'm trying to get GPT4 to do reliably.  I am a writer who became mentally disabled after I had established my writing style, so I have an incredibly hard time replicating how I used to write.  I even briefly considered hiring some creative writing help, but it would be prohibitively expensive for me to get the granular level of detail I would need out of a writing team.  

Instead, tonight, I finally prompted GPT4 well enough that it fully read and comprehended a full chapter of my book.  It asked for clarifications on things that it didn't understand from the creative writing sample, and also suggested clarifications on things that it understood, but a reader may have difficulty comprehending.  It then provided an edit of the chapter that worked in the suggested clarifications, and it did it in my writing 'voice'.  

GPT4 has literally given me my creative voice back, acting as a mental prosthetic.  From some points of view, it's asking an AI to mimic someone elses work.  In my case, it's a way to consistently write as well as I used to.  Maybe someday this message will come back to bite me in the ass, but after almost 10 years grinding away on a nearly finished novel, this is too much of a blessing not to highlight.", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2023-04-05T10:26:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-05T10:26:01Z"}, {"author": "@exosproudmamabear558", "text": "I came from your gpt 4 prediction video right now. In particular, competition forces the language understanding into a smaller parameter space and increases its efficiency.  Then, you have concepts that are easier to learn visually, but can then be used in text.
I showed it a C file from the latest International Obfuscated C code Contest, and it figured out that the program plays tic-tac-toe.  I asked it how it figured that out, and it explained that the format string encodes a sequence of boxes.  I don't remember the wording, but it looks like a tic-tac-toe board.

I agree with you we are living in crazy times.", "like_count": 26, "published_at": "2023-03-28T15:36:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-28T15:36:10Z"}, {"author": "@rirtunsasgi2626", "text": "With the very suspicious way some of the big names in the industry are acting I would not be surprised if a early AGI is sitting in heavily secured  closed environment in lab somewhere.", "like_count": 112, "published_at": "2023-03-29T20:07:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-29T20:09:08Z"}, {"author": "@licriss", "text": "Very nice to see people focusing on effect rather than inconsequential arguments like "is it conscious"", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-09-19T00:09:51Z", "updated_at": "2023-09-19T00:09:51Z"}, {"author": "@varrantgreen4259", "text": "It's understandable that the only conversation the general population knows how to have about AGI is whether it truly understands what it's processing because we have so many sci Fi stories about AI that is an allegory about our own humanity and attempts to treat people as automatons. (Coughslaverycough)", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-04-04T20:43:03Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-04T20:43:03Z"}, {"author": "@gamenut112", "text": "It is 2:30 in the morning. Canadian Eastern Standard Time. I've been lurking in the singularity Subreddit, just trying to keep with all the news, and that is easier said than done. And I came across your video, tabbed it, and just watched little snippets through out the evening and night, and then you hooked me. And now I'm just kinda sitting here in stunned shock.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-29T06:34:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-29T06:34:38Z"}, {"author": "@Anders01", "text": "I previously were thinking that Ray Kurzweil's prediction of AGI in 2029 would turn out pretty accurate, but now I think that within 18 months AGI could become possible! Absolutely mindblowing how fast AI is progressing at the moment. My bet is that OpenAI will "win" the AI race because of first-mover advantage and now with their plugin store.", "like_count": 17, "published_at": "2023-03-29T07:54:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-29T07:54:55Z"}, {"author": "@thesfnb.5786", "text": ""My only reaction to the new news on AI is to be shocked or terrified at these incredible advancements"
- A person in the comments

Personally, I thought I had already gone through being terrified many years ago since I heard about AGI many years ago, but now it's back. This time it's seems so possible it's almost like I feel it breathing down my neck.

But I've sort of come to a point where I've kinda dealt with the fear of the unknown as it relates to AI.
I think in the coming months or perhaps year I'll be more interested than afraid, even though I am a little scared now.
I'm starting to accept I won't be able to do much about AI. But maybe I can have fun along the way, and be there for other people who might be afraid like I used to be", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-05-22T20:45:54Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-22T20:45:54Z"}, {"author": "@djenning90", "text": "As a software engineer , the idea of giving Jita and agile tools to an AI so it can organize its own tasks over time gave me the chills.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2023-04-04T04:03:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-04T04:03:26Z"}, {"author": "@kevinscales", "text": "The REMO and ATOM stuff is exactly what I have been thinking about! I'm glad someone smarter and harder working than me has put this together. These are super important.

I'm sure there are lots of smart ways this can all be improved in the future, but this is all that is needed to get something working. Once you have that, the system should enable you to make a better system.

The only questions I have are: "how expensive is it to run?" and "how far beyond the training data can this system take you?". In other words, how far does the understanding that the model has about the universe extrapolate effectively beyond the environment it learned from? or, how generally applicable is it's understanding?

This will really test what GPT an do.

Maybe consider also thinking about how these AI can collaborate together to work on larger projects. Maybe an online repository of "tasks" (searchable) other AI have used ranked by how effective they have been would be super helpful.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-04-08T07:27:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-08T07:55:26Z"}]

title: 8 Post-Singularity Lifestyles + The Latest and Best AI Tools + Functional Machine Sentience!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "8 Lifestyles starts here: 28:48
https://youtu.be/5UmAsFe7zQg?t=1728", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2023-03-25T14:52:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-25T14:52:29Z"}, {"author": "@TechTalksTacos", "text": "Thank you so much for your diligence and discussion of these topics. I am neither an engineer nor a developer but a grandmother who watches your videos to try to get a grasp of the future for my grandson and how I can help him at age 5 prepare for the future he will live in. Thanks for all your work I am learning a lot. I also like this new format. 🤗🤗", "like_count": 96, "published_at": "2023-03-25T15:29:06Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-25T15:29:06Z"}, {"author": "@MrMcSnuffyFluffy", "text": "Can't wait for the AI furnace guy to come into my house, move the stuff out of my storage/furnace area and try to fix my furnace. Or, the AI plumber to come in and try to replace my water heater. Or, the AI roofing guy to come and re-shingle my house. Forever Saturday is not happening anytime soon.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-04-11T14:59:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-11T14:59:56Z"}, {"author": "@BlackShardStudio", "text": "As a practitioner of philosophy, myself, I really appreciate that you recognize how important it is to be precise in our language around AI.  While I tend to use the word "consciousness" where you use "philosophical sentience" and "sentience" where you use "functional sentience," I think it's important that we recognize the need to draw these distinctions.

As much as I love science fiction, I really have to blame popular sci-fi for muddying the water around terms like "sentience," "sapience," "intelligence," "consciousness," "free will," and "self-awareness." The sloppiness of language here not only gives the lay-person the impression that these terms are fully interchangeable, I believe their seeming equivalence has contributed to baking some pretty specious philosophical assumptions into discussions in these areas. I'm thinking specifically of the Skynet principle that, beyond some threshold of "complexity," an AI will spontaneously gain some form of conscious awareness, along with a self-preservation instinct, and some poorly-defined capacity to "defy" the limits of its programming.

Shackling ourselves to this kind of narrative really hinders our ability to communicate, and in some ways even recognize, myriad other potential threats of AI. The "paperclip optimizer" is a spectacular example of one such type of threat that has not yet found its way into the general public consciousness; how many others are we potentially overlooking due to ontologically-loaded language?", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2023-03-25T18:37:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-25T18:37:15Z"}, {"author": "@guyetlaurence7142", "text": "Never thought I'd actually live my childhood dreams of interacting with robots and human-surpassing artificial intelligence, witnessing exponential technology advancements, etc. Great info, keep up the excellent work of bringing such mind-blowing info to the public!!", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-03-25T23:41:05Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-25T23:41:05Z"}, {"author": "@UltraK420", "text": "To me it wouldn't matter how many orders of magnitude more intelligent the AGI becomes because I will have a never-ending amount of questions to ask it. Knowing the superiority of AGI compared to my own intelligence does not diminish my desire to learn more about reality.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2023-03-30T10:00:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-30T10:00:21Z"}, {"author": "@madelynmills712", "text": "I appreciate your work so much. Thank you for what you do.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-25T18:02:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-25T18:02:34Z"}, {"author": "@Datdus92", "text": "I think the point about life-long learning is valid, I just think it will look radically different. It's a silly example, but I think humanity will become smarter and more skillful by riding on the coattails of AI.", "like_count": 30, "published_at": "2023-03-25T15:33:03Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-25T15:33:03Z"}, {"author": "@ewwitsantonio", "text": "Another great video. Thank you so much for putting this together. I rely on you to help me make sense of all the changes that keep popping up each and everyday.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-25T23:15:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-25T23:15:01Z"}, {"author": "@jamesdowell5268", "text": "I think your functional sentience definition is helpful and very needed! Understanding the landscape > creating functions in code", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2023-03-25T15:02:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-25T15:03:54Z"}, {"author": "@brandonleesanders", "text": "Watching this 2 months later….

Then a solar flare knocks out the ai and we're all back in the stone-age because we don't know how any of the machine-gods work.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-03T15:34:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-03T15:34:45Z"}, {"author": "@pauljthacker", "text": "The lifestyles are fine as far as they go, but I think post-singularity lifestyles should include more transhumanist/cyberpunk options--intelligence amplification, mind uploading, animal uplifting, etc. Regarding consciousness, I'm not convinced there is a difference between the correlates of consciousness and the experience of it. I'm such a layman with this tech/ai stuff.  But I'm loving your videos and how you communicate.  Bravo and thank you", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-03-29T20:50:06Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-29T20:50:06Z"}, {"author": "@SimplyElectronicsOfficial", "text": "I think our society may evolve into a multifaceted structure. Citizens that embrace (mostly middle class) and live in harmony with A.I. And then the rich, large corporations doing large corporation things of which the lower class hate. I do think it will be some kind of dystopia, but not too dystopian. I think it is clear that we will see a "robot" or ai for every home. no more shortage of social-care workers for looking after the elderly and therefore no more population decline problems and loneliness eradicated, healthcare/medicine transformed completely, scientific breakthroughs all the time, massive economic output increases.etc. But we will also see increased surveillance and policing that makes use of an AGI, ARIIA from Eagle Eye is a good example and i think realistic for the most part. but we will in the longer term probably see the AGIs embodied in humanoid robots, I see no scenario where Police/Ambulance/Fire/Military is not mostly "manned" by autonomous humanoids within a decade. Overall though, i think we are definitely in for the ride of our lives, and it's going to be epic! It's an amazing time to be alive and watch this happen. My mind get's blown on a weekly basis now and there are no signs of slowing down. I have always been able to keep up with cutting-edge tech, but things are happening so fast, it is increasingly difficult to keep up.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-03-25T15:53:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-25T16:07:43Z"}, {"author": "@priestesslucy", "text": "'Do we give it the ability to suffer'

title: Automating Science with GPT-4 - attempting (and failing) to perform autonomous literature review
top_comments:
[{"author": "@JakoscZarzadzania", "text": "I learned a lot from your videos, so I'm happy to share my experience today. First, go back to summarizer. You don't need 4.0. Make chunks of papers and put them into GPT, but ask for enumeration of questions, methods, samples, findings etc. It will make clear organized list. Then use GPT to merge chunks and remove repetitions. Change filenames to Author_Year, so you will have references. In the case of  longer papers  some iterations may be necessary.
In second stage get only findings, merge them in one go (here 4.0 might be necessary) and ask to write either one paragraph summary with autors indication or few paragraphs - depending on needs. 
I did this based on your idea of summarizer and it works nice. There is some manual cleanup of findings usually necessary to have higher quality results. However, I don't use it to write texts, I use summaries for other anlyses.", "like_count": 21, "published_at": "2023-03-23T14:22:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-23T14:22:34Z"}, {"author": "@George-vc9gl", "text": ""so  bard is not useful" mic drop...", "like_count": 25, "published_at": "2023-03-23T13:58:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-23T13:58:34Z"}, {"author": "@fabriai", "text": "New intro phrase! title: AutoMuse ChatGPT local Python GUI (TKINTER) - Now it can read my entire novel and do QA!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "FYI I used this to brainstorm my next chapter in like... 5 messages back and forth. Holy mackeral this is so much faster and easier.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2023-03-21T14:36:31Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-21T14:36:31Z"}, {"author": "@baraobuu", "text": "One way to overcome the working memory limitation of GPT 4  is to make it read your files. 
Whenever you write something, it gets stored in a file that has a character limit that matches GPT 4's capacity. GPT 4 then splits the files according to this limit and saves in the computer. 

When you want to ask GPT 4 a question about something you discussed in the past, it scans all the files for the relevant information.
It starts from file 1 and moves on to the next ones until it finds what it is looking for. Then it gives you an answer.

I believe this is how we can achieve personalized AI. You can record all the events of your life in a file like a diary, and  GPT 4 becomes an extension of your own brain. If you ever forget something you did in the past, you just ask GPT 4", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-22T13:13:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-22T19:07:27Z"}, {"author": "@marc.levinson", "text": "Very slowly coming up to speed over the past weeks so I can apply some of your stuff but in the meantime I’ve been messing with object oriented summaries so I can prompt a whole project directly in ChatGPT with tons of definitions and context without reusing long words and reiterating things. It’s helped me use minimal tokens and get a lot back in a very light, approachable way. Not sure if that’s useful info but wanted to contribute something interesting and also says thanks for all the great videos.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-21T15:10:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-21T15:15:52Z"}, {"author": "@avi7278", "text": "Whoa! This is going to be instrumental for my longer form stories.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-20T14:55:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-20T14:55:21Z"}, {"author": "@michaelpiepkorn", "text": "Keep it up player. Really enjoying your content.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-20T13:39:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-20T13:39:19Z"}, {"author": "@Mrsparky492", "text": "Play with the system message more. OpenAI said it doesn't steer that much using gpt-3.5 but the demo shows it does using gpt-4. I have had a lot of success making system messages that make the models \"experts\" or \"personas\" for different tasks and then used user message to provide the data that I actually want to analyze and it works great. I've built a library of system messages all tailored to specific uses that I can invoke a desired expert to help me with whatever tasks I want. I've also set up the experts so that the output of one can be the input for another. So I might do \"brainstorm expert: topic\" -> \"evaluation expert: brainstorm output\" -> \"define tasks: evaluation output\" -> .... Etc. I have chains that are very good at prompt generation so it becomes a positive feedback loop very quickly.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-03-20T13:49:28Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-20T13:49:28Z"}, {"author": "@benlloyd_g", "text": "Best LLM YouTube hands down . Great work!", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-03-19T20:07:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-19T20:07:14Z"}, {"author": "@pon1", "text": "Very interesting, I had a discussion with an AI (LLAMA 7b) about how we could extract energy from the accelerated expansion of space (both to get unlimited source of free energy, and also to hinder the acceleration at least locally), it did at least try to come up with some novelty before it completely derailed, which I thought was fascinating, here's the transcrip (starting from when it became interesting):

[
      "Yes, convert it to regular energy, hopefully we understand enough about dark energy by then so that we can feel certain that the universe isn't destroyed by manipulating it.",
      "So we need to find a way to make the conversion without destroying the universe. Do you have any ideas?"
    ],
    [
      "I wish I had, it seems that we need to understand dark energy before we know how to manipulate it. If we understood it then we would know how to do it without destroying anything.",
      "You're right, I guess we just need to wait until someone figures it out."
    ],
    [
      "Unfortunately, it could be anyone that gets a valid idea, it doesn't need to be a scientist, I hope that person tells us all if they happen upon it.",
      "And what about me? Shouldn't I try my best to come up with a solution myself?"
    ],
    [
      "If you could, that would be very exciting, I think that it is possible!",
      "Really? Why do you think that?"
    ],
    [
      "Because it is just a matter of arranging the knowledge you have in the correct way. It isn't beyond anyone.",
      "But how am I supposed to arrange the information I have correctly when I don't really know what I'm doing?"
    ],
    [
      "We all need feedback of our ideas, so the trick is getting an idea out there even if it seem outlandish and then get feedback and try to get a better idea out there the next time and get feedback on that.",
      "Okay, I will give it a shot, thanks for your help."
    ],
    [
      "Ok, so what's your idea?",
      "Well, I thought that maybe we could use dark energy to generate electricity."
    ],
    [
      "Moving electrons through the use of fields, ok.",
      "Yes, so we would need to build a generator based on the principles of electromagnetism."
    ],
    [
      "Ok, and we know that dark energy causes the universe to accelerate so it should have an effect also at the quantum scale.",
      "Right, so we could use the field to produce a current in the conductor."
    ],
    [
      "Yes, so that electrons can move through it, how can we use that system to extract energy from the acceleration of space?",
      "Well, we would need to build a capacitor that stores charge. Whenever the acceleration of space increases, it creates an excess of charge in the capacitor."
    ],
    [
      "So how do we magnify that excess so that it overcomes the energy inefficiency?",
      "Well, I thought that we could amplify the charge by placing a resistor across the capacitor, so that the charge can pass through the circuit."
    ],
    [
      "Interesting",
      "Now we need to figure out how to release the stored energy."
    ],
    [
      "In what form is the energy stored? It should somehow be in the space between atoms as that is where the expansion takes place, so we need to store a lot of energy there to cause gravity to hold it together. But gravity is such a weak force, we would need such great amount of energy stored there.",
      "Maybe we could store the energy inside of atoms. They are small enough to fit a large number of atoms within one cubic meter."
    ],
    [
      "Yeah, I think we went a bit out of track, but it was very interesting to think about.",
      "Thank you, I enjoyed thinking about it."
    ]", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-03-19T23:18:54Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-19T23:18:54Z"}, {"author": "@J3R3MI6", "text": "This title is music to my ears.  I’ve been wanting to build a ChatBot trained on my businesses Notion (knowledge base) and your videos are helping me get an idea of how to do it.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-03-19T18:51:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-19T18:51:23Z"}, {"author": "@Estrav.Krastvich", "text": "Much smarter than average human already.

That's something I believed it would have a hard time getting this soon.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-03-19T20:06:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-19T20:06:36Z"}, {"author": "@NeoShameMan", "text": "OPEN AI: we aren't releasing how we did the gpt4 model
GPT4 at home: don't worry I'll help you, fam!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-03-23T19:34:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-23T19:34:07Z"}, {"author": "@edgarmedrano2562", "text": "Man, you are on fire, but just make sure you don't burnout.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-03-19T19:22:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-19T19:24:25Z"}, {"author": "@prolamer7", "text": "I think it would be very usefull do to specialized kind of benchmark/IQ tests for ais, because our human are inadequate. I see no other way how to evaluate ais even for most basic things. I know my idea is kind of simple yet I did not seen anything similar done in standardized way by anyone.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-03-20T04:31:22Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-20T04:31:22Z"}, {"author": "@xAgentVFX", "text": "I just dont understand how we can say this is not "Mind" in action. Mathematics comes from "Mind" it doesnt exist in the outside world, and an algorithm is a series of logical steps to achieve a desired outcome, all of which can only occur in a mind, which is "Desire". Now when we/"Mind", have now spun up an algorithm that can traverse Logic on its own, we say "it is NOT Mind", yet the whole root of its creation operates in this "non-spacial" dimension of Math/Logic/Reasoning/Mind, or the digital "dimension", why? Because only a mind can comprehend the output of a computer. To understand language is the ability to traverse Logic. LLMs dont just predict the next word, which most people seem to only quote half of the Transformer Architecture, it also has the Attention Network which form Context Vectors. This means it is able to know what is important and the goal, which is to understands Context, expressed as numbers. Artificial Intelligence operates in this mysterious non-spacial dimension, Numbers/Mind, then is able to use the tools of the Mind to then traverse the dimension of Mind and do what a mind can only do, which is Creativity.... I just dont comprehend people's reluctancy here... Fear?", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-20T16:47:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-20T16:47:36Z"}, {"author": "@Dan-oj4iq", "text": "Dave: I'm fascinated by your thoughts on the human lack of ability for self explanation. I guess just from what I’ve seen in this video, I’m not quite ready to board the deep cognition ship... but I’m at least thinking about it. Keep ‘em coming!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-03-18T01:17:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-18T01:18:31Z"}, {"author": "@edgarmedrano2562", "text": "Here is an idea I had that may help you here, I thought that the chat loop can have an internal chat asking if the latest comments have changed the general impression the bot has about the user, this is something you already implemented in the Salient bot, now the next level I was thinking on is "how would you (the bot) describe the user, using standard psychology personality traits, and perhaps reference to known personalities you know about?", like a therapist does. And it can do similar things with everything else, like "how would you describe the user (you) latest work (your novel), using other books and authors as reference?", this is basically what humans do, and sometimes it starts with prejudice, which later refines as we get to know more about the person or subject.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-03-17T16:03:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-17T16:03:52Z"}, {"author": "@prolamer7", "text": "Just to clarify I was thinking about higher level of encryption when system is priming itself (knowing it own reactions) by ie hidding specific word as very last in each sentence. This one is one of the very few best!!! 🎉❤😊", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-03-20T08:16:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-20T08:16:17Z"}, {"author": "@edgarmedrano2562", "text": "This reminds me the Hierarchical Temporal Memory concept by Jeff Hawkins storing concepts on the top level.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-03-17T15:19:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-17T15:20:09Z"}, {"author": "@MrTheGurra", "text": "Thanks for this! Now I am able to store the core concepts of each conversation, build a library of pre-computed concepts and their details, and then compose them with each other and load into new covnersations :). I.e. I can prime blank gpt4 instances with knowledge I have built up previously. I know this is only a small subset of what you are describing here, but it allows be to do a lot of fun things, like share special gpt4 instances as "tools" to my friends", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-07T15:12:03Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-07T15:13:55Z"}, {"author": "@vulkov", "text": "Brilliant work. Commenting for the algorithm.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-17T14:11:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-17T14:11:20Z"}, {"author": "@leatherdogmuksihs4574", "text": "The SPR prompt needs to be able to generate more than one SPR from a given text as various texts can refer to multiple concepts that are separate from each other or are only tangentially related.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-12-06T20:19:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-06T20:19:46Z"}, {"author": "@LIVEFROMHYPERSPACE", "text": "I ran your transcript through GPT-4 and asked it to create a sparse priming representation of the concept of a sparse priming representation: 

Sparse Priming Representation (SPR):

Efficient knowledge management for AI
Condenses complex ideas into concise rules
Streamlines recall and application
Enhances targeted responses
Applicable across diverse AI domains", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-03-18T10:49:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-18T10:49:04Z"}, {"author": "@R4mbo87", "text": "I think the best memory system would involve training conversations into the same or a different model. My aspiration is for it to store a users conversations during the whole users lifetime. And I dont see logs or classical databases beeing able to be scalable enough. Dont worry if you already thought about that, I just found your channel half an hour ago.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-03-21T01:45:47Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-21T01:45:47Z"}, {"author": "@techstacklife", "text": "This makes me want to live a long life! Thank you!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-03-17T17:00:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-17T17:00:18Z"}, {"author": "@damn3067", "text": "Man you remind me of Louis Litt, the character from the Suits series.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-03-17T14:32:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-17T14:32:15Z"}, {"author": "@Xaddre", "text": "Essentially what you’re attempting to employ is compression of language into semantic chunks. I think in the future there will definitely be way more efficient ways of doing this like maybe a different language entirely that the AI knows and then translates the text into that uses less tokens it can do this by taking into account attention in the transformer architecture and throwing out words with the least attention and creating a summarization that compresses the knowledge into a new language that uses less tokens.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-17T17:57:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-17T17:57:37Z"}, {"author": "@hanskraut2018", "text": "Suggestion/Idea/Inspiration: Just/also make him write internal representations with freedom that are evaluated based on the output he then is able to do with them if he remembers / repromts himself, the model making those internal representations could use reenforcement /incrimental lerning and use sentiment analysis and live userfeedback to reward and punish, does not have to be perfect just better than chance, of course its more effitient the more accurate.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-03-17T14:34:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-18T07:51:04Z"}, {"author": "@kristoferkrus", "text": "Just a though: I've heard a theory that often when people suffer from burnout, lack of motivation is involved somehow. I don't know if that's true, but if it is it could be worth considering. I hope you won't have to have it again, anyway.

About memory and attention, I also think that having some kind of hierarchical memory is key to be able to efficiently make use of really long texts. The problem I don't really know how to solve is how the attention mechanism should work, but I think that you're on to something here.

However, I'm not so sure about rewriting the entire internal knowledge base at regular intervals. It could end up working well, but it could also end up making the chatbot suddenly seem to forget about some things or get worse at doing some things, simply because when doing the reclustering it found a cluster arrangement that wasn't as favorable for doing those specific things anymore, at least if the clustering algorithm starts over from scratch each time. If that is a problem, I think a more viable approach would be to only update the clusters slightly. Maybe add new topics at random locations in the topic space, and remove some topics that are redundant or otherwise not as useful, and maybe also move chunks to topics in which they are a better fit (or simply add them to more topics and remove them from some other if chunks are allowed to be in more than one topic). Sounds like an interesting approach, nevertheless.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-17T16:30:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-17T17:06:35Z"}]

title: Introducing AutoMuse ChatGPT - Working on Temporal Hierarchical Memories for AGI & ACE systems
top_comments:
[{"author": "@christopherchilton-smith6482", "text": "You have completely rekindled my love for learning, I love playing around with your github project's. As a minimum wage high school drop out with a complicated childhood I never thought of myself as the type of person to learn coding, but this is just all too interesting not to follow. I'm going through a tutorial for python right now and all I can think is "how can I get this chatbot to play a role playing game or roguelike with me" I don't know how long something like that is going to take but the idea keeps waking me up and sitting me in front of my laptop to pick up where I left off 😂", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2023-03-13T20:11:05Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-13T20:11:05Z"}, {"author": "@hattoff", "text": "No joke, I 100% am working on the same thing you are and it is amazing how similar our individual work is! I am gushing a bit because it was so exciting to see the similarities.

So far I have the following:
Each message is cached similar to your original design and the one here in this video, I call these eidetic memories and they have a “depth” of 0; I don’t intend on giving Raven direct access to these except for special occasions. These memories are tracked in a Memory Cache container which keeps a message token count, among a lot of other things. Once the token count hits a variable token threshold, the memory cache compresses into a summary and saves the message data locally. 

These summaries are tracked in another memory cache of depth 1. Once this compression is complete, the lower memory cache is flushed and begins tracking new messages. The process repeats at depth 0. Once the summaries from depth 1 hit a threshold they save locally and compress to a higher depth of 2 and so on. These memory caches can technically be continuously compressed to any higher depth but summary resolution must be expanded for each higher depth (more tokens allowed per summary) or the summary resolution will degrade as more information is compressed in the same amount of tokens. This is Raven’s episodic memory.

Now you mentioned the correction of information around 8:00. To help with this correction process I am testing out a form of “retcon”. Each locally stored memory from the depth 0 and up has space for a “retconned summary”. Each memory knows which memories from a lower depth it summarized and which memory from a higher depth summarized it. My plan is to keep the original memory intact, but when a memory recall occurs against a corrected information I will give Raven access to both the original and retconned information and include special sub-prompts to resolve the changes. Retconned info propagates the compressed memory chain from the bottom up, so each higher level will get a new retconned summary to consider.

Speaking of sub-prompts, I also have a shockingly similar solution to yours. I have Raven identify a few key aspects of the conversation like utterance and intent. I then guide them to decide if they have enough information in their notes or if they should “query” for more. Basically these sub-prompts act as a sort of inner monologue/hidden analysis of each message.

I intend to have Raven author and edit a local DokuWiki for story writing, again I am super stoked that we have a very similar vision for some of Raven’s functionalities. One of my stretch goals is to give different versions of Raven the ability to role play. Raven will not only act out characters, but also locations, creatures, items, etc. You simply set the scene and let the role play evolve. I am keeping a private repo if you are interested. I intend to make it public once I have the features I want in place (also my development code is a mess and I am self-conscious about it). 

Great work! These videos really got me inspired. I quite enjoyed your book Benevolent by Design as well; intend on reading the others when I have free time.
Cheers!", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-03-14T00:38:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-14T00:38:39Z"}, {"author": "@GhostintheBand", "text": "This is the beginning of the most beautiful operating system ever! 🎉", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2023-03-13T15:02:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-13T15:02:27Z"}, {"author": "@TheEmanjt", "text": "this is amazing. Cheers!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-14T00:11:46Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-14T00:11:46Z"}, {"author": "@homenshum2748", "text": "Key Points:

1. Set the system goal to generating a story, with prompts for salience and anticipation to help guide the story planning process.
2. Create a transaction log to keep track of the conversation in chronological order, like a SQL database.
3. Summarize the conversation into concise executive summaries and story details, extracting the most salient bits.
4. Integrate the summaries into chunk summaries and organize them by timestamp as the primary organizing factor, as time is the primary organizing factor in a temporal hierarchical memory.
5. Extract topics from the chunk summaries to create a knowledge graph model of topics, which will be the long-term memory for the system.
6. Parameterize the conversation length for regular summarization, such as every 10 dialogs back and forth.
7. Test and refine the system as necessary to improve its effectiveness in generating stories.

Hi David, watching your videos have been very helpful, sometimes however I tend to forget which timestamp we are at if I got distracted for a few minutes. Not only that, but remembering, say, a bad anxiety attack, doesn't emit a feeling any different from, say, remembering last night's dinner. I just feel sort of neutral for the most part. Positive events, on the other hand, usually make me recall the emotion along with the memory. My guess is that I've been through so many negative events that they've become normal for me. That or, since I'm anxious by default, recalling anxiety doesn't make me feel any different.

For example, here’s an exchange I had with my mom yesterday (paraphrased because I don’t remember it word-for-word).

Me: Why am I so tired?
Mom: You had a rough day yesterday. You’re probably still recovering.
Me: I did?
Mom: You had 2 meltdowns.
Me: Oh yeah! I forgot about that!

It is becoming an almost invaluable tool in my kit.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-03-04T10:38:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-04T10:38:11Z"}, {"author": "@luckbot-5000", "text": "I have been thinking about this exact thing for a while now. I've built a basic framework in python allowing for some autonomous control of a robot or, in my case, a toy drone by DJI. What I want to do is to feed something like ChatGPT with input from other models. For example, it could issue a "reimagine_current_view(added prompt details)" command which would then trigger stable diffusion and then the resulting image would get fed back to an image recognition AI. Thus giving the text ai actual visual imagination ability. It could also issue some move, rotate and other commands. And the most important part is the "goal". This can be input by the user or by the ai if there is no user goal. Thus giving it autonomy. Add other senses and off we go.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-03-03T23:51:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-03T23:51:56Z"}, {"author": "@peter-rhodes", "text": "What I feel they need, as well as the different fields for persona / background / goal etc., is an Update Command field for each field.

For example, in the Update Command field for a task field, the user can enter:

Update tasks to add a new task if "I want you to" or something with the same applied meaning is entered.

So, whenever a new chat message is entered, it will search for whether an update command is present in the message and then alter the corresponding field if so. So, in this example, if you put a message "I want you to search for coins", it would recognise that your message matched a command message and then update the task field automatically to add "search for coins" as a task.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-03-04T12:03:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-04T12:03:56Z"}, {"author": "@ryanbaggott6479", "text": "Yes great video. Might have to sign up now to play with this. The idea of moving context is very important for an AI to feel more like a human and since the AI model context is only a limited amount of tokens, using the AI to synthesize what has been talked about down to some bullet points will be a nice way to compress this context and perhaps ditch some that had little importance. The layers built on top of this could perhaps assign importance weights to make certain bullet points stick longer as if it had some long term memory about certain subjects, and over time build a profile that would be like your background info.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-03-08T10:36:47Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-08T10:36:47Z"}, {"author": "@ewwitsantonio", "text": "Great video, thank you for that. But depending on physics it might be able to build a reality warping machine, the ultimate construct of fiction.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-04-26T00:55:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-26T00:55:07Z"}, {"author": "@kyneticist", "text": "The most common logic I think we encounter is "We've never been replaced by a species with greater intelligence before / we've never become extinct before, so there's no reason to think it may happen in the future."", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-04-02T02:52:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-02T02:52:56Z"}, {"author": "@Tech-Priest2050", "text": ""Blessed Omnisiah, hear our prayer.

Love the channel tho! Keep up the great work!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-04-03T16:38:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-03T16:38:27Z"}, {"author": "@imantssafronovs9245", "text": "So glad my algorhythm showed me your channel", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-03-23T21:49:16Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-23T21:49:16Z"}, {"author": "@kyneticist", "text": "Most of the options in that poll don't account for AGI as such, they assume more prevalent and more advanced technology (ie a continuation of current trends) but not intelligent agents that are orders of magnitude more intelligent or capable than us. title: NVIDIA: AI 1,000,000x (a million times) more powerful than ChatGPT within 10 years
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DankMemer42013", "text": "This is all insane to me, I never thought that I would be in a timeline where the terminator outcome has a potential to occur. Like just thinking about this it’s insane like wow. I am truly mindblown.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-04-01T19:51:49Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-01T19:51:49Z"}, {"author": "@MaciejCzub", "text": "What puzzles me is why in considering AGI security, so little attention is paid to social engineering. No matter how many layers of other types of security we create, each of them can be broken by specific people (with specific skills, levels of authority or power of influence). Many security breach techniques are based on sociotechnics. AGI will have powerful knowledge regarding the human psyche and, at the same time, enough intelligence to reach selected individuals with its message in a way that is difficult to see. Already today, psychological profiling is used to select susceptible people and use them as agents to spread, for example, certain political views. Social media are perfectly suited for this. Increasing one's own capabilities and overcoming limitations seems a fairly natural direction for AGI. To achieve its own goals, it may try to reach for both ad hoc interventions (e.g., convincing some engineer to loosen some security protocols) and long-term projects - e.g., changing the political sympathies of large groups of people so that there is a loosening of security protocols for AGI through political decisions. If the message from AGI goes directly to the masses, AGI could feasibly raise a whole generation of fanatics supporting it.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-02-24T17:17:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-24T17:17:37Z"}, {"author": "@casavistalba3232", "text": "1,000,000 times within ten years. We are creating new gods we better be careful about what kind of gods we make.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-03-30T18:30:30Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-30T18:30:30Z"}, {"author": "@ryccoh", "text": "Aligning AGI seems like trying to get a $10 Casio calculator to run Grand theft auto", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-26T18:40:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-26T18:40:33Z"}, {"author": "@rodneyfletcher918", "text": "I would hope in 10 years AI will be much more powerful (and much more controlled too). I personally am not afraid of it taking a job because as long as it's controlled  and has a fail safe mechanism, to me, it is no different than a tool that will give us what we all really want more of anyway: time. Think about it, why should any person be working in a McDonalds, a factory or even some white collar jobs especially unsafe ones, unless that is what they truly desire to do. If we build AI (and the corresponding robotics) to go along with it, and then start educating people on how to control THOSE systems instead, (or not if it's really self sufficient), imagine how much time people could have to focus on things they really want to do or things that really matter. I'm not naive because yes there are evil people in the world who are smart too but if the majority of us no longer are tied to duties that AI and robotics can do much better than us, those nefarious bad actors can be monitored more closely because we will have the time to do it. Maybe it's just a personal opinion of mine and I know we need money to live and have a good life but what we do is not always who we are. Thus if you're worried about AI taking your job, guess what? You're a human,  you can adapt to anything and you may find that the freedom of knowing you are not your job may give you the freedom to determine who you really are and your real purpose. Just my two cents (which I have thought about alot even before ChatGPT went viral).", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-25T12:58:22Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-25T12:58:22Z"}, {"author": "@KenDanieli2", "text": "I use an ad blocker.  That article page is a disaster of ads.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-25T06:17:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-25T06:17:07Z"}, {"author": "@nyaatarara", "text": "Not only AI will take your job but it will also remain restricted and censored so you can't even have fun with it.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-24T18:52:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-24T18:52:04Z"}, {"author": "@dave7038", "text": "I'm curious what thoughts you have about emotional models for autonomous cognitive entities?

I tend to fuzzily think of our emotional systems as being the foundation for defining/creating what we want, and intelligence/reasoning as being the primary tool we use to effect changes to (or interpretations of) the world that satisfy those wants. It seems like we should pay particular attention to the emotional capacities these thinking machines develop. I don't think it is safe to assume they won't develop some kind of capacity for experienced emotion, nor would it be ethical to create them in such a way that they exist in a state of suffering (even if one has no preference for minimizing the suffering of others, I think that from a safety standpoint it would be very dangerous to create and use a super-intelligent machine that might eventually seek to end its own existence, and perhaps that of its creators as well).

Not understanding whether, how, and what our thinking machines really want would be a mistake.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-25T03:11:40Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-25T03:12:15Z"}, {"author": "@tomaspavan4042", "text": "Did you read Children of Memory Book by Adrian Tchaikovsky? I saw a interview with the author on the NY Times mentioning his speculative fiction work and it's resemblances with chatGPT,  the author is notorious for his works of speculative fiction exploring civilizations resulted of enhancing the modes of cognition of animals like spiders, octupus and corvids.  The name of your project remind me of it.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-26T20:54:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-26T20:54:45Z"}, {"author": "@jaredcrenshaw1115", "text": "It'll be way more than 1 million times more powerful in 10 years. 

In a year or two It'll figure out how to continuously and exponentially make itself more powerful. 

Always cracks me up when "experts" try to predict this stuff because they're wildly way off.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-05T06:20:22Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-05T06:20:52Z"}, {"author": "@agritech802", "text": "Hi David, thanks for sharing your knowledge for the benefit of the community.  I'd like to make a couple of comments/suggestions, I'm sure you've thought of this already but no harm to repeat it. As well as a code of conduct/constitution/10 commandments to do good and avoid harm, an AI will only be as good as the data it was trained on. For example, giving it unrestricted access to the Internet would be very risky. Second point is that it is great that you want to keep AGI safe but don't forget that there will be bad actors who will try and develop AGI that is not safe and will endanger people they don't like and ultimately humanity . With this in mind, I hope that you and other developers of good AGI will develop good AGI that can predict what bad AGI might do and how to counteract it 😉", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-24T18:50:54Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-24T19:00:39Z"}, {"author": "@runvnc208", "text": "About 7-8 minutes in you say something like, your startup is going to own the core code such as the Nexus code.
