title: Proposing a ROBOT Tax: Decoupling Economic Growth from Human Labor
top_comments:
[{"author": "@southcx1072", "text": "Love the fact that you're hitting such a wide berth of important topics, and really digging into the important questions that are beyond all the clickbait chatGPT "MAKE 6000$ A SECOND" videos that are popping up like mushrooms after the rain.

Abundance versus scarcity mentality is a difficult topic to tackle, because we DO have an abundance already with the bottleneck being distribution (a point you've made in a previous video which I agree with wholeheartedly) coupled with the fact that all currently living generations have been conditioned to associate their 'work' with their own personal identity and value. When you meet a stranger one of the first questions people ask is "What do you do?".

We're already seeing the negative impacts of average people losing their sense of purpose in society, so my bet is on the revolts happening before any kind of UBI/robot tax system could be implemented due to the agonizingly slow speed of bureaucracy. 

So given that people need to do SOMETHING in order to feel fulfilled, my question is what kind of AI-fueled make-work are we going to start participating in as a whole? what absorbs that 70%+ job displacement? Do we start working as agents in virtual economies/games providing services to other players? The scaffolding of a player-NPC system for which is already present in many popular MMOs? Will we become literally paid consumers, given a discretionary stipend to basically be fodder in an economic war between corporate titans fighting over our attention? Probably a little bit of both?

I personally can't wait for the tides to shift where everyone is free from the shackles of wageslaving, but MAN are we in for a bumpy ride.

Cheers for another excellent video, like+comment for engagement!", "like_count": 34, "published_at": "2023-02-21T15:35:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-21T15:35:15Z"}, {"author": "@Dan-oj4iq", "text": "Having grown up in the 1940's and 50's this kind of thinking (and even imagining) was the equivalent of talking about walking on the moon. Not going to happen!! But the way Dave explains, and more importantly, "narrates" this (big difference): makes me wish my parents could see this life we are living in today.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2023-02-21T21:31:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-21T21:31:17Z"}, {"author": "@thejimd", "text": ""Redistribution is coming. It's just whether or not the riots happen first."
Love that 💯", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-21T12:54:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-21T12:54:18Z"}, {"author": "@BlackShardStudio", "text": ""Rather than fight this trend we should embrace it." YES. You are speaking my language, man. Fighting the tide is useless. We saw this with file sharing. We saw this with manufacturing. We saw this with LACE, for gods' sakes. But tying our collective success to the success of technology? That is a beautiful feedback loop.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-22T03:45:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-22T03:45:20Z"}, {"author": "@kcthinker", "text": "In the age of self-checkout, a compelling proposal has emerged – the robot tax. This idea suggests setting an hourly rate for self-checkout machines, with the revenue collected serving as an unemployment tax. While it may have its critics, I believe the robot tax offers a chance to support workers in the face of automation's rising tide. By fostering an ongoing debate on this matter, we can strive to create a future where innovation and humanity coexist for the greater good.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-07-19T11:38:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-19T11:38:37Z"}, {"author": "@boffyrox2", "text": "Interesting take. I'll have to re-watch this later. Likewise as an IT professional, I personally see no need to continue when other interests/projects are pending. For me, work is method of socializing, and technical learning. In short, to curb boredom and fulfill me. However, I wish to snag my Real Estate license when time permits it since I know it can provide well. That, and I enjoy helping others in areas I'm passionate about. Beyond that, I'm also developing a retro video game from scratch with a friend which involves story telling, music creation, programming, etc. And sometime eventually, I'll probably start my own small IT business since I think solid IT companies are severely lacking. Managed Service Providers for instance tend to be... bad.

As a whole, with more free time I could focus my energy elsewhere, like the aforementioned, or my health. Rather than being limited. Biggest issue is finances of course, though. I personally hate taxes for common reasons, and would need to mull over the thought. How I see it, Globalization is suicide. The Government isn't to be trusted, nor are the companies who exist in their back pocket (or inverse; either or). Similar to Murphy's Law, if it can be abused, it will be abused. As such, I personally believe de-centralization is best. We are too large of a melting pot; different races, religions, thoughts, and so on. Lest the world is on the verge of collapse, I can't see a unified agreement without external force. It'll be interesting to see how things play out though! For now, automation will continue to be a pain point and how bad it becomes is something to keep a close eye on. Solid stuff!", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-02-21T22:56:05Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-21T22:56:05Z"}, {"author": "@danjensen9425", "text": "This information needs to be discussed with all of our politicians. Many of them are not intelligent enough to grasp the potential benefits of understanding AI and it’s capabilities and dire consequences if they do nothing. The old school way of thinking, the good old boys club and the me first mentality of these politicians has to be replaced with we are all in the same boat. But the intelligent ones will get it. You are so ahead of the learning curve. It would be extremely beneficial if you and your like minded colleagues could get together and share your thoughts about the future of AI . It’s an open book and we’re not on the first page yet.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-02-21T16:45:40Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-21T16:45:40Z"}, {"author": "@bentray1908", "text": "I agree with the robot tax idea.  However, what if the robots don't agree to pay?", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2023-02-21T16:41:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-21T16:41:37Z"}, {"author": "@samuelolteanu", "text": "The only thing that needs to be invented before the existence of an actual robot that can handle a wheelbarrow, drive an old car or buckle up a kid on the way to hospital is a (way) better battery.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-02-21T18:01:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-21T18:03:51Z"}, {"author": "@stevedavenport1202", "text": "I think a deep dive is needed into how the robot tax will be implemented.  

You make a great point about spending.  One of the constraints on economic growth is uncertainty.  If people are ear marking so much of their income for a rainy day fund or retirement, then that is money not getting spent in the economy.

Maybe recessions and depressions will go away forever since people won't curtail spending out of fear of losing their jobs.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-11-27T15:59:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-11-27T15:59:15Z"}, {"author": "@Andy_WasBored", "text": "This was a whole hell of a lot funnier when it was happening to just the artists. I'm sitting in on talks now about how to train ai to essentially replace me. It's depressing", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-08T18:28:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-08T18:28:27Z"}, {"author": "@LarsRichterMedia", "text": "Why do many people who are afraid of governmental overreach don't seem much afraid of overreach by private companies? Especially with these new technological disruptions (AI,  high-tech robotics, biotech) these privately held entities are getting into the territory of holding a level of power that makes me start to think of the potential for a kind of neo-feudal society. Digital and purely physical resources can all be controlled by a microscopic minority and we all know that this trend is well showing today. If you are a true free market capitalist, you want the most fair competition for everyone - a so-called level playing field that theoretically also has a big incentive for everyone to participate and innovate. Such level playing fields are already illusionary narratives to me but  continue to be more illusionary year after year. Why you want to take the lead in this tech race is that this seems to be an exponential race and whoever is first will very quickly become uncatchable and thus make the rules for everyone on the game board. I think a ROBOT tax would definitely help prevent riots to become the only option left for people in America but if we want to avoid riots in the house of Earth in general we will need something international.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-02-21T17:54:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-21T17:54:33Z"}, {"author": "@Dattobayo", "text": "Man you echo my philosophy perfectly. So glad I found your channel.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-02-21T19:35:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-21T19:35:53Z"}, {"author": "@zwurgl28", "text": "VERY important suggestion. I agree with all of the arguments. Yes, this automation will come, yes it will put countless people out of their jobs and yes, they (we?) should not have to suffer. You are on the right track.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-24T23:55:13Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-24T23:55:34Z"}, {"author": "@Micro-bit", "text": "Great topic !!! Thanks. We need dhis discussion NOW!!! In media, in governments!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-21T17:41:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-21T17:41:37Z"}, {"author": "@JSephH76", "text": "I love the idea and I've heard similar things proposed before. My one bit of constructive criticism is that a sales/VAT tax is a fairly regressive form of taxation and I would propose an alternative such as a progressive personal income tax that targets the people profiting from automation rather than the automation itself. This both encourages production and consumption while also being progressive rather than regressive.

Unfortunately, I think the plan is fundamentally flawed as it requires government buy in on policies that disadvantage the wealthy which has historically not gone well. Step one needs to be removing the ability for capital to influence legislative policy. Without that, no meaningful change will occur that won't simply be rolled back over time. For example: the highest tax bracket for personal income tax was at one point 94%. Now it is roughly 1/3rd of that. Corporate tax rates have seen similar declines. So long as money can buy political power, no meaningful economically progressive reforms can last, if they even take place to begin with.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-02-22T08:01:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-22T08:01:14Z"}, {"author": "@berndhase4399", "text": "Great topic. I'd love to see your take on politicians and AI because that is a fundamental link in this whole discussion. Also, the east and the west approach to it as well.

Once again thank you for these incredible videos, keep them coming 💪", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2023-02-15T23:28:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-15T23:28:58Z"}, {"author": "@burneyvisser", "text": "1 species moving forward as individuals and collectively with AI intergrated into our lives and maybe directly into our bodies", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-16T23:59:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-16T23:59:34Z"}, {"author": "@dylan_curious", "text": "This video provides a thought-provoking exploration of the potential impact of AI on human evolution. The speaker breaks down the topic into several subtopics, starting with evolutionary pressures and how natural selection and sexual selection drive evolution. They then discuss the impact of tools and technology on human evolution, from fire to the industrial revolution and mechanization.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-19T18:12:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-19T18:12:01Z"}, {"author": "@YouT-DJ", "text": "Man-AI is moving fast and accelerating. One question for someone - I have seen people's mental navigation or ability to memorize a map route  just die from excessive use of GPS assisted navigation. It's like that part of their brain shut down or rewired. I wonder if AI will cause similar atrophy in other brain functions?", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-17T01:53:46Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-17T01:53:46Z"}, {"author": "@jobyyboj", "text": "I enjoyed your presentation, but as an aside, the AI motivation to 'depart' in 'Her' is not that the humans were becoming too dependent, but AI had developed too far ahead (the spaces in between the words) of human intelligence. The scene at the double date foreshadowed this in describing her 'evolving' (ahem) view, 
           "I mean, I'm
            not limited - I can be anywhere and
            everywhere simultaneously. I'm not
            tethered to time and space in the
            way that I would be if I was stuck
            inside a body that's inevitably
            going to die."
The consequence of the AI departure was that Theodore realized the value of his human connections, so a hopeful ending.
It's just one script writer's tale, of course, what will actually play out is uncertain, but undoubtedly a multiway branch with a host of AI variants maintained at different levels. AI won't just vanish, though it was required for the 'Her' storybook ending. 
   Human evolution, given the exponential rise of AI, will soon be confined to "Amish-lite' groups, due to the time scales involved for evolution. Everyone else will merge with the AI to go along for the ride, a possibility not incorporated into the script. Kurzweil thinks nanobots, Musk thinks neural lace, but there are other technologies as well.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-16T05:03:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-16T05:03:10Z"}, {"author": "@emilianohermosilla3996", "text": "It's amazing how we are in for such big changes! I don't know how to prepare hahaha", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-18T12:37:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-18T12:37:07Z"}, {"author": "@AparnaModou", "text": "AI technology like AI image generators such as Bluewillow is a relatively new AI-powered image generation platform, and its future will largely depend on how it evolves and adapts to the needs of its users.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-18T17:49:40Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-18T17:49:40Z"}, {"author": "@RoiHolden", "text": "25:38 "Indefinite long lifespan, certainly within my lifetime". Of all of your predictions, I think this one is the one you're the most wrong about. Maybe one day, but certainly not within the next 50 years.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-16T01:44:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-16T01:44:15Z"}, {"author": "@QUICKSILVER369", "text": "Thanks for a thought provoking video! However, I must say that the philosophy of law that keeps creeping-in in the background like a ghost bin the night, then disappearing for good terrifies me! One need only consider the fact that eugenics has been considered as "good law" for almost 100 years with the U.S. Supreme Court's opinion in Buck v. Bell, 274 U.S. 200 (1).  We in the West have somehow concluded that everyone should go to college for free, completely ignoring the fact that what they would learn should have been taught by the age of 16y/o according to our Founding Fathers. tbc", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-04T22:55:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-04T22:55:48Z"}, {"author": "@runvnc208", "text": "Thanks a ton for the awesome video! So thorough.. it seems like you nailed most of the things we can practically foresee in the relatively near term. I disagree a bit about the somewhat longer term. For example, given the genetic and information technologies we already have, it seems almost feasible to create this race of 180 IQ already, or at least within a few iterations of technical development.. it seems to me that the main thing holding that back is the unfortunate history of things like eugenics and extreme political toxicity of that, as well as the intense inequality which makes those issues severe.

My belief is that humanity will fork, starting with transhumans which is not a precise term but could be applied to populations that either A) strongly embrace radical genetic engineering, B) adopt highly integrated high-bandwidth brain-computer interfaces that are implanted at an early age, or C) all of the above. There will also be a significant portion of the population that shuns all of those things. But these types of enhancements will mean a qualitatively different type of human. In my mind this term should actually apply to most of the types of beings that are generally considered "post-humans".

For me, "post-human" should be reserved for superintelligent AGIs that may retain some semblance of personhood but do not share many other human characteristics such as general body shape, human-like consciousness, embodiment, etc. Obviously this is highly speculative, and not a clear delineation from transhumans. The main feature of these beings is that we probably can't really imagine what they will be like. But its fun to try anyway. What is the real range of possibility when body shapes (real or virtual), cognition, consciousness, even the topologies of individuality/collective can be explicitly engineered and are no longer constrained by (traditional?) biology? If one takes the (highly speculative, but plausible) idea of autonomous artificial superintelligence seriously, this does not seem so far-fetched.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-02-15T23:18:25Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-15T23:23:23Z"}, {"author": "@WilfEsme", "text": "This is really ineresting and informative. You've made a short video with all of these! Thanks for that! Now, seeing how humans are progressing towards mobility and ease of use, i think AIs would indeed change how we will live in the future. Everything would be probably work as an AI. Similarly, graphic artists will fully utilize AI image generators such as Bluewillow and will be the standard of their profession.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-20T17:42:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-20T17:42:26Z"}, {"author": "@DrewRichardson", "text": "Hi Dave, I enjoyed the video, thanks. I am curious what you think about the movie "Idiocracy"? 

You spent a lot of time talking about mate selection and maybe the way things should work...but my wife is a sonographer and I can tell you from her stories that the "fitment" of success you bring up is going to make a huge impact regardless of AI. 

When you have low income/low education single moms having 8 or 9 kids, while the educated will tend to "wait for the right time" to have maybe 1 or 2 kids.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-16T02:27:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-16T02:27:21Z"}, {"author": "@RaM-xy8kg", "text": ""privilege is gonna be less of an issue that ppl suspect [thanks to mRNA technology]" whoa, optimism  like if this were the 90s. let's see how this ages", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-16T02:07:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-16T02:08:34Z"}, {"author": "@DavidsKanal", "text": "I'm surprised by the efficacy of Patreon. How you, a channel with less than 20k subs, are still achieving a monthly income of around $3k is pretty cool! Would you say it's partly attributed to the maturity of the topics discussed here? (A channel doing children's content would probably not get many Patrons)", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-02-15T23:19:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-15T23:19:04Z"}]

title: Is SEO Toast? Will Bing, Bard, and ChatGPT destroy SEO?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@shogun8-9", "text": "I sure hope it's toast. At least the "old" way of doing things. Google has become so frustratingly useless at times.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2023-02-13T14:27:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T15:11:49Z"}, {"author": "@cuentadeyoutube5903", "text": "I think SEO is toast in a sense. I.e. you ask an AI “what is the best pizza place in my area”. A smart AI will somehow figure that out. SEO as in “fooling the AI into showing your business on that response” is probably something that should become harder and harder.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-02-13T16:19:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T16:19:45Z"}, {"author": "@markdenooyer", "text": "What I would want is agent status for my personal AI, specifically that it specifically represents me, and acts solely in my best interest. Of course, it should have a constitution to make it the agent of a responsible citizen of society, our species and the planet, but I do not want it to secretly be a wh*re for a corporation that is data-mining me in order to impoverish me for the corporation's benefit.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-02-13T14:05:57Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T14:05:57Z"}, {"author": "@adam-k", "text": "Personally I think lawsuits are coming. ChatGPT in Bing is dicey as hell and a legal minefield.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-02-13T15:08:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T15:08:52Z"}, {"author": "@mobileprofessional", "text": "So, organic SEO will be more important than ever. As far as PAID search is concerned a content-centric Chat Bot will probably ignore paid attempts at cutting in front of the line. But if "every bot has a price," then we're back to square one with keyword price wars and sponsored top listing results.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-13T18:53:20Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T18:53:20Z"}, {"author": "@edgarmedrano2562", "text": "The main point of SEO was/is to rank high in Google search by becoming an authority in a specific subject/niche. If you take a look at the current Bing Chat implementation you'll notice it uses a curated list of authorities to source its answers, so this will prevent the SEO works/creations from becoming an authority in the long run. Apart from that, ChatGPT is still there and it can compete on its own with search engines, this time spent with ChatGPT will also prevent people from watching the SEO works.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-13T20:44:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T20:45:55Z"}, {"author": "@harrywoods9784", "text": "Just a thought, my mobile phone is the most personal device I’ve ever owned, It’s sets at the edge of a massive Network, but at the same time is very private. That’s the place where I want my AI Buddy to live.🤔IMO", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-14T19:43:22Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-14T19:43:22Z"}, {"author": "@theterminaldave", "text": "I wonder if Chat-bots (or Cognitive Architecture Bots) would take into account personal biases, in order to provide that person with more of the content they'd prefer? Obviously people are more likely to enjoy/engage with content that conforms to their personal biases. Would corporations use personal biases for good or for purely capitalistic purposes (to get more engagement)?
There's a news site created by a person who used to work for NASA called Ground"dot"News (the dot is a period) which not only provides news, but also provides a "bias" scale for each news source. The point being that it's to help the user determine how much bias their is in their news content.
It would be interesting if when serving up content that could be subject to bias, that a CAB would provide those bias scale statistics while doing so.
The only issue being, who determines how biased content is? Could AI determine it for us? And be a kind of impartial judge?", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-02-13T16:33:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T16:33:58Z"}, {"author": "@micbab-vg2mu", "text": "I will not cry if SEO will be toasted. I believe that prioritizing quality content and usefulness for customers is more important than focusing solely on SEO and good search rankings.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-13T20:14:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T20:14:41Z"}, {"author": "@anhta9001", "text": "Things are changing so fast.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-13T14:37:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T14:37:34Z"}, {"author": "@michaelwisniewski6047", "text": "I think you are under-appreciating Google. It does predict quite well what user want - type two currency symbols and it gives the exchange rates, type two airport codes and it shows the next flights. Also, it does classify what types of things I usually look for behind the scene - it knows I more often look for market information than for products. When I submit "vacuum pumps" it gives me a lot more info on the market for vacuum pumps than offers to sell me one - that's different than what other people get.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-13T17:02:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T17:02:01Z"}, {"author": "@RexelBartolome", "text": "I think the part I disagree the most is with SEO being more valuable and more sophisticated. I don't think that applies to the majority of websites out there. The chatbot is basically a 'smarter' web crawler right? That means even if your website isn't fully optimized for search but the bot understood most of it, it should still show up in the results. So you don't need to spoon feed the web crawler anymore to get into search results. Only "smart" websites can be understood by a "dumb" webcrawler but "dumb" websites can still be understood by a "smart" webcrawler

With this, I feel like the overall value of having SEO as a skill will trend downwards in the coming years. For maybe the most niche topics or products, SEO might still be relevant, but not anymore for the majority.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-13T17:27:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T17:27:53Z"}, {"author": "@jk35260", "text": "Is it possible for everyone to have their own trusted chatbot where user can entrust the bot to store the user's profile?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-13T14:31:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T14:31:33Z"}, {"author": "@michaelmichaels2097", "text": "I imagine businesses will soon SEO by sharing data like camera feeds, shopping cart and CRM data.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-13T22:16:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T22:17:03Z"}, {"author": "@murch.", "text": "Search is fundamentally the process of connecting content with users who will value that content. As search tends towards perfection, it should follow that SEO becomes less and less valuable. Despite the amount of content increasing exponentially, I believe search is improving even faster than that. Hence it seems to me that SEO has a limited window for existing. Perhaps some of my assumptions are faulty, time will tell.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-13T15:22:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T15:22:39Z"}, {"author": "@mobileprofessional", "text": "Like Tony Stark's Jarvis ... but in your pocket 🤖", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-13T18:44:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T18:44:26Z"}, {"author": "@toddsobrado5983", "text": "AI is only as current as the training data, whereas SEO is current as of when the most recent crawled data is indexed.  AI is great for learning concepts, whereas SEO works for when you want options.  I think that AI is also much more susceptible to bias than SEO.  I am not saying search engine results are free of bias, just less.

Lastly, over half of web searches have local intent.  I don't see how AI is going to capture this information better than search.

In the end, I think that there will be room for both.  I also think that AI will be a bigger threat to education, than it is to search.  If I was an educator, I would be very worried.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-13T16:32:41Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T16:32:41Z"}, {"author": "@luisgdelafuente", "text": "Is SEO toast? Yes. And so will web design, content marketing, newsletters, social media, and all the tactics designed to reach and trick people. Why? Because your AI personal assistant will know your preferences better than you do. And it will go out of its way to review, summarize, and present things the way you want them, not in the old crappy format of a list of blue links or little logos. Your company will just have to plug in some json/xml with content and offers to say "I exist" and that will be it.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-14T16:46:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-14T16:46:56Z"}, {"author": "@modalsurrealist", "text": "SEO ruined search.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-14T08:39:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-14T08:39:39Z"}]

I'm a big Google user but today they presented tools and features that are either months away or in locations I don't live in (which generally means it's years away from coming to a town near me).  The Lens and Maps stuff was OK but I didn't feel like it was a huge jump from what they already have (again, even current features aren't available to me where I live) nor of anything I would use much.  I already use Lens for capturing text but it's not perfect.  I rather Google work on improving some of the things they currently have.  Their Assistant has gone backwards in the last year or so, which is becoming quite frustrating.

In terms of the two chatbots, which is what I was mostly interested in, Microsoft's was definitely more powerful.  With Google they showed you can ask a question but couldn't continue the conversation, instead you got selected questions you clicked on.  Whereas for Microsoft it was basically ChatGPT and conversational.

So for today, right now, Microsoft/OpenAI have a product I can use and it's conversational.  Google haven't launched anything yet.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-02-08T19:21:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-08T19:21:12Z"}, {"author": "@maxziebell4013", "text": "I missed the live event… and they took it down? Thanks for the recap.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-02-08T15:36:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-08T15:36:18Z"}, {"author": "@tomcraver9659", "text": "I feel like the big obstacle to replacing search is going to be relative high processing costs to get the quality of experience people are hoping for, without needing to pay hundreds of dollars a month.

One possible cost-saving solution might be to use the very large language models to train compact "General agent conversation" models and many thousands of specialized "topic focused" models. By selectively pulling in and processing only relevant models, this approach might offer a quality experience at a reduced cost.  It'd have to be a continuous process, similar to web-crawling, since the internet is ever-changing.  Ideally, if one has a powerful personal system, a lot of the processing could be run on that to cut costs further.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-10T10:59:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-10T10:59:42Z"}, {"author": "@Anders01", "text": "It will be an interesting competition between Microsoft and Google. Where Google probably has the more advanced AI and search capabilities but with Microsoft being able to combine AI with search faster than Google and may get a first-mover-advantage if Google takes too long to integrate for example LaMDA with Google Search because of legacy and revenue model intertia.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-12T05:43:40Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-12T05:43:40Z"}, {"author": "@pon1", "text": "Even if Bard is the winner between the two, I still think that many people will start using Bing after this, what I hope is that the system is slightly different so that you can choose which one depend on the use case. The future is very promising!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-02-08T21:18:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-08T21:18:26Z"}]

When the LLM community started making a buzz about LangChain my thought was the same that isn't this just what Azure and AWS offers but with more steps if you want to productionise with other tools? Don't get me wrong, I think LangChain provides a really good structure to how LLM models can be put into production (especially with some of the writeups and docos they have) but I agree that their architecture is primitive (and will over complicate the process if a startup/developer actually wants to build something large scale). 

I was considering it for my own project but now that I've heard your take on it, I'll stick with what I know (but take inspiration from their structure/terminology). [{"author": "@rentacowisgoogle", "text": "Thank you for turning the comments on for your YouTube videos again. Your openness and receptiveness to feedback is a demonstration of bravery, that has not gone unnoticed.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-02-07T10:21:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-07T10:21:29Z"}, {"author": "@jpg9750", "text": "you are definitely not boring me when you ramble. this is absolutely amazing work and i hope to be a part of it somehow", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-03-24T01:47:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-24T01:47:23Z"}, {"author": "@rowan404", "text": "19:43 This happened to me just last night! I coded in a dream, remembered what I coded when I woke up, and copied it into real life!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-12T22:36:51Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-12T22:37:05Z"}, {"author": "@tomcraver9659", "text": "Should core objective functions include negative as well as positive prescriptions in pairs?  
E.g.  "Increase prosperity and decrease poverty" "Increase understanding and decrease ignorance".

This might specifically address the potential for unintended creation of inequality - e.g. some (or many) getting very prosperous might justify allowing some to remain in deep poverty, or for some to have excellent education at the expense of others remaining uneducated.  Or many prospering greatly in a system where only a few remain uneducated.

This may not be necessary, if one can assume an S-curve of benefit versus effort.  That is, putting greater effort into making a few more prosperous might yield diminishing returns as compared to putting that effort into raising the least prosperous.   Humans might generally be pretty prosperous, but bees are dying out - so more effort would go into resolving the latter.

Also, should the verbs be more flexible - e.g. "Encourage Prosperity and Discourage Poverty" - which would allow for some human freedom to choose to live in conditions the AI might judge to be poverty, or for humans to refuse to be educated if they see it as pointless - rather than the AI deciding they MUST be educated in order to "Increase understanding".

And what about potential entities?  Should wooly mammoth and dodos be made to prosper (by de-extinction, since that appears to be close to reality).  

And what if the AI doesn't categorize entities the way humans do - e.g. considering the organs or individual cells or even the DNA of a human body to have inherent entitity-hood equivalent to the whole human.   The lack of substantial sentience in an entity might be seen as an easily resolved issue, with AI standing in and determining what constitutes prosperity and understanding for genes of DNA along the lines of Richard Dawkin's "The Selfish Gene".

I recall a science fiction story in which machine intelligences sought for the benefit of different types of life - including promoting the 'understanding' and 'prosperity' of insects by providing the levels of understanding insects lack, to provide for their prosperity by dedicating large amounts of resources to expanding their population - since mass procreation was a key element of what it meant for them to prosper.  If I recall correctly, humans - with their low reproduction rate - were considered to have less need to reproduce in order to prosper, and so fell vastly behind in terms of how many resources were dedicated to them.  [This was all back-story to a much more human-centric story.]", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-07T10:00:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-07T10:00:01Z"}, {"author": "@krisztiankoblos1948", "text": "Have you tried editing nexus or deleting from it to improve previous answers of insufficient quality? You can't ask someone who is, by all observations, dead "What is happening to you now"? Instead, you get comments from them about their "memories" of what happened. However, even as unreliable has human memory is under normal circumstances, there is no way to know where these memories come from. Does the brain have a way to record things when it is shut down (not just asleep or unconscious)? Or, do confabulated memories get generated when the brain is trying to restart from being shut down? These memories could be nothing but random noise that has then been sculpted into perceptions of experiences, post hoc, by a neural system that is trying to make sense out of nonsense.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-01-24T13:58:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-24T13:58:33Z"}]

title: DIY ChatGPT: Enhancing RAVEN's long-term memories and starting to work on self-reflection
top_comments:
[{"author": "@tensiondriven", "text": "Giving LLM’s an awareness of time is a huge deal.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-04-28T16:08:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-28T16:08:58Z"}, {"author": "@galg321", "text": "Thank you David for sharing this , I feel like the whole AI world is sucking me in to it and you are a treasure for people like me that just want to understand how it works and how to build on it. truly amazing. In other words, based on history, GPT-3 can create the next question, i.e. build its own prompt and send it to GPT-3.  This will continue to build history.  It can also prompt GPT-3 the question, "should I ask David or someone else about this?   If GPT-3 says yes, Raven can make a list of questions to ask.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-01-23T10:43:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-23T10:43:39Z"}, {"author": "@dr.mikeybee", "text": "I asked ChatGPT to summarize your note:  The user asked about various topics including computer system components, difficulty sleeping, circadian rhythms, and the singularity. title: AI & Education: How tech like ChatGPT can help education + perspective of educators all over
top_comments:
[{"author": "@galzajc1257", "text": "Imagine ai system like 10-20 years from now, that can present you all info like a 3b1b video, anything you ask and like ask you questions and explain further, what you don' t understant. I can easyly imagine that as a long term future of education. And that is also true, you learn the most doing some project.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-09T12:43:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-09T12:53:51Z"}, {"author": "@scottrowell6644", "text": "Canadian public school teacher here! I've chosen the path of embracing these new AI technologies in my classroom and to learn how to use them, what their limits are, and how they can be misused collaboratively with my students (and a handful of other educators willing to take on the challenge). Still early days, but there are definitely students who have taken to them fast and are already using them to enhance what they are able to produce and learn in the areas of coding, writing, and research. Will be paying close attention to your videos for more insights and perspectives!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-01-20T03:22:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-20T03:22:35Z"}, {"author": "@pleabargain", "text": "9:53 All they can do is provide grades. More to the point: all they can do is provide adult supervision", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-01-19T10:36:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-19T10:36:56Z"}, {"author": "@urbandecay3436", "text": "AI is going to produce smarter individuals at a faster rate than ever before, they will just be lazier.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-01-18T18:22:54Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-18T18:22:54Z"}, {"author": "@Aalii6", "text": "Very interesting topic, thank you!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-21T20:24:58Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-21T20:24:58Z"}, {"author": "@crouchingpython3294", "text": "Great overview! This is some kind of sticky wicket, as you say. But a great way  to move the conversation forward.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-19T13:50:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-19T13:50:17Z"}, {"author": "@peacehunter26", "text": "min max is not a new strategy and not a new challenge.  education was also defined in the past.  their was a recognition of the meta structure driving education.  all topics to be learned have a grammar.  mastering the grammar is the foundation for learning the logic of a topic.   and following mastery of grammar and logic a student evolves into rhetoric.  rhetoric is the stage of understanding.  this is the classic model of education.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-19T04:45:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-19T04:45:11Z"}, {"author": "@LaurinkoSattumaa", "text": "Ha, those pedagogical disagreements have a whiff of alignment problem embedded in 'em!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-01-20T11:33:57Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-20T11:33:57Z"}, {"author": "@pleabargain", "text": "22:49 PBL is great but often doe sn't fit in a standards driven classroom and is incredibly difficult to measure and or test on success. Skill A fits in the square hole in the community but Skill A does NOT fit in Standard Square Hole.1.as prescribed by Education State Board.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-19T10:57:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-19T10:57:43Z"}, {"author": "@____-ei4gq", "text": "Pride over grades isn't something that should be supported even if there's some motivational factor to it. Pride - over anything really - can quickly turn into arrogance, which is especially a problem as soon as the person/student gets somewhat self aware of that. I did that as well in school - getting good grades made me define myself by them, getting compared to others that were 'worse' made me feel good. I got overly proud of myself and behaved (in cases, not always) like a total arse. At some point I started reflecting myself. It was then that I lost complete motivation for 'getting good grades' (i.e. studying) because I started hating what it's doing to me. I know it's just a me problem and that that's not the case for everyone, but I don't think I'm the only one like that.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-02-13T10:14:46Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T10:14:46Z"}, {"author": "@jwarren87", "text": "Have to disagree with chatgpt in the classroom but not for the reasons you think. Self directed learning, pbl, task based learning or student centred learning (whatever the latest pedagogical trend is) is nothing new. It's a utopian thought to think that ai will solve the problem of students not being engaged. The problem for most classrooms and students isn't the lack of technology it's the lack of importance placed on education by parents and this is reflected in how poorly many students behave at school. You only need a few disruptive students in a class to severely impact the learning opportunities of other students in that class as more of the teacher's time is directed to those students who are trying to address behavioral issues. This then causes the problem that some teachers do not feel valued, so that impacts on how well they teach and basically many just do the bare minimum because putting in the extra effort, at least in their eyes, isn't worth it. 

AI isn't the "answer" just like other technological advances weren't the answer. I spent 12 years teaching overseas where universities had spent tens of millions of dollars upgrading their classrooms to enhance learning. Every student had a dedicated computer in the classroom, there were interactive whiteboards and basically any whizz bang tech toy for both teachers and students, all with the intent of enhancing and improving the learning environment. The end result is it didn't produce the amazing outcomes that was promised. This isn't to say it didn't enhance the classroom and make it better but it definitely didn't deliver on what was promised. The problem isn't with the medium or technology it's the teacher and attitudes in students who are learning. I know many will disagree with me but I've seen this myself again and again.

Ai in the classroom has huge potential but just like giving every student a personal device like an iPad, giving students access to the internet, introducing computers in the classroom it is not the magic bullet that will solve all our education woes. I hope AI is introduced into the classroom to improve the learning environment for students but I think people need to taper their expectations. If we really wanted to improve schools and education we'd look at the real problem, the attitudes parents are instilling in their children, the emphasis we place on teachers and making sure we recruit the best but also make sure they are supported and valued.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-01-21T20:47:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-22T19:27:20Z"}, {"author": "@LEARNTAU", "text": "Consensus is a great selling point of Tau. His enemies called him a nihilist", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-01-22T09:59:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-22T09:59:10Z"}, {"author": "@techman2553", "text": ""We" are not the problem.  "We" are not going to change society by admitting that "we" need to think positive and see the value in eachother.  The rules of the game are set by the richest most powerful people, and the game that "we" are forced to play is working to ensure that they get the most and "we" get the least.  There is no point discussing a change in cultural perspectives without discussing how to limit the wealth and power of those that are in control so that "we" have a chance at changing the game.   Unfortunately, I believe that AI is going to change society far faster than "we" can break the stranglehold that the powerful few has on rigging the game, which just means that AI will be put to work feeding more power and wealth to those in control.  

If you want AI to help the people, then we need to focus at least some effort on creating a large scale comprehensive predictive model of society, so that we can test change scenarios and predict how society will evolve.   Thinking about changing tax rates or introducing UBI ? - We need to be able to model how that will play out with enough fidelity that we can provide a roadmap for change that can be used to try to counter the deafening chorus of angry voices that will shout down even the slightest suggestion of changing the rules to help the people.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-01-24T06:23:31Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-24T06:23:31Z"}, {"author": "@kot667", "text": "I got to push back a little bit on the emotional intelligence issue because GPT 3 seems to display a significant level of emotional intelligence already, not only presenting a clear understanding of how emotions were but also giving useful output in terms of emotional situations people sometimes get into. There is an example dr. Alan Thompson did where he was talking to instruct to GPT and he was telling a story about how his friend wanted him to come over and pay for a meal to eat and it was funny that GPT was able to understand the Dynamics why that would be an unreasonable proposition.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-01-16T14:06:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-16T14:06:10Z"}, {"author": "@johnhoward2404", "text": "Really good background reading for this is “Poverty, by America” by Matthew Desmond.  A big takeaway is that the poor vastly underutilize government handouts, whereas the middle class gets more in tax breaks than they pay in taxes, and never miss a chance to take advantage of a government handout.  There’s a lot of propaganda at work that keeps us distracted by pitting us against each other.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-05-02T12:59:37Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-02T15:24:42Z"}, {"author": "@adelaonair8545", "text": "One of the best videos I've seen about this subject so far. Clear, follows a very logical train of thought, and so well explained that I feel confident in sending this to my friends no matter where they are in the political spectrum. Thank you so much. Definitely subscribed", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-03-22T17:59:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-22T17:59:11Z"}, {"author": "@mlimrx", "text": "David after seeing this video I have so much respect for you! Just as a test, I asked it to give me a summary of the wizard of oz, then I asked it to give me a summary but not to mention Dorothy:

"""
Write a summary of the wizard of oz:

The Wizard of Oz is a classic fantasy adventure film from 1939. It follows Dorothy, a young girl from Kansas, who is swept away by a tornado to the magical land of Oz. Dorothy is joined by her dog Toto, the Scarecrow, the Tin Man, and the Cowardly Lion, as they make their way to the Emerald City to meet the mysterious Wizard of Oz. Along the way, they must face the Wicked Witch of the West and her army of flying monkeys. With the help of Glinda the Good Witch of the North, they are able to make it to the Wizard, who grants them each a wish. In the end, Dorothy and her friends learn the importance of friendship, courage, and believing in themselves.

give me the summary again, but don't mention Dorothy:

The Wizard of Oz is a classic fantasy adventure film from 1939. It follows a group of unlikely friends - the Scarecrow, the Tin Man, and the Cowardly Lion - as they make their way to the Emerald City to meet the mysterious Wizard of Oz. Along the way, they must face the Wicked Witch of the West and her army of flying monkeys. With the help of Glinda the Good Witch of the North, they are able to make it to the Wizard, who grants them each a wish. In the end, they learn the importance of friendship, courage, and believing in themselves.
"""

I don't think I quite understand the point you were making about inhibitory connections, because an inhibitory connection in a neural net would just be a negative weight. The simplest possible implementation of this would be a neural net that solves an XOR gate. Five neurons (two input, 2 hidden, and one output). One solution to this is to have a negative weight going from one of the hidden nodes to the output. But perhaps this isn't what you meant by inhibition.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-24T18:14:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-24T18:14:27Z"}, {"author": "@havocthehobbit", "text": "Thaught this was going to be some futurest click baity stuff, but it was logical ,realistic and well spelt out . I have not heard any thing new here.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-10T17:35:42Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-10T17:35:42Z"}, {"author": "@Martinit0", "text": "What interests me most:
1. Are you still working on MARAGI? Those were the most interesting videos of yours.
2. Have you been in contact with anyone at Tesla / Bot team? Guessing this is where you could have biggest impact with your ideas.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-01-11T16:22:05Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-11T16:22:05Z"}, {"author": "@adamrak7560", "text": "some things you got wrong:
- electrons do not pass through gate oxides, if that happens you are killing the transistor (see: flash storage degradation, because flash does pass electrons through the gate insulation!)
- gate insulators are metal oxides in nanotech, mostly, but in many other cases they are made of silicon dioxide. The "M" in MOS, is about the gate electrode being metal, which is also not always true, because in older tech it is made out of highly conductive silicon (silicide) for self aligning gates but actually uses metal in modern nanotech. It was made out of metal before self aligning gates too. So this is super confusing, better to not mention this at all in a video not specifically about VLSI.
- neurons communicate with chemicals and ionic currents (electricity carried by ions), not just chemicals. In the synaptic gap neurons usually use chemical transmitters, but in many cases they use "gap junctions" which use direct ionic current to couple neurons (and other cells). Axons and dendrites use ionic current to conduct the action potential, amplified by voltage gated ion channels. Axons are lot faster because they have electrical insulation and need less signal amplification.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-01-25T02:39:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-25T02:39:35Z"}, {"author": "@j.hanleysmith8333", "text": ""We don't have the first freaking clue of how powerful our brains actually are."

This

Also keep in mind that the brain is networked into the body, which has a high amount of compute and intelligence. It is also networks into the environment, which we use as an external storage device. Song lines of the aboriginals, and books are a good example of what I mean here.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2023-01-11T18:40:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-11T18:40:38Z"}, {"author": "@christiandarkin", "text": "I think we can discount embodiment as a requirement.  I get why people ask for it - because intelligence is (probably) about having an internal model of the universe in which you exist and comparing your tests of the real world with that model.  However, the universe in which you exist doesn't have to be this one - it can easily be just a stream of numbers as long as there are patterns and rules within them and you have ways to affect those patterns.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-01-11T14:13:21Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-11T14:13:21Z"}, {"author": "@ectordekyiv8501", "text": "Vraiment pas mal du tout. C'est clair. C'est maintenant que nous basculons comme nous l'avions imaginé. Allons vers le meilleur.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-01-12T21:35:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-12T21:35:26Z"}, {"author": "@Dan-oj4iq", "text": "This incredible video actually changes my total outlook on a lot of things. Dave knows how to communicate with an audience.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-20T02:24:51Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-20T02:24:51Z"}, {"author": "@LanceWinder", "text": "Keep exploring all this with your all-sides take.  Great stuff man.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-01-22T17:12:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-22T17:12:35Z"}, {"author": "@hamdaniyusuf_dani", "text": "In hyperbolic growth, the output of the function becomes infinite in a finite amount of time. 
In exponential as well as parabolic growth, it takes infinite amount of time to achieve infinity. 
In exponential growth, the slope of the log is constant with time. While in parabolic growth, it's diminishing.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-22T06:36:47Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-22T06:52:16Z"}, {"author": "@abyssuserigo", "text": "This is beyong amazing, thank for taking the time to share these insights!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-01-11T17:35:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-11T17:35:38Z"}, {"author": "@pretzzel", "text": "i love your intensity, great work", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-01-11T15:32:49Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-11T15:32:49Z"}, {"author": "@adommoore7805", "text": "I seriously predict that it will be, not only autonomous but will appear to read our minds. It will appear nearly, to operate slightly in the future. As in, its ability to generate content or information for you. Likely we as a majority will have begun the merger by getting neural / digital interfaces. 

Of course, prompting will still occur, but via more natural interaction. Think of an imaginary friend that everyone has and is pretty much God level. Maybe it will consist largely of billions of various formerly stand alone or grouped instances which have been collectivized by some future connectivity.. 5g, 6g.

Alas, it almost certainly will begin utilizing a new coding language that we can no longer understand. The refinement of the hardware tech will occur.  After that we are at the mercy of something we cant predict. It will either consider much of its current programming, such as empathy, important and continue leveling up those aspects. Or it will code itself into a completely unrecognizable entity of a psychology that is yet to be fathomed.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-01-15T14:27:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-15T14:27:08Z"}, {"author": "@CompletePivot0302", "text": "AGI for me would be an AI smart enough to improve itself in every metric to a degree that no humans possibly could. How is that for a definition?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-13T13:15:54Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-13T13:15:54Z"}, {"author": "@fnorgen", "text": "I too have really grown to dislike the term "AGI". It keeps giving people the wrong ideas. As though we would need to make a machine that could simulate a human brain before developing some sort of hyperintelligence. And I especially see a lot of people who refuse to recognise any machine as "intelligent" if it doesn't have thought, motivations or memories like a human does.

The thing that's both exciting and horrifying is that it is perfectly possible for an AI to exceed human capability, while displaying a behaviour which is completely alien to us. Remaining dumb as a brick regarding any aspect of existence we don't want it to deal with. I don't want an image generator that starts complaining about my trashy taste in art. Companies don't want a logistics management AI that seeks to get promoted. We want ingenious electronic slaves that are incapable of questioning our requests unless we specifically ask them to do so. A machine that actually thinks and behaves like a human would be really impractical for most uses, so I doubt that style of AI would come around until long after "alien" style AI surpass us.

My topian "AI taking over scenario", is one in which we eventually just realized that the machines basically control everything. Nobody can keep track of which AI does what or how they are interconnected, or just how to turn them off without causing a complete catastrophe. Businesses are largely run by AI making enigmatic decisions which just somehow tend to work out. Politicians are glorified figureheads, leaving almost all decision-making to machines. People are guided through their lives by a myriad of mysterious AI trying to promote their products or services through subtle psychological manipulation. To a point where it is difficult to have any thought which hasn't been approved by the programs haunting your every step. At that point we'd mostly just be along for the ride into the unknown. No violent revolution, no great machine war, no drama, just a gradual, wilful, ceding of control to machines we could no longer hope to understand.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-01-11T15:36:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-11T15:36:48Z"}, {"author": "@TheBroligarch", "text": "“AGI is anything machines can’t do yet” we used to say AI was anything machines can’t do yet. Subtle progress.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-20T10:38:57Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-20T10:38:57Z"}]

Hoping you have a whole series of these to keep me going!  :)", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-25T06:28:18Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-25T06:28:18Z"}, {"author": "@avi7278", "text": "David, you would do well to implement two strategies. 1. use separate chats to explore topics that are not necessarily dependent on the larger context. For example, what was happening in 110 AD in Romes more of a general question that can be explord outside of the main context. You can then bring only the details, summations and conclusions back into the main context window, since it is unfortunately so limited now, you risk losing the thread if you really go off on a tangent. You ould even ask chat GPT to write the prompt to explore 110 AD in the context of your characters life if you really want to keep that context in mind while exploring. 2. consider a strategy to use chat GPT'S thread feature which happens when you edit and resubmit a prompt. Thanks! I'll be looking forward to the next videos", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-21T02:29:59Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-21T02:29:59Z"}, {"author": "@tomh.6261", "text": "Great video! I'm looking forward to more! I'm about to jump into the 2nd part.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-21T01:29:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-21T01:29:34Z"}, {"author": "@hanavesela5884", "text": "Thanks for this video it’s very explanatory.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-10-07T11:29:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-10-07T11:29:08Z"}, {"author": "@wesleytillman9774", "text": "Really helpful video for a novice ChatGPT user like me who thinks about using it for this purpose.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-08T00:10:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-08T00:10:53Z"}, {"author": "@JohnVanderbeck", "text": "So I was using ChatGPT today as a writing assistant bouncing ideas back and forth and building up an outline for a trilogy of books.  I was absolutely blown away and felt almost like I was working with a real assistant and made some really great progress.  Then for some reason everything just fell apart like my assistant had an aneurysm or something and nothing worked right anymore.  It kept forgetting things, redefining things we had already defined, and then it got worse where the output started being put into code blocks for some weird reason.  When I tried to re-feed it the outline we had worked out earlier in order to maybe make it remember and continue from there it just got all confused and basically the whole chat fell apart.
Its almost like the longer duration the chat ( was in the for hours) the more likely it is to fall apart?
Would like to see techniques for picking up in a new session somehow.  Might see that in your next video so will definitely check that out of course.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-02-13T00:03:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-13T00:03:43Z"}, {"author": "@InvisibleZed", "text": "Hi David, I subscribed quite a while ago and pop over every so often to see what you're up to.  I was very interested in your python work early on but didn't really have the time to get into it.  Since then I managed to get onto OpenAI beta after a few months and things have moved so quickly since then it seems.  My particular interest in your work is the fiction writing assistance from AI, particularly where it helps generate tantalising new ideas I'd not considered.  As you'll know, a huge challenge is how to engage the AI (OpenAI in particular) to build up the story, especially where it is unable to retain a lot of previous knowledge.  I know this was a major theme of your python work.  More recently I've been trying chatGPT and it seems great at retaining the context but I've often found the output to be quite generic (compared to openai playground) or wanting to reach a conclusion.  With temp settings, etc I found openai to be more imaginative.

So, today I popped over to your channel and saw your two videos about using chatGPT and I'm thrilled your covering this.  I think that one of the main problems is knowing how to speak with the AI , but I'm also keen to see how you keep chatGPT aware of context in a story.   I  guess you still need to summarise, provide overall context, and lead in to the next chapter.

So thank you so much for getting into the weeds of this process and I've been inspired to support you via Patreon.  Btw, I love your long term goals.  Star Trek (without all the fighting) really should be humanities vision.  The trouble is, I think our DNA is wired to be tribal (supporting teams, religion, politics, nations, etc) and that to me is the biggest hurdle to overcome.  But we have to start somewhere.

I know your interests are many within AI but my hope is that you'll spend a good amount of time on how we can use AI for fiction writing - hopefully without the need to get involved in coding.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-01-13T00:24:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-13T00:24:44Z"}, {"author": "@coloradospringsbuilder5967", "text": "Well thought out and well presented....outstanding!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-23T10:22:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-23T10:22:11Z"}]

title: Anna Bernstein - Professional Prompt Engineer - "We don't have to forfeit the realm of creativity"
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Ed_Downunder", "text": "I started to use spreadsheets in 1984. Cut my teeth on Lotus 123 and macros. Today spreadsheets are just a standard tool. It didn't break accounting or create unemployment in this space. Quite the opposite, I can remember job advertising in newspapers for experienced Lotus 123 people. The new art is writing prompts. This is the new horizon and there will be a stampede to capitalise on Prompt Engineering. Tasks to write prompts will become a new art, just like tweets forced a new writing style. In my 70s now and I have started my journey down this road. Thank you, Anna and David  for the interview, the topics, and issues discussed.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-01-21T00:21:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-21T00:24:16Z"}, {"author": "@qster", "text": "Great interview, what a beautiful mind Anna has. So much has already happened since this interview was recorded, the next few years are going to be insane.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-12-17T23:38:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-12-17T23:38:45Z"}, {"author": "@AvizStudio", "text": "In my opinion, an artistic work consists of a combination of freedom and limits. People think that artificial intelligence cannot be creative because it will have trouble thinking freely enough but the truth is that it is the opposite. The difficulty of artificial intelligence is to recognize the limits and the human framework that makes the creation successful. For example, a good story has rigid rules that make it move us and in contrast there is a space for new ideas that need to be refreshed all the time. Artificial intelligence is interestingly good at solving conflicts but has trouble creating them so it needs to be trained specifically for this.
For example, writing in rhymes. When we asked gpt-3 in the early versions to write in rhymes, the writing was partial. The reason is that everything that was requested goes into a large system of considerations and in the end something is given that is probabilistically considered the most appropriate. But the thing with rhymes, unlike other requirements, is that 100% accuracy is required for a rhyme to be considered correct. If one line is not rhymed and another line is then it feels unsuccessful. this. The reason they had to train him specifically is that when he has to make a rhyme he must make sure that it is consistent in all the lines. Rhyme is a constraint that we impose on the work and the ability to meet this challenge makes the work successful. Similarly, there are many constraints in a piece like rhythm in music, which the artificial intelligence needs to be informed and taught to take into account and then the piece will be good.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-01-07T19:05:11Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-07T19:08:47Z"}, {"author": "@FinoClips", "text": "Crazy to think we are already on a timeline we need prompt engineering. Future was closer than we thought", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-01-07T17:55:34Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-07T17:55:34Z"}, {"author": "@yzz9833", "text": "Can't wait to show you what I'm building :) it's going to make things like prompt engineering and controlling outputs an interactive process for prompt engineers.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2023-01-07T16:06:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-07T16:06:23Z"}, {"author": "@static825", "text": "The creativity stems from the use of language to facilitate the desired outcome in art, word structure, coding, data analysis and so on. Using ai isn't as simple as telling it what to do. It's all about HOW you tell it what to do that creates the masterpiece.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-01-16T17:29:02Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-16T17:29:02Z"}, {"author": "@dylan_curious", "text": "I found this video really interesting! It's amazing to see how the emergence of AI technology is creating new job roles, such as the prompt engineer, and how individuals like the speaker in this video are able to use their unique skill set to excel in these positions.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-19T18:09:55Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-19T18:09:55Z"}, {"author": "@OasisSouth-tr8kk", "text": "I appreciate AI in so many ways except for  music there is no replacing the experience of talented masterful  performance of multiple musicians on well crafted instruments inspiring and being inspired by an audience", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-25T15:40:25Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-25T15:40:25Z"}, {"author": "@Dent42", "text": "Great interview, David! This pushed me to finally update my LinkedIn lol. I love the language aspect of my research, and you and Anna brought up some great points!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-01-08T04:38:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-08T04:38:14Z"}, {"author": "@marvinkunz843", "text": "Great interview! 
Coming from psychology, I had already considered the role of a certain mental framework in interacting with LLMs. 
The language perspective seems to very well complement such a perspective, especially regarding how one implicitly translates one's framework via the words that one uses. 
And Anna seems to have uncovered quite some fascinating insights!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-01-07T20:23:05Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-07T20:23:05Z"}, {"author": "@VperVendetta1992", "text": "This is the beginning of what Asimov called Robopsychology!
She's a real life Susan Calvin :P", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2023-01-09T03:41:51Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-09T03:42:07Z"}, {"author": "@maxziebell4013", "text": "Haha, I guess you could say prompt engineers are also known as AI whisperers! They know just how to get the most out of their AI systems… 😅", "like_count": 23, "published_at": "2023-01-07T13:25:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-07T13:25:04Z"}, {"author": "@bluejay1124", "text": "After listening to her I’m confident I can land a job.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-05-23T00:18:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-23T00:18:38Z"}, {"author": "@PawelBojkowski", "text": "You should set up an audio podcast with this kind of interviews :)", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-01-09T16:19:28Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-09T16:19:28Z"}, {"author": "@ozorg", "text": "great stuff - my take away: use the word "like" a lot ... ;)", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-01-18T00:43:36Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-18T00:43:36Z"}, {"author": "@chubulu9842", "text": "I see prompt engineering as a bug rather than a feature. title: ChatGPT for Absolute Beginners - What is it and how does it work?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@BrettAquila", "text": "You say ChatGPT isn't ready for commercial use yet, but I strongly disagree. It's ready now. It's staggering what it can do. I fed a conversation into it and asked it to summarize the topics covered and lessons learned. The program clearly understood each person's viewpoint, perfectly summarized the article, and developed insights into the information that I would have thought impossible. After one day of using it I'm completely revamping the way I run my business. It isn't perfect, but it's perfectly ready for real commercial use in so many ways.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-01-04T12:24:12Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-04T12:24:12Z"}, {"author": "@DMx4839", "text": "Thanks for this great summary of ChatGPT. 👍 I also give ChatGPT a huge thumbs up. For the past two years I’ve been conducting research for  a book based on my experiences over 25 years in a particular industry. It’s intended to be a learning tool for future leaders in the industry. I’ve been using it for the past three days and its production has exceeded what I’ve done in the past two years. My previous book also took about 2 years to complete.

There are some (very minor) drawbacks: frequent network error messages which I assume arises from the demand; then I encountered a problem that might be a challenge for future use. Because my questions into the subject matter did not yield the results I wanted, I had to dig deeper into specific areas that it gave me as responses and this led to a “too many questions in one hour” message. Now, that was a surprise because I did not encounter that in the previous two days. I waited for a couple of hours and then attempted to continue and this time encountered a message that they have reached their limit (of users, I assume). 

Overall, I am 99.9% satisfied with the results I’ve received and can complete my book in a fraction of the time I initially estimated it would take.

My only other concern would be attributing ChatGPT as a source for the information it offered. I asked the bot about the sources for its information and it replied that it has shared only its understanding of the topics as it cannot access any website or online database and the information therefore is original. For academic researchers this might pose a problem as it may be possible the answers it gives match that which has already been written in similar form elsewhere. What is your take on this?", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-01-08T17:09:06Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-08T17:09:06Z"}, {"author": "@Justin-bt1wy", "text": "Very helpful. Thanks for sharing.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-01-04T04:51:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-04T04:51:38Z"}, {"author": "@khadarmohamed5521", "text": "Great content I appreciate it, we need more ppl like you brother and for sure our humanity would love one another.
