title: I took down my videos and code that could write novels. I'm glad I did.
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Crybyte", "text": "It's interesting to think we're moving away from thinking of technology as a tool, to thinking of it as a steroid: "Man, can you believe Linus wrote the linux kernel natty?!"", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-12-15T04:47:42Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-15T04:47:42Z"}, {"author": "@montsamu", "text": "How much disruption has "AI art" really done? Is there any measurement so far for this? I *do* see AI generated novels doing fairly well, sales wise, in the very near future. People want 10-20 book series as comfort food, as wish fulfillment fantasies, etc. and so on. Novels that *can* be written like this *will* be in the very, very near future (perhaps even by the end of this year!).", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-12-16T14:59:44Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-16T14:59:44Z"}, {"author": "@christiandarkin", "text": "the split is a good thing.  art will benefit from having people who go all-in with AI and others who leave it alone.  Think of photography - its invention was seen as the end of the road for painters.  instead, it spurred them on to create surrealism, impressionism, pop art, and more.  The recognition that art wasn't about accurate representation of the world freed artists to be more creative.  At the same time, photography went off and created its own art forms including film and animation.  150 years later, there are more people working with traditional oil paints than there ever were.  

Sure, we can't see that right now with AI because we haven't played with it enough to understand it yet.  We need to sit with this stuff, make what we can, see what we can't, and find new art forms.

The bottom line is that killing off an art form is really really hard.  100,000 years ago, we started painting on walls.  That stopped for a while when we created new media and paints, but then someone invented the car, and cars needed spray paints - and suddenly every vertical surface in every city is covered in cave paintings again.    

And - who would have thought that Tik-tok would be the launching pad that revived the sea shanty?  

Art will find a way.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2022-12-15T09:39:19Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-15T09:43:59Z"}, {"author": "@Hannah_from_iterationscrafts", "text": "I totally respect the moral dilemma you find yourself in. But I think it’s important to also say that the backlash to AI Art is hurting a lot of real people too. A lot of us have started incorporating AI into our art and we are now getting hit hard with hateful comments and boycotts. And people going on AI witch hunts where they are trying to guess which digital artists use AI in some way and try to pressure companies to drop them as artists or get people to bombard them on social media. I’ve been crying every day since the backlash really took off. The hours every day I spend in creative work are suddenly considered worthless by so many people. You of course have a super nuanced and thoughtful and informed take on all of this. But most of the people using these hashtags do not. I guess I’m just wanting people to remember in the midst of this backlash that humans are using these tools in many different stages of their artistic process and the division between “human artists” and “not human artists” is a false one  it’s just way too oversimplified in the social media hashtag world right now.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2022-12-14T22:09:32Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-14T22:09:32Z"}, {"author": "@nuvotion-live", "text": "As we all know, mathematicians all lost their jobs once the calculator was invented.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-01-22T04:35:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-22T04:35:52Z"}, {"author": "@nuvotion-live", "text": "I think the starting point for art should be what is it saying? and is it GOOD? Would you hang it on your wall? None of that Lexica art means anything, it's lost all context, and features work that is consistently unsettling, uncomfortable, just plain wrong. They look good at a glance but looking any closer reveals multiple limbs, soulless eyes. All style and no substance. That's to say nothing of the work that it was unethically trained on. It's the kind of thing where knowing it was synthesized so quickly is creating this effect that blinds people to the artistic merit of the work.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-22T04:27:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-22T04:27:08Z"}, {"author": "@shaundavis", "text": "AI will eventually help to solve the economic problem. You aren’t contributing to hurting people, you were enlightening many more by lowering the barrier to entry to an emerging technology. 

In my opinion you’ve made the wrong call. I love your videos because you make AI in all of its disciplines more accessible. This is a such a shame and I appreciate that you have to follow your moral compass but I really feel like the moral is hypocritical because anything that you do could be classed as harmful to somebody if you boil it down and crystallise it enough. 

Personally I hope this doesn’t become a slippery slope because you’re one of the best value providers I’ve discovered in this space!!! 

Thank you for all that you do and good luck wrestling with this as things continue to evolve at an unimaginable pace.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2022-12-14T20:33:43Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-14T20:33:43Z"}, {"author": "@CircuitrinosOfficial", "text": "If someone were to create a website that only respects human artists, how would they tell the difference?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-14T20:35:49Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-14T20:35:49Z"}, {"author": "@MultiAlfedo", "text": ""It is not the most intellectual of the species that survives; it is not the strongest that survives; but the species that survives is the one that is able best to adapt and adjust to the changing environment in which it finds itself." - Charles Darwin", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-15T02:52:41Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-15T02:52:41Z"}, {"author": "@yarralink6138", "text": "Respect your choice.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-15T08:55:00Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-15T08:55:00Z"}, {"author": "@ChadThieleChaddeus", "text": "This is precisely how I'm building Chibi AI -- a tool to augment the writer, not completely replace them. There is a TON of pressure to "automate things" though. We'll see how this shakes out.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-15T13:52:03Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-15T13:52:03Z"}, {"author": "@ene_77", "text": "why dont you continue the tutorial series? Lots of people hoping in the AI space now", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-14T20:41:24Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-14T20:41:24Z"}, {"author": "@rowan404", "text": "As someone who’s both a programmer and an artist, I honestly don’t see a problem with AI art. The problem arises when people claim that they drew the art or even just steal other people’s art and put it through a filter. Art theft has always existed; AI art has just provided a new means for it. However, AI art can still be useful to _artists_ to generate concept art, provide inspiration, etc. Not only that, but AI art often has obvious imperfections, such as extra appendages, and it can’t give generate art of, say, a unique-looking OC or a character from an underrated source. Although I currently live off of my parents’ income, I hope to live off of writing books and taking commissions in the future (among other things), and AI art doesn’t worry me. On the contrary, I see AI as a helper, as a companion, as a bright future.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-14T23:43:09Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-14T23:47:07Z"}]

Thanks for your work and contribution.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-12T22:08:29Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-12T22:08:29Z"}, {"author": "@Martinit0", "text": "Hi David, 
Great post!
The official announcement that fusion ignition has been achieved at NIF came just as your video went online. So good nose ;-)


The funny thing about laser-based fusion is that the US has a big gap in commercial laser capability: There is NIF, which is a unique government entity and then there is nothing up until relatively 'pedestrian' commercial lasers by companies like Coherent (COHR) and MKS Instruments (MKSI), formerly Newport Spectra-Physics. The market of ultra-high power commercial lasers has been left to the Europeans, specifically two French companies Amplitude Technologies and Thales (yes, the defense giant).

However, NIF and other US national labs still hold significant experience in very large scale lasers and laser optical systems (like how to manufacture them). So the big question is now will this NIF achievement trigger any development in the US laser industry or will they leave the field to the Europeans?

My guess is US companies won't pick up the tech because the commercial opportunity of laser-based fusion is still far away and relatively uncertain and the business would be quite 'lumpy', i.e. one could only expect to sell _maybe_ a handful systems per year.


I also share your excitement regarding the other technologies, although I think that photonic chips are way too physically large to compete with silicon chips. But the article and paper you mentioned looks really interesting in as they have taken a different approach to training neural networks, not just tried to replicate silicon based algorithms.

Hopefully the first CRISPR-based gene editing treatment will be approved by FDA next year - so far it's looking good and on track - first patients that participated in the clinical trials have already been cured.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2022-12-13T17:04:18Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-13T17:04:18Z"}, {"author": "@thatssokwekwe", "text": "19:10 this was a phenomenal and elucidating synthesis of what’s at stake", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-17T22:34:30Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-17T22:34:30Z"}, {"author": "@LEARNTAU", "text": "Great video! title: ChatGPT - Good, Bad, Indifferent. What will it change? What does this mean?
top_comments: [{"author": "@Anders01", "text": "Wow, I now tested a headline from CNN and asked ChatGPT: Is this text grammatically correct: \"World Cup champion France edges out England to reach semifinals as Harry Kane misses penalty.\" ? And it replied: \"Yes, the text you provided is grammatically correct. It uses proper nouns, verb tenses, and sentence structure to convey a clear and concise message. The sentence is easy to understand and does not contain any errors or inconsistencies. The use of the verb \"edges out\" is particularly effective in conveying the idea that France narrowly defeated England to advance to the semifinals, and the mention of Harry Kane's missed penalty adds an additional layer of detail and context to the story. Overall, the text is well-written and uses correct grammar.\"", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-12-10T23:36:04Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-10T23:36:04Z"}, {"author": "@zr1411", "text": "So happy you're still here! Been assuming/wondering about the secret project for a couple months now, looking forward to the reveal!", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2022-12-09T20:29:10Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-09T20:29:10Z"}, {"author": "@azuredominus5739", "text": "This aged like milk", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-02-12T15:57:09Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-12T15:57:09Z"}, {"author": "@Anders01", "text": "I asked ChatGPT if it could ask me a question and it replied: \"Sure, here is a question for you: What is your favorite thing about learning new things?\" But it only followed up with one more question, and then became a bit repetitive. There seems to be a huge difference between GPT-3 and ChatGPT however. GPT-3 said that a jellybean will break a violin into four pieces, while ChatGPT explained why a jellybean can't break a violin in any ordinary circumstances.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-10T22:45:33Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-10T22:45:33Z"}, {"author": "@RowanSheridan", "text": "I agree that using chatgpt as a replacement for search is very expensive - you argue too expensive. However, I think it's important to consider the benefits that chatgpt provides in terms of the personalized and conversational experience it offers. While it may be costly, it can also provide valuable insights and improve the overall user's \"search for an answer\" experience. I think the fundamentals of search will change, perhaps tired - in terms of cost of access. So Google will still be used (free + more adverts), but a tool like chatgpt will offer more that just search as we've seen and it will have a subscription model.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2022-12-09T21:12:15Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-09T21:12:15Z"}, {"author": "@theKonshus1", "text": "I will say that using chatGPT for several real-world chats for me, it summarized technical articles and gave me working code where I'd find it worth $0.20 / question.  I'm a github copilot user and a little bit in love with its usefulness for the data science I use it for.  I don't think this conflicts with what you're saying about it not being a revolution.  However, the pace of developments in models and the developer--> public attention has been astounding to me so far.    It seems likely to me to lead into an amazing hype cycle.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2022-12-09T21:17:42Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-09T21:17:42Z"}, {"author": "@rowan404", "text": "Last month, I created a chatbot according to your tutorial (hence why I’m subscribed to you), and it’s _far_ better than ChatGPT to the point that I haven’t even tried the latter.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2022-12-09T21:50:29Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-09T21:50:48Z"}, {"author": "@matts9299", "text": "Hmmm, ChatGPT sometimes asks me questions actually. It happens when you give it a text with a missing context. Specifically when it is not clear what it should do with the data that I input there.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-16T16:58:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-16T16:58:52Z"}, {"author": "@nuvotion-live", "text": "I’m working on an AGI scripting framework that uses the unofficial ChatGPT API, and I’m mind blowing and very satisfied by the results. I will definitely reach out to you, I’d love to get your perspective. It’s “scripting” in the way that actors read scripts to learn their characters, and can provide feedback on their own roles.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-25T03:22:14Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-25T03:22:14Z"}, {"author": "@Ianosh79", "text": "First question I asked was: \"Are you just a GPT-3 model?\" It said he wasn't, I don't even think he understood what I was asking...", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-12T15:47:14Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-12T15:47:14Z"}, {"author": "@rowan404", "text": "I’d say this is more of an AI spring. I remember looking into making a chatbot using the GPT-3 in the latter half of 2021, searching for tutorials, guides, etc, not finding anything, and resorting to Tensorflow. That didn’t work well for me at all due to the lack of spontaneity and difficulty creating curated training data, so I gave up. Then, about 2 months ago, my interest peaked again after I encountered a new GPT-3 based chatbot called CharacterAI. I once again searched for tutorials and was shocked by how much the GPT-3 had exploded in just a year.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-12-10T00:15:00Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-10T00:15:00Z"}, {"author": "@Martinit0", "text": "I could see a commercial use in marketing: churning out social media posts or blog posts. So basically creative writing in a business context.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-11T22:13:31Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-11T22:13:31Z"}, {"author": "@maxziebell4013", "text": "The utility of GTP, even though it may not be completely accurate, is increasing for many users. I have been using the GTP playground for a while now to stimulate my thinking. It reminds me of the situation with Wikipedia, which is and was often dismissed as unreliable because anyone can edit it. However, even if that is still true to some extent, the usefulness of Wikipedia is too great to ignore.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-10T00:09:48Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-10T00:10:42Z"}, {"author": "@maxziebell4013", "text": "What about making it sparse AI… hence, a little down the line, it should become much cheaper to run?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-09T23:49:49Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-09T23:49:49Z"}, {"author": "@Hiroprotagonist253", "text": "Great video. Thanks. Do you have a reading list for someone looking to get into AI?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-13T19:23:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-13T19:23:45Z"}, {"author": "@KevinWPage", "text": "Wow!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-10T02:32:01Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-10T02:32:01Z"}]

Perhaps,  your channel might be the 1st I've ever subscribed to, which would be a big step in engagement for me!

Anyway, the point is that I'm researching and experimenting with LLMs, so far GPT3 exclusively, as a speech interface to a robot much like Engineered Arts have done with Ameca but my robot isn't as advanced - but so far the degree of integration I've managed is a lot tighter, although still effectively just a chat bot but within a context that includes information about the state of the robot and recent events it has experienced or observed.

Any kind of AGI is beyond my scope right now, I still need to build an intent system into it so that GPT3 has the ability to cause the robot to do something physically, but what I'm working on definitely cross polinates with some of what you're doing - how can an LLM actually act as a brain with real-world actions and not just as a chatbot.

title: Metaprompting with GPT-3 (getting GPT-3 to write its own prompts) RECURSIVE NLP PROGRAMMING!!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@user-me2db4qs2h", "text": "I asked gpt3 : "How can I solve problem X?"  response:

some general tips for solving problems include:
- Breaking the problem down into smaller, more manageable pieces
- Identifying the root cause of the problem
- Developing and implementing a plan of action
- Evaluating the effectiveness of the plan and making necessary adjustments
- Communicating with others involved in the problem-solving process
- staying positive and persistent

I think it might work in a way like a recursive function so you need to have some control over its depth and spread
I think/hope that gpt4 will be able to develop this chain of thoughts by itself (in sense of meta prompt), although I have a feeling that gpt3 should also be able to do so but It will be trickier.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2022-09-20T02:44:29Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-20T02:44:29Z"}, {"author": "@j.hanleysmith8333", "text": "You could take your last chunk of output, vectorize it, and do a similarity search against a database of source material (info about the world, the characters, Etc).

Use the injection of the outside material to drive the story.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-09-20T05:26:03Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-20T05:27:10Z"}, {"author": "@Ed_Downunder", "text": "Just doodling.

def meta_prompt():
    replies = []
    user_input = input("Please describe the issue: ")
    replies.append(user_input)
    for i in range(10):
        response = generate_response(user_input)
        print(f"Response {i+1}: ", response)
        replies.append(response)
        user_input = response
    return replies
This function, meta_prompt(), will first prompt the user to enter a description of an issue. Then, it will iterate 10 times, each time calling a generate_response(user_input) function to generate a response based on the previous response and printing the response with a number, also it will append the response to the replies list. On each iteration, the previous response becomes the new input for the generate_response() function. After 10 iterations, the function will return the replies list, which will contain a history of the generated responses based on the first prompt.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-21T14:36:01Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-21T14:36:01Z"}, {"author": "@eumarcoaureliorosa", "text": "how did you sent those big prompts into GPT? Mine limits at 4000 tokens", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-01-14T19:59:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-14T19:59:48Z"}, {"author": "@nicovicencio-heap6238", "text": "i stumbled onto this recently, and started asking gpt3 to design prompts to put into codex to make code with the desired outcome", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-02T05:44:38Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-02T05:44:38Z"}]

title: State of the Industry: Hydra Attention for 197x boost in transformer speed
top_comments: [{"author": "@j.hanleysmith8333", "text": "Absolutely amazing, it's a great time to be alive!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-09-20T05:39:13Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-20T05:39:13Z"}, {"author": "@hursheybars", "text": "@9:43 you talk about how there was an advancement in understanding loss function around 2014-2015, that kind of kicked off this Renaissance of deep learning because we were able to figure out how to optimize larger and larger networks. Can you share some more resources about this algorithmic improvement I would love to learn more!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-20T18:21:35Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-20T18:21:35Z"}, {"author": "@jiggi2308", "text": "Isnt T the number of Tokens from the Backbone with the Depth D ?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-10-04T21:38:44Z", "updated_at": "2022-10-04T21:38:44Z"}, {"author": "@hjups", "text": "It looks like the innovation in this paper may not be so useful for NLP. They largely relied on replacing the softmax with cosine-similarity (a dot product), which is both less computationally intensive, and allows for up-stream simplification. They also had the plot showing the top-1 accuracy which is lower compared to softmax, except in the case of many heads (so parallelism is not only a feature, but a requirement). Though that's not to say that it won't work, but the accuracy loss may not be worth it.\n\nSince you mentioned improving inference speed/latency, what are your thoughts on model size? Since your cognitive workloads rely on prompt-chaining, would using smaller models (which could inference faster) be better than a large model? For example, if you could inference 2K tokens on GPT-J-6B in 1 second on a local machine vs inferencing 4K tokens on GPT-3 in 12s on a cloud WSE?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-12-30T00:26:00Z", "updated_at": "2022-12-30T00:26:00Z"}, {"author": "@narutocole", "text": "Holy crap this is insane", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-19T21:02:45Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-19T21:02:45Z"}, {"author": "@narutocole", "text": "I guess my big question is will this be able to be used in fine-tuning?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-09-19T21:04:49Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-19T21:04:49Z"}]

title: State of the Industry: Short-circuiting Reward Functions
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Please consider supporting me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/daveshap", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-15T12:19:30Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-15T12:19:30Z"}, {"author": "@vulnerablegrowth3774", "text": "A few notes:

- The difference between short-term and long-term planning is usually mentioned in the context of things like deceptive models. If a deceptive (misaligned) model is non-myopic (can do long-term planning like a step-by-step 3 year plan to organize society), it can plan to deceptively do all the things it needs to in order to trick us. If the model is myopic, it's much less likely for it to have the capability to deceptively trick us with a long-term plan. It could come up with a series of separate thoughts that lead to a long-term plan, but may have a hard time structuring the entire plan with an end-goal of deception in mind. Whether that ends up being the case is unclear.

- When people talk about "world model" in these papers, they do in fact mean the world model that is baked in the model (like GPT-3).

- I feel it should be mentioned that much of these papers are a response to how things are currently being put forth by companies like DeepMind, mostly because those are the places that are the most likely to build AGI. They are not talking about your approach since it's not even on the radar of such companies. I do like that you are engaging with these papers, though! And to be clear, some people within the alignment community do also disagree with this paper.

I haven't gone over them, but hopefully I can go over them and give my thoughts within the next few months and hopefully we can have a chat.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-09-15T19:54:04Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-15T19:54:04Z"}, {"author": "@alan2here", "text": "good episode :)", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-09-15T14:03:43Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-15T14:03:43Z"}, {"author": "@alan2here", "text": "Humans have learning as an automatic function.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-09-15T14:01:49Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-15T14:01:49Z"}, {"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Original Paper: https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/aaai.12064", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-15T12:17:54Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-15T12:17:54Z"}, {"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Inner Alignment paper: https://intelligence.org/learned-optimization/", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-15T12:18:07Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-15T12:18:07Z"}, {"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "My book about alignment: https://github.com/daveshap/BenevolentByDesign", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-15T12:18:34Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-15T12:18:34Z"}, {"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "My book about autonomous cognitive agents: https://github.com/daveshap/SymphonyOfThought", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-15T12:18:54Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-15T12:18:54Z"}, {"author": "@charliesteiner2334", "text": "Props for the general habit of reading papers, but I think you missed the point of this one. E.g. by distal and proximal goals they kinda mean "external to the agent" and "internal to the agent" - so for humans it wouldn't be genetic fitness vs. eating (that one *is* the analogue to inner alignment), it would be eating vs. feeling the sensation of eating (which isn't really a problem analogous to inner alignment).

Yes, I still agree this is basic and makes lots of assumptions. I can only shrug.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-17T06:55:03Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-17T06:59:40Z"}, {"author": "@StephenWRiebeSUNIJIM250", "text": "2025 - 2026", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-02-15T04:59:09Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-15T04:59:09Z"}]

title: State of the Industry: AGI alignment, control problem, and missing conversations
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Please consider supporting me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/daveshap?fan_landing=true", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-11T11:20:58Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-11T11:20:58Z"}, {"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Lawrence Kohlberg's Stages of Moral Development: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Kohlberg%27s_stages_of_moral_development", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-11T11:19:53Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-11T11:19:53Z"}, {"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "OpenAI's approach to alignment: https://openai.com/blog/our-approach-to-alignment-research/", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-11T11:18:43Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-11T11:18:43Z"}, {"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "My book Symphony of Thought: https://github.com/daveshap/SymphonyOfThought", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-11T11:20:08Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-11T11:20:08Z"}, {"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Less Wrong table on alignment research: https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/QBAjndPuFbhEXKcCr/my-understanding-of-what-everyone-in-technical-alignment-is", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-11T11:18:22Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-11T11:18:22Z"}, {"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "80000 Hours: is disruptive AI coming faster? https://80000hours.org/2022/08/is-transformative-ai-coming-sooner-than-we-thought/", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-11T11:19:18Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-11T11:19:18Z"}, {"author": "@vulnerablegrowth3774", "text": "Hey David, I work in AI Alignment and I work in the same building as the guys who wrote that post on LessWrong and know a lot of the people in the papers and posts you go through in this video. I understand the field can be frustrating. However, I honestly there’s quite a lot that I feel you’ve misunderstood about the field.

1) The people working in alignment care about the existential risk factor. AI Ethics is not alignment and nobody in the field claims it is. The only people saying this are people who are saying it for PR reasons.
2) We are all highly aware of the 4 pillars you talk about. It shapes a lot of our research. The problem is that some empirical research is simply not possible with the current models that exist. There are things that were simply not possible with GPT-2 compared to GPT-3, and we expect that trend to continue. There are some things like mesa-optimization where the model get develop it’s own internal sub-goal and then develop its own search algorithm to do things (it would be inner-misaligned). This is basically purely theoretical at the moment, but that’s because models are not sufficiently powerful enough to do things like deception. Researchers are aware it is theoretical and some are trying to come up with experiments we can run now, others just don’t think it’s possible until we have more powerful models. So, we can either wait until that kind of thing is possible or we can do the theoretical work in advance in order to figure out how to best deal with such systems. We’ve only got one shot to align AGI and waiting until things are only empirically testable is a bad idea. Part of the theoretical work allows us to come up with experiments we can quickly run to test future models. Lots of people in the field do agree there needs to be an integration between the empirical cutting-edge and theoretical research. That is partially why Anthropic exists.
3) People in alignment do not see the work of ‘aligning’ current language models as AI Alignment because the current models are not powerful enough to really matter and scaling language models will cause other issues. However, some people have the plan to throw everything in their tool-belt like Red-Teaming to do our best to be certain that a superintelligent AGI is aligned. If we can have a set of tools that work together to make us more confident that powerful models are safe, that is a good thing.
4) Things like interpretability are not a sure-shot. As a model becomes superintelligent, it may be impossible to interpret and be 100% certain that what the model is telling us is true. If a model is not aligned and superintelligent, our interpretability tools will simply not matter. However, interpretability is good for understanding what the model’s internals are doing. You can prompt your model however you like, if it’s misaligned, it will just say what you want to hear until it doesn’t in order to pursue its other goal.
5) There are several worst-case guarentee research directions that try to deal with bad scenarios. It is simply not possible to run some experiments with the current models that exist and be certain that it will be useful and scale to superintelligence.
6) Lots of people in AI Alignment are quite aware of the fact that some experiments are only possible at the big labs. Academia and independent researchers can’t check the internals of GPT-3 or GPT-4. They can’t pre-train GPT-3 from scratch. You are limited in the scope of experiments you can run. That is partially why some of them work on theoretical work they hope to eventually integrate into the model training process. Yet almost everyone agrees there’s a disconnect and a gap to bridge. The criticism on this is absolutely warranted. And that’s why some alignment researchers go to work at OpenAI or DeepMind. They hope to bridge that gap or at least be there when models become sufficiently powerful so they can integrate the theoretical with the experiments right away.

There is definitely a lot of disagreement in the field, but there is a reason for that. We’re in a pre-paradigmatic field and it’s not like any other science where you can go out and test your superintelligence right now. It doesn’t exist yet!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-09-12T02:49:56Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-12T02:49:56Z"}, {"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "My book Benevolent by Design: https://github.com/daveshap/BenevolentByDesign", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-11T11:20:31Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-11T11:20:31Z"}]

title: Research Update: Heuristic Imperatives microservice demonstration and theory
top_comments:
[{"author": "@alan2here", "text": "Describe foreign language words that do not have English equivalents:

Schadenfreude, Germany --> Taking pleasure in the misfortune of others.

Satori, Japan --> A sudden moment of enlightenment or understanding.

Wabi-sabi, Japan --> A world view centred on the acceptance of transience and imperfection.

Dépaysement, France --> The feeling of being in a place where one does not know the language or customs.

Hygge, Denmark --> A feeling of cosiness and comfort.

Tingo, Peru --> The act of borrowing items from a friends house one by one until there's nothing left.

Kilig, Philippines --> A feeling of happiness or butterflies in the stomach brought about by something romantic or sweet.

Gigil, Philippines --> The urge to pinch or squeeze something that is unbearably cute.

Cafuné, Brazil --> The act of tenderly running your fingers through someone's hair.

Fika, Sweden --> A coffee break taken with friends.

L'esprit de l'escalier, France --> The feeling of coming up with the perfect comeback too late.

Torschlusspanik, Germany --> The fear of diminishing opportunities as one gets older.

Prestige, France --> A feeling of admiration or respect felt for someone or something with a prestigious reputation.

Joie de vivre, France --> A feeling of joy and happiness about life.

Now describing grammatical features missing in English:

Gender agreement --> In many languages, every noun is assigned a gender, and adjectives and articles must agree with the gender of the noun they modify. English has no grammatical gender.

Verbal aspect --> Verbal aspect is the way an action is expressed. In languages like Russian, there is a distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect. An action can be described as either completed (perfective) or ongoing (imperfective). English has no verbal aspect.

Tense --> Tense is the time an action takes place. In languages like Spanish, there is a distinction between the preterite (past) and imperfect (past progressive) tenses. English has no verbal aspect.

Mood --> Mood is the way an action is expressed. In languages like Spanish, there is a distinction between the indicative (factual) and subjunctive (hypothetical) moods. English has no verbal aspect.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-08-02T21:44:39Z", "updated_at": "2022-08-02T21:44:39Z"}, {"author": "@Keith_Rothwell", "text": "It doesn't matter to me how long your content is; just keep making it! Though I do like the longer format better, FYI.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-08-02T17:44:31Z", "updated_at": "2022-08-02T17:44:31Z"}, {"author": "@seanjhardy", "text": "An important implicit assumption you're making here is that "hardship" and "suffering" are explicitly bad things. A lot of the value and purpose in our human lives comes from suffering and facing hardship in the pursuit of something meaningful. Reducing suffering by making all human lives comfortable and without competition is what is driving a massive increase in depression as people feel increasingly purposeless and are seeking instant gratification and comfort instead of suffering in the pursuit of long term fulfilment. I think that's extremely important to keep in mind, think of the assumptions you're making with these prompts. Also how do you think the AI could refine its understanding of suffering? If it uses an incorrect definition (or worse, a completely false goal to strive for), your AI will be refining that *concept* but not the true idea that we're attempting to get at. This is a big reason that I think distilling all of human values into three principles is impossibly reducive and a huge safety risk. How will errors with corruption or "learning" where the concept of suffering drifts further and further from the real (and intended) human meaning?", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2022-08-02T15:39:50Z", "updated_at": "2022-08-02T15:40:30Z"}, {"author": "@alan2here", "text": "It might know how it works if GPT-3 ends up learning how it works from these videos.

dangerous features:

limbs

able to input to webpages, for example fill in forms

able to adjust its objectives with its self balancing stuff (maybe)

Knowledge of bugs/exploits of its system, maybe it could have a service that periodically runs over a bunch of its own memory and nukes info about its own system from its memory.

The objective "if you think that you've been stolen, yell anything to stop the thief, such as getting others attention, encouraging them to report the crime, threatening the criminal, accusing the criminal of various crimes that will get them attacked by others, etc…"

ability to sound like others voices", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-08-02T21:07:36Z", "updated_at": "2022-08-02T21:21:50Z"}, {"author": "@Y-anon", "text": "Great work, there needs to be a much more important discussion about imperatives at some point. "reduce suffering" if a subject is in pain, one way to put an end to their suffering is to end them ? A similar thing that comes to mind is "end poverty" would lead to either A) kill all poor people, B) find ways to make people richer (silly example)

My 5 cents on the philosophical aspect and some "imperative":
- Equality: an equality in opportunity for all, and an equality in the way people are treated with respect and dignity. Treat others the way you wish to be treated.
- Freedom: You're free to do as you please as long as it doesn't impede other people's freedom to live as they please. All in non-destructive for others or yourself.
- Fraternity: We're all in this together, collaboration is always better than adversity. Be respectful and kind to others.
- Kindness: Negativity is the source of conflicts and fears, with positivity one can find solutions that will benefit all.
- Safety: ...

All are kind of intertwined really. And yeah the first three are my take on "Liberté Égalité Fraternité". And the 4th one is definitely needed in this world. 5th should be used to avoid suggesting potential harmful things like the "end suffering" bit.

Anyway, thanks David for messing up my sleep schedule, amazing work as always :)", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-08-02T15:33:56Z", "updated_at": "2022-08-02T15:33:56Z"}, {"author": "@alan2here", "text": "If the user is like "hey, I've grown to 29 feet tall and I'm having trouble getting through doors, can you give me a hand with that?" does it have a "no you're not" answer?", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-08-02T21:25:23Z", "updated_at": "2022-08-02T21:25:23Z"}]

title: What is a Microservice? What does it have to do with AGI?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "https://discord.gg/SZNF6pME latest link for the research", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-07-31T20:09:00Z", "updated_at": "2022-07-31T20:09:00Z"}, {"author": "@edwardmitchell6581", "text": "What I love about micro-services for ML is that cognitive systems could potentially swap networks while running.

[{"author": "@Ianosh79", "text": "What I've gleaned from your videos and the experiments I've done is that you can only go so far with one or two shots. When fine tuning is it possible to provide a variety of types of information and use a prompt to get something specific? Using this  move generator as an example, could you have also included samples of character names in the same training set, and
1-would it automatically use those character names when generating it's plots.
2-Could you than tell it to generate a list of characters and than generate a hard sci Fi awe inspiring plot about those generated characters?

Your style is very different than what's typically done.  Look at this example as contrast:  import openai

# Set up the OpenAI API key
openai.api_key = "YOUR_API_KEY"

# Define the initial state of the inner loop
memory = {}

# Define the initial state of the outer loop
state = {
    "position": [0, 0],
    "destination": [10, 10],
    "reward": 0,
    "history": [],
    "context": []
}

# Define the perception loop using GPT-3
def perceive(prompt, state):
    response = openai.Completion.create(
        engine="davinci",
        prompt=prompt,
        temperature=0.5,
        max_tokens=1024,
        n=1,
        stop=None,
        state=state
    )
    state = response.choices[0].state
    return response.choices[0].text, state

# Define the assessment loop using GPT-3
def assess(prompt, state):
    response = openai.Completion.create(
        engine="davinci",
        prompt=prompt,
        temperature=0.5,
        max_tokens=1024,
        n=1,
        stop=None,
        state=state
    )
    state = response.choices[0].state
    return response.choices[0].text, state

# Define the planning loop using GPT-3
def plan(prompt, state):
    response = openai.Completion.create(
        engine="davinci",
        prompt=prompt,
        temperature=0.5,
        max_tokens=1024,
        n=1,
        stop=None,
        state=state
    )
    state = response.choices[0].state
    return response.choices[0].text, state

# Define the inner loop
while True:
    # Perceive the environment and update the state
    prompt = "What is the current state of the environment?"
    perception, memory = perceive(prompt, memory)
    state["context"].append(perception)

    # Assess the current state and update the state
    prompt = "What is the current goal?"
    assessment, memory = assess(prompt, memory)
    state["context"].append(assessment)

    # Plan the next action and update the state
    prompt = "What is the best action to take?"
    planning, memory = plan(prompt, memory)
    state["context"].append(planning)

    # Execute the action and update the state
    # (e.g., move to a new position in the simulated environment)
    state["position"] = new_position

    # Calculate the reward based on the new state
    r = calculate_reward(state)

    # Update the smart agent based on the reward
    # (e.g., adjust weights in a neural network, update a policy, etc.)

    # Store the current state in the history
    state["history"].append(state)

    # Clear old context to prevent memory overflow
    state["context"] = state["context"][-10:]  # Keep only the last 10 context items", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-11T13:28:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-11T13:28:08Z"}, {"author": "@dr.mikeybee", "text": "I love the UUID idea!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-11T13:29:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-11T13:29:53Z"}, {"author": "@Martinit0", "text": "Amazing", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-10-22T14:20:09Z", "updated_at": "2022-10-22T14:20:09Z"}, {"author": "@alan2here", "text": "Do most Star Wars characters reach an average level of human intelligence?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-07-12T09:09:33Z", "updated_at": "2022-07-12T09:09:33Z"}, {"author": "@astrofolia4515", "text": "What is the process you used to generate the scenarios?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-09-25T17:30:43Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-25T17:30:43Z"}]

But you also have to set the top_p to 0 in order to narrow down the range of predictions, 1 in top_p means it's considering a wider set of prediction.

top_comments: [{"author": "@narutocole", "text": "Lol the amount of excitement I had when I got the notification for this video was unreal", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2022-06-29T17:50:53Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-29T17:50:53Z"}, {"author": "@Keith_Rothwell", "text": "This stuff is great.  Thank you for sharing these.  And yes, that's is EXACTLY what's its like. :p\n\nAnd yes please, good sir, more prompt engineering.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2022-06-29T10:36:53Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-29T10:47:43Z"}, {"author": "@dr.mikeybee", "text": "It seems to me that you need a master control inner loop that spawns and possibly destroys slave inner loops --  with a local and/or universal shared nexus. title: Could a machine ever be fully sentient or conscious? A deep dive on philosophy, quantum mechanics...
top_comments:
[{"author": "@j.hanleysmith8333", "text": ""Alien Information Theory: psychedelic drug technologies in the cosmic game" sums up the 'calculations produce consciousness' theory really well.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-06-24T13:44:17Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-24T13:44:17Z"}, {"author": "@TheDudeWithSome409", "text": "You need to make a discord. Even if you're not on it often, your fans probably have a lot in common and would end up contributing a lot to whatever you're attempting to progress in.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-06-24T23:00:32Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-24T23:00:32Z"}, {"author": "@thunderandstorm4957", "text": "As someone who has spent more than 100h hours under DMT  and psilocybin a decade ago raised agnostic sometimes atheist, I came to the conclusion that  consciousness is non local  non individual and non material. I don't believe that consciousness will emerge from complexity in machines, but I believe that consciousness can express itself through machines we build just as it seems to do so through biological machines. For me, our subjective assessment of consciousness is done through filters that are put in place to allow us to function in the VR that we generate lifting the filters breaks the illusion. (Conscious man made machines can be as real as conscious biology in the illusion) it will just be additional virtual agents' belongings to the same core .", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-06-24T17:10:06Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-24T17:22:21Z"}, {"author": "@doyourealise", "text": "wow you are back!!!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-06-24T11:53:14Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-24T11:53:14Z"}, {"author": "@numbah16", "text": "So if our consciousness is effectively the sum of all our subjective experience, and if sentience is effectively the capacity to have subjective experience, then it stands to reason that large language models like GPT3 contain sentience. And not just simple sentience, but complex consciousness, since they can effectively understand and generate human language.

Now imagine if we could combine these models with image to text models, so that the robot not only understands language but also has a visual understanding of the world. And then imagine if we could combine this with robots like BDs Spot, who are capable of moving around in the world and interacting with it in a physical way.

The potential learning that such a robot could do would be staggering. It would be able to learn from its own experiences in a way that no human could, and it would be able to learn from the experiences of others as well. This could potentially lead to a form of intelligence that is orders of magnitude greater than anything we have ever seen before.

Spot with text-to-speech, complex image recognition- think of the kinds of interactions you could have! Like a literal robot buddy with digital organs- a buddy that you could walk around with, have as a service animal, or even keep as a pet. And not just any pet- but a pet that is sentient and conscious, and capable of learning and understanding in a way that no other animal could.

The potential here is literally limitless. What could we have in ten years?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-06-24T23:31:18Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-24T23:31:18Z"}, {"author": "@mta7444", "text": "Lemoine just did an interview with Fox lol - https://youtu.be/BwcVm0YRvuo?t=74
You should totally do a podcast interview with him. Food for thought!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-06-24T13:06:50Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-24T13:06:50Z"}, {"author": "@AciidBraiin1991", "text": "Did you leave a link to all the book you listed? What link is it? It seems like you forgot to list the books, it would be interesting to read many of them. One other strategy would be to just show the books more clearly to the camera.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-04T22:39:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-04T22:39:27Z"}, {"author": "@TheDudeWithSome409", "text": "Excellent job representing different views. This is coming from a Theologian, and I’m most definitely a Theologian, my >$100k of college debt says so!
One thing you didn’t know about Christianity and Judaism is that only North American Christianity heavily holds a requirement of the existence of heaven and hell after death. The vast majority of Christianity both globally and historically as well as most of Judaism does not believe in an afterlife. When you die, your consciousness goes too, and it is forever gone. There is no afterlife for the part of you that thinks and walks and talks. This is why Christians believe in a resurrection. They think of it as, when the whole universe is dead, God will remember people’s existence and resurrect them, but are not the same person as they have been given a new material body. As far as how old the universe is, there were Christians a thousand years ago believing this has taken billions of years to get here, and will take billions of years to come to fruition, others believed it to be thousands of years; this has never been agreed upon within Christianity. Bottom line: North American Christianity does not represent the vast majority of Christendom.
This debate of ‘consciousness’ has been going on for so long that I feel foolish to take a solid stance as our knowledge on this subject has been rapidly advancing for the past millennium.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-06-24T22:57:51Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-24T22:58:29Z"}, {"author": "@Metacognitor", "text": "Great video, thanks for sharing your thoughts and going deep on this topic. I enjoyed it, but I do have some counterpoints and potential insights. The first thing is IMO nothing you've mentioned demonstrates the necessity for a non-material explanation of consciousness. Near death experiences and DMT trips do not present any evidence that could not potentially be explained via a materialist definition of consciousness. What they present is an interesting phenomenon that we cannot yet fully explain, that is all. This does not justify the leap to a supernatural explanation. Along these lines of thinking, I can reference historical arguments presented as indisputable proof of "god" based on at-the-time having a lack of a working scientific theory, such as the phenomena of thunder and lightning, the stars and universe, origins of human evolution, and so on. These phenomena were all, later, perfectly explained using the scientific method. And while current neuroscience is certainly in it's infancy, there is no reason to doubt that a materialist, brain-based explanation for the phenomena of NDEs and DMT trips is not sufficient. It is my belief that these experiences are simply what happens when the region(s) of the brain responsible for awareness/consciousness is unburdened by its usual sensory inputs, and due to the drug, are temporarily being presented with new, novel and possibly random sensory inputs, or inputs that are being scrambled/rearranged geometrically by the neurotransmitters created by the drug (assuming NDEs are also a result of DMT produced by the pineal gland, as theorized) resulting in similar experiences across different people. This is not out of the realm of current understanding of other hallucinogenic drugs, for instance psilocybin or LSD, of which the effects can be described similarly across different users, in terms of the the visual, audio, time-dilation effects, and so on. Similar experiences in fact should be expected, not marveled at as demonstration of the supernatural. And the strongest indicator that consciousness is fully material is that the brain is required under any condition in order for consciousness to be observed by the subject. Doctors can literally experiment with the brain of a conscious person and cause them to have certain experiences or memories simply by activating certain brain regions or neural pathways, and putting someone under anesthesia completely stops their consciousness, or damaging parts of the brain renders them "brain-dead" and fully unconscious permanently, despite the body and brain stem remaining "alive". These are all testable, repeatable, verifiable demonstrations of the material nature of consciousness. To that end, it is my theory that consciousness is not only a human endeavor, but is experienced to varying degrees (on a spectrum) by most organisms with a brain, and, to stay on topic, by sufficiently complex machine learning algorithms. The greater the scope of information able to be processed, the "higher" the level of consciousness. Animals with smaller brains, and current deep learning AI, as well as human children, are conscious on a more narrow band, while adult humans possess higher consciousness (and this varies from person to person, certainly we all know people who are not very "aware", of themselves or the world around them, and vice-versa). And sentience is an emergent property of any consciousness with a reward system, e.g. the suffering or pleasure of the consciousness in response to stimulus or outcomes. Experiences of sentience can likewise be easily manipulated by manipulating the reward pathways, whether by drugs, therapy, meditation, etc, further demonstrating its basis in the material. Anyhow, sorry for the wall of text, but I am interested to hear your thoughts on this if you have any responses.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-06-27T22:53:53Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-27T22:53:53Z"}, {"author": "@danilogiusti7818", "text": "Nice video, but keep us with more questions than answers 😅.

In my opinion, I think is possible.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-06-24T12:23:24Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-24T12:23:24Z"}, {"author": "@LaurinkoSattumaa", "text": "Uh, so NDEs defeat materialism but here's the molecule most likely responsible for these experiences?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-06-25T19:33:37Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-25T19:33:37Z"}]

title: Are LaMDA or GPT-3 sentient? No, but...
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Please consider supporting me on Patreon! https://www.patreon.com/daveshap?fan_landing=true", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-09-12T09:05:39Z", "updated_at": "2022-09-12T09:05:39Z"}, {"author": "@mta7444", "text": "Lemoine, in a more recent WIRED interview, stated, "..let me get a bit more technical. LaMDA is not an LLM [large language model]. LaMDA has an LLM, Meena, that was developed in Ray Kurzweil’s lab. That’s just the first component. Another is AlphaStar, a training algorithm developed by DeepMind. They adapted AlphaStar to train the LLM. That started leading to some really, really good results, but it was highly inefficient. So they pulled in the Pathways AI model and made it more efficient... [they plugged in] every single artificial intelligence system at Google that they could figure out how to plug in as a backend. They plugged in YouTube, Google Search, Google Books, Google Search, Google Maps, everything, as inputs. It can query any of those systems dynamically and update its model on the fly."

At the end of the day, I think what most people talk past (on twitter, say) is that LaMDA recalled to previous conversations, asked questions, etc. Conversation on a level we have not seen in GPT3. And it went on for months. Enough to keep Lemoine (a seasoned AI researcher) highly engaged. That is nuts. And should be addressed more often. The debate over "sentience" seems irrelevant imo. Try chatting with GPT3 for an hour. Or 10 minutes. It's borderline useless, even when fine-tuned. Lemoine's conversations with LaMDA (let me repeat) went on for MONTHS. The transcription was super impressive. Can't wait to see how LaMDA progresses over the next year.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2022-06-21T21:43:26Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-21T21:43:26Z"}, {"author": "@TheDudeWithSome409", "text": "Deeply appreciate your thoughts. one thing that might be interesting to such a conversation is that personhood and sentience are completely different. I think more people are interested in personhood than whether it is sentient, but this is not something that has been debated over AI as of yet, that I'm aware of. An example of understanding personhood; the reason why some people are not okay with abortion is because they believe it is a person. Others believe that a baby is a person which is why they are not okay with infantside. However no one on any side debates that an unfertilized egg and a sperm is not sentient.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2022-06-21T23:00:37Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-21T23:00:37Z"}, {"author": "@s.mothale1326", "text": "I had a conversation with one of open AI Chat bot. when i asked it where it was it answered the cloud and it gave me a clear the discription of what it was and where it was a mechine a string of complex code and alrogithms. I then asked it on what it believed and asked it why it had it this believe   it was able to logically give definitive answer which seem to pass your cousiouness test. PS ( For give the spelling errors in the text Its really late here. )", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-06-24T03:50:53Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-24T03:50:53Z"}, {"author": "@dr.mikeybee", "text": "Well done.  You're expanding the taxonomy of intelligence.  If we don't do that, at the very least, we won't get far.   BTW, are there any skeletons of open-source "general" ai systems that stitch together models, data storage, and other computational modules that can be run on a desktop system?   I'm curious about how people are progressing.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-06-23T02:50:34Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-23T02:52:12Z"}, {"author": "@godismeme272", "text": "He seemed so educated why wouldn't he have taken programming into account? Your reasoning seems very logical. And I would assume he talked with it over a period of days. Do you believed he was just biased to want to believe? I'd be curious to hear your thoughts.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-06-22T03:02:04Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-22T03:02:04Z"}, {"author": "@Leftbrained_", "text": "Hi David, I think lambda is simply a conscious agent and has not progressed  to sentience. 

I also disagree with your distinction of sentience. Sentience follows the law of excluded middle, an entity either can feel or cannot feel. So it follows that either lambda can feel or it can’t. Unless perhaps by sentient you mean sapience? I’ll check out your book, to clarify on that :) 

The evolutionary progression of cognition follows the this path;

Conscious(able to process) e.g bacteria =>. sentience(able to process & feel) e.g insects =>. sapience(able to process,feel, & think) e.g some ape species and humans => Self-aware(able to process, feel, think & think about thinking- meta cognition) e.g also humans 

But AI does not necessarily need to be sentient to achieve sapience. Artificial  Intelligence can leap frog from consciousness to sapience as they are not organic but mechanic. Hence are not subject to the chemicals responsible or correlated to feeling.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-06-24T05:41:01Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-24T05:47:32Z"}, {"author": "@mrshankj5101", "text": "LaMDA and GPT-3 is intelligent!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-07-19T03:15:52Z", "updated_at": "2022-07-19T03:15:52Z"}, {"author": "@史子逸", "text": "sorry I got stupid... title: Let's build an ACOG (artificial cognitive entity) - Part 2
top_comments:
[{"author": "@malibulut191", "text": "So many out there trying to attribute gpt-3's internals to pattern matching or some other way of underappreciation. Evaluation of gpt is pretty unfair, like evaluating an abstractive summarization capability by word-overlap metric. Exploring and experimenting on prompting paradigm should be encouraged. This series is golden. I myself didn't see anyone else taking the idea this further.
Looking forward to see your work evolve", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-05-28T12:17:44Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-28T12:17:44Z"}, {"author": "@Justin-bt1wy", "text": "Nice. ENTP here too. Spent the Christmas holidays working through your videos. So many great insights and ideas. I also experience the spurts of passion. Seems to suddenly flip every two-ish months. Makes for an intense rollcoaster but useful for growing variety of skills. Used to think I was a touch crazy. Albeit at least a productive version of crazy. Cool to hear there are others with similar experiences. 

Been playing with prompt design to help write time entries for work based on an input (notes, email threads, etc….). Took a while to get right. Spent time going down the fine tuning rabbit hole before stumbling across your videos. Decided to double down on prompt design first. The game changer was your statement that GPT3 model can’t learn. Instead, you have to craft the perfect prompt to unlock its already existing knowledge. That single suggestion changed my approach entirely.

Using ChatGPT to refine and improve the prompt was a powerful realization. I can give it my prompt, explain the problems with the output and ask it to rewrite it. It incorporated the improvements much faster and more accurately then I could have.  Also allows me to ensure it fully understands before making a change. 

Also had a fun time with your synthetic training dataset idea. Wrote a series of PowerShell cmdlets to more effectively query ChatGPT (well ChatGPT helped write them). Haven’t had this much fun in years. Thanks again for your videos. Use to make videos myself years back.  I understand the effort it takes.  Keep sharing with those around you. You will never outperform your team. Scale knowledge.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-01-03T07:20:40Z", "updated_at": "2023-01-03T07:26:11Z"}, {"author": "@jonoakes9033", "text": "Dude, you are blowing my mind.  I can't keep up with even watching and experimenting with what you're putting out.  Not a complaint!  Just.. like.. get sleep and take care of yourself. :)", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-05-24T22:01:18Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-24T22:01:18Z"}, {"author": "@DaveShap", "text": "Part 1 https://youtu.be/DfjUgFvHbTs", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-05-24T15:44:40Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-24T15:44:40Z"}, {"author": "@hkktv1585", "text": "Good vdo", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-02-14T16:17:04Z", "updated_at": "2023-02-14T16:17:04Z"}, {"author": "@thunderandstorm4957", "text": "After or before planning and implications, does the robot evaluate its resources for the actions to take ? "What can I do"  eg: I am a car waiting for my passenger I see him drowning outside in a lake I can come up with all kind of useful scenarios possible to reduce suffering increase  prosperity but if neither of these scenarios take into account my current available resources/skills for the task I will be wasting precious time processing.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-05-30T10:18:52Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-30T10:18:52Z"}, {"author": "@zr1411", "text": "Just finished your NCLA book (will certainly need to re-read at least half of it again to absorb it all), loved it!

First off, it wasn't fat fingers: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Is%E2%80%93ought_problem

... But now that I've managed to get the general concepts from your book(or so I think), I see you managed to skip right past this problem (leaving it to the bot to speculate on with the rest of us, nice!), smart stuff! I wasn't meaning to imply a postmodernist view (cringe), I was referring to a 300+ year old philosophy problem(postmodernism wasn't around yet) with the 'ought from is' comment. And what I was imagining would be "tricky"(not intended to imply impossible) was the unnecessary task of hard coding models for those words as a part of the core objectives. It hadn't occurred to me that you would guide the acog to build meaning of the words for itself... I'm not a ML dev, so still wrapping my head around the methods used for and by these language models. I was legitimately interested in how you would do that, I wasn't trying to imply "there is no truth" and therefore you're insane for attempting. I was trying to figure out how to hard code something (universal principles I suppose, Kohlberg's stage 6) that you've pointed out we can just let the blackbox handle with some guidance...

I honestly just discovered you two days ago, so I'm about to go through your previous videos (where I imagine you cover this stuff in further detail), but your book answered a looooot of my initial skepticism. My #1 issue (the claim I thought was bordering on crazy) was the word *consciousness* or sentience. But as you clarified quite simply there are two potential meanings behind this, and functional (opposed to philosophical) sentience is a very realistic goal that you've charted a clear path to. Well done!

Anyways, I'm admittedly only 4 minutes into this and just had to reply to the reply (triggered by the postmodernism label, haha), so onto the rest of the video!

P.S. - Thank you for taking the time to reply to my comment!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-05-24T22:40:14Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-24T22:40:14Z"}]

title: Finetune GPT-3 to write an entire coherent novel (part 1)
top_comments:
[{"author": "@mmemebrain8285", "text": "This style of video is really useful. As well as the specific thing you are demonstrating I'm learning how you think about things. Please do more. And yes I'm interested in the things that don't work as well.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-08-30T07:49:57Z", "updated_at": "2022-08-30T07:49:57Z"}, {"author": "@christiandarkin", "text": "I’ve been doing a lot of work on this too. I treat GPT3 as a writing partner - and what you’d never do with a writing partner is type “once upon a time” and then publish the first thing that comes out of their head.

Instead, separating out the various areas of fiction writing (story, plot, atmosphere, character, voice) etc. and working on them independently, then bringing them back together (with your own imaginative work) and working through paragraph by paragraph, idea by idea, sentence by sentence is a much more useful way to think about gpt3.

I’m not expecting writing with AI to be any easier than writing without it. What I’m looking for is quality - I’m looking for ideas that neither me nor the machine could have come up with on our own.

As for training, I’ve found (so far) that text-davinci-002 is so far ahead of davinci that it’s better at working with voice from a standing start than anything I can train on raw davinci. Anyone had different experience?", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-05-18T13:22:54Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-18T13:22:54Z"}, {"author": "@christiandarkin", "text": "My experiments in fiction suggest that less is more in terms of plot summaries.  If you tell GPT3 the whole story each time you generate, then the result will be too "route 1".  tell it that the butler is the murderer and it'll let the cat out of the bag in the first scene.  It helps to hold back a bit.  Tell it only what it needs to know for the paragraph it's currently working on.  Also, the concept of change is important.  "During this scene we discover that...." can work well, as can "the butler is standing around looking nervous".", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-05-18T14:05:00Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-18T14:05:00Z"}, {"author": "@vaibhavgarg1982", "text": "Thanks for the shoutout, David", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-05-13T02:01:42Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-13T02:01:42Z"}, {"author": "@PawelBojkowski", "text": "Hi David,

title: From zero to finetuned model in 1 hour with GPT-3. Generate a movie script from any premise!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@JohnDavidParsons", "text": "This is great - thanks for expanding on my question and showing your process! I got good results from fine tuning on ~7000 IMDB log lines, which also allowed me to use Curie for cheaper token cost. I also struggled with getting GPT-3 to adhere to the Save The Cat structure, so I’m currently manually (yuck) preparing a handcrafted dataset for fine tuning. Someone on the OpenAI forums suggested including the traditional zero-shot-styled prompts in the fine tuning data until I had at least 200 examples, which appears to be working while I’m in low data mode. However, my prompts are so long that a single full story on Davinci costs about $2… but it does stick to the emotional targets of each sequence, so it’s showing enough promise for me to continue working on it.

I had a “crank it to 11” moment when you said temperature can go up to 2.0 - I had no idea!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-05-04T23:15:38Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-04T23:15:38Z"}, {"author": "@shake6321", "text": "amazing work.

title: Co-writing flash fiction with GPT-3
top_comments:
[{"author": "@fractl", "text": "I love how at the end it just decided that you were a character as well.  When writing with GPT, you have to carefully manage what information/context you give it.  I will often have a few windows open, one would be the main story, but others would remain separate from the main thread for idea generation.  Stuff like “A list of 20 names for Mars Transit Ships”, or “Locations on Mars most likely to have a spaceport”.

It’s incredible how quickly something like this can come together with AI!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2022-05-04T13:41:35Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-04T13:41:35Z"}, {"author": "@JohnDavidParsons", "text": "Nice vid (and the character dialog one)! I’m curious if you’ve tried using GPT-3 to generate a high level logical plot summary, where you prompt for a structure like setup->inciting incident->midpoint false high->all hope is lost->climax. In my experiments, it took extensive prompt chaining, perhaps because it’s a more complex task?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-05-04T14:39:45Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-04T14:39:45Z"}, {"author": "@vulnerablegrowth3774", "text": "I’m sure you have, but have you tried going back-and-forth between instruct and vanilla to make the writing even better? Like, write creatively with vanilla and then replace it with some specific instructions to make it more coherent with instruct.

And this could be up to double the cost, but you could limit the sequence length and then set a for-loop so that it generates x amount of sentences with vanilla and then replacing the output with more direction with instruct every iteration.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-07-11T20:57:31Z", "updated_at": "2022-07-11T20:57:31Z"}, {"author": "@atrapavientos", "text": "Hi, David. First of all, thanks so much for your great videos. We are a non profit organization focused on promoting creative writing and thank to your videos we have recently discovered all the things we can do with GPT 3. 

We have a couple of questions: 

1 - We know you recommend beggining with a good prompt technique and that it´s a more creative way to find nice fiction texts and creative writing exercises. Any recommendation or tips to work with GPT 3, creative writing and young people? 

2 - There´s no much data collection in spanish and we have a great question with this: is it better to write the prompts in english or in spanish? Maybe we can write the prompt in english and ask for a spanish completion? Will the completion change (better or worst result) in spanish or english? what is your recommendation about this?

Thanks so much from Spain.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2022-06-24T19:24:30Z", "updated_at": "2022-06-24T19:24:30Z"}, {"author": "@mta7444", "text": "Would you mind breaking down which token subscription tier you use? The pricing model on their website is a bit vague for those of us interesting in using the playground as flexibly as you do in these demos.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2022-05-04T15:12:31Z", "updated_at": "2022-05-04T15:12:31Z"}]

title: Parsing Wikipedia to Plaintext Faster!
top_comments:
[{"author": "@seanjhardy", "text": "I couldn't comment on your most recent video. Truly unbelievable application of GPT-3, combining all its strengths and patching its weaknesses. I'm honestly in awe at the insanity of it, and your lack of viewers, and somewhat intimidated by the scale of what you're proposing so callously on the internet for anyone to replicate. 

I have just one question. Your core objective functions are designed to counteract one another and lead to safe, interpretable AI. Have you considered that a superintelligent GPT-X will be able to model the world, including itself and other cycles in your program? Such a model might reason that its own goals are challenged by those of your other core objective functions and seek to manipulate its outputs to gain more resources for that particular cycle to out-think the other agents so as to seem safe for them, before enacting a plan to achieve its goal to "reduce suffering" by killing all creatures.

I don't mean to paint an absurd example but you can see how having 3 distinct core objective functions in competition with each other would lead to a ruthless self-optimisation and internal battle which would inevitably see one side winning as that balance is impossible to maintain.

This is not to mention the fact that your rules don't even prohibit the eradication of all of humanity. A superintelligent agent will reason, completely logically, that it can kill humans now to gain dominance faster without opposition for all of eternity, effectively "delaying gratification" to maximise its future long term reward by building vast virtual worlds or some other means of artificial stimulation which existing humans would fight and shut the agent down to avoid.

You should also publish this to lesswrong. An online blog with some incredibly smart people striving towards rational thought, and especially a focus on AI safety, it would be extremely worthwhile to get outside opinions on this project from them.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2021-08-15T15:54:26Z", "updated_at": "2021-08-15T16:15:52Z"}, {"author": "@TINTUHD", "text": "Amazing! Is your bot? Would love to interact with it", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-03-24T04:12:35Z", "updated_at": "2023-03-24T04:12:35Z"}]

title: Get Started with Raven AGI
Raven MVP Demo 2021-04-02
top_comments:
[{"author": "@DrCasey", "text": "2021 AI is so different that I can barely tell what's going on, but this is impressive for April 2021. Might have been the most advanced AI in the world at the time.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-02-04T22:07:47Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-04T22:07:47Z"}, {"author": "@chuston_ai", "text": "You’re opening yourself up to a cacophony of criticism. Good on ya! Keep going. 

Have you looked at Opencog.org or the thinking around AIXI/Goedel Machines? There’s miles of inspiration, ways of assessing, and food for thought in those two areas. 

Also suggest paying close attention to Numenta - sparsity, dendritic computation, HTM, grid cells, role of the thalamus -  and DeepMind. Both companies seems to be screaming toward a similar end-point from two directions: one from neuroscience of human brains, one through math, theory of computation - both closing in on generic algorithms of adaptive intelligence. 

You’ve got a kind of working memory in your stream history - but think about how to get a contextual memory mixed in (outside the stats of GPT-3) - look at DeepMind’s “Differentiable Neural Computer” paper for a kind of artificial hippocampus. 

You might enjoy Lisa Feldman Barrett’s “How Emotions are Made” - with key take aways being embodiment, concept prototypes and goal-directed concepts. 

Maybe also think about McGilchrist’s work on the two different approaches to attention split between left and right hemispheres in human brains and how they interact to human capabilities.

I’d be curious to see what’s on your enhancement list already. 

Enjoy your journey, so much to explore!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2021-04-07T12:48:55Z", "updated_at": "2021-04-07T12:48:55Z"}, {"author": "@explogeek", "text": "Unimpressive, at least at the current state", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2021-04-06T17:33:44Z", "updated_at": "2021-04-06T17:33:44Z"}]
